DOC.HEAD: Investigators Take Last Look at Subway Wreckage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with NTSB official saying dragging motor likely cause of accident, DELETES earlier speculation by union official and edits to conform. Pick up 15th graf pvs, `There's only...
DOC.TEXT: A subway car derailment that killed three people and injured 162 may have been triggered by a dragging motor that hit a track switch, federal investigators said Thursday. The altered switch may have sent the last three cars in the six-car train onto another set of tracks Wednesday, causing one car to be yanked into steel support beams, said John K. Lauber of the National Transportation Safety Board. Evidence indicated the motor dropped when a nut came loose, Lauber said, adding that investigators were told that subway motors had dropped from their supports three times in the last 15 years, most recently just a month ago. ``That probably resulted in the pivoting of the motor under the car ... and that probably was the initiation of the accident,'' he said. A 37-block section of west Philadelphia's 12.8-mile subway and elevated train line, a major commuter artery in the nation's fifth-largest city, remained closed Thursday as federal investigators made their final inspection of the wreckage. Extra buses were pressed into service to handle some of the 100,000 people who typically ride the line twice a day. The accident was the worst in the 21 years the commuter system has been operated by the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. Many of the cars on the line are 20 years old, but all six on the train in the accident had been renovated in the last eight years, SEPTA said. All three of the dead were among seven passengers trapped in the wreckage after three support beams tore into one car, authorities said. Of the 162 people treated at 10 hospitals, 16 remained hospitalized Thursday; two were in critical or serious condition. The city Medical Examiner's Office identified two of the dead as Denise Devlin, 34, and Gospodin Kanchev, 52, both of Philadelphia. The third victim, a 60-year-old woman who died after her leg was amputated in an effort to free her from the wreckage, remained unidentified. The motor, which was under the third car, hit a crossover switch about 1,500 feet after coming loose, Lauber said. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported that problems with the bolts breaking led SEPTA employees to brace the motors with bars. Harry Knittel, business agent with the Transport Workers Union, said the car with the suspect motor had been inspected once a month for at least the past 12 months and the last inspection had been Feb. 1. ``There's only so much welding and repairs that 30-year-old frames can take,'' he told the News. SEPTA has ordered inspections of all older subway cars, which date from the early 1960s. NTSB investigators documented damage to cars and tracks, made diagrams of seats, examined training, maintenance and operations records; interviewed survivors and studied blueprints of the cars, Lauder said. ``Our people are underneath the car,'' he said. ``They're crawling all over the car. They've been crawling underneath and around the sides and all over. We've also been collecting bits and pieces from along the entire accident scene.'' The NTSB gave SEPTA permission to finish clearing the shattered glass and twisted metal left from the wreck. SEPTA put an extra 120 buses into service to deal with the service shutdown, which also affected underground sections of a subway-surface streetcar system. Subway support columns dating to about 1907 will be repaired if necessary, SEPTA said, but Lauder said there were no indications the beams had been damaged. The NTSB has no regulatory powers but determines the probable cause of about 3,000 plane crashes and other transportation accidents annually. It recommends preventive steps to government agencies and industry.

DOC.HEAD: Wife of Death Row Inmate Sues to Bear His Child
DOC.TEXT: The wife of a death row inmate is suing for a conjugal visit or artificial insemination by her husband so he can ``give back a life'' before his own is taken. ``I would like to visit my husband in private so that we can conceive a child the way God intended,'' Lisa Petrocelli said in a statement Wednesday after filing suit in federal court. ``If I'm not granted my wish to be a real wife to my husband I want to have his baby by artificial insemination.'' Tracy Petrocelli, 38, was sentenced to death in 1982 for fatally shooting a car dealer during a test drive. He also was sentenced to life in prison for killing a former girlfriend in a Seattle restaurant in 1981. ``My husband is being punished, but that does not make it right to punish me and my baby,'' said Mrs. Petrocelli, 26. ``We are running out of time. I want to have this baby and I do not think God would think it is wrong to bring a new baby into the world.'' The Nevada prison system has no intention of allowing conjugal visits, which would require special rooms and supervision, said prison spokesman Glen Whorton. ``We're not planning on developing any kind of artificial insemination program either,'' he said. Carter King, the couple's attorney, called it cruel and unusual punishment to prevent Petrocelli from fathering a child. ``The best thing he can possibly do now is give back a life,'' King said. ``He took a life and this allows him to give one back to the world.'' The Petrocellis were married in 1988 at the state prison in Carson City, 30 miles south of Reno. They began corresponding after an inmate at a Las Vegas jail where Mrs. Petrocelli worked as a nurse put them in touch. In October they sued the state because prison authorities barred her from visiting her husband after drug-sniffing dogs zeroed in on her car trunk and her purse. No drugs were found. The lawsuit is pending; Petrocelli has been transferred to the state's new maximum-security prison in Ely, about 300 miles from his wife's home in Reno. At his trial, Petrocelli said the car dealer was accidentally killed in an argument over the car's price. Petrocelli has exhausted his state appeals and his case is before a federal judge. Robert Dulin, a paralegal working on the case with King, said he doesn't believe either of the Petrocellis has any children. ``Just because her husband has committed a crime and is on death row paying for it doesn't mean his would-be children should suffer,'' Dulin said. ``She just wants to have his baby to carry on his name.'' Nevada has 51 men and one woman who face death by lethal injection. Four men have been executed in Nevada since the Supreme Court allowed states to resume use of the death penalty in 1976. According to the Criminal Justice Institute, as of Jan. 1, 1989, 10 states allowed conjugal visits: California, Connecticut, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Mexico, New York, South Carolina, Utah, Washington and Wyoming.

DOC.HEAD: Hose Rupture Caused Atlantis Pressure Drop, NASA Says
DOC.TEXT: A ruptured hose spilled five gallons of hydraulic fluid inside shuttle Atlantis and caused a brief drop in pressure just before landing, but the astronauts were never in danger, NASA says. NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said Wednesday the damaged hose will be analyzed to determine what caused the problem. Atlantis was returning on Sunday from a secret military mission to deploy a spy satellite when Mission Control announced an indicator light was on, warning of a pressure drop in the hydraulic system that controls flaps and steering. A few minutes after the 9:40 a.m. PST announcement, NASA reported pressure had been restored. The shuttle landed smoothly at 10:08 p.m. Neither of Atlantis' two backup hydraulic systems was used, the space agency said. ``We don't think it was any threat at all based on the information we had at the descent,'' NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said. Because of a Pentagon-imposed blackout surrounding the 4{-day mission, the hose may have ruptured before the problem became public, Malone said. The blackout was lifted 1{ hours before touchdown at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. ``It wasn't announced until re-entry,'' she said. ``It could have happened on the mission or on the way up.'' A thin coating of hydraulic fluid was found throughout the aft engine compartment, Malone said. Engineers discovered a 1-inch split in a 3-foot-long high-pressure hose for one of the shuttle's three auxiliary power units. Technicians on Wednesday removed the rubber-coated stainless steel hose and sent it for analysis to Rockwell International in Downey, Calif., Malone said. The company builds the orbiters but contracts out work involving the hoses. If the problem had existed and been detected before liftoff, NASA would have delayed the mission until the hose was repaired or replaced, Malone said. Malone said she was not aware of a hydraulic line rupturing during any previous mission. Removal of the hose will not affect the shuttle's piggyback jet ride from Edwards back to Kennedy Space Center, Malone said. A modified Boeing 747 is scheduled to transport Atlantis on Saturday. The trip, including stopovers for refueling, is expected to take about nine hours.

DOC.HEAD: Finally, They Win Official Recognition; But Ethnic Poles Are Wary
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In a shabby, ice-cold meeting room behind a village store deep in the farmlands of southern Poland, 150 people burst into patriotic song _ in German. The sound is chilling to Poles with vivid memories of the brutality of Nazi occupiers and a history of partition by foreign powers. But it is encouraged by the Solidarity-led government, which is committed to recognizing Poland's ethnic diversity after decades of repression. ``We've been negated for a long time, we didn't exist ... We had to save ourselves,'' says Jan Krol, founder of the newly registered German cultural society. He was in his 20s when his native Gogolin became part of Poland. Yet just as Poland's German minority is being acknowledged, the debate over guaranteeing Poland's western border prior to German reunification is again stirring tensions between two nationalities that have often in their histories fought bloody battles over land. With the assent of the other World War II allies, Stalin created postwar Poland's western third from lands seized from the defeated Nazis, compensation for an even larger swath the Soviets took from eastern Poland. Millions of ethnic German nationals were expelled _ 1.4 million from the Silesian region that includes Gogolin _ and the acquired territory was resettled by the Poles uprooted from the east. Communist governments in Warsaw refused to acknowledge that hundreds of thousands of ethnic Germans still lived in Poland; their secret police and vigorous discrimination worked to prevent any manifestation of German identity. But under the red-tile roofs of Silesia, German is spoken to this day. And in some West German political circles, these lands are still considered German. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's reluctance to unequivocally renounce claims to Silesia and commit a united Germany to its current Polish border along the Oder and Neisse rivers has strained relations with Poland. Just five months ago, Kohl made a long-planned conciliatory visit to Poland, and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki assured Kohl that Poland was committed to helping its German minority maintain its heritage. Four times since 1985, attempts by Krol to register his cultural society had been rejected. On Feb. 16, it was officially registered. Now, the sitting room of his modest house, without a telephone like most in this tiny hamlet, is a beehive of activities to organize the estimated 300,000 to 400,000 ethnic German Silesians. ``We are facing a difficult task to get back what was taken away in 1945 _ our culture, or language. We are going to strive for that, fight for that,'' said the white-haired, raspy-voiced Krol in an interview frequently interrupted by German-speaking visitors bringing petitions. When Krol's son, Henryk, tried to become the only ethnic German to gain election to Parliament, there was an outburst of anti-German nationalism. Grafitti went up saying: ``Germans Go Home.'' Henryk lost the February by-election. Some Poles are sympathetic to the German minority's desire to practice its traditions. But many are not, suspecting aspirations are harbored for parts of Poland to become German again. ``We are willing to grant full rights to persons or groups of authentic German descent who profess their allegiance to German as their native tongue and to German tradition,'' Solidarity's Jerzy Wuttke, chairman of Parliament's ethnic minorities commission, told Tygodnik Solidarnosc. ``We will make sure, however, that those rights will not be abused to harm Poland's national interest,'' he said. Poles, who lost 6 million people during World War II, say it is unsettling to see banners proclaiming ``Helmut You Are Our Chancellor, Too'' greeting Kohl. Some wonder if it is the better economic situation in Germany that moves some ethnic Germans to profess such allegiance. When mostly older ethnic Germans gathered late one recent afternoon in Gogolin to organize their ranks, they started by singing of ``heimat,'' the homeland. ``This is `heimat.' It's ours ...,'' said the elder Krol. ``We were born here. It is our home. Our family is here.'' The Krols and their neighbors say they hope their efforts will maintain a German presence in the region. ``The younger people are waiting and watching to see what will happen now, if it will be positive ... They have their suitcases packed,'' said Hubert Materla, who returned to Gogolin in 1946 after being released from an American prisoner-of-war camp. He said the secret police harassed him for speaking German and that of 16 people who tried to organize an ethnic German group in the early 1980s, only he remains in Poland. For the Krols, Materla and others in the community, German reunification means the elimination of one border, East Germany's, now crossed to visit the many, including 70 percent of the Krol family, who have already left. Without expressing desire for change, the Krols stop short of affirming Poland's current territory. ``Very often I am asked like Chancellor Kohl about recognition of the Oder-Neisse border,'' said the younger Krol. ``The issue is very simple: the border does exist ... Today it would be difficult to imagine a similar resettlement of people ... It seems there is no other way,'' he said. Added his father: ``The hopes for any kind of border change are very small.'' Instead, they say they seek German teachers for their schools. ``There are many young people who speak Polish but have German hearts,'' said Henryk Krol, a 41-year-old veternarian who considers his German ``like a 5-year-old's.'' And they want to win representation in May elections for local governments _ villages that are 90 percent German dot the region.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter's Notebook: Uncertainty Against A Background of Poverty
DOC.TEXT: The midday sun seems about to burn holes in the streets of the capital. The dry-season wind blows dust against still-bright election slogans, painted in yellow on curbs and daubed red and blue on the sides of dilapidated buildings. The Feb. 25 election spelled the defeat of Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista government. If all goes as planned, power will be transferred next month to a largely conservative opposition coalition which says it will use free-market tactics to rescue the country from economic collapse. The task will be a mighty one. Each side in the election had its own view of Nicaragua's future, but they agree about the grimness of its present: a largely agrarian, potentially prosperous nation where war, inflation and unemployment have brought many close to despair.

Managua used to have a downtown, before the earthquake of 1972. Those streets now see only a trickle of people, walking past boarded-up buildings and vacant lots filled with scrub. The national cathedral has looked like a medieval ruin since the quake, its Gothic arches, roofless, soaring into the sky. Families live in the downtown now, pigs and chickens wandering in crude courtyards beside their shacks. Within sight of a modernistic new convention center, one of downtown's few attractions, a naked toddler and his raggedly dressed brothers and sisters play in the street on a 90-degree day. Inside a crumbling downtown building that somehow survived the quake, a Sandinista-organized collective works busily, women hunched over sewing machines. The Sandinistas built collectives throughout the country, calling them an answer to capitalist exploitation of workers. They also built schools and health clinics and told workers that they were finally masters of their country. A slogan painted on a cracked outside panel of the sewing collective's building reads, ``We are free now. We will never be slaves again.''

At the gracious home of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, Nicaragua's president-elect, a houseman brings coffee and Coca-Cola for visitors. The house is nondescript from the street, but inside it spreads into a handsome mansion, flowing gracefully from interior rooms into a garden with twisting paths and plants dramatically backlit at night. Sitting in a dark study crammed with memorabilia, her left leg in a cast from a recent knee operation, the 60-year-old, silver-haired Mrs. Chamorro says she is certain her UNO coalition can solve Nicaragua's problems. She promises to abolish the Sandinista military draft and put the country back to work. But she is characteristically vague about details; she often says they are in the hands of her advisers. As her visitors leave, one of them asks if, with the bitterly fought election just over, her biggest troubles _ running the country _ are really only now beginning. Leaning on her crutches, Mrs. Chamorro smiles. ``You're such a pessimist,'' she says.

Raul Solorzano, who runs a plastics plant in Managua and serves in the local Chamber of Industry, is optimistic. Mrs. Chamorro's coalition is going to get business running again, he says, and the country will prosper after near economic ruin under the Sandinistas. ``We want the United States to help,'' he says. But if it doesn't, he says, Nicaragua's private sector will rebuild the country by itself. The accomplishments of the Sandinista revolution, he says, were few. People received land to live on, but basic services like water and sanitation never appeared. The Sandinistas never understood economics, he says, and failed to generate money for improvements they wanted to make. ``One thing is for certain,'' Solorzano says. ``This country is through with communism. People here will never be communists again.''

At the shiny Olof Palme convention center, Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega, in jeans and a dark blue-and-red striped shirt, is very much defending the accomplishments of the revolution. Addressing the Inter American Press Association, he makes no apology for what the Sandinistas have done in nearly 11 years since they overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza. Sandinistas say the revolution would have accomplished even more if the government had not had to fight a war against the U.S.-backed Contras. ``After the 25th of April I shall be in the opposition,'' Ortega says. ``I shall be in constructive, not destructive, opposition.'' But he warns that he and the Sandinistas, who will hold the biggest single bloc of votes in the new National Assembly, are determined to ``strengthen and carry forward'' what the Sandinistas have done so far. ``Today we are facing a very difficult situation,'' he says. ``And it will depend on the maturity of those who rule, and those who are ruled, to take the country on the road to development and peace.''

A Sandinista mural on a downtown street shows a grotesque Statue of Liberty, hands transformed into talons, trying to strangle the Nicaraguan revolution. Helping is a Grim Reaper, clad in an American flag. The Sandinista election campaign hammered home the claim that a vote for the opposition was a vote for U.S. domination and a return to the brutal rule of S them back,'' said Dana Neal. Some 6,300 bus drivers and 3,000 maintenance and office workers walked off the job Friday after talks broke down over a new three-year contract. The company has been operating at reduced levels, using about 700 replacement drivers plus union members who crossed picket lines. The company says about 350 union drivers are at work; the union says 95 returned. ``The cause of this strike is singular,'' union spokesman Jeffery Nelson said after Wednesday's talks. ``The company has refused to negotiate with the union that represents its 9,000 employees in good faith.'' In other developments Wednesday: _ Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, and 10 other senators asked Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole to intervene as she did in last year's Pittston coal strike by appointing a ``supermediator.'' A spokeswoman for Mrs. Dole said she had no such plans because the dispute is still under the normal mediation process. _ In Redding, Calif., about 500 mourners, half of them striking drivers in uniform, marched in memory of a driver killed on a picket line. The mourners were led by the widow of 59-year-old Robert Waterhouse, who was pinned against a building Saturday by a bus operated by a replacement driver. No charges were filed. _ In Richmond, Va., David W. Batchelor, president of Greyhound's Eastern division, reiterated the company's position that the replacement drivers are permanent hires and that strikers who return will get jobs only as slots become available. _ The company obtained its 12th temporary restraining order prohibiting violence, vandalism and interference with operations. Several such incidents have occurred since the strike began, including shots fired at buses in Chicago and windows and mirrors smashed in other cities. Court orders have been granted in Chicago; Cincinnati; Cleveland; Des Moines, Iowa; Jacksonville, Fla.; Los Angeles; Mount Laurel, N.J.; Philadelphia; Pittsburgh; Portland, Ore.; Sacramento, Calif., and San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Buoyed by Chamorro Victory, Nicaraguan Contras Defy Sandinistas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Although U.S. aid and Honduran hospitality toward them have all but run out, Contra rebels are defiant and even menacing toward their Sandinista archenemies. Reluctance to demobilize promptly _ as has been called for by all five regional presidents and the outgoing and incoming Nicaraguan administrations _ may jeopardize a peaceful transition of power in Nicaragua on April 25. ``We're not going to put down our guns until the people's will expressed Feb. 25 is respected. If the Sandinistas try to continue to run things, it won't only be us fighting them, but the 55 percent of the nation that rejected their totalitarian project,'' said a soldier who uses the pseudonym ``Comandante Wilmer.'' The 27-year-old veteran of nine years of counterrevolutionary war was loath to put down his AK-47 assault rifle for even a moment. He grasped it by the barrel, the wooden stock leaning on a log, throughout an interview at Contra command headquarters in Yamales, 85 miles east of Tegucigalpa. The sprawling camp of shacks of bamboo, black plastic sheeting and U.S. government issue ponchos is home to about 10,000 rebels and 42,000 dependents. Most have spent the better part of the last two years here, since Washington suspended military aid. The army that tried to topple Nicaragua's Sandinista government was sustained for years by U.S. aid; 30,000 people died in the war they waged and ended up losing, at least in the field. Some non-lethal aid remains in the pipeline. According to Contra estimates, it is enough to keep them in food, clothing, fuel and medicine for seven weeks _ or just past Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's inauguration. Wilmer spent several months of last year inside Nicaragua leading rebel forces despite a cease-fire and the end of military aid. He said he did not return to Yamales until Feb. 25, the day an opposition coalition of 14 parties routed the incumbent leftists in presidential and legislative elections. ``We've seen Daniel Ortega's demagogic politics for 10 years, so it's not enough for us that he says he'll respect the people's will. Especially when with his other face he's distributing weapons to provoke civil war in Nicaragua,'' Wilmer said. The Sandinistas insist on Contra demobilization and say they will not transfer control of the army and Interior Ministry security forces until that happens. Contra commanders just as adamantly insist they won't disarm or demobilize until after all powers are transferred to a new government. They accuse the leftist regime of intending to retain power by clinging to military power. A statement by Oscar Sovalbarro, chief of a Contra team discussing demobilization, came only hours after Ortega made a vehement defense of the Popular Sandinista Army, as the army is known. Ortega said attempts to reform it _ much less abolish it _ ``would unleash a national war.'' Sovalbarro and Israel Galeano, the top Contra commander, met this week in Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital, with Jaime Cuadra, Mrs. Chamorro's representative. Cuadra described the talks as preliminary. Asked about a specific plan for demobilization and a deadline, he said: ``There is no plan, and no established deadline.'' Wilmer said the Contras are still ready to fight if need be. ``We're guerrillas,'' said Wilmer. ``Before we were more like a conventional army. Now our logistical resources are limited. But we are a nationalist and popular army that arose from the peasant-farming sector. We have our social and logistical base inside Nicaragua, and if needs be, we will operate from inside without outside help.'' The Contras maintain perhaps 3,000 fighters inside Nicaragua, and visits to the Nicaraguan countryside before last month's elections found strong support for the Contras in several provinces. ``Our morale is high, especially after Dona Violeta's victory,'' said Contra fighter Noel Lopez, 22, who said he has been fighting since he was 13. ``The campesino, once he decides on something, keeps with it until the end.'' If war resumes, the Contras might stand a fighting chance against a Sandinista army demoralized by electoral defeat and weakened by desertions that began only days after the election. Even so, doubts remain about the combat readiness and will of many at Yamales. Most have spent the past two years nearly idle, with occasional drills. The wives of many are here and many have had children. Whether they could resume a life of extreme privation _ forced marches, bad food, exposure to inclement weather and mortal danger _ is uncertain.

DOC.HEAD: Fendi Puts Fur Inside Coats and Out of View of Activists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The five Fendi sisters have tried to save their skins, just as animal rights activists threatened to make them extinct. The Fendi claim to fame as the most innovative elegant furriers on the market was about to put them at the head of the conservationist's wanted list. They are still using fur, but in coats shown Wednesday night it was used as lining instead of as an outright fashion statement. The styles, too, were less elaborate with many down-coats, parkas and shearlings. Karl Lagerfeld, the creative genius behind the Fendi label indulged in what he termed ``organized confusion,'' dying leather in bright shades, working it into chamois as soft as silk, or stuffing it with silk for a down effect. He also worked over sheepskin, detailing it with velvet strands, folk braiding or panels of Tuscan tapestry. Meanwhile, inside the coat lurked plush mink or sable, out of view of animal rights activists who have mounted a campaign to stop the use of animal skins in garments. The opening of a Fendi mega-store on New York's fashionable Fifth Avenue this past fall risked being a flop when protesters walked out front shouting anti-fur slogans. The campaign could hurt the multimillion-dollar Fendi fashion empire, which is famous for its furs, but even more renowned for its leather goods. But at the end of Wednesday's show, presented in an elegant Renaissance palace in downtown Milan, there was much praise for the move from showy furs to discretion. In the past decade Fendi, designed by Lagerfeld, has also become one of the top labels of Italian ready-to-wear. The new fall-winter 1990-91 collection presented during the fur show was short and sexy with lots of demure coat dresses, cute wool skating skirts and ribbed wool miniskirts, often worn over thick wool tights and leg warmers. To go under the sportier jackets, Fendi presented skintight stretch jeans with bright velvet braiding, often coupled with thigh-high, super-soft suede boots.

DOC.HEAD: Man Found Guilty in Julie Love Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Testimony in ...,' to fix typo in `Aryan.'
DOC.TEXT: A jury convicted a man of murder and kidnapping late Wednesday in the shotgun slaying of a preschool teacher, a case linked to the mail bomb assassinations of a federal judge and a lawyer. Defendant Emmanuel Hammond, 24, of Marietta bowed his head when the verdict was announced in Fulton County Superior Court, but otherwise showed no emotion. The jury reached its verdict around 11:15 p.m., about eight hours after deliberations began. The prosecution plans to ask for the death penalty. Judge Ralph Hicks said the trial's sentencing phase would begin Thursday morning. In addition to felony and malice murder and kidnapping, Hammond was found guilty of armed robbery in the slaying of preschool fitness teacher Julie Love. Miss Love, 27, disappeared in July 1988, and was the subject of a highly publicized search until her body was found in a northeast Atlanta dumping ground last August. She had been shot in the head. A letter from a group claiming responsibility for the mail bomb deaths last December of 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance in Mountain Brook, Ala., and Savannah attorney Robert Robinson said the attacks were motivated by outrage over Miss Love's slaying. The letter, signed by Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System, threatened more violence if any other white women were attacked by black men in Alabama, Florida or Georgia. Miss Love was white; Hammond is black. Bombs were also intercepted at the 11th U.S. Circuit courthouse in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla., chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Testimony in Hammond's trial began last week under heavy security because of concern over the mail-bomb link. A death threat from a group called the Aryan Resistance Movement, apparently unrelated to the bombings, prompted even tighter security later. In closing arguments Wednesday, Assistant District Attorney William L. Hawthorne III urged jurors to convict Hammond, saying, ``Give the devil his due.'' He said there would be more violence if Hammond were acquitted. ``As sure as I stand here before you, there will be another victim,'' Hawthorne said. ``You just don't know her name yet.'' Defense attorney William A. Wehunt said in his closing statement that Hammond was innocent. Wehunt charged that Hammond's two chief accusers, former girlfriend Janice Weldon and Hammond cousin Maurice Porter, killed Miss Love and were trying to frame his client. Porter pleaded guilty to murder, armed robbery and rape in the death of Miss Love and is awaiting sentencing. He testified last week that Hammond abducted Miss Love from an Atlanta street after her car ran out of gas and dragged her into some bushes before shooting her to death. Miss Weldon, who led police to Miss Love's body, also testified against Hammond.

DOC.HEAD: A Princess's Wonderful Day at Coronation
DOC.TEXT: Papa looked very beautiful in his crimson robe, but there was a terrible draft in Westminster Abbey, wrote the little princess after her parents' coronation in 1937. The childhood essay of Queen Elizabeth II gets its first public showing beginning Friday in the Queen's Gallery, where royal treasures are displayed at Buckingham Palace. It's part of 271 exhibits called ``A Royal Miscellany'' showing through Jan. 13, 1991. The exhibition includes everything from clocks and jewelry to the embroidered linen overshirt worn by King Charles I as he knelt to the headsman's ax in 1649. Visitors can view a lock of French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte's hair, a watercolor of Balmoral royal estate by Prince Charles, and a copy of the Mainz Psalter _ a 1457 German collection of prayers that was the first book printed in more than one color. Among the displays are the neat, proper letters of the 11-year-old princess Elizabeth. They are written in a lined exercise book that would have cost tuppence, four cents at that time. ``I thought it all very, very wonderful and I expect the Abbey did, too. The arches and beams at the top were covered with a sort of haze of wonder as Papa was crowned, at least I thought so,'' wrote the princess. Elizabeth, her sister Princess Margaret and their widowed grandmother Queen Mary had a grandstand view of the ceremony from a royal box in the abbey, where Elizabeth herself would be crowned in 1953. ``What struck me as being rather odd was that Grannie did not remember much of her own coronation. I should have thought that it would have stayed in her mind forever,'' Princess Elizabeth wrote. However, toward the end, the child found the service becoming ``rather boring'' as it was all prayers. ``Grannie and I were looking to see how many more pages to the end, and we turned one more and then I pointed to the word at the bottom of the page and it said `Finis.' We both smiled at each other and turned back to the service,'' she wrote. ``The princess was probably asked by her tutor to record her impressions of the coronation,'' said Oliver Everett, director of the Royal Library at Windsor Castle, the favorite royal residence 21 miles west of London. Everett, a former diplomat, selected the essay and 270 other items for the exhibition. ``The library is closed to the public, but the queen takes her guests there. As the castle is being rewired and repaired, guests cannot be shown round so we took the opportunity to send some interesting things to the gallery,'' Everett said in an interview at Wednesday's preview. Even the prophetic thoughts of King George III after the British defeat by the American colonists in 1781 are displayed: ``America is lost! Must we fall beneath this blow?'' he wrote. But he was consoled by the thought that ``it is to be hoped we shall reap more advantages from their trade as friends than ever we could derive from them as Colonies.''

DOC.HEAD: 11-Year-Old Boy Abducted, Set Ablaze
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy on his way to school was abducted, beaten and set on fire Wednesday by a man who tried to force him to smoke crack, authorities and witnesses said. The child, whose name was not released, was in critical but stable condition with second- and third-degree burns over 55 percent of his body at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's burn unit, said hospital spokeswoman Myrna Manners. ``His injuries are life-threatening,'' Manners said. ``We're saying he has a 50-50 chance.'' She said the boy was conscious and talking. ``Right now, we don't have a motive,'' said detective Lt. Charles Monahan. ``We may be dealing with just a psycho.'' Police believe the boy's attacker was a lone teen-ager who approached the child as he walked to school in the borough of Brooklyn and forced him into a small garage between two private homes. Inside the garage, which had been converted into a clubhouse, the child was tied up and beaten before flammable liquid was poured on him and he was set on fire, police said. Fire Department spokesman Efrain Parrilla said the assault appeared to have been drug-related, but Monahan said, ``At this point, we don't have anything to substantiate that.'' However, The New York Times reported in Thursday editions that the assailant was a man in his 20s, possibly deranged, who is known to extort money from children in the area. The burning child managed to flee the garage around 10:15 a.m., and run to a small auto-body shop about a block away, where workers called the police and fire departments. The boy, whose 12th birthday is Thursday, told the workers his attacker had tried to force him to smoke crack, the Times said, attributing the information to police. Mechanic Jean Victor, 28, told the Times the boy ``said the guy started smoking crack and said, `Do you want some?' He said he did not smoke crack. The guy knocked him down, poured gasoline on him and burned him.'' The garage is about six blocks from the boy's home. The boy's mother said her son left their apartment around 7 a.m. to wait for a school bus, as he did every morning. The boy's family emigrated from Port-an-Prince, Haiti, a year ago, and the boy speaks little English, the mother said.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Town Seeks Pied Piper To End Plague
DOC.TEXT: An Australian beach community is searching for a Pied Piper to rid it of a plague of rats, who sit on the beach and grow fat on scraps thrown to them by barbecueing beachgoers. Balsa Park, 80 miles north of Brisbane on the Sunshine Coast strip of Queensland state, is infested with hundreds of rats up to a foot long. Andrew Champion, an alderman on the Caloundra Town Council, said Wednesday that the filthy animals usually come out from their riverside rock residences around dusk but also make appearances at afternoon cookouts. The rats show no fear of humans. Champion said that although the rats appear to be friendly, residents are concerned they may bite children and the council is search for a way to get rid of the animals. The risk of disease also is a concern, he said. Champion said poisoning cannot be considered because of the danger it poses to humans and small animals. He said he believes trapping the pests in cages is probably the best option, but the problem is how to attract well-fed rats used to gourmet offerings from barbecue pits. ``This is why we're calling for a Pied Piper who could offer a solution,'' Champion said. Town Clerk John Smith said he believed in an old-fashioned remedy. ``If there are more rats, just get more cats,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Luciano Pavarotti says a diet to reduce his substantial girth has melted away 80 pounds. But when pressed at a news conference Wednesday he refused to say how much he weighs. ``I have lost 80 pounds and so I am 80 pounds less than I was,'' Pavarotti said with a broad smile. Asked how he did it, Pavarotti replied: ``Very simple. I don't take alcohol, sugar or fat. Just 1,800 calories a day. It's brilliant.'' To laughter, he said: ``Tonight, I will have a beautiful piece of salmon with vegetables, a piece of bread, strawberries, mineral water and lemon and coffee. What do you want more?'' The 54-year-old Italian tenor was in London for his first appearance in nearly six years at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden.

The town where Bruce Springsteen got his start is losing the museum that documented his rise to fame. The Asbury Park Rock 'n' Roll Museum will not reopen, its curators say. One of the biggest thrills of Bill Smith's life was the day in 1987 when Springsteen sauntered into the museum that claims the world's largest publicly displayed collection of Springsteen memorabilia. Within a year, the Palace Arcade that housed the collection of rare posters and recordings was closed. Now Smith and his partner have put the items up for sale. ``We looked into the possibility of reopening, but we couldn't find any place to move to,'' Smith said. He said more than 35,000 fans from all 50 states and 18 other countries had visited the museum since it opened in 1986.

Travel writer Stephen Birnbaum has developed this axiom of travel in Eastern Europe: The softer a country's currency, the harder its toilet paper. The 52-year-old author also said at a conference on tourism this week that the biggest mistake Americans make is not researching their destinations. ``Aside from a house or car, your vacation is the single largest expense you will incur in a year,'' he explained. ``Yet the amount of homework we do is abysmal compared with the other two expenses. ``We buy a plane ticket, make hotel reservations, arrive in an unfamiliar location and say, `Maude, what do we do now?'''

Singer Freddy Fender doubts the death of one of his band members is drug-related but says the tragedy stirred memories of his own previous struggle with drugs and alcohol. Fender, 52, said Wednesday he suffered a deep loss in the death of bass guitarist Johnny Garcia, who collapsed and died on Sunday. The cause of death is under investigation. ``I am a recovering alcoholic and drug addict and it's my commitment to other drug addicts and other drunks to help them, because it's going to help me ... If there is any person that is anti-drugs and anti-booze, it's me,'' Fender said. Fender, best known for his country western hit ``Wasted Days and Wasted Nights,'' saw his career plummet when he drank heavily and used drugs. Since entering a treatment center in 1985, he has tried to rebuild his career. He knows exactly how long he's been sober: ``Four years, six months and nine days.''

Nadia Comaneci's agent says she may have broken up with Constantin Panait, the married man who engineered her escape from Romania. The Olympic gymnast canceled her first U.S. appearance on the lecture circuit, apparently because she was upset over the breakup, said her agent, Bob Davis. She was to have given a speech Wednesday night at Nassau Community College. Davis said he hasn't spoken to Comaneci since she left for Tokyo more than a week ago with Panait, a roofer with a wife and four children in Florida. But people in Comaneci's entourage say the two broke up en route back from Japan, Davis said. Comaneci is staying with friends in Montreal, Davis said, where she won the first perfect 10s in Olympic gymnastics history in 1976. Panait is on the road. Comaneci said in a recent magazine interview that she and Panait had no plans to marry. She said last month that she intends to marry a 30-year-old fellow Romanian who is expected to enter the United States later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Agreement Would Allow More US-Soviet Air Travel
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union are moving toward a major increase in scheduled and charter air service, opening for the first time a wide array of destinations in each nation. The development represents one more signal of closer relations between the two superpowers and opens a potential opportunity for U.S. commercial air carriers. ``Clearly it would appear that the market is going to increase more rapidly in the future,'' said Pamela Hanlon, a spokeswoman for Pan American World Airways, now the only U.S. carrier that flies into the Soviet Union. ``Potentially it's an excellent market,'' she said. If the tentative agreement reached in London last week bears fruit, it would normalize and greatly expand air service disrupted a decade ago as the United States imposed sanctions to retaliate against the 1979 Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and the 1981 Soviet-encouraged crackdown against dissidents in Poland. Under the preliminary agreement, U.S. airlines would increase scheduled service to Moscow and Leningrad and gain new rights to serve six additional Soviet cities, including two in the Soviet Far East, according to the State Department. A department official said Wednesday these cities include Kiev, the capital of the Ukraine; Riga, the capital of Latvia; Minsk, the capital of Byelorussia; Tbilsi, the capital of Soviet Georgia; and Khabarovsk and Magadan in the Soviet Far East. Khabarovsk is a station on the Trans Siberian Railroad north of Vladivostok. Magadan is a port on the Sea of Okhotsk, which opens to the Pacific. In return, the Soviet airline Aeroflot would be permitted to increase its trans-Atlantic service to New York and Washington and would gain new rights to serve Chicago and Miami with onward service to two undisclosed points in South America. Aeroflot service over the Pacific also could begin to Anchorage, Alaska, and to San Francisco with a stop in Anchorage, the State Department said. Airlines of both nations also could increase the number of weekly flights and increase the number of airlines designated to serve the expanded routes, the department said. Ms. Hanlon said Pan Am sees the new development as an opportunity to expand more rapidly in a modest but steadily increasing market. Pan Am, which began non-stop service to Moscow two years ago with three flights a week, added a flight last year and will operate five flights a week this summer, Ms. Hanlon said. ``We are currently looking to increase that to seven non-stops next year,'' she said. The spokeswoman said Pan Am and other U.S. carriers would not necessarily open air service to each of the new possible destinations inside the Soviet Union but would look at each city ``to see if the market is there.'' The tentative agreement also would allow the United States and the Soviet Union Soviet up to 100 charter flights a year over the Atlantic. The State Department said ``positive consideration'' also would be given to trans-Pacific charter flights between the two countries. The preliminary agreement was reached by U.S. and Soviet negotiators at a second round of the London talks. A third round will be convened in London in late April to discuss financial provisions and other outstanding issues. Then-President Carter ordered Aeroflot to stop its service to New York after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. In 1981, then-President Reagan cited Soviet-inspired repression in Poland in ordering Aeroflot to terminate its service to Washington. The latter action halted all Soviet air service to the United States with the exception of Aeroflot flights carrying diplomatic personnel and supplies intended for Soviet embassies and consulates. In 1983, Reagan ordered Aeroflot's offices in New York and Washington closed in protest over the shooting down of a South Korean jetliner by Soviet warplanes. Commercial flights between the two nations were resumed in April 1986 with regularly scheduled Aeroflot flights to Washington and Pan Am flights to Moscow. The next year the two nations signed an agreement permitting an expansion of air service beginning in May 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses: Hazelwood Appeared Sober Before Boarding Ship
DOC.TEXT: After losing a bid for dismissal of all charges against Joseph Hazelwood, the defense called three witnesses who said he appeared sober hours before his tanker caused the nation's worst oil spill. Among the witnesses was a florist who said she took Hazelwood's order for Easter flowers to be sent to his home in Huntington, N.Y., about six hours before the skipper boarded the ship. The other witnesses were marine terminal guards. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone on Wednesday showed keen interest in a defense argument on why the Exxon Valdez skipper should be cleared, but rejected a motion to cut short the trial and acquit him. Defense attorney Dick Madson, in arguing for acquittal, raised a new legal point: Hazelwood is innocent of operating a vessel while intoxicated because he was not at the helm when it went aground March 24. ``We realize we are asking this judge to go where no judge has gone before,'' said Madson. ``In my research, there has never been a case where a person who is intoxicated has been convicted because he has the authority to control a vehicle but is not actually at the controls.'' He noted that Hazelwood turned over the ship to a third mate about 10 minutes before it went off course, struck Bligh Reef and dumped nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude in scenic Prince William Sound. The oil devastated hundreds of miles of rocky shore and killed countless birds, fish and other wildlife. The defense steadfastly maintains the skipper was sober when the ship went aground. But Madson drew the analogy of a person who is intoxicated, gets in a cab and tells the driver where to go. If the driver runs a red light and hits a school bus, the person in the back seat giving directions is not at fault. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole said Coast Guard regulations clearly require the captain to be sober, no matter where he is on the ship. The judge countered that Coast Guard regulations do not apply because Hazelwood is on trial under state, not federal, law. But he refused to drop the intoxication charge or the other charges, criminal mischief, reckless endangerment and negligent discharge of oil. Hazelwood, 43, could get up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted on all counts. The legal arguments took place outside the jury's presence. Following the judge's ruling, Madson called to the stand Emily Kaiser, a Valdez flower shop owner who said she took Hazelwood's order. ``He was sober,'' she declared, saying she remembered him because she also is from Huntington and they chatted about their hometown, which is on Long Island. ``Were you pretty busy that day?'' Cole asked on cross-examination. ``Yes,'' said the witness, ``but not that busy that I don't remember Mr. Hazelwood because of the Long Island deal.'' Two other witnesses were guards at the Aleyeska terminal who screen seamen for contraband and signs of intoxication before they board their ships. Charles Dudley and Michael Craig remembered Hazelwood arriving by cab with two other crew members and said they noticed no signs that Hazelwood was drunk. The prosecution rested Wednesday after calling 45 witnesses in 4{ weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Congressman Seeking Election to Maryland Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Former Michigan congressman Charles Diggs Jr., who resigned 10 years ago after being convicted of accepting payroll kickbacks, says he'll run for a seat in the Maryland House of Delegates. Diggs, a Democrat, said Wednesday he would serve just one term and has no interest in running for Congress again. ``My principal reason for running is to be in Annapolis during the reapportionment consideration in 1991 and '92,'' said Diggs, explaining that he wants to tap the political potential of blacks in the state. States redraw political boundary lines, including congressional and legislative districts, after the national census every 10 years. That process would begin in 1991 based on population counts from the 1990 census. Although Maryland is not likely to pick up an additional congressional seat, ``there's going to be significant realignment in drawing new lines,'' the former Detroit representative said in a telephone interview. He said there is increased discussion about changing the boundaries of Maryland's suburban 5th Congressional District, now represented by House Democratic Caucus Chairman Steny Hoyer, ``to create a district that would be ripe for a black candidate.'' Diggs, a licensed mortician, served in Congress for 25 years before resigning in 1980 after he was convicted of mail fraud and falsifying staff payroll vouchers. He founded the Congressional Black Caucus, chaired the House Committee on the District of Columbia and also headed the Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa. Diggs said he sees the importance of protecting Hoyer, who is fourth in the House leadership hierarchy, but said ``progress toward power-sharing among white controlling interests in the state and (Prince George's) county is moving too slowly.'' Hoyer said the scenario for redistricting outlined by Diggs is one of several being discussed. ``I think any area that experiences growth in an ethnic or minority group needs to accommodate that,'' said Hoyer, but ``political realities'' will make it difficult to expand the Maryland congressional delegation while protecting incumbents. Diggs, 67, said he has no interest in a congressional seat that might come out of redistricting. ``I'm interested in the development of the talents of younger people to take over various offices'' that will become available as the county and state black population grows, he said. Diggs said he will file candidacy forms next month for the Maryland House from a legislative district in Prince George's County.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Approves First Gene-Transfer Therapy
DOC.TEXT: The first human gene-transfer therapy could begin within a year if other government panels join a National Institutes of Health committee in approving the experimental treatment to combat a rare immune deficiency in children. Six other federal committees must concur with Wednesday's decision by the NIH Institutional Biosafety Committee before the experimental therapy can be tried. The treatment would be the first time that a human illness had been directly treated by the process of gene transfer. The process would insert curative genes into the blood cells of children suffering adenosine deaminase deficiency. If approved, clinical use could begin by late fall or winter. The proposal was presented by Dr. W. French Anderson of the Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, one of the National Institutes of Health, and Dr. Michael Blaese of the National Cancer Institute. Blaese said the clinical plan is to remove lymphocytes _ white cells _ of the blood of children with the immune deficiency and insert into them the gene they lack. Lymphocytes are the major infection-fighting element of the immune system. The treated cells then would be cultured until they increase in number by about a thousandfold, and then transferred back into the patient's bloodstream. Adenosine deaminase is an enzyme that performs an essential function in the immune system. Without the enzyme, the body's ability to fight infection is crippled. The gene that would be inserted would program the cells to produce the missing enzyme. The therapy would not be a permanent cure, Blaese said, since the enzyme would be produced only as long as the genetically manipulated cells live. ``We don't know how long these cells last,'' he said. ``Some lymphocytes, however, can live for years.'' The researcher said the therapy might allow patients to live longer than they would otherwise. However, scientists hope to develop a system where the gene could be placed in the cells of the bone marrow, which would permanently correct the enzyme deficiency. Adenosine deaminase deficiency is ``very, very rare,'' said Blaese. ``There are only 20 to 30 patients in the whole world.'' The sufferers are born without the required gene. Some are treated successfully by bone marrow transplants, but for many the disorder means death within the first year or two of life by some infectious disease.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 9:15 a.m. EST; time set by source
Group Proposes Boosting Tax Credits for Working Poor
DOC.TEXT: Poor people who live and work in rural areas would benefit more than city dwellers from several proposed anti-poverty programs, according to a report released today. The study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities notes that a disproportionate share of working poor live in rural areas. Although only 23 percent of the nation is rural, 33 percent of the working poor live in rural areas, it said. Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., whose state's poverty rate increased from 13.4 percent in the early 1980s to 15.5 percent by the middle of the decade, said some of the center's recommendations would cost more than the country can afford now. ``However, there are smaller steps we can take, and have taken, to begin to meet the needs of the rural working poor,'' said Synar, who released the study along with Sen. James Jeffords, R-Vt. The report suggested aiding the working poor by: _Enlarging the earned income tax credit for low-income families with children. _Extending the child care tax credit to low-income working families. _Restoring the minimum wage to its average purchasing power during the 1960s and 1970s. _Partially reversing cutbacks made during the 1980s in the unemployment insurance program. _Expanding Medicaid so it can provide health care coverage to more children in working poor families. The earned income tax credit _ available to low- and moderate-income families with children _ offers an example of how rural working poor benefit more from such programs than those in the city. To receive the credit, which was worth up to $910 in 1989, families need only to file a federal income tax return. The family either gets a tax break, or if the family's income is too low to be taxed, the government sends a check for the appropriate amount. ``Since wages are lower in rural than in urban areas, and since a larger proportion of the rural poor work, the proportion of families qualifying for the (tax credit) is higher in rural than in urban locations,'' said the center. Legislation to increase the amount of money available under the earned income tax credit is pending in the House. If the minimum wage were increased to give it the same purchasing power it had 20 or 30 years ago, a larger share of rural workers would benefit than city dwellers, said the report, because one in three rural workers earn at or near the minimum wage, compared with about one in five urban workers. ``Expansion of the earned income credit, combined with full restoration of the minimum wage, would lift a substantial number of rural working poor households out of poverty,'' said Robert Greenstein, center director and coauthor of the report. Providing extended unemployment benefits in areas of states with very high unemployment _ even if the state as a whole doesn't qualify _ would help rural areas where unemployment is often seasonal, he said. Currently, extended benefits may be provided to the long-term unemployed only when the statewide jobless rate is very high. The report is one in a series of rural poverty reports by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, an independent research organization that specializes in the analysis of data and policy issues affecting low- and moderate-income Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Production Keeps Falling Under Drastic Economic Plan
DOC.TEXT: Production in state industries has fallen by nearly a quarter since the Solidarity-led government began its shock transformation of the economy from central planning to capitalism, statistics show. Since the plan took effect Jan. 1, industrial managers have started exporting some goods because of slack domestic demand, the official PAP news agency said Wednesday in a report based on government figures. Tens of thousands of Poles have lost their jobs and others can afford few things to buy because price rises have outstripped wage increases during the first two months of the plan. The government lifted price controls and subsidies, which caused prices to rise to market levels, and restricted wage increase as part of the plan to fight hyperinflation and restructure the economy by forcing inefficient enterprises to close. But the figures from the Main Statistical Office showed not a single state enterprise had gone bankrupt despite the drop in production, the news agency reported. In February, state industries reported a drop in production of 23.9 percent compared to December 1989 with the sharpest decline in food and light industries, PAP said. It said wages in Febuary had increased 15 percent from January, when the average monthly pay in major industries was $65. Industrial prices were up 7 percent, while the statistical office predicted once the final tabulations were made that the inflation rate for February would not exceed 23 percent. Prices in January were estimated to be 60-70 percent higher than in December, while the inflation rate for 1989 was put at about 700 percent. The Finance Ministry announced on Wednesday that it expected the inlation rate for March to be about 6 percent, PAP said. The PAP report gave no figures for unemployment, but the agency earlier this month reported that as of Feb. 28 there were 152,190 jobless in Poland with only 20,500 openings for jobs. Nearly 56,000 people registered as unemployed in January. The government initially forecast about 400,000 unemployed as inefficient firms close down and others cut back on the number of employees. The economic program, developed by Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, has the support of many Western governments, the Paris Club of creditor nations, the World Bank and officials of the European Economic Community. Balcerowicz has anticipated the mass layoffs and prices increase but stressed the economic pain was temporary and needed to halt the inflation and to end Poland's economic decline under more than four decades of Communist rule. In August, Solidarity activist Tadeusz Mazowiecki became prime minister, the first non-Communist head of a government in Eastern Europe. Since then, democratic reforms have swept the East bloc.

DOC.HEAD: Farmer Mac Preparing to Make Debut
DOC.TEXT: The new Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corp., called Farmer Mac for short, is tuning up for its grand entry in the financial market later this year. Farmer Mac was created a little more than two years ago by the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987 as a secondary market for agricultural real estate loans. But it has taken time to organize, to work out the kinks and follow the instructions Congress laid down, Farmer Mac officials said Wednesday. Start-up procedures included the initial sale of $20 million in voting common stock to banks and other lenders. Rules and operating specifications are still being honed. John R. Dahl, chairman of the board, said after the corporation's second annual stockholders' meeting that underwriting standards and other guides must be developed meticulously to ensure integrity. Dahl said Farmer Mac has a ``very strong foundation'' and that all the deadlines specified by Congress have been met. The aim of Farmer Mac, he said, is to ``accomplish the goal that Congress set out for us ... to increase the availability of capital, to allow agricultural borrowers and rural housing borrowers an opportunity of more places to go to look for credit.'' Hopefully, Dahl added, these borrowers also ``will have the benefits of competition and competitive interest rates.'' But Dahl and Henry D. Edelman, the corporation's president and chief executive officer, could not offer a firm timetable or identify those in line for actual ``pooling'' operations. Banks and other lenders can convert long-term assets _ in this case real estate mortgages _ by selling the loans on the secondary market. At that point, those who buy the mortgages package or pool the loans and then sell loan-backed securities to the public. Meanwhile, the original lenders are able to increase their cash and are able to make more loans to agricultural borrowers. Farmer Mac will share the risk of the farm real estate loan business by guaranteeing returns on the securities. Other federal agencies such as the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (Freddie Mac), Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and Government National Mortgage Association (Ginnie Mae) serve a similar function for their clientele. Dahl, a rancher from Gackle, N.D., said in an interview after the meeting that ``we've come a long way'' in getting Farmer Mac on solid ground. But he said there is no way to estimate the corporation's eventual impact on the nation's agricultural credit market. ``There's no history involved here,'' he said. ``There's a lot of enthusiasm for Farmer Mac, and I wish I could tell you that we're going to do a billion dollars in business, or something. But there's no way we can predict this.'' But what can be predicted, Dahl added, is that ``we're going to do everything we possibly can to come up with the kind of program that Congress envisioned agriculture needed.'' There has been some concern among other financial authorities that demand for Farmer Mac's secondary market services might fall short of expectations. Dahl said he wasn't aware of any major threat to Farmer Mac, at least not in the formative stage. ``There are some that are hesitant about Farmer Mac,'' he said. ``And there have been some things in the (news) media from time to time. But I think those are based on perceptions more than fact ... nothing's 100 percent, I'd be the first to say that.'' Also, Dahl said there has been ``some impatience'' about Farmer Mac not being in business yet. ``But we need this program developed with quality and with integrity,'' he said. ``We're here for the long pull.'' Dahl said he tried to look back a few years when so much of the nation's agriculture was going through the financial wringer, and what Farmer Mac might have done to help. ``And I think it would have been a lot easier, a lot more stable if we had had it,'' he said. ``That's what we need to try and do in the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Seeking Special Envoy to Coordinate Hostage Talks
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress are urging the Bush administration to appoint a special envoy of ``prominence and stature'' to coordinate discussions about the American hostages in Lebanon. ``All signals suggest that an opportunity for release exists,'' Rep. Louise Slaughter, D-N.Y., told a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee Wednesday _ amid a flurry of news reports suggesting movement in the hostage situation. Slaughter said she and Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., first proposed an envoy to tackle the hostage question two years ago. ``Since that time, Congress has recognized National Hostage Awareness Day and I have commemorated Terry Anderson's five birthdays in captivity,'' Slaughter said. ``How long do we wait? Will we again gather in October with heavy hearts to mark another of Terry's birthdays?'' Anderson, chief correspondent for The Associated Press in the Middle East, is the longest held of the eight American hostages in Lebanon. He will mark five years in captivity on March 16. Slaughter's district includes his hometown of Batavia, N.Y. Most, if not all, of the hostages are thought to be held by Shiite Moslem groups with ties to Iran. In all, 18 Westerners are held in Lebanon. The subcommittee sent a resolution by Slaughter seeking a special envoy to the full Foreign Affairs Committee. Moynihan is seeking a companion resolution in the Senate. If passed, the resolution would not be sent to President Bush or have the force of law, but would express Congress' sentiments. Slaughter's measure calls on the president to appoint ``someone of prominence and stature, with a keen understanding of Middle East politics, to initiate and coordinate discussions between the Syrians, Iran and other influential parties.'' Rep. Olympia Snowe, R-Maine, wondered if a special envoy might conflict whatever the administration is doing secretly on behalf of the hostages. Slaughter said she wouldn't proceed with the measure ``if I have any reason to believe that this would hurt ongoing efforts.'' U.S. officials usually oppose the idea of special envoys, said a State Department source, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Remember Terry Waite _ he was a special envoy,'' this official said, referring to the Anglican churchman who was seized in Beirut while trying to free the hostages. Mike Kraft, an official in the State Department's counter-terrorism office, said ``a great deal is being done that is not publicized'' and that the administration has an ``open-door'' policy in talking to people. Officials have insisted however that the U.S. government is not negotiating with Iran for the release of the hostages. U.S. policy is not to deal directly with the Iranians. ``There are no U.S. government talks,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said. But White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said administration officials were ``encouraged by the comments'' of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, who said there might be a solution soon. ``They certainly are more hopeful than what we've heard in the more distant past,'' he said of Rafsanjani's remarks. But the Revolutionary Justice Organization said it had no intention of releasing the hostages it claims to hold, Joseph Cicippio of Valley Forge, Pa., and Edward Austin Tracy, an American author. A statement by the group, delivered to Beirut newspaper An-Nahar and a Western news agency, was accompanied by a black-and-white instant photograph of Cicippio.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Rising Unrest, Avril Says He Might Resign
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Under the pressure of mounting anti-government unrest, Haiti's military leader has indicated he would consider resigning but also says his departure ``would create a lot of turmoil.'' Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril spoke Wednesday as thousands of students rallied in provincial cities for the second straight day to protest the army's killing of an 11-year-old girl. The girl was to be buried today and student groups called for a national day of mourning. Eleven political parties urged businesses and factories to close in sympathy. Asked in a rare interview whether he might resign, Avril said: ``I will never resist the will of the people.'' But, he added, ``We must get on with elections because elections reflect the will of the people.'' ``If I step down hurriedly, it will create a lot of turmoil,'' Avril said at the Presidential Palace. ``I have thought a lot about how to prevent the country falling into revolution and chaos.'' On Wednesday, thousands of students marched in the provincial towns of Jacmel, Jeremie, Leogane, Petit Goave and Mirebalais, the Roman Catholic Church's Radio Soleil reported. In Gonaives, 100 miles north of the capital Port-au-Prince, schools stayed closed for a second day, and students set up flaming tire barricades. Schools were also closed in the northern coastal city of Cap-Haitien, Radio Soleil said. The student marches were reminiscent of demonstrations in November 1985 to protest the army's killing of three high school students in Gonaives. Those protests led to the downfall of former dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, who fled to exile in France in February 1986. Avril, a former Duvalier aide, came to power in September 1988, replacing Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy in a coup led by lower-ranking soldiers. He promised elections and reforms but shipped seven pro-democracy leaders into exile during a crackdown in January and arrested more than 50 opposition activists, some of whom were beaten in custody. Avril, who has promised presidential elections later this year, said he imposed a state of siege Jan. 20 as a ``preventive measure'' after the killing of an army colonel because ``the electoral process itself was threatened.'' He lifted the emergency nine days later after an international outcry. On Wednesday, the U.N. Human Rights Commission agreed to begin a special investigation into allegations of abuses in Haiti, saying the situation under Avril ``remains disturbing and even seems to have deteriorated.'' The Geneva-based organization said it was ``alarmed by the proliferation of acts of violence in Haiti, particularly against arrested or detained persons, and by the apparent inability of the judicial system to put an end to such acts.'' Virtually all political parties and unions have vowed to boycott any elections under Avril. They say he can't be trusted to turn over power to elected civilians. Eighteen parties have proposed that Avril be replaced by a Supreme Court justice until a new leader is elected. ``If there is a change of government, that will only delay elections even more,'' Avril said. In the interview, Avril repeated his promise to allow elections this year and abide by the results. Avril repeated he was not interested in running for office. County and municipal elections are scheduled for April 29, legislative elections July 22, and presidential elections Oct. 28. In November 1987, the first free general elections since independence from France in 1804 were canceled after attackers protected by soldiers massacred at least 34 voters. This week's student marches began Tuesday to protest the death of 11-year-old Roseline Vaval. She was studying on her porch when she was fatally shot Monday by a soldier breaking up a small anti-government demonstration in Petit Goave.

DOC.HEAD: Dates For Shevardnadze, NATO Meetings Set
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will hold his next round of talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Washington April 4-6, U.S. officials say. An official announcement is expected by the end of the week. The session is designed primarily to prepare for the summit meeting Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will hold here with President Bush in the second half of June. The precise date for the summit has not been set. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said Wednesday the meeting might be moved up to earlier in June to accommodate the Soviets, who are expected to hold a major Communist Party session in late June. ``We're always willing to change,'' Fitzwater said. ``We can do it any time.'' Baker went to Moscow last month to see Gorbachev and Shevardnadze. The trip produced a narrowing of differences on a strategic arms reduction treaty the two leaders would like to sign at the summit. And, the two sides moved closer on provisions for agreements also being negotiated with other nations to ban chemical weapons production and to reduce troops, tanks and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. Baker is making arrangements for a meeting with the 15 NATO foreign ministers, probably in Brussels, after the Shevardnadze visit, the officials said. This is in addition to a meeting Baker will hold with the NATO ministers in Ayreshire, Scotland, June 7-9. The session, which has not been announced, was disclosed by the officials on condition of anonymity. Baker has held five rounds of talks with Shevardnadze so far _ in Vienna last March, in Moscow in May, in Paris in July, in Jackson, Wyo., in September, and in Moscow Feb. 7-10. They also could meet in Namibia while attending ceremonies marking the new African country's independence from South African rule Feb. 21. The active schedule reflects both a step-up in talks with the Soviet Union to try to hasten arms control agreements while lending U.S. support to political and economic reform and increased consultation with the NATO allies on U.S.-Soviet relations. Also, Baker has pledged to consult regularly with the West Europeans about German unification. The U.S. formula gives special roles to Britain and France, as well as the Soviet Union, as the Big Four allies of World War II. A number of smaller countries feel left out. Many are victims of German aggression in World War II and some are worried about the situation in Europe after West Germany merges with East Germany. Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti carried these concerns to President Bush and Baker on Tuesday. It then was decided to have Baker meet with the foreign ministers after Shevardnadze's visit.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,690.89, up 328.55 points, or 0.98 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Choice Spars With Senators
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's choice as the Justice Department's civil rights chief is headed for likely confirmation after parrying thrusts by Democratic senators. John R. Dunne, a former New York state senator, was peppered with questions Wednesday by members of the Senate Judiciary Committee over his lack of civil rights experience, his former memberships in men-only clubs and investments in companies that do business in South Africa. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said he was ``having great difficulty'' supporting Dunne's nomination to be assistant attorney general for civil rights. Nevertheless, Metzenbaum said, ``I'm not sure President Bush would appoint anybody better than you. Regardless of how I vote, you're going to be confirmed.'' A staff aide said the committee would probably vote on the nomination March 22. At one point, Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., who chaired the hearing, asked Dunne if he was ``offended'' by a number of recent Supreme Court cases that make it tougher for individuals to prove racial or sexual discrimination. ``It triggered my concern,'' Dunne said. ``Ideally, I would like to have that nominee sitting there say, `I was offended,''' Simon said. ``Taking those 11 or 12 decisions, I'm alarmed. I'm not offended yet,'' Dunne replied. ``OK,'' Simon said, ``You're getting a little stronger.'' Metzenbaum also pressed Dunne about his long memberships in the men-only Garden City (N.Y.) Golf Club on Long Island, N.Y., and the Fort Orange Club in Albany, N.Y., which began admitting women in 1988. Asked whether he ``might have taken a different course of conduct,'' Dunne replied, ``I believe I would have.'' Dunne, 60, was tapped for the civil rights job in January. The post has been vacant since December 1988 when William Bradford Reynolds resigned. Bush's first nominee for the job, William C. Lucas, then a Michigan county executive, was rejected by the committee by a 7-7 vote last August. Lucas, who is black, had spent most of his career in law enforcement and had little litigation experience. He was also opposed by many civil rights organizations. Dunne, who resigned from the New York Senate last year after losing a race for majority leader, has been criticized by civil rights groups for lacking civil rights experience. None opposed his nomination outright, however. Simon asked Dunne to explain his position on apartheid in light of the fact that he and his law firm hold stock in companies that do business in South Africa and that he voted against a measure requiring New York state to divest such holdings. ``Let me put right up in the front: I hate, if one can hate, the principle of apartheid,'' Dunne replied. ``The three items ... are unconnected and not indicative of an attitude that favors that system.'' Dunne said he cast the vote against divestiture as part of his responsibility to lead debate on the state Senate floor. ``On a personal note, I found it very difficult,'' he added. As for his own investments, Dunne said his brother is his stockbroker and ``I have no standard with regard to investments.'' Simon said it ``would be a very wise thing to do'' if he now told his brother not to invest in companies that do business in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Profits Drop 34 Percent; Sagging Real Estate Market at Fault
DOC.TEXT: Real estate problems in the Northeast are dragging down bank profits and some analysts worry the weakness will spread. Banks earned $2.7 billion in the fourth quarter and $16.3 billion for all of 1989, a 34 percent drop from $24.8 billion in 1988, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Wednesday. Provisions for loan losses hit a near-record $30.3 billion last year. The FDIC attributed about two-thirds of that to domestic loans, primarily for real estate development. Third World loan problems caused the rest. Five of the country's 10 largest banks were in the red last year, primarily because of provisions for losses on developing country loans. They were Chase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty, Manufacturers Hanover, Bankers Trust and Chemical Bank. Bad real estate loans more than doubled in the Northeast, where four states _ Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Hampshire and New York _ were among the 10 with the highest percentage of sour real estate loans. The Boston-based Bank of New England alone lost $1.1 billion last year, most of it in real estate. Problem real estate continued to cause losses in the Southwest, but institutions in that region appear to be recovering somewhat.
