DOC.HEAD: In Key West, Some Say Battle is Over Its Traditional Ambience
DOC.TEXT: The battle was over charging rent to dockside merchants, but as Anthony ``Captain Tony'' Tarracino, the former skipper and barkeep elected mayor, put it, ``The fight was over a lot more than you could see.'' At stake, said the 73-year-old Tarracino, was Key West's bohemian ambience, which some see as endangered. After the City Commission last month voted to charge far lower rent than Tarracino feared, he headed to the Full Moon Cafe to celebrate past midnight with other friends of Key West's nightly sunset festival, a collection of vendors who sell snacks, crafts, caricatures and tarot readings on Mallory Square Dock. But the effort to protect the vendors from ``big money'' interests remains an uphill fight, said Tarracino. ``They'll be back,'' he said. ``They're like barracudas. They don't let up.'' The debate over charging rent to the vendors brought out the conflicts facing the city. Many businessmen say Key West must raise revenues to pay the costs of living on a popular island, such as skyrocketing prices for water, which must be piped in from the mainland 100 miles away, and sewage treatment, which has become more costly because of Florida's environmental protection push. ``It's just a matter of economics,'' said Richard Heyman, a two-time former mayor who operates an art gallery. ``If you want to be here, you're going to have to pay the price.'' To attract well-heeled tourists and new residents, the city has tried to change a raucous image. Officials sent a letter to colleges warning that lawless behavior wouldn't be tolerated, and ordinances have been passed against noise, outdoor display of T-shirts and some pushcart vendors. More pricey restaurants and bars are springing up alongside such longtime local favorites as Sloppy Joe's, Capt. Tony's and Jimmy Buffett's Margaritaville Cafe, which has a souvenir shop in which T-shirts carrying the lyrics of Buffett's songs celebrating the Keys lifestyle sell for $13.95 each. During the City Commission meeting Feb. 26, tempers flared during debate over a city lease with the Cultural Preservation Society representing the sunset vendors, who had never paid rent before. The city commission had voted 3-2 at its previous meeting to charge $48,000 for an annual lease. But Commissioner Sally Lewis, moved by complaints the sunset festival was threatened, succeeded in putting a $24,000 annual ceiling on the rent, based on a $2 nightly charge per vendor. The lease requires the rent go for dock improvements. Performers, who depend upon donations, won't be charged. The sunset festival has evolved over two decades into a ritual that draws hundreds of tourists each evening. While awaiting sunset over the sea, they are entertained by offbeat performances, such as housecats jumping through flaming hoops or a man who balances a bicycle on his nose. ``The businessmen downtown saw money being made and they wanted it,'' said Lester Gibbs, who moved 23 years ago from Festus, Mo. ``These are nickel-and-dime operations, and they're trying to take it away from us.'' Businessmen scoffed at arguments that what they call a flea market is essential to the ambience that lured Ernest Hemingway and playwright Tennessee Williams to live and write here.

DOC.HEAD: Relief at Last? College Tuition Increases May Be Easing
DOC.TEXT: Many schools are announcing some of the smallest tuition increases in a decade, and some college officials attribute that to cost-cutting moves with resultant savings being passed on to students. But some higher education leaders believe next fall's modest increases also are a response to a growing sense of outrage among students, legislators and others after a decade in which tuition increases far outstripped inflation. ``I think we're approaching the end of the big increases,'' said Robert Atwell, president of the American Council of Education. ``What's doing it is the demographics, the student response, the legislative response in some cases, the governing boards getting interested in this issue, the editorial boards of newspapers and magazines.'' Especially sobering, said Atwell and others, has been a recent falloff in applications at many colleges, including top ones such as Harvard, suggesting that schools no longer can simply raise their rates with impunity. Stanford University is raising fixed student fees by 5.25 percent in 1990-91 to $20,210, the smallest increase in 15 years, and considerably less than the 8 percent hike in the current year. The smaller increase results from a $22 million cost-cutting program, school officials said. This week, Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced its rates next fall will rise to $20,700, a 7.1 percent increase, compared to 7.2 percent the previous year. The University of Michigan and Wayne State University are holding increases to the lowest level in years _ 6.5 percent. A year ago, Michigan posted a 9.6 percent increase. The Iowa Board of Regents, which oversees the University of Iowa, Iowa State University and the University of Northern Iowa, approved a 3 percent rise for 1990-91, the smallest in a decade. Columbia College announced a 5.7 percent increase, the smallest in more than 20 years. Harvard's fall tuitions won't be announced until later this month, but spokesman Peter Costa said fees probably will be up 5 percent to 7 percent. Average tuitions rose 5 percent to 9 percent during the current school year, according to the College Board's most recent annual college cost survey. Costs rose in double digits from 1981 through 1984. Rates at four-year public colleges shot up 20 percent in 1983-84. They leveled into the 5-9 percent range for the past five years. Still, some like Richard Rosser, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, aren't ready to declare an end to the college cost spiral. He and others point out that next fall's announced increases are ``all over the map,'' with some still in double digits. And students on several campuses have protested steep increases in recent weeks. Such protests would seem to indicate a mood change from previous years when students paid their tuition with barely a murmur even as rates were climbing by as much as 20 percent. Next fall's more modest increases also may reflect nervousness in academia over a continuing U.S. Justice Department investigation of at least 56 private colleges. The probe is looking into whether school officials are improperly collaborating in setting tuition and financial aid.

DOC.HEAD: Reporters Withhold Bylines in Contract Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Today's editions of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch hit the streets without bylines as reporters and columnists withheld their names to express unhappiness over a proposed contract. The ``byline strike,'' which began Wednesday, was approved in a vote Sunday by Local 47 of the St. Louis Newspaper Guild. About 600 union members have been working without a contract since their old pact expired midnight Feb. 28. The Guild, the largest of 11 unions at the newspaper, is one of six that have not reached agreement on a new contract. Talks between the newspaper and its unions were to resume today. Herb Goodrick, the local's executive director, said Wednesday that he thought the byline strike, the first in the paper's history, was effective. ``It's to show that they're embarrased to put their name on a paper that takes the bargaining position that the Post has taken,'' Goodrick said. Photographers also were withholding their names from photo credits. Publisher Nicholas Penniman had no comment other than to say that the writers were within their rights to withhold their bylines under the contract. The dispute comes at a time when the Post-Dispatch has new competition _ the non-union St. Louis Sun, started in the fall by Ingersoll Publications Co. The Post-Dispatch, founded in 1878, is owned by Pulitzer Publishing Co. Goodrick said two issues _ drug testing and a system that would pay new hires lower wages _ prevented acceptance of a contract proposal in October. But the company's latest proposal deleted a 4 percent cost-of-living increase and added other points of disagreement, including the denial of sick leave to employees who contract illnesses through ``immorality.'' Goodrick said the union had not threatened a real strike against the newspaper. ``At this point we've tried to be very restrained and responsible,'' Goodrick said. ``Our objective is to get an agreement. A strike is one of the tools for that, but we think there are other steps we can take before that.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sentences Three Drug Dealers to Hang
DOC.TEXT: A special court has sentenced three ``prominent hashish traders'' to hang under the military government's get-tough drug policy. The defendants, who were not identified, had ``big quantities of hashish'' with them when they were captured, the official Sudan News Agency reported Wednesday night. Reporting from Wad Medani, 105 miles southeast of Khartoum, the agency did not give the date of execution set by Col. Awad Khairalla, the court president, or other details. The court's action brought to five the number of narcotics smugglers or traders sentenced to die since Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir's military junta took power June 30 and made drug-dealing a capital crime. One was hanged in Khartoum last year.

DOC.HEAD: China Accuses Foreign Journalists Of Illegal Activities
DOC.TEXT: China today denied its security forces have stepped up surveillance of foreign reporters, and implied that journalists' complaints of harassment were a ``smokescreen'' for illegal activities. Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing also denounced a U.S. Embassy investigation into intimidation of American journalists in Beijing, calling it interference in China's internal affairs. Correspondents from nearly a dozen foreign news organizations, including those from the United States, Europe and the Soviet Union, say they have been followed or their Chinese sources harassed by Chinese plainclothes police in recent weeks. Li, who has so far refused a request by foreign correspondents to discuss the alleged harassment, said such reports were ``groundless.'' ``If the report was the result of oversensitivity to the extent of excessive suspicion on the part of a few correspondents, well, that would not matter much,'' Li said. ``But if it was the result of an attempt by certain individuals to create by spreading rumors a smokescreen for their own illegal activities and to extricate themselves from their predicament or worse still to deliberately disrupt the stability and unity in China for ulterior purposes, that would indeed call for the vigilance of all kind-hearted people, including large numbers of media people.'' Reporters who carry out normal and legitimate news coverage ``need not worry that they might run into troubles,'' he said. He said the U.S. State Department had ``no right'' to direct the embassy in Beijing to investigate the alleged intimidation of American journalists. ``Should an investigation be really necessary, the justice-upholding people in the world would have every reason to ask, how many things has this superpower done in broad daylight over the years to trample upon the sovereignty and infringe upon the human rights of other nations?'' He added, referring to the U.S. invasion of Panama: ``How many innocent Panamanians were killed and how many houses and how much property were destroyed? How many people were rendered homeless and deprived of their basic freedoms?'' U.S.-China relations, which plummeted after China's military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in June, hit another low point last month after the State Department issued a report detailing widespread abuses of human rights in China. China has responded by assailing the United States' human rights record and its interference in the affairs of other countries. The surveillance of foreign reporters appeared to step up after martial law was lifted in Beijing on Jan. 11, with some journalists saying they have been tailed even while jogging or shopping. Journalists say Chinese security agents have also tried to photograph their meetings with Chinese sources and have interrogated their Chinese contacts.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Company Wins Smoker Death Suit
DOC.TEXT: People who want to hold cigarette makers liable for their products got a discouraging signal from a jury that ruled American Tobacco Co. shouldn't be held accountable for a smoker's lung-cancer death, a lawyer said. ``This just puts a further chill on anyone having the audacity to take on one of the empires of industry,'' said Eric Nissen, one of the attorneys who brought the lawsuit. A federal jury ruled in favor of the cigarette company Wednesday after a three-week trial. The case marked one of the rare occasions such a suit had reached the courtroom. In 1988, a federal jury in New Jersey awarded the first damages against a cigarette company, giving $400,000 to Antonio Cipollone, whose wife died of lung cancer. But an appeals court this year overturned the award and ordered a new trial. Richard Daynard, a Northeastern University law professor who heads a project that helps lawyers who sue tobacco companies, predicted the American Tobacco case would be appealed. But he added that the ruling in the Boston case ``means you need to have a little more to go on than simply a failure to warn.'' The suit was filed by Joanne Kotler of Cambridge, whose husband, George, started smoking when he was 11. He died of lung cancer in 1986 at 55. The plaintiffs argued that American Tobacco, a subsidiary of American Brands Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., should have warned the public of the dangers of cigarette smoking before the government required warning labels in 1966. Andrew Lane, an attorney for American Tobacco, declined to comment on the verdict. Earlier Wednesday, during closing arguments, he stressed that Kotler had ample opportunity to quit smoking but chose to continue his habit. ``In spite of today's decision, I still feel that my husband's generation of smokers was consciously misled about the dangers of smoking,'' said Mrs. Kotler. ``I do know that this is one battle, and the war still can be won. It's not over, and this case isn't over.'' Lane told the jury Wednesday that the first credible evidence linking lung cancer to smoking surfaced in the 1950s, but the studies were not definitive and some medical experts disagreed with the findings. He further argued that warnings would not have made a difference for Kotler. ``Forty million people have stopped smoking,'' Lane said. ``They made the decision. That's what this case is really about _ choice.'' Garry Inge, representing Mrs. Kotler, said the addictive nature of nicotine contributed to Kotler's habit.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: In this Wild West town, voters had enough of a mayor so tough that he allegedly mowed his lawn with a gun strapped to his leg. In a recall vote Tuesday, Mayor Richard Hill lost in a showdown with voters by a 2-1 ratio. Two councilmen _ Bruce Freels and Kurt Larrecou _ also lost by in lopsided votes. ``It's always a blood bath in San Juan,'' said Jill Bohn, organizer of the recall. ``People got to council meetings instead of watching `Jeopardy.''' Residents in the town about 40 miles south of San Jose said that Hill, Larrecou and Freels treated town employees poorly. But Hill's alleged activities had townspeople buzzing the most. Police, investigating a report of gunfire at Hill's home a few years ago, found Hill with a bandoleer across his chest, a knife in his boot, a pistol at his side and a shotgun across his lap. They also found a bullet hole in his ceiling. Hill, a reserve police officer, said he had killed a pit bull in the line of duty, and was expecting the dog's owner to arrive. Several townspeople also said that Hill would mow his lawn wearing a gun. Hill, 42, denied that. ``Maybe I should,'' he said. ``I've got some big weeds out back.''

County commissioners hope they've stopped residents of a subdivision from killing a native plant: poison ivy. Broward County planners say residents of the Oak Knoll subdivision have been going beyond their property lines to hunt poison ivy, clip tree branches, plant their own landscaping and dump lawn clippings. Planners say residents are trampling on a protected public nature preserve near the subdivision. The County Commission threatened Tuesday to fence the yards unless the families stopped destroying vegetation. They ended up agreeing to wooden posts placed at the lot's corners to make sure homeowners stay on their side. ``Poison ivy, while none of us likes it, is part of the native vegetation there,'' County Commissioner Lori Parrish said. Some residents thought the concern over poison ivy was strange. But resident James Inklebarger said people would cope with the decision. ``We'll keep the calamine lotion handy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The governments and current leaders in Czechoslovakia, Poland, Hungary and Bulgaria will have to accept responsibility for the blood that spills in Cuba if the United States dares to attack our country.'' _ Cuban President Fidel Castro, in a speech Wednesday announcing Cuban military aid was being cut off to Nicaragua. He also criticized Eastern European nations for approving a U.N. resolution against human rights abuses in Cuba.

``Overall, their data represent very good news for women in their 30s who are contemplating their first pregnancy.'' _ Dr. Robert Resnik of the University of California, San Diego, about a study in today's New England Journal of Medicine that shows women in their 30s and 40s face little unusual risk of delivering premature or stillborn babies.

``My husband is being punished, but that does not make it right to punish me and my baby. We are running out of time. I want to have this baby and I do not think God would think it is wrong to bring a new baby into the world.'' _ Lisa Petrocelli, 26, who sued Wednesday to get Nevada prisons to allow her a conjugal visit or artificial insemination by her husband, death-row inmate Tracy Petrocelli, so she can have his baby.

DOC.HEAD: Second Hotel Fire In A Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with fire extinguished, guest quotes. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out today in a kitchen at the luxury Nile-side Shepheard Hotel in downtown Cairo but was extinguished in less than an hour, officials and witnesses said. Police on the scene said the only casualty was a hotel worker treated for smoke inhalation. Damage was minimal, they said. A week ago, another five-star Cairo hotel was devastated by a nine-hour fire, which officials said was accidental. The 12-story hotel, a block from the U.S. and British embassies, is in Garden City, Cairo's embassy row. The witnesses said smoke began billowing from the roof shortly before 10 a.m. The 281-room hotel, owned by the government's Egyptian Hotels Co., had an occupancy of ``almost 90 percent'' at the time of the fire, but most guests had left their rooms when it broke out, hotel officials said. Maj. Gen. Fakhreddin Khalid, chief of tourist police, said the fire began in the ground-floor kitchen of an Asian food restaurant and sent smoke up a chimney to the roof, where it was seen throughout the neighborhood. He said the the thick smoke was caused partly by sparks from the kitchen touching fat and grease inside the chimney. There was ``hardly any damage'' to the hotel, he said. Last week, an early-morning fire driven by strong winds devastated the 630-room Heliopolis Sheraton Hotel on Cairo's northeastern outskirts. Seventeen guests, including four Americans, died, and 70 people were injured. Authorities said the Heliopolis Sheraton fire was sparked by an oven in a tent restaurant immediately behind the hotel building.

DOC.HEAD: Battered Woman Who Shot Husband Over Dinner Sentenced to Five Years
DOC.TEXT: A woman was sentenced to five years in prison for shooting her husband to death after an argument over her cooking that climaxed some 27 years of beatings and drunken abuse. Judge William E. Crane on Wednesday imposed the maximum sentence for a conviction of homicide by negligent use of a weapon, despite testimony that Virginia Eagan suffered an abuse-related emotional disturbance known as battered wife syndrome. ``People have to face up to responsibility,'' Crane said. ``Battered woman syndrome doesn't warrant killing someone.'' Mrs. Eagan was convicted by a jury Jan. 31 of shooting her husband of 32 years, Eugene Eagan, during a July 2 argument. Eagan, 56, was disabled since a work accident and walked with the help of canes, with which he often beat his wife, according to both the prosecutor and defense attorney. Mrs. Eagan said the beatings had begun five years into the marriage. Trial testimony indicated the shooting followed a Sunday evening quarrel in which Eagan criticized the way his wife cooked boiled potatoes and beets. Mrs. Eagan grabbed a handgun from the pantry and shot her husband once at close range after he taunted her, saying: ``You don't have any guts. You won't do it.'' Defense Attorney George Curtis said that imprisoning Mrs. Eagan, 53, a factory worker who is going blind, was cruel and compounded the family's tragedy. ``This lady has gone through hell and doesn't deserve another minute of it. She was a helpless victim,'' Curtis said.

DOC.HEAD: Small Quake Jolts Southern California
DOC.TEXT: A small earthquake hit Southern California today, shaking up residents still jittery from an earlier tremor but there were no reports of injuries or damage. The 3.0 magnitude quake struck at 3:03 a.m., said Bob Finn, spokesman for the seismology lab at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. It was centered 2 miles west of Highland Park, he said. ``I was asleep and it felt like some shook the hell out of my bed,'' said Chris Harris of Hollywood. ``I hardly ever wake up, but this time I did. Nothing fell down but the pictures on the wall are at an angle.'' ``It felt pretty small and quick here,'' said county sheriff's Deputy Rafael Estrada from downtown headquarters. Pasadena police reported several calls from shaky residents. Glendale police dispatcher Anna Maria Taylor said the department received about five calls. Another sharp jolt, which struck 10:25 p.m. Wednesday, registered 3.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion, said Finn, calling it an aftershock of the destructive 5.5 magnitude Upland quake last week. The aftershock was centered about 4 miles north-northeast of suburban Pomona, which is about 30 miles east of downtown Los Angeles. No injuries or damage were reported. This morning's Los Angeles area quake was ``not at all related to the Upland quake,'' Finn said. The 5.5 quake that struck the suburban Upland Feb. 28 was the biggest shaker in California since the devastating earthquake that struck the San Francisco area last October, causing dozens of deaths and billions of dollars in damage. Between 400 and 500 aftershocks have occurred since last week's quake, Finn said. He noted only a few dozen were big enough to be felt. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage.

DOC.HEAD: Freezing Rain in the Great Plains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to W.Va. sted Va.
DOC.TEXT: Freezing rain fell on the Plains today, and the Pacific Northwest got snow. Temperatures dipped to zero in upstate New York and Vermont early today, and the cold gripped much of the East Coast. A low of 16 was recorded at Martinsburg, W.Va. A warming trend was forecast today and into the weekend. Thunderstorms lashed Arkansas early today, rain drenched much of Texas, freezing rain cascaded over Minnesota and the Plains states, and snow fell in Oregon and Washington. The forecast was for showers and thunderstorms in the lower Mississippi Valley and southern Plains. Floods threatened parts of Texas and Arkansas. Hail the size of gumdrops fell at Yantis, Texas, on Wednesday and a strong gust destroyed a trailer at Alton, Kan. Heavier rainfall during the same 6 hours ending at 7 p.m. EST Wednesday included more than an inch at Des Moines, Iowa, and .9 inches at El Dorado, Ark. A low Wednesday of 14 degrees at New York City's Kennedy Airport set a record for the date. The high for the nation was 91 degrees at Mcallen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: City Bucks the Trend, Encourages Private Business
DOC.TEXT: A city with rising unemployment is offering a prize and tax breaks to new private businesses, a report said today, in a break with the current anti-capitalist trend. The northeast industrial city of Shenyang has started a ``Glory Cup'' competition for people starting private businesses who create jobs for themselves or others, the official Xinhua News Agency said. It said one city district set aside the equivalent of $83,000 to help start new private businesses, and Shenyang was offering preferential treatment in taxation and simplified bureaucratic procedures. ``Li Zidan, a tailor, said she was perplexed and discouraged because of disputes about individual businesses in the past few months,'' Xinhua reported. ``But since the municipal government launched the Glory Cup competition, she has felt confident about the future of the private sector.'' Li is not the only confused and discouraged entrepreneur. Ever since conservative leaders cracked down on massive pro-democracy protests last year, the state media have harshly attacked private businessmen for making too much money and living better than ordinary workers. Local governments started policing them for tax payment and enforcing other formerly ignored regulations, forcing many out of business. Banks stopped loaning them money. Top Communist Party officials branded them ``bourgeois'' and said the private sector must be controlled so it does not threaten the socialist system. The number of private businesses dropped 14.4 percent, to 12.4 million. Shenyang's pro-private measures seem a case of ideology being defeated by practical considerations. Xinhua quoted local officials as saying that state companies do not have enough openings for new middle school graduates. The number of unemployed could reach 103,000 this year, about 3 percent of the non-farming population of 3.3 million, it said. The actual figure is probably far higher, as Chinese unemployment figures do not include young people who are waiting to be assigned their first job, or workers idled by factory slow-downs or temporary shut-downs. The national government also may be forced to soften it stand toward private businesses. The State Planning Commission has said that 12 million people will enter the urban work force this year, but government offices and state factories will be able to employ only 5 million. The rest will be forced to seek work in collective enterprises, such as small factories run by neighborhood committees, or the private sector. Liu Minxue, director of the State Administration for Industry and Commerce, said recently that while private business must be only a supplement to the state-owned economy, the country should help them ``develop in a healthy way.''

DOC.HEAD: At stake, 2nd graf
Rebels Kill American Rancher in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels killed an elderly American rancher on the central Philippine island of Masbate after he refused to pay ``revolutionary taxes,'' Filipino and U.S. officials said today. The victim, Stewart Frank Raab, was the second American killed by Filipino rebels in a month and the fifth in the past year. Raab, 76, was seized Tuesday by about 30 New People's Army guerrillas at his ranch near Milagros, 240 miles southeast of Manila, Maj. Leo Pangilinan said by telephone from Masbate. The guerrillas forced Raab from his vehicle and shot him in the head, Pangilinan said. U.S. Embassy officials confirmed the report and said Raab was born in the Philippines, when it was still an American colony. According to Pangilinan, Raab had been paying ``revolutionary taxes'' _ or protection money _ until the rebels increased the fee to $34,000 a year. After refusing to pay, Raab began receiving death threats, Pangilinan said. One week before he was slain, rebels ransacked his home and took a television, video recorder and assorted weapons and ammunition, the major said. The rebels fled with Raab's clothing and personal effects after the killing, Pangilinan said. On Feb. 21, rebels killed geologist John Robert Mitchell, 42, of Fairbanks, Alaska, his Filipino wife and father-in-law in an ambush on the central island Bohol. One rebel arrested in the killing said gunmen were out to get Mitchell's father-in-law for failing to pay ``revolutionary taxes.'' In September, rebels killed two American civilians working at a U.S. military installation about 60 miles north of Manila on the day Vice President Dan Quayle arrived for an official visit. In April, rebels killed U.S. Army Col. James ``Nick'' Rowe in an ambush on a busy street in suburban Quezon City. Rowe, a Vietnam War hero, was assigned to the Joint U.S. Military Assistance Group in the Philippines. In October 1987, three Americans and a Filipino civilian were killed by rebels in a series of attacks around Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. Rebels have repeatedly threatened to target Americans because of U.S. support for President Corazon Aquino. The New People's Army has been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state.

DOC.HEAD: A Dime Late; And 54 Dollars Short
DOC.TEXT: A dime's worth of difference is nothing to sneeze at where the Internal Revenue Service is concerned. When Mary Frances Stinson of Dorchester, Mass., filed her tax return in 1987, she was 10 cents short on her payment. Nearly three years later the IRS notified her that the 10-cent debt had grown to $54.94 because of interest and penalties. The computer-generated form letter said the IRS had assessed a $24 late-payment penalty plus $30.84 interest on the late payment. However, the billing noted that under the law, the penalty cannot exceed 25 percent of the late payment _ in this case that would be 2 cents. The interest rate charged on late payments has been averaging around 10 percent, or about a penny a year calculated from the April 15, 1987, due date of Ms. Stinson's return to the Oct. 30, 1989, date of the IRS's late-payment letter. Ms. Stinson took her case to the National Coalition of IRS Whistleblowers, a Washington-based organization established by the Church of Scientology, which gave a copy of the bill to a reporter. Ms. Stinson could not be reached to determine the outcome of the case, and the IRS is prohibited by law from comment on tax files. However, IRS spokesman Wilson Fadely said today that since a stamp costs 25 cents, ``I wouldn't think we would even send a notice on 10 cents due.'' If an erroneous bill is sent, he added, ``you should just write and tell us.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Soliders, Police Break Up Demonstrations
DOC.TEXT: Security forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse hundreds of Palestinian women who staged anti-occupation marches today in the West Bank and Arab east Jerusalem, police and Arab reports said. At least 17 demonstrators were hit by rubber bullets or rubber-coated metal balls, including a teen-ager shot and wounded in the head, Arab reporters said. One of the protests was broken up in the walled Old City of Jerusalem. Army and police said they were checking the casualty reports. The demonstrations were organized by underground leaders of the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising to coincide with International Women's Day. Protesters carried placards calling on Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to negotiate with the PLO and demanding a Palestinian state. ``Shamir, you must talk to the PLO,'' read a banner carried in a march of about 200 women in the West Bank town of Ramallah. ``Yes to the Cairo dialogue that will lead to an international peace conference,'' said another placard held by marchers in the biblical West Bank city of Bethlehem. Shamir, head of the right-wing Likud bloc, refuses to negotiate with the PLO, saying it is a terror organization. His fear that the PLO would dominate Palestinian negotiatiors has held up a U.S.-supported plan to hold preliminary negotiations between Palestinians and Israel in Cairo. One of the worst clashes today occurred in Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem, where riot police fired rubber bullets to disperse about 100 Palestinian women near the walled Old City's Damascus Gate. At least six women were hit by rubber bullets, according to journalists at the scene. Following the march, Palestinian youths took to nearby streets throwing stones and empty bottles at passing Israeli cars, said Jerusalem police spokesman Uzi Sandori. About one dozen demonstrators also overturned an Israeli car in nearby Salah Edin Street, said Associated Press reporter Haitham Hamad. The youths also broke the windows of a car belonging to a tax collector. Six mounted policemen and officers on foot carrying shields and clubs chased the youths who escaped into the bustle of east Jerusalem's central bus station. Sandori said 10 Palestinians were arrested. There have been sporadic anti-Israeli protests in east Jerusalem, which Palestinians consider the capital of a state they hope to establish one day. But the violence has been far less than in the West Bank and Gaza Strip during the uprising against Israeli occupation. In Ramallah, troops fired rubber bullets at about 200 women, and chased the fleeing demonstrators into the city's old market, Arab reporters said. Ten women hit by rubber bullets were treated at Ramallah Hospital and released, a hospital official said. Another demonstration of about 200 women in the West Bank town of Jenin was dispersed when soldiers fired tear gas and rubber-coated bullets, Arab reports said. Hospital officials said a 17-year-old girl was injured in the head by a rubber-coated metal ball, but an army spokesman denied soldiers fired such ammunition. The rubber-coated metal balls are more likely to cause serious injuries than rubber-coated bullets. In Nablus, also in the West Bank, soldiers fired tear gas to disperse about 400 women, and confiscated Palestinian flags and banners, Arab reports said. One of the banners raid, ``Yes to the Palestinian peace process.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Guerrillas Killed Near Israeli Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Israeli report that guerrillas from Islamic fundamentalist Hezbollah organization. Pickup 7th, `Israel radio...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers shot and killed five Shiite Moslem guerrillas today in south Lebanon, officials in Lebanon and Israel said. The guerrillas involved in the pre-dawn clash were members of the pro-Iranian Moslem fundamentalist group Hezbollah, said Maj. Gen. Yossi Peled, head of the Israeli army's Northern Command. ``They apparently came to attack one of our positions or to plant explosives in the security zone,'' a six-to-10-mile area in southern Lebanon that is controlled by Israel and allied militiamen, Peled said on Israel radio. A security source in Lebanon, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Israelis opened fire with tank cannons killing five guerrillas after spotting the squad in the Zommaraya district of the security zone. A fierce battle with machine guns, automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenades ensued after the Israeli assault, as other guerrillas tried to recover the bodies, the source said. Israeli officials said the guerrillas were armed with large quantities of explosives, hand grenades and five Soviet-made Kalashnikov rifles, the radio reported. The military said Israel suffered no casualties in the encounter. Israel radio quoted sources in the U.N. peacekeeping force in Lebanon as saying Israeli-backed militiamen of the South Lebanon Army exchanged mortar fire with guerrillas through the morning. Guerrillas later fired a salvo of about six Katyusha rockets at an Israeli army outpost in the town of Hasbaya, on the eastern edge of the zone. The day's fighting was the first clash in south Lebanon between Israeli forces and guerrillas since Feb. 14, when one guerrilla was slain and three captured. Israel has since staged three bombing raids against guerrilla targets in south Lebanon. Israel maintained control over the border area across south Lebanon when it withdrew the bulk of its invading army in the summer of 1985, three years after they moved over the border. The zone serves as a buffer against cross-border guerrilla attacks in northern Israel.

DOC.HEAD: New Journal of No-Apologies Liberalism To Be Launched
DOC.TEXT: A group of writers and academics is starting a journal with the aim of bringing liberal ideas back to the top of the national agenda. The American Prospect, scheduled to debut Sunday and be published quarterly, ``marks the rebirth of no-apologies liberalism,'' according to a release. ``We're not neo-liberals, or post-liberals or any other hybrid. We're liberals,'' said co-editor Robert Kuttner. The entry of the journal coincides with the exit of the Cold War and its attending fixation on military issues, the editors said. ``A lot of the antagonisms that arose in the 1960s have died out,'' said Paul Starr, a Princeton University sociologist who will be one of the magazine's two editors. ``We think America's challenges today are mainly social and economic.'' The first issue contains several meditations on the role of liberalism in the 1990s, a feature article on ``The Real Welfare Problem'' and a pollster's blueprint on how the Democratic Party can reclaim middle-class votes without moving to the right of the political spectrum. The journal's board of sponsors includes economist John Kenneth Galbraith, historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. and Marian Wright Edelman, founder of the Children's Defense fund. Who will pay $7.95 for the journal? ``My simplistic vision is of a great emerging army of liberal people who don't have anything to attach themselves to, no clear policy directions, no distinct political directions, no distinct public philosphy, certainly no leaders,'' Robert Reich, a Harvard University economist and chairman of the editorial board, said in The New York Times.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Will Go to Court to Get Lawyers to Disclose Sources of Cash
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service is prepared to go to court to force 90 defense lawyers in drug cases to tell the source of large cash fees. ``We are talking about the hard-nut cases where we have made repeated attempts to get the information and have not been successful,'' says IRS public-affairs director Ellen Murphy. The IRS, which is playing a major role in the government's battle against illegal drugs, is acting under a 1985 law requiring anyone accepting a cash payment of $10,000 or more to file a Form 8300 spelling out the source of the money. The agency wrote 965 lawyers last fall that the forms they had filed were incomplete. Since that time, Ms. Murphy said, all but 90 have supplied the required information. Those 90 cases have been referred to IRS district offices around the country. ``In those cases, we plan to pursue summonses in order to get the information,'' Ms. Murphy said. ``If we don't get compliance with the administrative summonses, we will refer the cases to the Department of Justice for enforcement action in District Court.'' Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said the department ``has assured the IRS that each case will be reviewed on its merits to determine whether a summons enforcement proceeding should be instituted.'' Continued refusal to provide the information could result in jail sentences for the attorneys. Neal Sonnett of Miami, president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, predicted attorneys will go to jail rather than comply. ``We cannot allow in this country the war against drugs to become the war against lawyers and a war against the Bill of Rights, and that's what's happening,'' Sonnett said. Ms. Murphy acknowledged that ``there is obviously the attorney-client privilege issue in these cases, but we believe that has been addressed in the instructions for Form 8300.'' ``This is a form that can be avoided simply by not accepting large cash payments. We are talking about $10,000 paid in a lump sum,'' Ms. Murphy said. A former federal prosecutor who specialized in drug cases said the information sought by the IRS would enable investigators to piece together tax cases against suspected drug dealers. ``If all of a sudden a drug dealer is shown paying $25,000 in cash in legal fees, all of a sudden he has to account for $25,000. It identifies the fact that individuals have assets,'' said the former prosecutor, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. James Holden, chairman of the tax division of the American Bar Association, said the dispute between lawyers and the IRS is likely to end up before the Supreme Court. ``This is something of a Holy Grail issue with attorneys, much like the First Amendment is with publishers,'' Holden said. ``I think it is unfortunate that Congress included lawyers'' when requiring any person with a trade or business _ such as car dealers, furriers or jewelers _ to report receiving $10,000 or more in cash, he said. Holden said the ABA is asking the Justice Department ``to exercise discretion in deciding whether to seek court action, to look at each case carefully and see whether there is a legitimate claim of attorney-client privilege.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Opens Business with Prayer in Sign Language
DOC.TEXT: The Senate opened business today with a prayer in sign language by two ministers from Gallaudet University, the nation's liberal arts college for the deaf. Sen. Robert W. Kasten Jr., R-Wis., introduced the ministers, the Revs. Jay Croft and Gerard A. Trancone, and said the invocation was the first in the history of the Senate given in sign language. Kasten said their invocation was in recognition of ``Deaf Awareness Week,'' which starts Sunday. The first sign-language interpreters on the Senate floor appeared last September during debate on the Americans With Disabilities Act, the wide-ranging civil rights bill for disabled Americans. The bill has passed the Senate and is awaiting House committee action.

DOC.HEAD: Panel To Seek Immunity For Former Pierce Aide
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee will ask a federal court to grant immunity to a top deputy to Reagan administration Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. in return for his testimony about abuses at the agency, sources said today. The former Pierce deputy, Dubois Gilliam, is currently serving a federal prison sentence for a conviction in a HUD-related case, and according to subcommittee sources the panel will ask that the court approve an immunity grant protecting him from further prosecution. The sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said former federal judge Arlin Adams, who is the independent counsel leading an investigation of Pierce and several top aides, did not object to the request to grant Gilliam immunity. Pierce's attorney, Paul Perito, has predicted the independent counsel will exonerate Pierce of any wrongdoing. Perito questioned whether Gilliam would provide accurate testimony or would seek to curry favor for a reduced sentence. The panel chairman, Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., was to announce the plans at a news conference today. The development was first reported in today's editions of The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal. Gilliam, according to the sources, is expected to testify that Pierce directed him to steer Department of Housing and Urban Development money to political and business allies. Subcommittee aides recently met with Gilliam at the federal prison in Lompoc, Calif., where he is serving an 18-month sentence. Pierce and several former top aides have refused to testify before the subcommittee, citing their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination. Among them was Deborah Dean, Pierce's former top aide. The panel considered granting her immunity but has dropped the idea. Gilliam would be the first witness to appear under such an arrangement. Gilliam, as part of a plea agreement in the Mississippi case, pleaded guilty to accepting cash gifts from a HUD contractor and conspiring to use a HUD grant for personal gain. Gilliam was a deputy assistant secretary for community development at HUD and considered one of Pierce's most trusted aides. Documents released last year by HUD under the Freedom of Information act show that requests for funds often were routed through Gilliam. His job gave him immediate supervision over a technical assistance program whose funding was largely discretionary. Many awards under the program were made after contractors made unsolicited proposals to the department, and HUD auditors have roundly criticized the program for allowing contractors to use the bulk of their cash for personnel and overhead costs. Gilliam's division at HUD also oversaw the Urban Development Action Grant program, which is now virtually defunct but was a favorite of municipal officials seeking federal money for a variety of development projects.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Richards Wins Backing of Editors of Texas Death Row Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Ann Richards got an endorsement for her Democratic campaign for governor she didn't expect or necessarily want, from editors of a Texas death row newspaper. ``If I were forced to, I'd choose Ann Richards,'' Robert West, editor of Endeavor, a newspaper written and produced by the men on death row, said Wednesday. ``I think she's just trying to be a human being. I think she recognizes people can change because she's a recovering alcoholic.'' James Beathard, an assistant editor, also said he would favor Ms. Richards, saying the Texas treasurer appeared to be concentrating more on issues like schools, minorities, women's rights and the budget. But he added that inmate support for Ms. Richards likely would hurt her rather than help her in the election. ``But it's us they're trying to kill, and we should have a right to comment about the people who are trying to kill us,'' said Beathard, awaiting death for a 1984 spree in which three people were killed. Asked to comment on the inmates' endorsement, Ms. Richards, campaigning in San Antonio for Tuesday's primary, first thought the question was a joke. ``I don't know what possibly could have engendered it,'' she said. `I don't know anybody on death row. My view on the death penalty is that it's the law and that the law should be carried out. ``I think perhaps they are contrasting me with a guy who goes on TV and struts up and down in front of pictures of people who have been executed. It's macabre and strange. What I think this campaign is about is life.'' law.'' Capital punishment has been the focus of television commercials from Ms. Richards' two Democratic opponents, Attorney General Jim Mattox and former Gov. Mark White. In their ads, Mattox and White take credit for making Texas the nation's leader in executions among states that have the death penalty. Since Texas resumed the death penalty in 1982, 33 men have been given lethal injections. Endeavor editors and other inmates were particularly upset with a White commercial in which large pictures of the executed prisoners are used as props. Inmate Lester Bower, who closely follows capital punishment legal issues, estimated about half of the more than 300 Texas death row inmates were eligible to vote since their direct appeals still were pending. Once a conviction is affirmed by the Supreme Court, the inmate loses his right to vote, said Bower, awaiting death for the slayings of four men in 1983. The newspaper, in existence for nearly a year, is believed to be the only one of its kind among the nation's death rows.

DOC.HEAD: Former Director of Defense Supply Agency Dies
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Melvin Lyle, a vice admiral in the Navy Supply Corps who was director of the Defense Supply Agency before retiring in 1967, has died at the age of 77. Lyle, who held some of the highest logistics posts in the armed services, died of cancer Tuesday at a nursing home. A resident of Reston, Lyle was born in Augusta, Ga. He graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy at Annapolis in 1935. He was an assistant supply officer at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, when the Japanese attacked it on Dec. 7, 1941. He remained in Pearl Harbor until 1944, then spent the next two years as supply officer at the Norfolk Naval Air Station in Virginia. In subsequent years, he served in various capacities in Hawaii and Philadelphia, California and Washington. He graduated from the Naval War College in Newport, R.I. In 1961, Lyle became deputy director of the newly formed Defense Supply Agency, now called the Defense Logistics Agency. In 1964, he was named director, and held that post until retiring from the service. After leaving the Navy, Lyle joined the National Security Industrial Association. He retired as president in 1977. Survivors include a son, Dr. Jerry Manning Lyle of Rockville, Md., and two grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Agrees to Move to Compromise Site
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing scheduled for 10:30 a.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff who seized a National Guard armory when he ran out of space at his century-old jail says he has agreed to move to the state's suggested compromise site _ a vacant armory in nearby Holyoke. ``The sheriff must have a temporary solution workable with the state until the new jail site is built in Ludlow. The sheriff has therefore determined to support the state's decision,'' Richard McCarthy, spokesman for Hampden County Sheriff Michael Ashe, said Wednesday. Holyoke Mayor Martin Dunn said city lawyers will oppose the move, involving a site across from a pre-school and kindergarten. ``I think the decision is ridiculous,'' Dunn said. ``I will fight it as long as it needs to be fought.'' The tentative agreement worked out between the state and Ashe was scheduled to go before Hampden County Superior Court Judge George Keady today. National Guard officials said they would wait until an agreement was final before making any comment. Ashe seized a National Guard armory in Springfield on Feb. 16, saying he had a choice between taking the building or putting more than a dozen prisoners on the streets. After the state tried to evict Ashe, he won a temporary court order giving him the right to stay at his makeshift jail. Since then, state and county lawyers have been working on a compromise. When Ashe seized the armory, he claimed authority under a 16th century statute requiring citizens to give ``suitable aid'' to law enforcement efforts of his office. But state officials contend that Ashe as a county official does not have authority over state property.

DOC.HEAD: Internationally Known Historian Dead at 68
DOC.TEXT: William Appleman Williams, a historian who sharply criticized U.S. foreign policy and asserted that the United States acted as an imperialist power, has died of cancer at age 68. Williams died Monday at Newport Community Hospital. He lived in the nearby coastal community of Waldport. He termed himself a radical and was particularly critical of America's role in the Cold War and in Vietnam. Williams was best known for a series of books written in the late 1950s and 1960s that challenged prevailing views of American history. He asserted the United States was an imperialist power, seeking to impose its economic and ideological will on an unwilling world. He argued that the nation's refusal to acknowledge its imperialist past led to a skewed national vision that made it difficult to set a course for the future. Critics accused him of employing a double standard, of explaining Soviet actions by citing national security while measuring Western actions against a utopian ideal. His books, which gave him a reputation as a revisionist historian, created widespread controversy in academic circles and influenced a generation of historians. His views had entered the mainstream of American thought by the late 1970s and, in 1980, he was elected president of the Organization of American Historians. ``I think of him as the clearest of the revisionist historians and the inspirer of a school of younger historians who put the Cold War into a perspective that they didn't have before,'' said Victor Navasky, editor of The Nation, the liberal magazine for which Williams frequently wrote. He was a professor at the University of Wisconsin from 1960 to 1968, and at Oregon State University from 1968 to 1986. He also taught at the University of Melbourne in Australia as a Fulbright scholar in 1977. Williams is survived by his wife, Wendy, three children, two stepchildren and three grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., France, Vatican Move to End Lebanon's Christian Fighting
DOC.TEXT: The United States, France and the Vatican are trying to end a monthlong showdown between rival Christian forces and help President Elias Hrawi spread his authority to east Beirut, government sources said today. One Christian source in the government said the Vatican told renegade army Gen. Michel Aoun and militia chieftain Samir Geagea that their fighting ``threatens the Christians' existence in Lebanon.'' The Vatican's stand was interpreted as ``an indirect threat that the Holy See would have to accept foreign military intrevention to quell the armed conflict in the Christian enclave,'' said the source, who demanded anonymity. ``Such a military intervention, most probably by the Syrian army, would spare neither Aoun nor Geagea,'' the source said. Christian troops under Aoun and the Lebanese Forces militia under Geagea fought each other to a standstill before accepting a cease-fire Saturday. More than 750 people were killed and 2,088 wounded during the inconclusive fighting, which broke out Jan. 30. At least $850 million in public and private property were destroyed. The source said the cease-fire was accepted after the Vatican's stand was relayed last week. Syrian-backed Hrawi and Prime Minister Salim Hoss returned to Beirut late Wednesday from a four-day tour of Saudi Arabia, Algeria and Morocco. Hrawi and Hoss released a statement today saying that the three Arab nations promised aid to help them ``spread the legitimate state authority over the whole of Lebanon.'' Leaders of the three Arab nations make up a mediation committee that brokered October's peace accord aimed at ending Lebanon's nearly 15 years of civil war. Hrawi was elected president in November under the plan. He replaced Aoun who headed a caretaker government. Aoun has refused to recognize Hrawi as head of state and rejected the peace plan, demanding that it specify a timetable for the withdrawal of the 40,000 troops Syria maintains in Lebanon. The independent newspaper An-Nahar said the United States was trying to persuade Geagea to withdraw his militia from Christian east Beirut and France had asked Aoun to step down and hand over the presidential palace to Hrawi. The paper said if Aoun agreed to step down and Geagea withdrew his militiamen from east Beirut, the U.S. would ``move seriously'' to arrange a withdrawal from Moslem west Beirut of Syrian troops and their allied Moslem and leftist militiamen. A Moslem government source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Bush administration has ``repeatedly informed all the parties to the conflict in Lebanon that it supports the creation of a greater Beirut free of militias.'' ``The Americans want a unified Beirut and its suburbs policed by troops loyal to President Hrawi as the legitimate head of state in Lebanon,'' said the Moslem source. Beirut has been divided into predominately Christian and Moslem sectors since the civil war broke out in 1975. Aoun's refusal to leave the shell-wrecked presidential palace has forced Hrawi to set up temporary headquarters in Syrian-policed west Beirut. Hrawi, Aoun and Geagea are Maronites, the Catholic community that has dominated Lebanon since independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow News Critical of Cuban Leadership
DOC.TEXT: In a rare Soviet attack on the Cuban leadership, a newspaper this week attributed the island's stability to Fidel Castro's intransigence and reliance on outdated ideas that cause suffering for the population. The weekly edition of the Moscow News, which came out Tuesday, also said dissension is growing in Cuba and that about 15 opposition groups have formed. The article in the weekly, considered a progressive newspaper, reflects a growing divergence between the Kremlin and Cuba as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev moves to reduce the power of the Communist Party here and strengthen the government. At the same time, Castro has repeatedly said his country will never embrace the reforms orchestrated by Gorbachev and increasingly accepted throughout Eastern Europe. ``To all appearances, the sweeping changes in Eastern Europe came as a complete surprise to the Cuban leader,'' Moscow News said. ``On both economic and political counts, they produced a shock.'' It noted that state-run Cuban radio carried editorial attacks on the collapse of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe and blamed the changes on ``weak governments unable to tackle economic turmoil.'' ``Such categorical judgments are pronounced in an island with total rationing, which insures people against poverty, but does not give them the impetus to work,'' Moscow News said. It mocked the Cuban leader for his Dec. 7 statement saying, ``if history will attach to us the role of the last defenders of socialism in the world _ we will defend this stronghold to the last drop of blood.'' The Cuban model that Castro wants to defend is based on a complete rejection of a market economy, moral principles over material ones, a militarized state and an untouchable party-state elite, the newspaper said. ``Cuba copied none other but Soviet administrative and economic structures at the time when European socialism was sinking into the swamp of stagnation'' based on the ideological dogma of the late leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, it continued. Cuba gets about $5 billion in annual aid from the Soviet Union. Despite Castro's pledge to defend the party at all costs and ignore change in the socialist community, Moscow News said reform is on its way. ``About 15 dissident groups have emerged,'' the newspaper said. ``Their demands vary from support for the perestroika process in the U.S.S.R. to freedom of religious beliefs in Cuba.'' Until change comes, Moscow News said, the island will remain stable, but only ``through the efforts of Revolution Defense Committees embracing the entire country.''

DOC.HEAD: Coup Leader Vows to Fight On; Guerrillas Reject Him
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to ADD official report of casualties, dismissal of Afghan officials. Pickup 4th pvs, `Shops and offices...'; Sub 16th pvs, `A more...' to ADD that Mojaddidi is president of exile govt.; Subs grfs 21-22, `Asked about...were injured' with one to ADD details of expulsions. Pickup last graf, `The insurgents...
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a coup attempt against the Afghan government said today his struggle to overthrow the Soviet-backed leadership is not over, and he urged the guerrillas he once opposed to join him in the fight. Leaders of the guerrillas' government-in-exile rejected Shah Nawaz Tanai's call. ``How can we extend our support to a Communist?'' asked the guerrillas' prime minister. The Afghan capital was reported returning to normal today, two days after Tanai, as defense minister, turned on President Najib and sent renegade forces to bomb the presidential palace. Official Radio Kabul quoted the Interior Ministry today as saying 56 people died and 200 were injured in the fighting. Diplomatic sources and guerrilla leaders have said hundreds of people died or were injured. The radio report also said four members of the Supreme Defense Council had been dismissed, apparently for supporting the coup attempt. Shops and offices opened and people poured into the streets of Kabul, according to diplomatic and Western sources there. Many buildings, including the presidential palace, the Finance Ministry and government-run Radio Kabul, were badly damaged, said the sources, who all insisted on anonymity. Diplomats, guerrilla leaders and U.N. officials in Pakistan said they still had reports of fighting in southern Kandahar, eastern Jalalabad and western Shindand, where the country's second-largest air base is located. One Western diplomat said he had reports that pro-Tanai forces were fighting government troops for control of Kabul airport. Another said the air force, given much credit for helping Najib's government survive without Soviet troops, had suffered severe losses. ``A lot of aircraft have been knocked out,'' the diplomat said. None of the reports could be independently verified. In a message delivered today to the news agency of the guerrillas' exiled government, Tanai said: ``We have risen up and our struggle will continue.'' ``I am inside Afghanistan,'' Tanai said in the 2-minute-long message, translated by the agency from Dari into English. ``I am sending this cassette with my friend outside to be broadcast to you.'' ``This is a call for Afghanistan's Moslem people and the army and the real party members. Najib and his dictatorship will fall. For this and for national unity, we have risen up.'' The tape was played to reporters, who recognized Tanai's voice from miltary briefings, news conferences, and television appearances in Kabul. Tanai fled Afghanistan on Wednesday, and Pakistani officials and guerrilla sources said he then defected to the Moslem guerrillas, whom he fought more than a decade. Tanai returned to Afghanistan, but his exact whereabouts were not known. Within hours after launching the coup attempt, one of the most radical guerrilla leaders, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, declared his support for Tanai. Hekmatyar has generally had the support of Abdul Rasul Sayyaf, leader of the radical Islamic Ittehad guerrilla faction, but Sayyaf said today the guerrillas would never accept Tanai because of his ties to the Communist leadership. ``He's no different than Najib,'' said Sayyaf in Peshawar, Pakistan, where the guerrillas are headquartered. Sayyaf is prime minister of the guerrillas' government-in-exile. A more moderate guerrilla leader, Sibghatullah Mojaddidi, the exiled government's president, also refused to accept Tanai. ``We do not have any understanding or solidarity with either (Tanai or Najib),'' he said. Tanai long opposed Najib's efforts to make peace with the Afghan guerrillas, who took up arms against the government after a Communist coup in 1978. The Soviet army fought alongside government troops until February 1989, when they withdrew under a U.N.-mediated accord. They still supply the government with arms, while the United States arms the guerrillas. Tanaii's alliance with Hekmatyar was one of convenience, not ideology, for Tanai is a staunch Marxist who favored a hard line against the guerrillas, while Hekmatyar is one of the most radical anti-Western rebel leaders. An Afghan government spokesman, meanwhile, said Najib had received ``messages from all provinces ensuring support for the government.'' The spokesman, Naqib Sameer, spoke in a telephone interview from London. According to Naqib, the coup attempt was plotted by ``a group of hard-liners, a group who were against national reconciliation policy and with the full cooperation of extremist groups of Gulbuddin and (Tanai) himself.'' Radio Kabul said four members of the Supreme Defense Council had been dismissed for ``national dishonesty.'' They were identified as Niaz Mohjammad Momand and Mir Sahib Karwal, both Politburo members; Gen. Nazar Mohammad, an alternate member of the Politburo; and Sayed Aqa Aka, a brigadier general who fled to Pakistan on Wednesday. The insurgents said pro-Tanai forces were still in control of the country's biggest air base, Bagram, where fierce fighting was reported Wednesday. However, one rebel source said the base had been destroyed by pro-Najib bombers.

DOC.HEAD: Former Ohio Congressman Dies
DOC.TEXT: Earl T. Wagner, a former congressman who practiced law until he recently became ill, died of cancer at a Cincinnati hospital. He was 81. Wagner, who died Tuesday, served in the House in 1949-51, as a Democrat representing the 2nd District. He was a member of the Cincinnati Board of Education in 1944-48. He was a 1930 graduate of the Salmon P. Chase School of Law in nearby northern Kentucky. He served as district counsel to the Homeowners Loan Corp. during the Depression, was special counsel to the Ohio attorney general in 1937-38 and was city solicitor in the Cincinnati suburbs of Sharonville and Addyston during the 1930s. Survivors include his wife, Stella DiVirgilio Wagner; a son, Earl W. Wagner, of Raleigh, N.C.; three daughters, Jean Wagner Nippert, Carol Huml and Catherine Grosse, both of Cincinnati, 10 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A burial Mass was scheduled for Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Moslems Demand Independence As Peace Mission Arrives ^Eds: Sub grafs 6, `The delegation...' to ADD that delegation was not allowed to leave hotel; Sub graf 14, `The deaths...' to CORRECT overall death count. Pickup 15th graf, `Jammu-Kashmir...
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Moslems today shouted Islamic slogans and demanded independence for Kashmir as a delegation of political leaders including former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi arrived to try to end the unrest. ``Allah is great!'' the crowds chanted as the convoy of army jeeps and trucks carrying the delegation drove through the streets from the airport. ``We want independence!'' Earlier today, gunfights broke out between the militants and security forces, and at least two civilians were reported killed. Soldiers carrying machine guns and automatic rifles strictly enforced curfew regulations as the delegation arrived. But hundreds of residents shouted slogans from the loudspeakers of scores of mosques in the city. The delegation, which included deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal and representatives from all major political parties, says it is on a peace mission aimed at ending the Moslem movement for secession of Kashmir from Hindu-majority India. The delegation met with Jammu-Kashmir state Gov. Jagmohan at a luxury hotel near Dal Lake, which was ringed by at least 1,000 policemen and paramilitary troops. They were not allowed to leave the hotel. ``I am shocked,'' Gandhi told reporters at the hotel. ``If there is no political solution, I see some very hard options ahead.'' Gandhi also said he had been refused permission to visit residents of Srinagar, the largest city in the valley, and the focal point of the Moslem campaign for secession. Jagmohan said allowing Gandhi to go out would create a ``tremendous security risk.'' When curfew was lifted from 5 a.m. to 10 a.m., almost-continuous exchanges of fire began, said witnesses who spoke on condition of anonymity. Moslem snipers fired at paramilitary police at four places but he had no details of casualties, said Jagmohan, a Hindu who uses one name. The witnesses said they heard firing from at least a half-dozen areas among the shops, houses and narrow, winding streets of downtown Srinagar. They said militants were sniping from rooftops and pinning down soldiers in roadside bunkers. The soldiers returned fire sporadically, the witnesses said on condition of anonymity. ``It was like a battlefield,'' said one witness contacted by telephone. ``I've never heard firing like this before.'' Witnesses reported two killed and 10 wounded. The deaths raise to 173 the number of people killed since Jan. 20, when security forces launched a crackdown on militants fighting for the independence of Kashmir. Jagmohan took charge as the state's governor Jan. 18 and ordered the crackdown. Jammu-Kashmir, India's only Moslem-majority state, comprises the Kashmir valley and the plains of Jammu to the south. The valley is disputed by India and neighboring Pakistan and has been the scene of a lingering secessionist movement by Moslem militants. The campaign for an independent Kashmir has flared in recent months, with India accusing Pakistan of fomenting the trouble, a charge that Pakistan repeatedly denies. The two countries have gone to war three times since their independence from Britain in 1947 _ twice over Kashmir. A U.N-sponsored cease-fire line separates Kashmir into Indian and Pakistani sectors. At least 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems. Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus make up 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Call for Greater Separation between Party and State
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese citizens are pressing their ruling Communist Party to revise a draft document to clearly show a separation of party and state, the official Vietnam News Agency said. ``All agreed that to rapidly reorganize the party is a task that cannot be delayed any longer,'' the agency said in a report released Wednesday on public debates througout the country. The party has eased its grip on society in recent years but has ruled out following the radical changes that are taking place in Communist parties throughout Eastern Europe. The agency said the draft program of an upcoming party meeting has raised debates throughout the country and ``is drawing the largest participation of the population of Ho Chi Minh City since liberation in 1975.'' The agency quoted an unidentified debater as saying: ``The draft should lay more emphasis on the reorganization of the party itself as the basis to broaden democracy and realize social equality, strengthen the people's power and the mass organizations.'' ``In this connection, it is necessary first of all to separate the functions of the party from those of the state,'' the debater said.

DOC.HEAD: Jackie Onassis Ends 10-Year Land Dispute with Wampanoag Indians
DOC.TEXT: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis ended a 10-year dispute with a group of Wampanoag Indians by agreeing to give them a plot of land and $100,000 in exchange for a tiny beachfront site. The case pitted Mrs. Onassis' desire for privacy against the Indians' belief that they should retain control of tribal lands on Martha's Vineyard, including 1.5 acres owned primarily by the Wampanoags that is surrounded by Onassis' estate on the island. ``After all this time I'm just happy the land was settled,'' said Thelma Weissberg, one of the 25 descendants of William Vanderhoop, a Wampanoag who lived in the area in the 1870s and owned the 1.5-acre plot. ``I've lived on the island all my life and I'm happy that we have some of our land back.'' Wampanoags have lived at the picturesque cliffs of Gay Head for centuries. The tribe believes the tract on Onassis' estate holds the last resting place of the great chief Moshup and his wife, Squant. In 1980, Mrs. Onassis obtained one-sixth interest in the 1.5-acre plot, and sought to buy the remaining five-sixths from the 25 descendants of Vanderhoop. She wanted to close access to the parcel and keep beachgoers and tourists away from her 400-acre property. But the Wampanoags resisted and a series of lawsuits and countersuits followed. According to the terms of the agreement signed Wednesday, the Wampanoags will surrender title and access to the 1.5-acre site in exchange for $100,000 and a 2-acre beachfront plot closer to the nearest road. Brian Hurley, one of Mrs. Onassis' attorneys, said: ``She's just pleased to have resolved this long matter and hopes to continue being good neighbors. She wants to put it behind her.'' Since 1974, various Wampanoags have regained about 400 acres of what they consider tribal land on Martha's Vineyard through a series of federal lawsuits. They claimed that a 1790 law that forbids transfer of Indian lands without federal approval was violated in the 1870s when the state redistributed tribal lands to other island residents. The Wampanoags have maintained a tribal structure for more than 370 years, according to tribal council president Donald Widdiss, but they did not receive federal recognition until 1987. There are only 250 Wampanoags left at Gay Head, and only 630 in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Demands $34 Billion in Compensation if Lithuania Secedes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 8th, ``Brazauskas said...'' to UPDATE with Gorbachev saying Soviet Union may demand port city if Lithuania secedes, possible Lithuanian demands. Pickup 9th, ``Solid victories...''
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has demanded that Lithuania pay the Kremlin billions in hard currency if the republic goes ahead with its plan to secede from the Soviet Union, the Baltic republic's president says. The demand for compensation came in a meeting with Lithuania's president, Algirdas Brazauskas, ahead of an expected weekend vote on secession in the republic's parliament. Vilnius Radio put the figure at $34 billion, saying the money would cover investments Moscow has made in Lithuania since forcibly annexing it in 1940. Lithuanian nationalists say the Kremlin has it backward, and should pay them for a half-century of exploitation. Brazauskas, who also heads the republic's breakaway Communist Party, told Lithuanian television Wednesday night that there was no need ``to frighten ourselves and others'' about the economic consequences of secession. In a Tass report on the interview, Brazauskas said Gorbachev told him during the meeting Monday that if Lithuania proclaims independence, ``economic relations would have to be legalized as relations between two independent states, and accounts between them will have to be settled in freely convertible currency.'' The Soviet ruble is not convertible, meaning its value is set by the government rather than through trading on world markets. The official Soviet news agency quoted Brazauskas as saying that to pay in convertible currency ``would be an extremely difficult task for the republic to accomplish,'' since it imports fuel, metallurgical products, and raw materials from the Soviet Union at about three times lower than world prices. Brazauskas said the republic would nevertheless be so much better off on its own that the advantages would offset its debt to Moscow, according to Eduardas Potashinskas, an editor at Lithuanian TV. Brazauskas said Gorbachev indicated the Soviet Union may demand Lithuania turn over the port of Klaipeda if allowed to secede, as well as a small section around Drushinikai in extreme south Lithuania, according to the editor. Potashinskas said the Lithuanians could make counterclaims for the areas around Oshmyany and Novogrudok that were parts of Lithuania after Lenin signed a treaty recognizing the republic's independence in 1920. Klaipeda, a warm-water port on the Baltic Sea 125 miles northwest of Vilnius, was occupied by the Germans and later freed by Soviet forces in 1944. Solid victories in recent elections have given backers of Sajudis, the pro-independence popular movement, control of Lithuania's Parliament. As a result, the group's leaders have decided to force the issue of secession. The Parliament, in a session called for this weekend, is sure ``to come out with some form of declaration of independence,'' said Potashinskas, who also is a Sajudis activist. Pro-secession sentiment in the republic of 3.8 million has been swelling for months. But Sajudis decided to move now to pre-empt Gorbachev's plans to introduce a vastly more powerful presidency with the right to crack down on restive republics. The national Congress of People's Deputies is scheduled to meet Monday to consider the presidency proposal. ``Why so fast? I think Gorbachev himself created such a reaction,'' said Audris Siaurusavicius, a reporter for Rebirth, the Sajudis newspaper. ``If there were no such proposal on the presidency, we wouldn't have done this now.'' All three Baltic republics, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, were independent nations between the World Wars before being forced to join the Soviet Union in 1940 while under Soviet occupation. Lawmakers in Moscow are considering a proposed law that would give republics the right to secede from the union. But settling financial issues is just one of a daunting series of requirements that the republics would have to meet in order to secede. The proposed law also says a republic can secede only after a republic-wide referendum in which three-fourths of the adults vote in favor of the move; then the secession proposal must be submitted to national lawmakers in Moscow. During a minimum five-year transition phase, defense, security and border questions are to be settled and the government of the seceding republic must also settle financial and property issues. The Soviet Constitution guarantees republics the right to secede, but the procedure never has been spelled out in Soviet law. Siaurusavicius said Sajudis leaders were expecting Moscow's response to the declaration to be restrained. But he said the republic could already feel the effects of a mounting Soviet economic blockade. Many factories are running short on raw materials and they expect the situation to get worse. Gorbachev has repeatedly denounced ``separatists'' and has asked activists to give Moscow time to work out the terms of a new Soviet federation before moving to secede. An article in the government newspaper Izvestia on Wednesday complained that ``Lithuania is getting public opinion used to the fact that it `is leaving,''' without thinking through all the economic and political difficulties secession would create. The article said such problems would include trade imbalances, the difficulty of deciding what to do about various Soviet-built factories and the fate of Lithuanian residents who want to retain their Soviet citizenship. Moreover, it said, the Lithuanian push for independence had spread to other republics. ``One after another, legislative measures are passed which, like a lancet, cut off vein after vein, nerve after nerve from the overall organism,'' the article said. About half of the Soviet Union's 15 republics now have popular groups pushing for independence or greater sovereignty, including Moldavia, Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Estonia and Latvia.

DOC.HEAD: Virgil Madison Rogers, Former Syracuse Dean
DOC.TEXT: Virgil Madison Rogers, a former dean of education at Syracuse University who helped pioneer school integration in Arkansas and Michigan, has died at age 91. A native of Spartanburg, S.C., Rogers was a dean at Syracuse for 10 years, retiring in 1963. Rogers, who died Saturday at a health care center in suburban Liverpool, graduated from Wofford College in Spartanburg, earned his master's degree at Western State College in Colorado and his doctorate at Columbia University in New York City. He was a school superintendent in Gunnison and Boulder, Colo., and River Forest, Ill. As a school superintendent in Battle Creek, Mich., in the early 1940s, Rogers hired the first black teachers in that system. Rogers was the former president of the American Association of School Administrators and in 1989 received the Distinguished Service Award in Education Administration. He was awarded an honorary life membership in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for his testimony on behalf of black students in the 1958 Little Rock, Ark., school integration case. The cause of death was not released. Surviving are two daughters, Virginia Rogers Andrews of Syracuse and Julie Catherine Rogers of Cottage Grove, Ore.; a son, Bruce C.
