Rogers of Sacramento, Calif.; a brother, Louis M. Rogers of Spartanburg, S.C.; a sister, Louise Rogers Rast of Eutawville, S.C.; and six grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Democratic Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 5 grafs new with Rules Committee action; picks up 5th graf pvs, The panel.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats pushed their version of a campaign financing bill through the Senate Rules Committee today but acknowledged it is subject to wholesale change if a compromise can be struck with Republicans. ``I expect that the leadership will propose a comprehensive substitute amendment to what we passed,'' the panel's chairman, Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., said of the Democratic proposal that would impose voluntary spending caps ranging from $1.6 billion to $9.2 billion on individual Senate candidates. The committee approved the bill on a 7-3 party-line vote. Republicans supported a bipartisan advisory panel's call to limit how much candidates can raise from political action committees (PACs) and out-of-state donors but place no limit on in-state contributions from inidviudals. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, called the recommendations Wednesday from the panel of six experts appointed by Senate Demnocratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine and Republican Leader Bob Dole a ``genius solution.'' Republicans plan to begin work next week on a bill based on the panel's recommendations but said they will add a provision to address unreported ``soft money'' contributions by non-party interest groups, such as labor unions, corporations and non-profit organizations. The panel endorsed individual candidate spending ceilings sought by Democrats, but with ``reasonably high'' and flexible limits and a provision that would let the GOP keep using its advantage in raising money through mass direct mailings. Under the panel's plan, individual candidates could exceed the limits through an exemption for limited donations from in-state residents and still qualify for the discount mail and television advertising rates intended to lure compliance. ``The fact that it embraces a concept of spending limits is an especially encouraging sign that there is bipartisan momentum building for real reform,'' said Boren. Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., the leading Senate critic of campaign ceilings, said the panel's report can serve as a framework for further talks. But he said he was ``confused'' by Democrats' insistence on advancing their bill in the meantime. Others, however, were highly critical of the panel's recommendations, including its acceptance of political action committees, or PACs, and so-called unreported ``soft'' money contributions. Fred Wertheimer of Common Cause called the package ``fundamentally flawed.'' ``No serious reform of the congressional campaign finance system is possible unless the role and influence of PAC money is dramatically reduced and the soft money system has brought back Watergate-size and Watergate-style contributions into federal campaigns is shut down,'' Wertheimer said. The experts _ three each picked by Mitchell and Dole _ supported Republican desires for unfettered party spending on phone banks, voter registration and direct mail campaigns and higher limits on individual contributions. The report recommended a compromise on PACs, opposing President Bush's call for an outright ban on corporate and union PACs that have overwhelmingly favored Democratic incumbents. Instead, it recommended diminishing their role. PACs could contribute only up to one-third of a candidate's spending limit under the panel's proposals. From then on their contributions to each candidate would be limited to half the current $10,000 limit for primary and general election campaigns together. The panel also would ban PACs from making post-election contributions to retire a candidate's campaign debt and restrict labor and corporate PACs in ``bundling'' or gathering donations on behalf of a candidate. However, it found ``little obvious cause for concern'' in bundling done by individuals, such as the more than $200,000 raised in campaign gifts raised by Phoenix savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr. for five U.S. senators. Other campaign financing abuses raised by last year's S&L crisis also were ignored by the panel, including the use of so-called leadership PACS by senior party officials to raise money for other candidates. It also had no recommendation on tax-exempt foundations. Of the $1.3 million Keating contributed to five Senate candidates, $850,000 was through a tax-exempt voter registration foundation headed by the son of Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Attends Flag Ceremony Commemorating Panama Invasion
DOC.TEXT: In a darkened ceremonial hall, President Bush watched as new streamers were attached today to the four flags of the U.S. military services to commemorate the invasion of Panama that toppled dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``We're here today to add another campaign streamer to the roll call of glory, the roster of great American campaigns _ Yorktown, Gettysburg, Normandy and now Panama,'' said Bush. He reaffirmed his support for overturning a Supreme Court decision that struck down laws making it illegal to burn the flag. The flag honors those ``who died in the defense of liberty ... and that is why I am determined that the American flag will be consecrated, not desecrated,'' said Bush. Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said, ``With the presentation of these streamers, the campaign in Panama is now part of the glorious tradition of our nation and its armed forces. ``For as long as the Stars and Stripes flies over this nation, the actions of the men and women who helped to restore democracy to Panama in December of 1989 will be remembered,'' said Powell. The flags borne by an honor guard from the Army, the Navy, the Air Force and the Marines already carry dozens of multicolored streamers, each signifying a different war or engagement, from the Revolutionary War to the Civil War to Vietnam and Grenada. ``On the surface the streamer is but a piece of multicolored cloth. But for every American and especially for those of us who wore a uniform in December of 1989, it will always represent unselfish sacrifice,'' said Powell. Bush reviewed the troops arrayed in Ceremonial Hall at this base just across the Potomac River from the capital. More than 200 soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines stood at attention, some bearing bayonets, others rifles and still others carrying flags from each state and territory. ``The people of that nation, Panama, needed us to stand with them to defend that struggle for democracy and for the opportunity that Americans have enjoyed for over 200 years,'' said Bush. He said that ``27,000 of America's finest sprang into action'' for the Dec. 20 operation that the Pentagon called Just Cause. The expeditionary streamer was the 169th affixed to the Army flag; the 13th for the Marine flag; the 19th for the Navy and the 78th for the Air Force. Bush said the streamer is ``most of all'' for the 23 soldiers killed in the Panama operation.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Convicted on All Counts in Julie Love Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors say they will seek the death penalty for a man convicted of a murder that was cited in a letter that claimed responsibility for the mail bomb killings of a judge and civil rights lawyer. Jurors deliberated eight hours Wednesday before convicting Emmanuel Hammond shortly before midnight of murder, kidnapping and armed robbery. Hammond, 24, of Marietta hung his head and rubbed his eyes as the verdict was read. Fulton Superior Court Judge Ralph H. Hicks scheduled the sentencing portion of Hammond's trial to begin today. Julie Love, a 27-year-old preschool fitness teacher who disappeared in July 1988, was the subject of a much-publicized search until her body was found in August. She had been shot in the head. Hammond was handcuffed in the courtroom and led away as Miss Love's family embraced. Her father, Jerry Love, rfused to comment ``until it's all over.'' Fulton County Assistant District Attorneys William L. Hawthorne III and Richard Hicks shook hands after the trial. ``I am obviously very pleased,'' Hawthorne said. ``I think the jury worked long and hard in their deliberations, and they apparently had some basis for their verdict,'' said defense attorney William A. Wehunt. Wehunt contended Hammond's chief accusers _ his former girlfriend, Janice Weldon, and his cousin, Maurice Porter _ actually killed Miss Love and were trying to frame his client. Porter has pleaded guilty to murder, armed robbery and rape in the death of Miss Love and awaits sentencing. He testified last week that Hammond abducted Miss Love from an Atlanta street after her car ran out of gas and that Hammond dragged her into some bushes and killed her. Miss Weldon, who led police to Miss Love's body, also testified against Hammond. Testimony in the trial began last week under heavy security because of concern over the possible link to the pre-Christmas mail bombs. A death threat from a group called the Aryan Resistance Movement, apparently unrelated to the bombings, later led to even tighter security. A letter from a group claiming responsibility for the mail bomb deaths of Judge Robert Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and Savannah lawyer Robert Robinson said the attacks were motivated by outrage over Miss Love's killing. The letter, signed by Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System, threatened more violence if any other white women were attacked by black men in Alabama, Florida or Georgia. Miss Love was white. Hammond is black.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Visits Capitol Hill to Talk About Foreign Affairs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Former President Richard M. Nixon returned today to the House of Representatives, where his political career started, in the role of political educator lecturing lawmakers about the world and the changes taking place. ``An extraordinary session,'' House minority leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said after the closed-door meeting. ``An extraordinary tour de force,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 man in the House Republican hierarchy. Nixon said he told the congressmen that while the Cold War is probably over in Europe, ``it is still going on in the Third World.'' He said any ``peace benefit'' coming from the reduction of tensions should go toward reducing this country's huge deficit. ``What really went through my mind was that here is where it all began,'' said Nixon, who entered the political world as a freshman congressman in 1948. He recalled that his office was a couple of doors down from that of another freshman congressman, John F. Kennedy, D-Mass. ``The two of us who disagreed politically and later, on some very big issues, agreed on foreign policy and our first vote was for President Truman's request for military and economic aid to Greece and Turkey,'' Nixon said. ``It was a good vote and it started the bipartisan policy which I hope can be reinitiated today.'' There was no mention that the House of Representatives was prepared to vote Nixon's impeachment in 1974 when he resigned the highest office in the land. Nixon spent more than an hour with Republican congressmen, speaking of global changes. Later, he went to the Senate side of the Capitol, to the office of Minority Leader Bob Dole, to meet with 18 incumbent GOP senators who are up for re-election this year. The former president was in good humor as he talked with reporters, saying ``as I look at this crowd, I know I'm getting older but the press seems to be getting younger.'' He suggested that a change could come in Cuba if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cuts off the $6 billion in aid it gives each year to that country. ``The key is Gorbachev,'' said Nixon. At that point, a reporter addressed Nixon as ``Mr. Gorbachev.'' When the laughter died down, Nixon said, ``I've been called worse.'' The former president reminisced that in his days as a congressman and senator, when the Cold War began, the chief goal of the United States was to defeat communism. Now, he said, the greatest responsibility is to see that freedom works. The 77-year-old Nixon has become more visible in recent months through his visit to China, a dinner with President Bush to discuss that trip, and his effort to help Bush convince the Senate to sustain a veto. Nixon's briefings were one more step in his increasing political acceptance. The former president was invited by the Congressional Institute Inc., an organization founded three years ago by House Republicans. The institute organizes retreats and events for members; a spokesman said this is the first time it has attracted a speaker of Nixon's renown. Nixon has written extensively, in books and in magazine and newspaper articles, about foreign affairs in recent years and is sought after as a speaker on global politics. His latest book, ``In the Arena: A Memoir of Victory, Defeat and Renewal,'' is to be published next month. Its profits will go to the Nixon Presidential Library and Birthplace Foundation, which built the Nixon library in Yorba Linda, Calif. The library is to be opened in July. Nixon made his sixth trip to China in November and, in private talks with top Chinese leaders, expressed American concern over political repression in that country. He was the most prominent American to go to China since the bloody military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last June. On his return, the 37th president had dinner with Bush, the 41st president. Bush found the talk ``interesting,'' according to press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. In January, Nixon made at least two telephone calls to Republican senators asking them to sustain Bush's veto of a bill protecting Chinese students from deportation. The Senate failed to override the veto.

DOC.HEAD: Official Discloses Plan for Jewish Housing In Arab Sector
DOC.TEXT: A planning official disclosed today that the government has plans to build a new Jewish neighborhood in Arab east Jerusalem, despite a dispute with the United States over new construction in the area. Ruth Kaminker, a member of Jerusalem's nine-member City Planning Board, told The Associated Press that the new 225-acre neighborhood was in ``final stages'' of planning after a three-month study of the site. The development, estimated to include up to 3,000 homes or apartments, is planned for a steep slope of a hill known as Mt. Homa, said Mrs. Kaminker, a member of the left-wing Citizens' Rights Movement. She said the government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir requested development of the Jewish neighborhood, apparently in an attempt to strengthen the Jewish hold in the Arab sector of Jerusalem, which was captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. City spokeswoman Bonnie Boxer denied any new neighborhood in east Jerusalem was in the planning stages. But she acknowledged the site was one of several under consideration in east Jerusalem for construction of Jewish housing. Israel has been under growing U.S. pressures to give the 140,000 Palestinians of east Jerusalem a role in Middle East peace talks, but Shamir has objected, saying such a move could harm Israel's claim to all of Jerusalem as its undivided capital. Last week, President Bush criticized Israeli building in disputed areas of Jerusalem. ``We do not believe there should be new settlements in the West Bank or east Jerusalem,'' Bush told reporters in California. Unlike settlements in the West Bank or Gaza Strip, new housing projects in east Jerusalem are generally referred to here as neighborhoods, because people who move into them do not get special benefits such as low-interest mortgages available in the occupied territories. Israel annexed east Jerusalem in 1967, but most countries including the United States, have not recognized Israeli sovereignty over the area. In response to Baker's remark, Jerusalem's city council held an emergency meeting Tuesday and adopted a resolution to ``continue to build the city for the good of all its inhabitants.'' In the past 23 years, Israel has moved 120,000 Jews into the annexed Arab area of the city. A total of 350,000 Jews live in east and west Jerusalem. Mrs. Kaminker said the new neighborhood would be alongside Zur Baher, an Arab neighborhood of several thousand people, and would in effect complete a Jewish ring around the city. But Mrs. Kaminker said plans for the new Jewish neighborhood were nearly complete, requiring only official approval that would be a ``foregone conclusion'' since the government asked for the neighborhood. Efforts at Arab-Israeli reconciliation have several times been stalled by housing built on confiscated Arab land. But Mrs. Kaminker said the current site already was state-owned, purchased by the Jewish National Fund from Arab landowners and then sold to Israel. The land had long been earmarked for tree-planting and banned for construction because of its rocky terrain, Mrs. Kaminker said. ``It is a very difficult area for construction, so the decision seems purely political,'' she added. Mrs. Kaminker said her party would protest implementation of the housing project. But the Citizens' Rights movement is a tiny minority on the city council dominated by Shamir's Likud bloc, the center-left Labor Party and conservative religious parties.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran President to Visit White House
DOC.TEXT: Honduran President Rafael Leonardo Callejas will visit the White House April 17 to discuss Central American peace efforts and other matters with President Bush, the White House said today. Callejas accepted an invitation from Bush to pay a working visit to the United States April 17-19, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``They will meet on April 17. They will discuss issues of interest concerning the regional peace process, economic assistance and President Callejas' economic reform program,'' he said. For years, Honduras provided a base of operations for Contra rebels seeking to oust the Sandinista government in neighboring Nicaragua. Callejas has called upon the Contras to lay down their arms and return home following Sandinista President Daniel Ortega's loss to Violeta Chamorro in Nicaragua's Feb. 25 elections. Vice President Dan Quayle visited Honduras in late January.

DOC.HEAD: Two Families Found Shot to Death in Northeast Ohio
DOC.TEXT: Two families have been found shot to death within hours of each in separate northeast Ohio cities and authorities suspect both were murder-suicides by the fathers. Police investigating the whereabouts of one family found all five dead Wednesday in their apartment in Mayfield Heights, about 10 miles east of Cleveland. Police think Robert W. Lynch, 52, shot his pregnant wife and their three children and then shot himself. About 4{ hours later, a family of four was found in their apartment in Painesville, about 30 miles northeast of Cleveland. Police said Bruce Clinton, 36, shot his estranged wife and two children and then killed himself. The bodies of Clinton, his wife, Angela M. Green, 23, and their two children, Wesley Adam, 5, and Winston Allen, 14 months, were discovered in the apartment shortly after officers were called Wednesday evening, police Lt. Charles Howard said. ``They hadn't been heard of for several hours, and friends of the family hadn't been able to locate occupants by phone or in person,'' Howard said. He said all four died of gunshot wounds to the head. ``Further investigation disclosed Clinton shot his wife and two children and then took his own life,'' Howard said. Lynch was found on a sofa in his living room, police said. The bodies of his pregnant wife, Joy M. Lynch, 44, and their sons Michael R., 16, Matthew D., 14, and Andrew S., 11, were found in their beds. All were shot either in the head or upper body. ``We have never had anything comparable to this. It's the biggest murder we've ever had,'' said Police Chief Dominic Caprara. ``She was just about ready to have her child any time and she seemed very happy,'' said apartment manager Frances Griffith. Police discovered two semiautomatic pistols in the apartment, along with several spent shells and a note believed left by Lynch. Police said the note contained the sentence: ``This is the last straw.'' ``The investigation isn't complete, but we believe the father may have been the one who shot the mother and three kids and committed suicide,'' said police Sgt. Larry McHugh. ``The man had been despondent over a number of things,'' including recent business setbacks, police Sgt. Harold DeBoe said today. He would not elaborate. Police entered the apartment with a building manager after a neighbor expressed concern that the Lynch boys had all missed school. The neighbor later told police she thought she heard shots early in the morning.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Atlantic University Offers Free Tuition to Black Freshmen
DOC.TEXT: Florida Atlantic University this fall will become the state's only public university offering free tuition to every black freshman who meets admissions standards, school officials said. The gesture, which the United Negro College Fund said was probably the only such program in the nation, is intended to boost the number of black students at the school in Boca Raton. ``Sometimes you spend too much time talking about why you should do something and not enough time doing it,'' FAU President Anthony Catanese said Tuesday. ``If you're serious about recruiting the best students, a full scholarship simply is the way to go.'' There also is a practical motive: The Board of Regents has ordered FAU to increase its freshman class by 50 percent next year, and the number of black students must go up to meet state targets for minority enrollment. ``It's a phenomenal idea, an excellent first step,'' said Maurice Hall, president of the West Palm Beach branch of the NAACP. Both Floridians and out-of-state students can apply, but in-state students will get preference under the program, which will be financed through private donations and school funds. FAU has 608 black students _ including foreign students _ out of a total student body of 11,310. But this year's freshman class had only 28 black students. That meets the Board of Regents' target for blacks, who must account for at least 7.7 percent of the student body. But it is smaller than the proportion of blacks in surrounding Broward and Palm Beach counties: 11.2 percent and 13.5 percent. ``The targets are far too low for this area,'' said Brian Levin-Stankevich, admissions director. ``It should be obvious to anybody that 28 black (freshmen) students are not enough.'' ``What bothers me is that the goals are rather modest. I want to redouble the efforts,'' Catanese said. University officials emphasized that boosting the number of blacks will not require cutting the number of non-black students, because freshman enrollment is being expanded so dramatically. ``We're not displacing anybody by adding minorities,'' Levin-Stankevich said. ``I think that's an important point.'' Enough scholarship money already is earmarked to pay full tuition costs for 30 black freshmen. Every black freshman this year has a scholarship. Financial aid officials estimate that tuition will be $1,350 a student next year. FAU would be the only university in the nation to guarantee full scholarships to each black freshman, the United Negro College Fund says. Private Lemoyne-Owens College in Memphis launched a program this year to give free tuition to inner-city black male high school students who stay off drugs. The school also set up a dual-degree program last week with predominantly black Bethune-Cookman College in Daytona Beach, allowing students there to transfer to FAU to earn an engineering diploma _ again with a full scholarship. Similar partnerships are being pursued with Florida Memorial College in Miami and Edward Waters College in Jacksonville.

DOC.HEAD: Johns Hopkins To Study Heart Disease In Women
DOC.TEXT: The first major study of women and heart disease is being undertaken by the Johns Hopkins Medical Institution and six other centers, after decades of research devoted solely to male heart disease. The $10 million, four-year study is designed to determine whether three different hormones can help reduce heart disease in post-menopausal women. Heart disease kills more Americans than any other disease. In the study, 840 women will be assigned at random to one of the three medications or to a placebo. High blood cholesterol, hypertension and heightened levels of a blood-clotting factor will be studied. The results could prompt doctors to prescribe hormone therapy for post-menopausal women, said Dr. Trudy Bush, an epidemiologist at the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health. ``In my opinion, there is good evidence at this time that women who use estrogens probably have about half the risk of heart disease compared to women who don't,'' Bush said. Estrogen hormones will be part of the study. Bush is heading the study at Hopkins along with gynecologists Dr. David Foster and Dr. Howard Zacur. In the past, major studies of heart disease in the United States have involved males because the ailment tends to strike men at a younger age than women, and younger people are less likely to suffer from additional health problems that could complicate a study. The new study, called Post-Menopausal Estrogen and Progestin Intervention, reflects a belief that women have been denied equal time in health studies, as well as a growing emphasis on the health of older people. Underlying the study is the belief that estrogen, a hormone needed for normal female sexual development, protects younger women against heart disease. Researchers also suspect the threat of a heart attack increases during menopause when estrogen production drops off. The study will try to determine whether hormone drugs take the place of natural estrogen in protecting the hearts of older women.

DOC.HEAD: House Ethics Committee Criticizes Gingrich but Will Not Pursue Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 3, Gingrich said, with comment. Removes pvs graf 9, Gingrich said, now redundant.
DOC.TEXT: The House ethics committee said today it will not pursue an investigation of Republican Whip New Gingrich, but criticized him for failing to disclose a house purchase and for improper activities by his staff. ``No adequate basis exists'' to begin even the preliminary phase of an investigation, the committee said in a report approved unanimously Wednesday and made public today. Gingrich said the committee's decision demonstrated that the charges were ``politically inspired nonsense.'' The panel said it decided that allegations in separate complaints last year by Rep. Bill Alexander, D-Ark. _ even if true _ did not ``state violations of applicable standards of conduct'' by the Georgia Republican. Gingrich, however, was ordered to amend his financial disclosure forms to ``reflect participation'' in his purchase, along with his daughter, of her personal residence in Georgia four years ago. The committee also criticized two letters sent on Gingrich's official letterhead in December 1986 and January 1987, promoting a for-profit senior citizens cruise sponsored by Marathon Travel Co. of Marathon, Fla. The panel wrote Gingrich, ``You were remiss in your oversight and administration of your congressional office'' in the cruise mailings. ``Accordingly, you are directed to immediately take steps to preclude recurrence of the type of improper activity here involved. You are further placed on notice that a future recurrence of improper use of mail and resources may result in more severe committee action.'' The outcome of the case was eagerly awaited on Capitol Hill, because Gingrich, the No. 2-ranking House Republican, was the chief accuser in the ethics investigation that led to the resignation last June of House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas. ``This process of responding to a clearly political smear cost a lot of money and was very demanding both politically and personally,'' Gingrich said, contending that the investigation cost the taxpayers at least $300,000 and himself more than $100,000 in legal fees. Gingrich said his failure to report that he co-signed the mortgage for his daughter's home stemmed from his misreading of House rules. And he blamed the travel-promotion letters on a staffer _ ``a young man who made a mistake in judgment.'' In a letter to Gingrich attached to the report, the committee said the joint purchase of his daughter's home ``as well as the underlying liability you incurred, should have been reported on your financial disclosure statements.'' The panel said it considered Gingrich's contention that he was only a guarantor of the loan and signed documents only as an accommodation for his daughter. ``Nonetheless, the committee believes that the true nature of the transaction, as reflected in the pertinent legal documents, should control reporting. Accordingly, pursuant to ... the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, the committee directs that you promptly amend your financial disclosure statements to reflect the transaction in question.' The panel also rejected Gingrich's assertion that he had no personal knowledge of the cruise letters until Alexander filed his complaint. The committee said each member is responsible for the conduct of his staff and that members cannot use official stationery or other resources for non-governmental purposes. Alexander had alleged that Gingrich committed hundreds of violations of House rules, including financial disclosure requirements, and also ran afoul of campaign finance laws. He filed the ethics complaints last April and October. Alexander said Wednesday: ``The ethics committee has resolved the Gingrich matter by deciding not to investigate further, but by deciding to admonish Gingrich.'' ``Further disciplinary actions against Mr. Gingrich are therefore not needed at the present time,'' Alexander said. In his ethics complaint filed in October, Alexander said Gingrich failed to list the Fulton County, Ga., home as an asset or the mortgage as a liability. The complaint said the home was bought in 1986 and the mortgage totaled $77,800. House rules exempt members from disclosing financial information about their own homes, but Gingrich acknowledged last year the residence was for his daughter. Gingrich said then he was ``incensed that the fact that I helped my daughter by co-signing, or signing the note, or whatever one calls it, gets drug out and becomes a story.'' He said Alexander's decision to include his daughter's mortgage in the complaint ``carries politics in the House to a new low level. I mean it just strikes me as madness.'' The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, as the ethics panel is formally known, never voted to hold an investigation of Gingrich, an outspoken conservative. But it took the unusual step of hiring a Chicago law firm to advise members on whether to proceed with the case. Late last year, the firm _ the same one that investigated Wright for the committee _ reportedly recommended that the panel not proceed against Gingrich. Alexander's original complaint in April 1989 focused on a limited partnership Gingrich created in 1984 to promote ``Window of Opportunity,'' a book written by the lawmaker, his wife and a third author. The ``COS Limited Partnership'' was made up of 21 individuals who each put up $5,000 to promote the book. Gingrich was not an investor, but his wife was paid more than $10,000 for running the business. The complaint contended the $105,000 raised by the partnership could be considered income to Gingrich, in violation of House limits on members' outside earnings. Or, it said, it could constitute a gift to Gingrich, in violation of a rule prohibiting members from accepting substantial gifts from anyone with a direct interest in legislation. The second complaint, filed in October, charged Gingrich with a long list of campaign finance and financial disclosure violations.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Prisoners Escape from California Jail
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen prisoners used hacksaws on window bars to escape from a jail section reserved for serious felony offenders, and 12 remained free this morning, authorities said. The South Bay Detention Facility inmates sawed their way through the bars Wednesday night, kicked out the plexiglass window and lowered themselves 30 to 40 feet to the ground on a rope made of knotted bed sheets, sheriff's Sgt. Jim Cooke said. The prisoners climbed up a brush-covered slope and scattered despite perimeter guards and remote security cameras, Cooke said. Sheriff's deputies said jail officials did not know how the inmates got the hacksaws. One inmate was captured minutes later hiding in the back of a pickup truck heading out of the area, said sheriff's Sgt. Roy Stamper. A second inmate was picked up by police while walking along a street near the jail. Police stopped and searched a trolley headed for the U.S.-Mexican border, but found no fugitives on board. Other officers chased handfuls of fugitives through the dark hills to the east of the jail, normally the scene of thousands of crossings nightly by undocumented aliens. The escaped inmates were wearing jail-issue blue pullover shirts and blue pants each bearing the stencil ``SD Jail,'' or were wearing pale green unmarked T-shirts. In early December, seven inmates slipped out of the same jail through a six-inch slatted window after greasing their bodies with lotion and climbing the 40 feet on a rope made of sheets. Five are still free.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Seeks Foreign Help to Stop Libyan Chemical Weapon Production
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The White House is urging ``vigorous action'' to shut down a plant in Libya believed to be producing chemical weapons. A West German official said quantities produced so far are small but enough to cause concern. Marlin Fitzwater, chief spokesman for President Bush, said that a plant located at Rabta, about 60 miles south of Tripoli, apparently is producing poison gas. U.S. officials said the plant was making limited quantities of mustard gas and nerve agents. ``Rabta is dangerous and becoming more so,'' Fitzwater said Wednesday. ``This points to the necessity for heightened international vigilance of Libyan procurement activities and for vigorous efforts to stop the operation of Rabta.'' In Bonn, Norbert Gansel, a lawmaker from the opposition Social Democratic Party, said today West Germany also has evidence the plant has begun making deadly gas in small quantities but enough to cause concern. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has proposed that the European Economic Community seek international inspections of the factory. Washington has replied by saying it wants the plant closed for good, a West German government source said. ``The Bush administration wants to dismantle the factory, but with our diplomatic means we don't have the possibility to do that,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anomyity. Another West German government official said Genscher has proposed that the EEC ask North African nations to bring pressure for international inspections on short notice. Officials said Washington has not rejected the initiative. Fitzwater, asked today to predict the life expectancy of Rabta, said, ``We hope two nanoseconds.'' A nanosecond is one billionth of a second. Fitzwater refused to exclude the possibility of a military strike to knock out the plant. ``We don't rule out anything,'' he said. However, Fitzwater also suggested the plant could be closed if foreign suppliers denied it the raw materials needed to produce chemical weapons. ``The international community should step up its efforts to deny Libya the ability to continue operating the plant,'' he said. Chemical weapons are relatively cheap to produce and hard to detect. Libya is one of about two dozen countries considered capable of or actually producing poison gas. The latest U.S. charges underscore the hostile relationship between the United States and Libyan dictator Moammar Gadhafi. Tensions reached a crisis point in 1986 when the Reagan administration ordered that Tripoli be bombed. Fitzwater, asked what he meant by ``vigorous action,'' said, ``We aren't willing to speculate on what specific efforts, but nothing is ruled out.'' He would not comment on the type or quantity of weapons being produced. ``Any amount is a major threat,'' he said. Gadhafi's regime has ``a history of terrorism activities and a history of erratic military behavior,'' Fitzwater said. ``And therefore, that is the most immediate threat.'' In 1988, the United States raised concerns about Rabta and persuaded West German companies and other foreign suppliers to stop providing technical assistance. U.S. officials said then that Libya had stopped work on Rabta before reaching full production but maintained an assembly line. Fitzwater said production resumed recently, and West German politicians have said that Libya had produced enough gas for 1,000 artillery shells. Fitzwater declined to discuss which countries were supplying chemicals to Libya. ``We certainly would urge all countries to survey their internal situation, inventory their chemical production facilities and to make their own judgments that they are not a source for any of these chemicals. ``We don't really know how the chemicals are getting there or where they are coming from,'' Fitzwater said. ``But there are so many routes, again I urge you not to focus on who's giving them chemicals, but to focus on Mr. Gadhafi and Libya.'' Gadhafi, who has steadfastly denied Libya was producing chemical weapons, says the plant was designed to produce pharmaceutical drugs. JANA, the Libyan news agency, said in a dispatch that an unnamed official source at the Libyan foreign ministry ``disclaimed'' reports that Libya has produced ``quantities of chemical weapons in (the) Rabta medicine factory.'' The source, according to JANA, contended that ``such allegations aired at present by some media circles aim at creating a state of suspicion'' in light of efforts by Libya and other Arab-African nations toward economic and political unity.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Einstein Film Lost by Delivery Truck is Recovered
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 4,000 feet of irreplaceable film on Albert Einstein that fell from a delivery truck last week was found and returned to the University of South Carolina's film library. The film was discovered by a resident on a downtown street, along with three other packages from the truck. The university said it was notified Wednesday. ``We're absolutely elated to have this film back. Historically, it's irreplaceable,'' said Glenn Smith, head of the film library. The newsreel film, which has historical value to researchers, shows the physicist appearing at various events during the 1930s. The university was shipping the film for copying onto videotape when it was lost.

DOC.HEAD: German Leader Discusses Reunification with NATO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with talks over, Kohl comments. Pickup 14th, `Western officials...
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany met today with the NATO allies and said he reassured them that their concerns will be considered in the drive to reunify the two Germanys. ``Nobody has to be concerned that the Germans would one way or the other want to go it alone,'' he told reporters after a nearly three-hour meeting at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters. NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner, a former German defense minister, described the talks as ``very intensive, constructive, fruitful and lively.'' He said the visit opened a formal series of consultations within NATO on German unification and related security issues. It will be synchronized with talks between the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II powers _ Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union. Kohl met first with Woerner and then with the ambassadors of the 16 alliance nations. ``What is happening in Germany at present must be embedded in the overall developments, the ongoing developments in Europe,'' he said at a news conference afterward. ``German interests must be taken into account,'' he said, ``but also the interests of all our friends and partners and neighbors in East and West must be taken into account.'' ``This means we need to have talks constantly, that we need to consult very closely and that we need to cooperate very closely,'' he said. ``That was the idea behind my visit. We shall pursue this practice of talking with one another at all necessary and possible levels.'' The trip was apparently prompted by complaints from smaller countries in the Atlantic alliance about having no say in discussions on the future of the two Germanys and how a new state would fit into the Western military alliance. One NATO official described the visit as ``damage limitation.'' ``He's going to be moaned to by the little guys ... He's coming here because people have been complaining quite loudly,'' he said before the talks began. The decision of the World War II Allies to meet separately to discuss German unity has angered officials in Italy, Belgium and the Netherlands. Under the ``two-plus-four'' process, the two German states also will gather after March 18 elections in East Germany to discuss their future. Western officials have repeatedly stressed that the unified state must remain in NATO, but Soviet officials have insisted it be neutral. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev reiterated on Tuesday opposition to NATO membership for the new German state. ``We cannot agree to that. It is absolutely out of the question,'' he said, according to the Tass news agency. East Germany is a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, and more than 380,000 Soviet troops are stationed on its soil. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany has proposed a formula that would keep the future state in NATO but only the territory of West Germany would be tied to its military structure. NATO troops would not extend into East Germany. NATO officials have previously said Soviet troops could temporarily remain on the territory of what is now East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Adopts Polish Border Guarantee Resolution After Raucous Debate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 4-5 pvs, `Kohl had....European house.' to UPDATE with Kohl reassuring NATO allies in Brussels. Pickup 6th, `Kohl, apparently...'
DOC.TEXT:
Parliament today adopted a resolution calling for a united Germany to honor Poland's western border after a raucous debate marked by charges that Chancellor Helmut Kohl had endangered the unification process. The resolution states that the two Germanys should adopt identical declarations saying, ``The Polish people are assured that their right to live in secure borders will not be questioned by us Germans through territorial claims either now or in the future.'' It further says that the future government of a united Germany should sign a border treaty on the basis of those declarations. After the Parliament session, Kohl traveled to Brussels, Belgium, to meet with NATO allies. He said he reassured them that their concerns will be considered in the drive to reunify the two Germanys. ``Nobody has to be concerned that the Germans would one way or the other want to go it alone,'' he told reporters after a nearly three-hour meeting at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters. Kohl had come under fire abroad and at home for his previous reluctance to unequivocally state that a united Germany would never lay claim to land ceded to Poland after the Third Reich's 1945 defeat. In Parliament today, one lawmaker from the opposition Social Democrats, Juergen Schmude, said Kohl's handling of the border issue had amounted to ``political arson in the European house.''
Kohl, apparently trying to avoid offending conservative voters before federal elections in December, had insisted that only the government of a united Germany could address the matter. His demands that a border treaty be linked to Polish concessions also caused an uproar, and he withdrew them earlier this week while at the same time proposing the resolution passed today. In today's parliamentary debate, the opposition Social Democrats charged that Kohl's pronouncements had seriously endangered the unification process. Party chief Hans-Jochen Vogel said ``seldom has a federal chancellor ... so mishandled'' his responsibilities to West Germans ``as Chancellor Kohl in the last days and weeks.'' Vogel charged that Kohl's pronouncements on the matter had ``squandered (international) trust of the German people, which is now needed more urgently than ever so that our neighbors do not reject the unification process.'' In his own address, Kohl battled back by pointing out the Social Democrats' contacts with East Germany's now-disgraced Communist Party in past years. ``The Social Democrats' contribution to the German politics (unification matters) in the last years can been characterized as simply pathetic,'' he charged. Kohl also seemed to address concerns by Moscow that he is trying to make unification occur too quickly. ``We are producing no artificial time pressures in order to speed up unification,'' said Kohl. He repeated that a united Germany must be a member of the NATO alliance, which the Soviets have consistently rejected. But he also reiterated that what is now East Germany could have a special military status in a united Germany, with NATO troops barred from being stationed there. Kohl also rejected fears that a united Germany could become a too-mighty presence in Europe. ``No one needs to be worried about a German dominance in the European Community. A united Germany would also be a reliable and solid partner,'' Kohl said.

DOC.HEAD: Post Card Arrives 56 Years Late
DOC.TEXT: A woman has received a postcard from her father nearly 56 years after it was mailed, and more than 40 years after he died, the Post Office said Thursday. Dorothy Horton, 73, of Stroud in western England, said she instantly recognized the writing of her father, Bill, on the early color postcard, dated June 20, 1934. The post card was found behind old closets last week during refurbishment of the Stroud sorting office, a Post Office spokeswoman said. Mrs. Horton was then 17-year-old Dorothy Meadows, but old-timers at the sorting office remembered the name and were able to trace her, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Canada to Hear U.S. Appeal on Extradition of McVey
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 4 grafs at end to ADD details on U.S. extradition appeal, that McVey also facing investigation regarding entry into Canada.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the United States' appeal for the extradition of Charles McVey, who is accused of selling computer secrets to the Soviet Union. The United States has been trying to extradite McVey, 65, since August 1987 when he was arrested while on a fishing trip in the Canadian Yukon community of Teslin. At that time, he had been a fugitive for four years. McVey once ran a computer export business in Orange Country, Calif. U.S. indictments in 1983 and 1987 accuse him of smuggling computer technology to the Soviets. If convicted, sentences could total 125 years, according to U.S. officials. In November, the British Columbia Court of Appeal ruled McVey could not be extradited because the charges against him in California do not constitute an offense under the Canada-U.S. extradition treaty. In its application to appeal to the Supreme Court, the United States argued the appeals court erred in deciding that an extradition crime must be an offense listed in the extradition treaty. McVey faces more than 30 charges on the two separate indictments related to the alleged shipment of Saxpy Matrix-1 supercomputer technology to the Soviet Union. Even if the U.S. extradition efforts fail, McVey still could be deported by the Canadian government. An immigration hearing in Vancouver is looking into the documents and information that McVey used to enter Canada in 1987 and trying to determine if he stayed longer than permitted.

DOC.HEAD: Armani, Ferre Go Their Own Way
DOC.TEXT: The general trend presented in Milan this week during the Italian fall-winter 1990-91 ready-to-wear collection is ultra-short and sporty. But two designers never known to follow the fashion pack, Gianfranco Ferre and Giorgio Armani, went their own way, showing discreet hemlines and more town than country clothes. Ferre, who also designs for Dior in Paris, presents a woman used to living in the lap of luxury. The gold theme is threaded throughout his collection, appearing from the early hours of the morning in gray mohair sweaters painted with gold to be worn over flannel sweat pants. This theme becomes ever more opulent as the day goes on with rich gold embroidery on silk brocade jackets and coats for the cocktail hour, and shimmery gold evening gowns for the grande soiree. The Ferre skirt stops a discreet inch above the knee and the elegant hemline is enhanced by the simplicity of the footwear: suede or silk moderately heeled pumps. The overall look is closer to couture than ready to wear, and definitely separates itself from the myriad of fast-fashion mini skirts, knit body suits, ski jackets and thigh boots that have permeated the Milan runway this week. Ferre did indulge in a series of gold leather parkas with fur trim, which looked a bit much on the runway but are sure to be a hit on the slopes of Vail or Gstaad. Ferre says he wanted to ``interpret Oriental themes in a European context.'' The Oriental theme is evident in his choice of palette _ lots of blue, yellow and multicolored porcelain prints _ the heavy use of gold brocade, of satin and velvet, and the robed styles in jackets and coats. Giorgio Armani also looks to the Orient for inspiration for his fall-winter 1990-91 collection, particularly in his evening wear. Armani, whose day wear with its tailored suits and multitude of jackets in super soft tweeds, has become a trademark of the ``moda Milanese,'' has for several seasons concentrated on evening to give the Armani woman an around-the-clock choice of outfits. His after-five wear for next winter is more feminine and flattering than ever. Delicate gold lace, velvet embroidered with graceful silk flowers, tiny pearl passamenterie, the softest of silk printed in dainty porcelain prints, all combine to create an image of fragile beauty, like a Ming vase. The shape too is vase-like, with a tiny velvet richly embroidered blouse with high collar and long sleeves creating a narrow bodice to the flowing silk printed skirt or pajama pants below. The new Armani jacket is longer than ever reaching far below the hip, often with a rounded lapel and silk cord belt like a Chinese robe. Other jackets have no lapel, are loose and close in a single button at the shoulder. Like Ferre, the Armani skirt is a good many inches longer than the rest of the Milan runway _ never more than several inches above the knee. The hemline is rounded and has an unfinished look to it, a style he introduced several seasons ago. Armani says his aim is to let women ``choose their own direction, without falling into the trap of trendiness.'' Along with his new feminine look, Armani proposes a series of man-tailored outfits, to satisfy the woman that identifies his style with the transposition of menswear into women's clothing. The new Armani pant suit in ultra light wool tweeds inspired by silk tie patterns, has a longer jacket, with narrower shoulders but a wider rounded base. The trousers are baggy and cuffed; a masculine shirt with mandarine collar completes the outfit. Coats play heavily in the new collection. They are either full and super-long with plush lining or long slim military coats closed at the waist by a brown leather silver buckled belt. Armani made yet another fashion statement Wednesday night, at the end of his much applauded collection presented in the theater of his downtown Milan headquarters. For the first time in memory, he appeared on the runway to take a bow in jacket and tie, as opposed to the usual casual sweater, throwing down the gauntlet to fellow designer Gianni Versace, who during the men's collections in January decreed the death of the tie. Versace took his runway bow earlier in the week in a polo shirt.

DOC.HEAD: Anniversary of Martial Law Passes Under Tight Security
DOC.TEXT: Lhasa residents passed the first anniversary of martial law Thursday under heavy security, and there were no reports of renewed protests by Tibetan nationalists. Authorities felt confident enough of their control to allow Tibet's strongly nationalist Buddhist monks to hold a major prayer festival, Moinlam Qenmo, which has been the occasion of anti-Chinese protests in the past. The 10-day festival, which began last week, draws hundreds of monks to Lhasa's ancient Jokhang Temple. Last year, Chinese authorities canceled the festival for fear of unrest, but Tibetans held a small march anyway. Police opened fire, triggering three days of violent clashes that ended when martial law took effect March 8. It was the fourth bloody confrontation with Tibetan nationalists since 1987. Lhasa authorities, who have tightly restricted tourism to the remote city in the past year, made sure even fewer foreigners would be there this week. Travel agents in Chengdu, the main gateway to Lhasa, said no new tour groups were being allowed in from March 1 until March 15. One of the few foreigners in Lhasa, speaking on condition of anonymity, said by telephone that the city appeared quiet Thursday. Sporadic reports in recent weeks indicate that authorities stepped up already tight security in anticipation of the anniversary. The People's Armed Police, a paramilitary force, paraded through the city center on Feb. 20. The local radio said thousands of police, a column of armored cars and other vehicles took part in the parade, held to ``display their majestic appearance.'' A special team was sent into a leading monastery, Ganden, to ``weed out rioters,'' according to another official report. Police also said they arrested six people for alleged separatist activities and seized several guns, bullets, separatist leaflets and banned Tibetan flags. The official Xinhua News Agency said the government shipped half a ton of butter to Lhasa for last month's celebration of Tibetan New Year in an apparent effort to placate the public. Tibetans use butter in tea and burn it in candles at religious shrines. At the same time, authorities issued stern warnings against renewed protests. ``We must fully maintain our vigilance,'' the local radio quoted Tibetan Communist Party Secretary Hu Jintao as saying. ``If those separatist elements dare to stir up trouble again, we will resolutely strike a heavy blow at them.'' China claims sovereignty over Tibet dating back to the 13th century. But there were long periods when Tibet had virtually no contact with China, and nationalists say it was actually independent. China's Red Army entered in 1950. The Chinese set up communes, closed monasteries and for years banned traditional religious and cultural activies. In the 1980s China reopened several monasteries, but many Tibetans remain bitter. Small-scale protests have continued despite martial law. In September, a small group of Buddhist nuns shouted pro-independence slogans during a festival and were arrested immediately. When Tibet's exiled religious leader, the Dalai Lama, won the Nobel Peace Prize in October, Tibetans showed their joy by making ritual offerings of barley flour outside the Jokhang.

DOC.HEAD: Tugboat and Oiler Collide, Leaving Hole but No Spill or Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A tugboat collided with a 38,100-ton Navy oiler Thursday as the oil-laden vessel set out for Europe. There were no reports of injuries or spilled oil, but the collision left a 3-by-5-foot hole in the oiler's hull more than 8 feet above the waterline, the Navy said. The accident occurred around 8:30 a.m. as the Savannah was being pushed by a Navy tugboat from a Norfolk Naval Station pier into the Elizabeth River channel, said Lt. Cmdr. John Lloyd, a spokesman for the Norfolk-based Atlantic Fleet Surface Force. From there, the Savannah was to join up with the carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower and 13 other ships for a routine six-month battle group deployment in the Mediterranean. The Savannah, a 659-foot vessel with a crew of about 450, can carry up to 8.8 million gallons of fuel. It also carries 600 tons of munitions, 200 tons of dry stores and 100 tons of refrigerated stores. Lloyd said the ship was taken to an anchorage area in Hampton Roads across from the naval station, where an engineering team was assessing the damage. No decision had been made on whether the Savannah could be repaired in time to rejoin the battle group.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds Policy on Abortion in Foreign Aid
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled that the Reagan administration acted within the Constitution when in 1984 it barred family planning aid to private foreign organizations that perform abortions. ``It is within the executive branch's plenary authority over foreign affairs to disassociate the United States completely from foreign organizations based upon their views or activities,'' U.S. District Judge John Walker said in a decision Wednesday. Walker made the finding in dismissing a lawsuit by the Planned Parenthood Federation of America challenging the policy. The policy, which was adopted by the Agency for International Development in 1984 and continued under President Bush, requires that foreign private health agencies, in return for American grants, certify that they did not perform or actively promote abortion as a method of family planning. Planned Parenthood, which assists private foreign agencies, had charged that the policy was a violation of their First Amendment right to advocate abortion and interfered with the rights of privacy of people seeking family planning information. Roger Evans, Planned Parenthood's director of litigation, said the organization would appeal the judge's ruling. The ruling was the second time Walker had dismissed the lawsuit. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals sent the lawsuit back to Walker, saying he must decide the constitutional questions of free speech and free association of American workers overseas who are affected by the policy.

DOC.HEAD: Snowstorm Turns to Freezing Rain As It Moves Eastward
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th, `About 130...' to UPDATE with school bus accident.
DOC.TEXT: A storm that buried parts of Colorado and Wyoming under 4 feet of snow turned into freezing rain as it moved eastward, snapping power lines and turning roadways into ice rinks. Half the homes in Des Moines, Iowa, were without power today. The snow cleanup was expected to get easier today, with temperatures expected to soar into the 50s. ``When you step off the curb, you're probably going to step into a slush pile,'' Craig Sanders, forecaster for the National Weather Service said Wednesday night in Cheyenne, Wyo. About 130 miles of interstate highway were still closed in Wyoming early today as crews tried to clear snow drifts and abandoned cars. The storm dumped up to 50 inches of snow in parts of northern Colorado and shut down travel from the Denver area to southeastern Wyoming. South of the snow belt, the weather system produced as much as 7 inches of rain overnight in parts of Arkansas, and a school bus was swept off a flooded road and into a rain-swollen ditch today near Cabot, northeast of Little Rock, Lonoke County officials said. Students had to be rescued by pontoon boat but none was injured, said dispatcher Barbara Eddy. The fierce storm, driven by winds up to 50 mph, was blamed for at least one traffic death in Colorado, and some highways were closed and littered with stuck and stalled vehicles Wednesday. The freezing rain moved into Iowa, Nebraska, South Dakota, Wisconsin and Minnesota, coating power lines, roads and tree limbs and knocking out electricity. ``It's just like an ice skating rink on the interstate,'' said Bob Gantz, a mechanic for Dave's Auto Repair in Ankeny, Iowa. ``The patrolmen couldn't even stand up on the pavement to direct traffic.'' Hundreds of schools closed or opened late today in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. Snow and sleet became mixed with rain early today, with an inch or two of snow reported in parts of central Minnesota, the weather service said. ``Definitely (I) wouldn't want to travel today if I didn't have to,'' said forecaster Bill Harrison of the National Weather Service in Minneapolis. Half of the village of Hemingford in the Nebraska Panhandle lost electricity Wednesday, as branches fell on power lines. ``It sounds like we have a lot of lumberjacks outside,'' said Peggy Reynold, administrator in the village of 1,023. At least 90,000 Iowa Power customers in central Iowa were without electricity today, and company spokesman John McCarroll said it may be the largest winter outage in the company's history. Schools were closed for the first time this winter in Des Moines. Police said nearly every street in Des Moines was closed or partly closed at some point by downed lines or fallen limbs. Thick fog covered the city early today, cutting visibility during morning rush-hour traffic. Commuters in Colorado today faced slush-covered highways, still strewn with abandoned vehicles. The public transit system in Denver was back on schedule today, after cancellation of up to 30 bus routes Wednesday. But at least two school districts decided to keep all schools closed for another day. Snow continued to fall overnight in southern Wyoming, northern Colorado and southwest Nebraska. Freezing rain extended from north-central Nebraska across parts of South Dakota, the southern half of Minnesota and parts of Iowa. Rain and a few thunderstorms reached from western Wisconsin across western Illinois, and parts of Iowa, Missouri, Nebraska, Kansas, Arkansas, Mississippi, Alabama, Tennessee and Kentucky. The heavy ice brought opportunities as well. In Webster City, Iowa, a 74-year-old man startled patrons of a truck stop by whizzing around the parking lot on a 50-year-old pair of hockey skates. ``It's the best skating I've had all winter,'' said Elmer Clare.

DOC.HEAD: DEA: Rolls-Royce Swapped for Cocaine
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents have arrested a man for allegedly swapping his Rolls-Royce for 4{ pounds of cocaine. Robert E. Cole negotiated with an undercover agent to trade his 1967 Rolls for nearly 4{ pounds of cocaine, according to affidavits filed by the Drug Enforcement Administration. Agents said Cole traded the car's title for the cocaine Tuesday and was immediately arrested in his home. He was charged with possession with intent to ditribute more than 500 grams of cocaine. Cole appeared before a federal magistrate Wednesday and was released on $25,000 bail.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer in Replacement of Damaged Hips Dies at 80
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Otto Aufranc, a pioneer in the surgical replacement of damaged hips, has died following a lengthy illness. He was 80. Aufranc, who died Wednesday, helped develop the first replacement hip in the United States and designed surgical tools for its insertion in patients, officials at New England Baptist Hospital said. Aufranc was head of the orthopedics department at the Boston hospital for 14 years, beginning in 1969. In addition to his surgical practice, he trained hundreds of surgeons, the hospital said. A native of Missouri, Aufranc graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1934. He was trained in orthopedics at Children's Hospital and Massachusetts General Hospital. ``Hip surgery has evolved to where it is today because of Dr. Aufranc's contributions and teachings,'' hospital president Raymond C. McAfoose said in a statement. ``His guidance and expertise will be sorely missed.''

DOC.HEAD: Astrophysicist Expert in Elements of Sun Dies
DOC.TEXT: Charlotte M. Sitterly, an astrophysicist who discovered one of the unstable elements in sunlight, has died of heart failure. Mrs. Sitterly, who was 91, died in her Washington home last Saturday. She was considered one of the world's foremost authorities on the composition of the sun. Her discovery of technetium, an element, changed scientific explanations of conditions in the sun's interior. Her research focused on the study of the sun's spectrum, including short-wavelengths that could not penetrate the atmosphere and could only be observed from rockets. She was born Charlotte Emma Moore in Ercildoun in Chester County, Pa. and married Bancroft Walker Sitterly, a colleague at the Princeton University Observatory, in 1937. They had no children, and he is deceased. Mrs. Sitterly was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate in mathematics from Swarthmore College in 1920. She earned her doctorate from the University of California at Berkeley, writing a thesis on the spectra of sunspots. She worked as an astrophysicist with the Department of Commerce's Bureau of National Standards and wrote many works on solar and atomic spectra. Mrs. Sitterly was cited as one of the first recipients of the Federal Woman's Award and was the first woman elected as a foreign associate by the Royal Astronomical Society of London in 1949.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Panel To Seek Immunity For Former Pierce Aide
DOC.TEXT: House investigators will seek a grant of immunity for a onetime aide of Samuel R. Pierce Jr., seeking testimony that Pierce made politically tainted contract awards as housing secretary in the Reagan administration, sources said Thursday. The former Department of Housing and Urban Development official, Dubois Gilliam, is serving a federal prison sentence for a conviction in a HUD-related case. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the employment and housing panel of the Government Operations Committee would ask a federal court to grant Gilliam immunity from prosecution for any crimes he might discuss during congressional testimony. Pierce has refused to testify to the subcommittee. He is also being investigated by an independent counsel to determine whether there was illegal activity in the awarding of grants under a HUD rehabilitation program. Several former Pierce aides have refused to testify before the subcommittee, citing their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination. Among them was Deborah Dean, Pierce's former top aide. The panel considered seeking a grant of immunity to compel her testimony but then dropped the idea. A HUD source described the move with Gilliam as a breakthrough, saying he ``knows everything.'' Pierce has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing and has accused the subcommittee of targeting him despite evidence to support his position. The independent counsel, former federal judge Alvin Adams, met with subcommittee chairman Tom Lantos, D-Calif., this week and said he would not object if the subcommittee sought immunity for Gilliam, the sources said. Pierce attorney Paul L. Perito said he questioned whether Gilliam would provide truthful testimony or merely seek to curry support for a reduced sentence. Perito also objected to the development on grounds it could interfere with the independent counsel's review. Gilliam was a deputy assistant secretary in HUD's community planning and development office, a post that gave him oversight of Urban Development Action Grants and a technical assistance program paid for through discretionary funds. Subcommittee aides recently visited him at the California prison where he is serving an 18-month sentence, and the sources said he could provide testimony about the role of Pierce in contract awards. Former HUD officials described Gilliam as a trusted Pierce aide who was in line to become the secretary's executive assistant. Agency documents show many funding requests were routed through Gilliam. A 1986 internal audit of the technical assistance program roundly criticized its administration, saying most contracts were for proposals that had been sent to HUD unsolicited, often were approved although incomplete or unnecessary and then were financed at levels that allowed exorbitant overhead costs. An Associated Press review of the program last year found that among the grant recipients was the Match Institution, a company headed by a man Pierce had picked to head a black Republican panel set up to advise Reagan. Also benefiting from the program was a company called One America Inc., whose president once served as chairwoman of the GOP group, the Council of 100. Also receiving technical assistance funding was a Mississippi company called Pro-Mark, whose owner had a longstanding association with Gilliam. Both One America and Pro-Mark first received technical assistance grants during Gilliam's tenure, which ended in early 1988. HUD documents show One America President Elaine B. Jenkins wrote Gilliam several times seeking additional grants. Pierce, in his final days in office, signed contracts making new grants to both One America and Pro-Mark, according to HUD documents and interviews. But those contracts were canceled by HUD Secretary Jack Kemp shortly after he took over for Pierce. Gilliam was quoted in The New York Times as saying Pierce ordered him to give a $300,000 grant to a longtime Pierce friend, Samuel Singletary, who had managed Pierce's unsuccessful campaigns for a New York judgeship. Pierce's order overruled agency officials who had recommended rejection of the proposal, Gilliam said. Gilliam, as part of a plea agreement in the Mississippi case, pleaded guilty to accepting cash gifts from a HUD contractor and conspiring to use a HUD grant for personal gain.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Say Millions of Youngsters Face Lead Dangers
DOC.TEXT: Despite efforts to reduce lead in the environment, millions of American children have levels of lead in their blood that could cause health problems, a government official told Congress Thursday. Dr. Vernon N. Houk, director of environmental health for the federal Centers for Disease Control, said lead exposure is ``devastating'' to the developing brains and nervous systems of fetuses and young children. Experts have steadily reduced their estimate of blood lead levels that have toxic effects, so that blood lead levels that cause concern for young children today _ 10 to 15 micrograms per deciliter _ are one-sixth the levels of concern in the 1960s and before, Houk said. ``Today in the United States, millions of children from all geographic areas and socioeconomic strata have blood lead levels high enough to cause adverse health effects,'' he said. Houk was joined by other federal health and housing officials, private health advocates and lead industry officials in discussing the toxic effects of lead before the Senate Environment and Public Works subcommittee on toxic substances, environmental oversight, research and development. Dr. Ellen K. Silbergeld, a scientist with the New York-based Environmental Defense Fund, cited federal estimates in 1988 that nearly three million children under the age of 6 have lead levels considered dangerous. She said her group estimated 50 percent of children under 6 are affected by lead from lead-based paint, and 90 percent of urban minority poor children may be affected. Lead has been used in paints, gasoline, solders, batteries and other products. Many uses have been decreased or eliminated, such as lead in gasoline and in paints. But lead continues to be used some areas and remains in the environment in existing paints, plumbing systems, and in dust and soils, said Victor J. Kimm, deputy assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's office of pesticides and toxic substances. Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev., said the estimates of exposure in children are alarming and called for increased federal efforts to regulate and clean up lead in the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Subway Train Derails, Killing Three and Injuring at Least 160
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 1st and SUBS 10th graf, `All three...' with one graf to UPDATE with today's developments.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PX2, PX3
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators focused on a motor found hanging loose under a subway car as they looked for the cause of a derailment that peeled open a train ``like a sardine can,'' killing three people and injuring 162. The subway line, which normally serves 100,000 riders per day, was out of service today. Transit employees used bullhorns to direct passengers to and from 97 buses temporarily assigned to the east-west city streets above the empty tunnel. Police lined the bus routes to keep traffic moving during the morning rush. News reports citing unidentified sources said the dragging electric motor may have hit a switch and caused the train to jump the tracks Wednesday, and passengers reported bumping and a ``bam, bam, bam'' before the accident. The train smashed into three support beams during the morning rush hour, trapping victims for up to five hours. A surgeon who took part in the rescue, Dr. Jina Joder, said she used a paramedic's buck knife to cut the leg off a dead man to free a victim beneath him. Officials said it was the worst accident in the 21 years the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority has operated the regional commuter system, whose trains run underground downtown and above ground in outlying areas. National Transportation Safety Board member John Lauber said late Wednesday that one end of the motor had separated from the train and that railroad ties leading up to the accident scene were chipped. Lauber said his agency is investigating whether the broken motor was a cause or effect of the accident. Russell Gober, NTSB investigator in charge, said he had not yet checked the maintenance and inspection records of the car. ``I was in the first car and as we went through the station, you could hear the train hit something, like something was dragging. It went bam, bam, bam,'' said Mark Robinson, who was en route home from an overnight cashier's job. ``The second and third cars were bent and the whole side of the second car was torn off,'' Robinson said. ``It was peeled like a sardine can.'' Doctors amputated the right leg of one woman to free her from the wreckage, but she died four hours later of complications from a second broken leg and severe chest injuries, said Hahnemann University Hospital spokeswoman Linda Clossey. All three of the dead were among seven passengers trapped in the wreckage, authorities said. Of the 162 people treated at 10 hospitals, two remained in critical condition this morning. More than 100 were treated and released. ``People were screaming,'' said passenger Robert Rogers. ``It was dark and people were going left and right and were falling off the tracks and stuff.'' Lauber said the NTSB hadn't seen any reason to order other cars pulled off the subway line, which serves about 100,000 riders a day. ``If in the course of the investigation, we run into anything that demands immediate attention, we would issue an emergency recommendation,'' he said. Louis Gambaccini, the transit authority's general manager, said the cars on the line are about 30 years old and there had been no indication of problems. He said the cars have been well maintained but that the entire fleet will be inspected. However, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today that bolts holding the motors in place have broken before and that the transit agency tried to solve the problem by bracing the motors with a bar under them. A preliminary inspection indicated there was no danger of a cave-in of the subway tunnel, said transit inspector James Sweeney. The city medical examiner's office identified one of the dead as Denise Devlin, 34, of Philadelphia. The name of a 52-year-old Philadelphia man was withheld until his family could be notified, and a third victim, a 60-year-old woman, could not immediately be identified.

DOC.HEAD: Former RI Senator, State GOP Chairman, Dead at 93
DOC.TEXT: William Jesson Thompson, a Rhode Island state senator for 12 years and former chairman of the state's Republican Party, died of complications from a fall. He was 93. Thompson began his Senate career in the early 1930s and ran the state GOP for five years afterward, said his wife, Regina. He moved to Boca Raton in 1954, opened a real estate officer and later served as president of the Boca Realtors Association. In addition to his wife, Thompson, who died Monday, is survived by his stepson Paul W. Crowley Jr. of Dearborn, Mich., and five grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Skinner Unveil Transportation Policy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 6-10, Sen. James, with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced today a new transportation policy that calls for more user fees, toll roads and local government help. He said it would help keep America ``the world leader in transportation.'' Bush and Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner unveiled the long-awaited policy, ``Moving America Into The 21st Century, '' to members of Congress and industry officials, many of whom already had found reason to criticize it. Its overall goal is to maintain the U.S. transportation system as ``the finest in the world.'' However, the report said ``there are increasing signs ... that the system is beginning to break down.'' ``If we work together in this joint venture, America can continue to be the world leader in transportation,'' Bush said. ``When transportation lags or is congested, when people and goods are stranded in traffic or in airports, they will suffer,'' Bush said. ``When people and goods flow through a responsive, well-maintained and efficient transportation system, our quality of life improves with it.'' Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., chairman of the Senate surface transportation subcommittee, said, ``I'm going to be looking through this to see whether or not this simply doesn't transfer the problems we have with the infrastructure as we head to the 21st century off the backs of the federal government and onto the backs of state and local governments.'' He questioned the administration's logic. ``They said today that moving people in a speedy fashion was obviously necessary while at the same time they're suggesting that we zero out all subsidies for Amtrak,'' Exon said. Rep. Norman Mineta, D-Calif., chairman of the House surface transportation subcommittee, called the proposal ``a good start'' but said the administration had failed to address ``the big question'' of funding. Shifting programs to the state and local level without financial resources ``would be the shift and the shaft,'' said Mineta. Rep. John Paul Hammerschmidt of Arkansas, the top Republican on the House subcommittee, said, ``I think the money has to come from users, one way or another, and because it is a national plan, the logical way for it to come from users is through a national tax system.'' A coalition of 16 aviation industry groups said it opposes Bush's proposed increases in aviation taxes, which the president's fiscal 1991 budget calls ``user fees.'' The American Public Transit Association said the policy was ``long on advice and short on help.'' The 129-page policy, published in a book with illustrations showing everything from a futuristic airplane to a traffic-clogged freeway, covered a wide range of issues affecting air, land and water transportation. Anyone looking for a far-reaching program such as the interstate highway system begun in the Eisenhower administration is likely to be disappointed. The policy statement outlined no strategy that would involve major federal funding beyond that already called for in the president's budget.
