It proposed that users, including airline passengers and motorists, pay more of the cost of building, maintaining and administering major transport systems. The policy set out six key goals: _Maintain and expand the nation's transportation system by shifting major responsibilities onto local governments and encouraging more private investment, while concentrating federal funding on projects of ``national significance.'' _Foster a ``sound financial base'' for transportation, emphasizing user fees ``as the key element to financing the federal share of transportation expenditures,'' as well as spending some of the billions of dollars in the aviation and highway trust funds. _Keep transportation businesses strong and competitive by deregulating the trucking industry and further deregulating other transportation sectors, including repealing railroad employee liability and retirement laws opposed by the rail industry. _Ensure that the transportation system supports public safety and national security. _Protect the environment and the quality of life by reducing pollution emissions by motor vehicles. _Advance U.S. transportation technology for the 21st century by encouraging research into high-speed rail, magnetically levitated trains, tiltrotor aircraft and ``intelligent'' vehicle and highway systems that use computers to increase safety and efficiency. Proposals that shift more of the cost to users are rising concerns in the aviation, mass transit and trucking industries. Skinner had described the policy to industry groups, and some people outside government saw drafts before it was released. The Transportation Department began working on the proposal shortly after Skinner took office early last year, holding 117 hearings in 48 cities to get suggestions The public transit group said, ``The administration's policy would give Uncle Sam junior partnership in the traditional intergovernmental alliance that has underwritten mass transit for more than 25 years,'' the group said in a statement. The Air Transport Association said it generally supported the new policy but opposed an airport head tax that is included. Bush called for such a fee, as well as other user charges, in his fiscal 1991 budget. ATA, which represents major airlines, also has been looking for clear national standards on noise levels at airports and a timetable for phasing out older, noisier airliners. Neither is found in the new policy. The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, speaking for thousands of private pilots, said the policy would have the federal government rely too much on state and local governments for improvements in aviation. The American Trucking Associations objected to Skinner's call for more toll roads and to the lack of a detailed plan for spending the $10 billion surplus in the highway trust fund, collected from federal gasoline taxes. Jerry Bastarache, spokesman for the Highway Users Federation, said the group generally likes the policy because it calls for greater capacity and highway improvements. But he said some areas cause concern, including toll roads and proposals for higher proportions of matching funds from local governments in Transportation Department projects.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached in AIDS Doctor Case
LaserPhoto NY27
DOC.TEXT: A settlement was reached today in a negligence lawsuit filed by a doctor who contends she contracted AIDS from a contaminated needle at a city hospital. The settlement came as closing arguments were scheduled to begin in the two-month-old trial in trial-level state Supreme Court. Dr. Veronica Prego sued the city's publicly funded Health and Hospitals Corp. and two physicians, charging negligence. Justice Aaron Bernstein directed lawyers not to disclose the terms. ``It's no one's business except the people who are paying it and the person who's receiving it,'' Bernstein said. Prego, 32, said she developed AIDS after pricking her finger in 1983 on a syringe left in a pile of gauze and bed linen at Kings County Hospital. She sued for $175 million in damages, but the figure later was dropped to allow a jury to decide damages. Prego accused her supervising intern of carelessly leaving the needle in the soiled refuse after drawing blood from an AIDS patient. But the intern testified that she did not take blood from the patient that night and was not in the room when Prego's injury occurred. City lawyers said Prego drew the blood herself. Prego also claimed in the lawsuit that another doctor violated her confidentiality in a study of health care workers who contracted AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Government Will Ban Over-the-Counter Prostate Drugs
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday it will ban the sale of all nonprescription drugs used to treat enlargement of the prostate gland. The agency said its review of these products found little evidence any of them eliminates, arrests or treats the condition, called benign prostatic hypertrophy. Surgery is currently the only effective treatment, the FDA said. The condition causes enlargement of the male gland, which can obstruct the flow of urine, create back pressure in the kidneys and cause urinary tract infections that are difficult to treat, the FDA said. The over-the-counter products, which contain the amino acids glycine, alanine and glutamic acid and a plant extract called sabal, can relieve some symptoms of the condition. However, their use also could lull men with the condition ``into a sense of false security,'' which could delay their getting proper treatment, the agency said. Few of these products are being sold today, the FDA said. About 50 percent to 80 percent of men with the condition will develop unstable bladders and have symptoms of frequency and urgency of urination. The FDA said the ban will take effect in six months. The agency's review of the products was part of its ongoing review of over-the-counter drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Heart Surgeon Dies from Complications of Heart Disease
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Robert J. Flemma, a surgeon who lead research into an artificial heart, died of heart diease. He was 56. Flemma, who died Wednesday at St. Luke's Medical Center, had predicted in August that a device known as the Milwaukee Heart would be available for human use in seven years. The device is to be a wholly implanted, electrically powered heart to aid patients with cardiomyopathy, the degenerative condition that led to Flemma's death. ``Bob had a vision of the ultimate value of an artificial instrument that could be used in situations not dissimilar to the one that led to his death,'' said Brenton H. Rupple, vice chairman of the Milwaukee Heart Research Foundation. Flemma said human hearts were in short supply and that a reliable mechanical device was needed for the thousands of patients who die while awaiting human heart transplants. He had been in Salt Lake City, awaiting a transplant at the University of Utah Hospital when he suffered cardiac arrest in January. After the attack, he was no longer considered a transplant candidate and never regained consciousness. Flemma, who lived in suburban River Hills, was a clinical professor of surgery at the Medical College of Wisconsin and University of Wisconsin Medical School. Survivors include his wife, Mary Ann, and six children. Funeral services are scheduled for Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: North To Testify That He ``Lied'' At Poindexter's Direction, Prosecutor Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs, edits thruout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North will testify that he ``lied ... lied ... lied'' to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair on instructions from John Poindexter, a prosecutor said today in opening statements at Poindexter's trial. ``North was not out there as a lone ranger over this multimillion-dollar enterprise'' to assist the Nicaraguan rebels, Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb told a jury of seven women and five men. ``Defendant John Poindexter was right in the middle of'' it. Webb told the jury that North, the government's leadoff witness, ``will tell you'' that after being ``instructed by Poindexter,'' he met with then-House intelligence committee chairman Lee Hamilton on Aug. 6, 1986. At that meeting, North ``was asked question after question'' about whether he was raising money and providing military assistance to the Contras, said Webb. ``Specific names were used, places.'' Webb, previewing North's upcoming testimony, said: ``He lied, he lied, he lied, one false statement after another.'' ``Every answer he gave is false. It worked like a charm,'' said Webb. Hamilton later told Poindexter to ``thank Nlegal gratuity. North's testimony was crucial to Iran-Contra prosecutors because it bolsters their assertion that Poindexter was trying to cover up from Congress his knowledge of a November 1985 shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran and North's covert military assistance to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Poindexter's lawyers contended that North's statements on both points were based on testimony that Poindexter gave to Congress in 1987 under a grant of immunity. Prosecutors disagreed. No part of a prosecutor's case may be derived from a defendant's immunized testimony. The government contends that Poindexter's knowledge of the existence of the finding was his motive in November 1986 for concealing from Congress the U.S. involvement in the missile shipment.

DOC.HEAD: Military Base Lease Talks Set for After Easter
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations to extend the stay of U.S. military bases were set for mid-April, and their success depends on how the United States explains aid cuts, the foreign secretary said Thursday. No specific agenda has been set for the preliminary talks, said Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus. ``This is an exploratory talk. We don't expect commitments,'' he said. ``We will have to assess the responses and attitudes of the U.S. government in order to help us arrive at our own decision.'' He said the Philippines is particularly interested in hearing the reasons why Congress cut $96 million in aid in January. Some Filipinos consider the reduction a violation of the October 1988 agreement under which the United States offered to give the Philippines about $962 million in the last two years of the 1947 Military Bases Agreement, which expires in 1991. About 2,000 members of militant feminist groups, marking International Women's Day, marched to the U.S. Embassy calling for the immediate dismantling of the six U.S. bases in the Philippines. Speaking at a rally in front of the embassy, Sister Mary John Mananzan, a Roman Catholic nun and head of the leftist Gabriela Women's Alliance, said the bases obstructed Philippine economic progress because they represented foreign control of the country. ``We say, `Out with the U.S. military bases so that we can achieve genuine development,''' she said. The United States maintains Clark Air Base, Subic Bay Naval Base and four other smaller facilities in the Philippines. A new bases treaty must be ratified by two-thirds of the Philippines' 23-member Senate, where opposition to the bases is strong. Also, many in the 195-member House of Representatives have urged President Corazon Aquino to postpone the talks until the aid is restored. Mrs. Aquino has refused to say publicly whether she supports extending the stay of the U.S. bases, but has agreed to talks. Meanwhile, a clandestine leftwing rebel umbrella group, the National Democratic Front, distributed a statement at the demonstration accusing Mrs. Aquino of being a puppet of the United States who has connived with other Filipino officials to keep the U.S. military bases in the Philippines. The Front, which includes the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines and its military arm, the New People's Army, urged Filipinos to take up arms and wage ``liberating violence'' against the ``criminal U.S. and its running dogs.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Blame Arson for Restaurant Fire That Killed 11
DOC.TEXT: Arson was the likely cause of a fire that swept through a downtown restaurant and killed 11 people, including four Americans, police said Thursday. Police first suspected that a gas leak in the kitchen may have caused the Wednesday night fire that gutted Koryo, a Chinese-Korean restaurant near Frankfurt's cathedral and the Zeil shopping district. ``Evidence now points more to arson,'' said police spokesman Manfred Fuellhardt after investigators searched the gutted restaurant. He said the fire broke out in a storage room, under the wooden stairs leading to the restaurant on the second floor of the five-story building. Smoke quickly filled the restaurant and some guests were injured when they jumped from windows to escape the flames, Fuellhardt said. He said the fire exit apparently was blocked. Fuellhardt said the victims suffocated. Seven people were injured, five of them seriously, police said. The dead included an American couple, both age 33, Fuellhardt said. Another police official, Franz Winkler, said two children, including the couple's 1{-year-old son, also died. The other child was an American girl of about 12 or 13, he said. Winkler said it was still not clear if the girl was the child of the couple, a relative or a friend out with them for the evening. Two of the couple's other children, a 4-year-old boy and a 6-year-old girl, suffered serious injuries, Winkler said. At least three of the dead were connected with U.S. forces stationed in West Germany, said U.S. Army spokeswoman Brigitte Schmitz. She declined to release their identities until relatives could be told. In addition to the Americans, the dead included three German women, a French woman and her British husband, a Korean man, and a person believed to be a restaurant employee.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Spy-Diplomat Asks for Review of Dismissal
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Service officer Felix Bloch, suspected of spying for the Soviet Union, has asked to appear before a diplomatic review board to appeal his dismissal as a security risk, the State Department said Thursday. Margaret Tutwiler, the department spokeswoman, said the appearance was requested by Bloch's attorney but no hearing date had been set. The department announced on Feb. 8 that Bloch, 54, had been suspended, his annual salary of $80,700 was being withheld and steps were being taken to fire him. The action was taken under provisions of a law permitting the suspension or dismissal of a federal employee ``in the interest of national security.'' Bloch had 30 days to file an appeal, which must be considered by a review board of Foreign Service officers. The three-person Foreign Service review board has the option of reinstating Bloch. But Ms. Tutwiler said: ``If he is not reinstated his employment will be terminated.'' Bloch has been under investigation since he was placed on paid leave on June 22. He has not been charged with any crime. The government suspects Bloch was recruited by the Soviet Union during the early 1970s. From 1983 to 1987 Bloch was deputy chief of mission at the U.S. Embassy in Vienna. When he was suspended on June he was director of the department's office of regional economic policy for Europe. It was reported last year that Bloch was videotaped passing a suitcase to a known Soviet KGB officer in Paris and has been under investigation since. Ms. Tutwiler said the hearing will be closed because there will be ``discussions of national security and intelligence matters.'' She said she did not know if Bloch can take his case to the courts if his appeal is rejected.

DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Draft Austerity Budget
DOC.TEXT: The government Thursday approved a draft of the 1990 budget that will include major cuts in defense, state subsidies and funding for the Communist Party, an official said. Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus said the austerity measures will cut $1.5 billion from a budget first proposed by the nation's Communist government before it was overthrown peacefully late last year. ``We have managed to turn a budget calling for a deficit of $1 billion into a budget with a $500 million surplus,'' Klaus said. He said savings will also be made by slashing price subsidies in agriculture, mining, administration and security, but gave no further details. Klaus said price rises were inevitable on heavily subsidized items such as food, housing and transportation and said he expected the price rises to be felt even before free elections scheduled for June 8-9. ``There is nothing to wait for, the elections can be no watershed. A cheap policy could be counterproductive,'' Klaus said. He said a compensation scheme was being prepared to help those who will be hardest hit by the price increases. The new budget requires final approval by parliament. Czechoslovakia's current inflation rate is between 2.5 percent and 3.5 percent and the nation has a foreign debt of $7.9 billion, one of the lowest per capita in the Soviet bloc, Czechoslovak Premier Marian Calfa said in his February report to parliament. Klaus also said state-owned industries will be sold to the private sector ``very quickly'' but 30 to 40 mostly public service industries such as railways and water will remain under state control.

DOC.HEAD: University Will Continue Shooting Cats
DOC.TEXT: NEW ORLEANS _ A committee at Louisiana State University Medical Center concluded today that it should not stop researchers from firing pellets into the brains of anesthetized cats despite opposition from animal rights groups. The $2 million project, funded by the Department of Defense, was suspended in November pending results of the internal review and a U.S. General Accounting Office study of the program. The status of the GAO study hasn't been made public. Dr. Michael E. Carey of LSU has said his project is aimed at studying head injuries and evaluating treatments. ``The committee concluded that the project addressed critical scientific problems and that Dr. Carey's approach was well conceived, proper, and made maximum effort to protect the welfare of animals,'' the review committee's report said. The research involving hundreds of animals is designed to learn how to return brain-injured soldiers to active duty. A group called the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine had asked Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to cancel the contract, saying the research is redundant, scientifically flawed and ethically unacceptable. The group said the primary conclusions by LSU researchers is that respiration stops when the brain is injured _ information critics say had been documented in neurosurgical literature for nearly 100 years. The LSU faculty committee reviewing the project, made up of five medical doctors and two Ph.D.s, said Carey's project had received unwarranted and distorted coverage in the news media. ``The committee was adamant in the opinion that the project should be continued and that the university should take the position of a strong defense on behalf of Dr. Carey,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Medicare to Begin Covering Liver Transplants
DOC.TEXT: The government will begin paying for certain liver transplants in Medicare beneficiaries, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan announced Thursday. Medicare is expected to spend $10 million for the operations in the first year and $120 million by the fifth year, as more hospitals gain approval for reimbursement under the liver transplant program. But Sulliivan said the net impact on the Medicare budget would be lower because the transplants will save the costs of treating patients with advanced liver disease. He did not estimate the expected savings. Under the proposed rule, Medicare payment would allowed for transplants in patients with primary biliary cirrhosis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, hepatitis B, antigen negative or postnecrotic cirrhosis, alcoholic cirrhosis, Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency disease, Wilson's disease and primary hemochromatosis. A Public Health Service study found liver transplants are safe and effective in treating those conditions in adults. More than 3,500 liver transplants have been performed in the United States. To qualify for payment under the program, a hospital must have a written patient-selection process for choosing patients for whom the operation is most likely to be successful. They also must show that at least 77 percent of their adult patients with the conditions covered under the program survive for at least one year after receiving a new liver, and that 60 percent of them live at least two years. The process is similar to the system used to approve hospitals for performing heart transplants on Medicare beneficiaries, the department said. After a 60-day period for public comment, a final regulation will be published in the Federal Register and become effective.

DOC.HEAD: Armenians to Elect New Leader After 40-Day Mourning Period
DOC.TEXT: Turkey's Armenian community will hold a 40-day mourning period for Archbishop Shnork Kaloustian before electing a new patriarch, church officials said Thursday. Kaloustian, 77, died Wednesday in Yerevan, in Soviet Armenia, after injuring his head in a fall on Tuesday. He had undergone a three-hour operation after falling on the steps of the residence of His Holiness Vazken I, head of the Armenian church, said spokesman Garabet Arman. The patriarch, who headed Turkey's 60,000-member Armenian community since 1961, arrived in Armenia on Saturday in connection with a commemoration of the 1988 Armenian earthquake. Arman said Kaloustian will be buried in the Armenian cemetery in Istanbul following a service in the Virgin Mary Church on March 18. The Armenian community will elect a new patriarch through district representatives after a traditional mourning period of 40 days, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Exiled First Lady Lonely Before Trial, Breaks Silence
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks before her fraud and racketeering trial, Imelda Marcos is trying to follow her lawyers' advice. But sometimes it's hard for a woman used to the world as her forum to keep quiet. For months, the 60-year-old Mrs. Marcos has ignored incessant interview requests, choosing instead to pore over legal documents in a cool, dark room that was once the wine cellar of her Makiki Heights home. Her new lead attorney, Wyoming maverick Gerry Spence, said the only way the usually outspoken Mrs. Marcos will get a fair trial in this country is if she keeps her mouth shut and lets the evidence speak for itself. ``She has been branded as a crook and a thief, everyone thinks of her as `that woman with the shoes,''' Spence said in a recent telephone interview. Nearly every evening, she visits the tomb of her late husband, former Philippines president Ferdinand Marcos. The visits are timed to avoid tourists. On Wednesday night, Mrs. Marcos broke her silence, saying in an interview that she is a misunderstood, nervous and lonely widow, and fears standing trial now that her defense team has been shaken up. Washington attorney Richard Hibey withdrew from the case less than a month before her federal trial in New York was scheduled to begin. ``I don't know how my present lawyers can familiarize themselves with more than three years of litigation just before my trial,'' she said. ``This is most unjust and so detrimental to my defense.'' Hibey and attorney Sandor Frankel of New York withdrew after prosecutors said Hibey faced a possible conflict of interest because they intended to call one of his partners as a witness. U.S. District Judge John Keenan delayed the start of the trial for six days, to March 20. Mrs. Marcos and her husband, who died in September, were charged in October 1988 with fraud and racketeering counts accusing them of stealing more than $100 million from the Philippine treasury to buy art and real estate. They also were charged with defrauding banks of $165 million in loans. Defense attorneys say the key to Mrs. Marcos' defense is proving that the Marcoses were forced out of the Philippines during a 1986 popular revolt with a promise of safe haven in the United States, and that they did not leave willingly, even though protesters threatened to overrun the presidential palace. Chief prosecutor Charles LaBella refused to comment on the case. Although exile in Hawaii has meant a series of ``indignities,'' life was never bleaker than after Marcos died, Mrs. Marcos said. She added that mounting medical, funeral and legal expenses and Philippine President Corazon Aquino's refusal to let him be buried in his homeland also were discouraging. The late dictator ruled the Philippines for two decades. Most of the Marcos' alleged billions of dollars in assets have been frozen as part of the criminal indictment and because of more than a dozen civil lawsuits accusing the Marcoses of acts ranging from corruption to murder. Mrs. Marcos refused to say where she gets her money, allowing only that ``millions'' of dollars in legal and medical bills remain unpaid and that she relies on the goodwill of friends to stay afloat. The U.S. government does not control Mrs. Marcos spending habits, but requires her to submit a monthly accounting and receive special permission if she wants to spend more than $10,000 a month. Marcos aides who spoke on condition of anonymity said the budget has fallen sharply from a high of about $200,000 a month shortly after the Marcoses fled here. One source of money is Mrs. Marcos' daughter, Irene Araneta, who lives in Woodside, Calif., and is married to the son of a wealthy Filipino industrialist, aides said. Marcos spokesman Roger Peyuan said the Marcoses have accumulated more than $3 million in legal bills. He said the household staff of about 30 is paid irregularly but remains loyal because the Marcoses ``have helped us so much and this is when she really needs us.'' ``It's very difficult to be a widow, to be alone for the first time,'' Mrs. Marcos said. ``I must admit that Ferdinand handled all of this, money, business, everything like that. We led a very compartmentalized life.'' During the interview at her home, she appeared at times nervous, apprehensive and lonely, wringing her hands and fidgeting, only to turn hopeful, philosophical and reminiscent, giggling and reading romantic inscriptions on cards from someone who signed them ``Andy.'' She recalled her past with ``no regret.'' ``Everything in life comes in pairs: good and bad, day and night, yin and yang.'' she said. ``Ferdinand always said `you cannot argue with destiny, just stay on top of it.' I'm just trying to keep control of my life.''

DOC.HEAD: Quotes From Imelda Interview
With AM-Imelda Marcos
DOC.TEXT: Here are a selection of quotes from an interview with Imelda Marcos, who is to stand trial March 20 in New York on fraud and racketeering charges related to the alleged looting of the Philippine treasury: ``You cannot argue with destiny, just stay on top of it.''
``It's very difficult to be a widow, to be alone for the first time ... without the support and counsel of your husband, who was a brilliant trial lawyer.''

``We had a marriage made in heaven, such romance. He protected me, took care of me. I miss that,'' referring to her late husband, former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, who died last September.

``Why is there all this notoriety on the shoes? Is it because everyone wears shoes, so everyone can relate to them? They really were unfair though, because so many of my dresses and things were already in trunks, ready to be donated to museums, and they made it look like I kept them all.''

``It is far better to give than to receive, I can see that now. It's kind of humiliating to be a constant receiver,'' referring to having to rely on the charity of friends now that her funds have been frozen.
Her dream is ``to live in peace in my country, united with what is left of my family.''
Referring to charges against her husband and his death in disgrace: ``It's not fair. The president was meticulously righteous. He was brilliant.''
``It's pathetic what has been done to this man. He's dead. He cannot even defend himself. History will be there now to judge him.''

``I think I made a statement. The statement was that I am a Philippine citizen, with my own country, my own constitution,'' explaining why she wore a terno, the traditional, formal Philippine gown, to her arraignment in New York.
``What more can they say, they've said everything already,'' explaining why she does not fear the media or comics who make her the butt of jokes.
``I have no nightmares because the bottom line is that you must live with God and yourself and I can.''

DOC.HEAD: MANAGING EDITORS:
WIRE EDITORS:
ENTERTAINMENT EDITORS:
DOC.TEXT: Starting Friday, March 9, all advisories and digests about arts and entertainment stories will carry a ``v'' instead of ``e'' category code. This is to conform with ANPA guidelines. The arts and entertainment stories themselves will continue to move with an ``e'' category code.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Travelers From Kabul Describe Coup Scene
With AM-Afghanistan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bombs rained down on the Afghan capital and the sound of artillery thundered through the city during the attempt to overthrow the government, said travelers arriving Thursday from Afghanistan. The Ariana Airlines plane was the first international flight to leave Kabul airport since the attempt to overthrow President Najib was launched Tuesday. Some passengers said that considering the ferocity of the attack, civilian casualties appeared low. State-owned Radio Kabul said Thursday night 56 people were killed and 200 injured since Tuesday. Many of the 150 passengers on the jet had been scheduled to leave Kabul on Tuesday but had their plans changed by the coup attempt, which began with an air raid on the international airport. ``Four jets began bombing the airport just before we were to leave. We grabbed our hand luggage and ran,'' said Ashok Patel, an Indian businessman. ``We walked for about 12 kilometers (8 miles) and sucked icicles to quench our thirst,'' he said. ``There were no taxis after the attack and none the next day either.'' Three people working with the International Committee of the Red Cross were among the travelers. They refused to give their names and nationalities but said casualties were not as high as might have been expected. ``In fact, we, as Westerners, were quite amazed at the normalcy while there was, quite obviously, a coup going on,'' one said. Other travelers spoke of repeated explosions, the boom of artillery and people fleeing from the streets into the relative safety of houses and cellars. ``I was very scared,'' said Harinder Singh, an Afghan whose ancestors were Sikhs from India. ``All of us thought we were going to die. A bomb exploded in a taxi near me and I saw the driver being blown apart.'' Singh said he walked from the airport back to the city Tuesday and spent the next day worrying about his luggage, which had already been checked onto the plane. ``But there was a curfew and I couldn't do anything about it. And when I heard there was flight today (Thursday), I just got on,'' he said. ``I'll check about the luggage later.''

DOC.HEAD: Environment Group Sues to Force Open Meetings
DOC.TEXT: Two environmental groups filed suit Thursday seeking to force the new Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board to hold public meetings. The Natural Resources Defense Council and the Energy Research Foundation are seeking an injunction to prevent the new panel from holding meetings unless it ends a policy of closing its sessions. The failure of a government agency to meet in public violates the Government in the Sunshine Act and the Freedom of Information act, the groups contend. The five-member safety board was formed in 1988 to look into allegations of problems at nuclear weapons production facilities. The suit was filed in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

DOC.HEAD: Malcolm Forbes Touted Good Health on Day Before He Died
DOC.TEXT: Malcolm Forbes touted his good health on the day before he died and said his philosophy was to ``live while you are alive,'' according to a British magazine published Thursday. Hello! magazine published what is said was Forbes' last interview before he died at the age of 70 in his sleep Feb. 24 at his New Jersey home. ``I don't think this life is for hibernating and getting ready for the next one. I think you are given it for a purpose and that is to live it. Live while you are alive!'' Forbes was quoted as saying. Forbes spoke enthusiastically about his next adventure to Brazil in a hot air balloon during the interview at his South London home on Feb. 23, and about his love of motorcycles. ``I am very lucky to have the health to do all this because that you can't buy,'' he was quoted as saying. ``I would just like to stay around a while and keep doing more of the things I am doing!'' Forbes was quoted as saying. The magazine included seven color photographs of Forbes in his London house and earlier pictures from Forbes' 70th birthday bash in August in Morocco. Asked what money has brought that Forbes most values, he was quoted as saying: ``The growth of the business which has enlisted all my sons with their enthusiasms and abilities. Success is being able to do what turns you on, and we have great fun together.'' Forbes' son, Malcolm Jr., succeeded him as editor in chief of Forbes magazine and chief executive officer of Forbes Inc. magazine. In the interview, the elder Forbes was quoted as saying: ``All that happens when you have money is that it gets fatter and you have to spend twice as much to thin it down! ``Similarly, your capacity for joy or pain is no greater but the costs can be higher. Capacity to enjoy life is not multiplied. It is mostly in the attitude. I am not talking about the grindingness of poverty but for the normal person the attitude, not the money, determines the joy.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began Thursday in the second trial against Paul Newman for a share of the profits from the actor's salad dressing. A mistrial was declared the first time around on a lawsuit by Westport delicatessen owner, Julius Gold who claims he was promised 8 percent of the stock for consulting services when Newman's company was begun in 1982. Newman's Own makes salad dressing, spaghetti sauce, popcorn and lemonade. The actor says all profits go to charity.

Prince Edward, Queen Elizabeth II's youngest son, said Thursday he is going to hoof it on March 26, and he urged other Londoners to walk home from work and give their saved fares to help the homeless. ``I'll be walking home,'' said Edward, who usually drives the less than a mile from Buckingham Palace to the Palace Theater, where he is a production assistant with Andrew Lloyd Webber's Really Useful Company. The ``Feet First'' campaign hopes to raise $164,000 for charities working with homeless young people in central London. The prince, who turns 26 on Saturday, said he has talked with homeless young people. ``It is well worth remembering that no one is homeless by choice. No one chooses to sleep rough night after night or to beg.'' Edward said huge increases in housing prices are a factor in the rising number of homeless. Buckingham Palace said the prince will either walk to work on March 26 or be dropped off if he has an official engagement before he goes to the office.

An ex-girlfriend of actor William Hurt is appealing the decision that she and Hurt did not have a common-law marriage. ``Hurt told her, `We're more married than married people. We're married in the eyes of God,''' A. Richard Golub, the lawyer for Sandra Jennings, told an appeals court Wednesday. Golub said the judge who ruled against a common-law marriage barred documents and testimony that would have proved Hurt a liar. Golub apologized for having said, right after the decision was issued last year, that Judge Jacqueline Silbermann ``was in love with Bill Hurt.'' ``It was a hotly contested case. I lost my temper. I shot my mouth off. I apologize to the court,'' Golub told the appellate panel. But outside the appeals courtroom, Jennings said that in a pretrial conference last year in the judge's chambers, Silbermann told Hurt, ``Oh! You're my favorite actor.'' Jennings, 33, a former ballerina, said Slibermann denied her request for another judge. Jennings' claim that a common-law marriage existed is based on the statutes of South Carolina, where she and Hurt lived for a few months while he filmed ``The Big Chill.''

Soul singer James Brown is being considered for two jobs outside the prison where he is serving six years for aggravated assault and failing to stop for police. Neither job has anything to do with music, but they are Brown's two top choices for the State Department of Corrrections' work-release program, said Brown's attorney Richard Crane. Crane didn't say what the jobs were. Brown, 56, serving his sentence in State Park Correctional Center, earned work-release approval last month. The program would require Brown to stay overnight in a state center after returning from a daytime job. Corrections spokesman Bennish Brown said there are no center beds available, and he could not confirm a statement by Crane that one would become available April 1. ``No dates have been firmed up,'' the spokesman said. ``I've been assured that we're still considering different jobs and still waiting on space at centers.'' The singer becomes eligible for parole May 5, 1991.

Ted Koppel doesn't pull his punches on the subject of fallen TV evangelists Jim and Tammy Bakker. They're con artists, said the ABC-TV moderator of ``Nightline.'' When asked by NBC's Bob Costas if he was suprised that the fall of the Bakkers gave his show its highest ever rating, Koppel said no. ``Quite the contrary,'' he said on ``Later with Bob Costas,'' to be broadcast March 21. ``It had sex, it had money, it had religion, it had duplicity, it had enormous public interest all the way through.'' Did he feel compassion for the couple? Costas asked. ``Not once we were on the air,'' said Koppel. ``I was much more concerned about the people who had given their trust and faith to Jim and Tammy. ... But they really are, they're a couple of shills. He's a con man and she's a con woman.''

The Nashville Network will telecast seven hours of the Farm Aid IV concert live from the Hoosier Dome in Indianapolis on April 7, the cable station announced Thursday. Several pop, rock 'n' roll, country and rap singers will perform at the concert to raise money for farmers. They include Willie Nelson, Don Henley, Bonnie Raitt, Richard Marx, Neil Young, LL Cool J, the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, Arlo Guthrie, K.T. Oslin, Kris Kristofferson, Jackson Browne, Lou Reed, John Cougar Mellencamp and Ricky Skaggs.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Stages Hunger Strike, Government Negotiates on TV
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's prime minister on Thursday held inconclusive talks on live television with opposition leaders and hunger strikers demanding a multiparty system, foreign sources in Ulan Bator said. Prime Minister Dumaagiyn Sodnom met with 30 to 40 representatives from five unofficial political groups, including several hunger strikers, but the televised debate broke off after 90 minutes, a source said. He said the hunger strikers are continuing their protest. About 10 members of Mongolia's infant opposition groups started the hunger strike Wednesday after the government failed to respond to their demands for reforms that were outlined in a petition delivered Sunday, sources said. The petition, signed by the Mongolian Democratic Union and three other unofficial political groups, calls for the Communist Party to give up its monopoly on power and hold new parliamenmtary elections. Also Wednesday, the ruling Communist Party said it would hold a meeting Monday, but did not say what would be on the agenda. Sources speculated the leadership might meet some of the opposition's demands. Long a Soviet ally, Mongolia began experimenting with reforms less than two years ago, but the 3-month-old opposition movement says measures are too slow. The hunger strikers, mostly men in their 20s, slept in sleeping bags in the square Wednesday night with no shelter from the below freezing temperatures. Two ambulances stood nearby, the sources said. Throughout the day, representatives from some half-dozen unofficial political groups gave speeches in the square, while supporters signed their names on a long roll of paper, the sources said. ``It's all very orderly and peaceful. There are a lot of people with baby carriages,'' one source said. He said there were no police or soldiers, even though public rallies are banned at the square and several other major sites in Ulan Bator. Mongolia is a vast, pastoral country of 2 million people.

The U.S. Armed Forces affixed new ribbons to their flags Thursday to mark the Panama invasion, which President Bush said had joined `'the roll call of glory, the roster of great American campaigns.'' He listed: ``Yorktown, Gettysburg, Normandy, and now Panama.'' Bush said the new streamers were ``most of all'' for the 23 soldiers killed in the invasion, which ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. At the ceremony, Bush joined top generals and admirals in a darkened hall where spotlights played on nearly 200 soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines standing at attention, bearing bayonets, rifles and the flag of each state and territory. The honors began with the roar of a 21-gun salute from cannons outside the Ceremonial Hall that doubles as the base gymnasium. It ended with the Old Guard Fife and Drum Corps, in colonial garb, marching off after the Army Band played the anthems of all four services. ``We're here today to add another campaign streamer to the roll call of glory, the roster of great American campaigns _ Yorktown, Gettysburg, Normandy and now Panama,'' said Bush. The flag honors those ``who died in the defense of liberty ... and that is why I am determined that the American flag will be consecrated, not desecrated,'' said Bush, who supports the idea of a constitutional amendment to make flag-burning illegal. The flags borne by an honor guard from the Army, the Navy, the Air Force and the Marines already carry dozens of multicolored streamers, each signifying a different war or engagement, from the Revolutionary War to the Civil War to Vietnam and Grenada. The Panama campaign streamer was the 169th ribbon affixed to the Army flag; the 13th for the Marine flag; the 19th for the Navy and the 78th for the Air Force. ``Panama was another chapter in a great epic, an act of free men and women in the Revolution of '89, a revolution that also swept the East and is now sweeping the globe,'' said Bush. ``The revolution continues. The people have spoken in Nicaragua. When they speak in Cuba and Haiti, our Western hemisphere will be entirely within the compass of freedom,'' he said. Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said, ``With the presentation of these streamers, the campaign in Panama is now part of the glorious tradition of our nation and its armed forces.'' ``For as long as the Stars and Stripes flies over this nation, the actions of the men and women who helped to restore democracy to Panama ... will be remembered,'' said Powell.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Says Anti-Apartheid Activists Prompting Homeland Violence
DOC.TEXT: Anti-apartheid activists are behind an outbreak of violence in tribal homelands because they don't want to negotiate, the government suggested Thursday. ``The violence is certainly part of an overall plan to destabilize the country and make it difficult to commence negotiations,'' said Constitutional Development Minister Gerrit Viljoen. ``It is quite clear that certain elements pretend to be keen on participating in negotiating reform, but are in effect not ready to do so,'' he said, apparently referring to the African National Congress and other leading black groups, ``They have been caught on the wrong foot by the initiatives of the state president,'' Viljoen said. ANC spokesman Pallo Jordan in Lusaka, Zambia denied that the recently legalized organization was behind the violence, which has led to 200 deaths in the past month, according to Business Day newspaper in Johannesburg. He said tension had been building in some of the 10 homelands, which the apartheid system has designated as the national states where the black majority of 28 million can own land and exercise political rights. ``The language of violence, looting and arson reveals the bitterness in the hearts of many of our people, but it is senseless and savage in the extreme,'' said the Rev. Stanley Mogoba, president of the Methodist Church of Southern Africa and a prominent black anti-apartheid activist. ``There may be leaders and groups who are encouraging this type of behavior,'' he said. If true, ``then I must brand these adults cowards who do not have the interests of our nation at heart,'' Mogoba said. Homeland army troops fired automatic rifles, shotguns, rubber bullets and tear gas at protesters and used whips to disperse crowds in Bophuthatswana, where demonstrators are demanding that the nominally independent Tswana republic be re-incorporated into South Africa. Soldiers and police in armored personnel carriers and trucks randomly opened fire with assault rifles to stop crowds forming in the Garankuwa area, witnesses said. Youths erected barricades of burned out vehicles to block streets, but were chased away by soldiers and police who tore down the barriers, eyewitnesses said. There were no immediate reports of casualties. Viljoen, the Cabinet minister in charge of beginning negotiations with black leaders on a new constitution and an end to apartheid, made his accusation at a Cape Town news conference. With him was Hudson Ntsanwisi, leader of the Gazankulu homeland, which shares a border with Kruger Park, the nation's largest wildlife reserve. After a meeting with President F.W. de Klerk, Ntsanwisi was granted national police personnel and equipment to help quell a three-week work stoppage that has closed government offices, schools, businesses and shops in Gazankulu, homeland of the Shangaan people. Black workers at the nearby Kruger Park's main camp went on strike Thursday. At least 25 people have been killed and more than 200 huts burned in the past two weeks in the homeland, where activists are demanding Ntsanwisi's ouster. De Klerk accused unspecified groups of ``making mischief,'' and when Foreign Minister Pik Botha was asked Wednesday night if the ANC was involved, he said the government had no proof. But Viljoen's comments were interpreted by local newspapers, and by the ANC, as referring to the organization which de Klerk legalized Feb. 2. ANC affiliates in Johannesburg issued a statement Thursday deploring violence in the township of Katlehong, 15 miles to the southeast, and sent teams to arrange peace talks between warring factions. A black man was hacked with knives, and a woman was shot Thursday, police said. Five houses and nine vehicles were burned. Up to 70 people were injured early Thursday, the independent South African Press Association said. In another development, lawyers for more than 340 prisoners on Robben Island in Cape Town said their clients had ended a two-week hunger strike. The lawyers said the government is considering the prisoners' demands to be granted political status and ultimately freedom.

DOC.HEAD: Ministerial Council To Discuss Moving League Back To Cairo
DOC.TEXT: The ministerial council of the Arab League will meet Saturday to discuss the question of moving the 22-member organization back to Cairo, Arab diplomats said. The headquarters of the regional organization was transferred to the Tunisian capital from Cairo in 1979 after Egypt signed the Camp David accords with Israel. The council, made up of the foreign ministers or permanent representatives of the member countries, does not have the power to make the transfer decision. Only a full Arab summit can do so. Inter-Arab squabbles have prevented the holding of a regular, non-emergency Arab summit since 1983. The Tunisian government has said it wouldn't oppose the return of the Arab League headquarters to Cairo if an Arab summit so decides.

DOC.HEAD: Evangelist Brings Crusade to Berlin Wall
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Billy Graham is bringing his crusade for Christianity to the Berlin Wall to fill the spiritual void left by retreating communism, the U.S. evangelist and German religious leaders said Thursday. Graham said the sweeping events of Eastern Europe have lessened the danger of nuclear confrontation, but that in its place have appeared threats of ``hedonism, materialism and self-gratification.'' At a news conference to discuss his Saturday evangelical meeting at the Berlin Wall, Graham said many people who were repressed under communism were ready to heed his message. ``A few weeks ago President (Vaclav) Havel of Czechoslovakia in an address to the United States Congress declared that the salvation of the world lies not in slick political slogans about freedom and democracy but rather in the human heart. I agree with that,'' Graham said. Graham said he accepted an invitation from religious leaders in both Germanys to address a gathering Saturday because ``I felt Germany was on the verge of a spiritual awakening.'' Hartmut Stepp, a West German evangelical church leader from Stuttgart, said Graham's ministry was sought at this time because ``a spiritual, ideological vacuum exists because of this social upheaval.'' Graham's crusade comes just a week before East Germans go to the polls for their first-ever free elections, which will seat a new parliament and set the nation on the road to reunification with West Germany. Graham, said the date for his appearance was set when the East German vote was planned for May 6. The election had to be advanced because of the swiftly worsening economic and political situation in East Germany. ``I don't want to say anything to indicate which side I'm on, because I must be politically neutral,'' Graham replied when asked how his Christian crusade might affect the elections. The East German Christian Democratic Union, aligned with the Christian Democratic Union of West Germany that is headed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, has been emphasizing its religious roots in the campaign. But the party trails the Social Democrats, who are predicted to win a majority of seats in the parliamentary elections. Posters announcing the crusade call on Germans on both sides of the wall to ``listen to the man whose message can give meaning to life: Billy Graham.'' Graham, 71, has conducted eight previous evangelical crusades in Germany, the first in 1954 when much of the nation still lay in ruins. Tens of thousands of West Germans attended those gatherings. He has also preached in the Soviet Union, Hungary, Romania, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEAD: Old-Guard Communists Admit Losing Effort to Keep Party Character
DOC.TEXT: Old-guard Italian Communists acknowledged Thursday they were fighting a losing battle to save the traditional identity of their party, its name and symbols. Party leader Achille Occhetto has all the votes he needs at the extraordinary congress of the Italian Communist Party to guarantee the success of his proposal to revamp the party, a move expected to lead to changing its name and eliminating its hammer-and-sickle symbol. ``It is true, 65 percent of the votes in the congress are in his favor,'' said Armando Cossutta, who has fought to block any reform that could destroy the party's traditional identity. But he argued it was not enough just to decide what form the new party would take, how it will be formed and who will lead it. He said the congress should decide ``if life really must be given to a new party.'' ``Occhetto speaks as if it is our fault that we have not succeeded in being in the government ... as if anti-communism stemmed from our name and not from forces that want to keep every prospect of change a long way from the government,'' Cossutta said to lukewarm applause from the 1,092 delegates gathered in Bologna's Sports Palace, awash in red for the congress that ends this weekend. Other old-guard Communists such as Aldo Tortorella have argued that the West's largest Communist Party, which claims 1.4 million members, could conduct major reforms without creating a new party. ``We are divided on what is a party of the left,'' said Tortorella. ``For this reason, we have defended our revered symbols, our name and our flag. It is true, this name has been muddied by others. But they are the ones that must change it,'' he added. Tortorella collapsed just after he descended from the speaker's platform on the red, multitired dais. Doctors said later that he had fainted because he was suffering from too much stress. He was taken to a hospital but doctors said he needed only to rest. Occhetto has pushed for the birth of a new party as part of an effort to reverse the party's electoral slide and offer an alternative to the domination of the Christian Democrats and their allies. The Communists nearly came to power in 1976 when they won 34 percent of the vote, but they dropped to about 27 percent in the last parliamentary elections in 1987. ``The strongest criticism I have of the party secretary is that he created the illusion in the body of the party and in public opinion that with this proposal it is possible to unblock the political situation dominated by the Christian Democrats and their allies for 40 years,'' Cossutta said. ``I don't know a single Communist who doesn't want to open the situation and who doesn't want us to be in the government,'' he added. But he said the objectives could not be reached simply by launching a new party. He said the party's electoral slide began before the ``storm in Eastern Europe.'' ``We lost votes among all the classes, but particularly among the working classes, because they disagreed not with our image, but with the substance of our political action, the uncertainty of those years.'' He was referring to the drift in the Communist Party since it abandoned the ``historic compromise'' of the late 1970s, through which it supported the Christian Democrats in return for being consulted on major government decisions. ``If the problem remains one of substance, then there is no need for us to eliminate our symbols and our name,'' said Tortorella. He agreed with Occhetto that unity was essential for the party, which has been fractured by the debate over changing its identity.

DOC.HEAD: Longest-Term Applicant Allowed To Leave For Israel
DOC.TEXT: EDs: SUBS 7th graf pvs, Gilman and, to CORRECT spelling of Greenwald; picks up 8th graf, Mrs. Raiz

Eighteen years after applying, Soviet molecular biologist Vladimir Raiz and his wife, Carmella, have received permission to emigrate to Israel, a New York congressman said Thursday. Raiz, who was denied an exit permit on grounds he knew state secrets, is the longest-term Jewish refusenik in the Soviet Union. Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman, R-N.Y., said Raiz was allowed to depart after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev interceded. Raiz, of Vilnius, Lithuania, was fired from his job at the Institute of Molecular Biology after applying for an exit permit in 1972. His wife has been in Washington on a tourist visa, trying to bring pressure on Moscow. A demonstration had been scheduled outside the Soviet embassy. Mrs. Raiz also was dismissed from her job as first violinist of the Vilna Philharmoic Orchestra. They have two sons, Moshe, 12, and Shaul, 8, and are observant Jews. The Raizes organized seminars on Jewish culture, religion, modern Israel and Hebrew while seeking permission to leave the Soviet Union. According to Gilman, the first secretary of the Lithuanian Communist Party, Algirdis Brezauskas, lodged an appeal for the family with Gorbachev and permission to emigrate to Israel was granted soon afterward. Gilman and Rabbi Ronald Greenwald of Monsey, N.Y., had approached the Lithuanian party official earlier. The State Department also interceded. Mrs. Raiz met with President Bush at the White House last December. Gilman said Albert Reichmann, a Toronto builder whose family supports various Jewish causes, would go to Lithuania to meet Raiz and accompany him to Israel. ``Freedom has finally been granted to this most deserving, courageous family,'' Gilman said in a statement. ``Their courage has been an inspiration to many for the past 18 years, and their new-found freedom is heartening for all.'' The congressman said the visas would be issued next Tuesday. The children also were granted permission to depart.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Introduced to Prosecute Suspected Nazi War Criminals
DOC.TEXT: The government on Thursday introduced legislation to enable prosecutors to charge three aging emigres as Nazi war criminals, and police said they probably will set up a special unit to investigate more suspects. The Nazi-hunting Simon Wiesenthal Center said Britain was ``finally on the threshold'' of meting out justice to the suspects _ Eastern Europeans who fled after World War II and became naturalized Britons. Government officials said they hoped the War Crimes Bill would be passed by the summer, raising the prospect of the first trial as early as year's end. But critics declared the bill was a revenge measure that would result in emotional and unfair ``show trials.'' ``Legislating in a spirit of revenge rarely produces good,'' said governing Conservative Party lawmaker Robert Adley, a leading critic of the government move. ``The idea of hounding three old men to court will either finish up in farce or tragedy for those conducting this vendetta,'' he added. The bill followed a Dec. 12 vote by the House of Commons to accept a government-ordered inquiry that said there was sufficient evidence to prosecute three suspects living in Britain. The report urged the investigation of 124 more cases of suspects who came to Britain with thousands of displaced persons after the end of the 1939-45 war. Scotland Yard, London's police headquarters, said there is ``a likelihood of Scotland Yard investigation team'' being set up to deal exclusively with war crime cases. Two eminent lawyers who conducted the inquiry for the government said Britain must change its law to allow prosecutions of British citizens for crimes committed abroad, or risk becoming a ``safe haven'' for Nazis. Britain is the last allied country to take action. Australia and Canada passed legislation in the past few years and are holding their first trials, while the U.S. Justice Department investigates and deports suspects for trial in Israel. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher supports prosecutions. But the government will allow a ``free vote'' _ according to conscience and not along party lines _ on the bill. The key legislative stage, the second reading, is scheduled for March 19. The Los Angeles-based Simon Wiesenthal Center, which submitted initial lists of suspects to the British government in 1986, urged Britain to set up a special Nazi-hunting unit similar to the U.S. Office of Special Investigations. It includes historians and archivists. ``But what is important is that the British government and the British Parliament ... have now finally entered the threshold where justice is about to be done in respect of Nazi war criminals,'' said Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the center. Hier estimated the first trial could begin about three months after the bill becomes law. The names of the suspects were kept confidential in a separate section of the report by the British investigators issued in July. But one suspect, Antanas Gecas, a Lithuanian-born retired mining engineer who lives in Scotland, has been identified repeatedly by the British news media. Gecas, 73, acknowledges serving in a notorious police battalion in Nazi-occupied Lithuania, but says he only watched the atrocities. All the suspects in Britain are from Lithuania or two other Soviet republics, Ukraine and Latvia, where locals manned mobile death squads set up by the Nazis. The squads rounded up and murdered tens of thousands of Jews. The trials would involve new rules of evidence in Britain to allow videotaping of testimony by aging witnesses in the Soviet Union and depositions left by witnesses who have since died.

DOC.HEAD: New Directors Named
DOC.TEXT: Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith on Thursday were appointed co-directors of American Ballet Theatre. Mikhail Baryshnikov, who became director of the company in 1980, resigned last September after a policy dispute with Mrs. Hermann. Since then, she has been executive director. Theater designer Smith began his association with Ballet Theatre in 1944 when he collaborated with Jerome Robbins and Leonard Bernstein on ``Fancy Free.'' The following year, he became the company's co-director, with Lucia Chase. They resigned in 1980. Mrs. Hermann joined American Ballet Theatre last summer from the Metropolitan Opera House, where she had been director of non-Met productions.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Calls for Increased Housing in Occupied West Bank
With AM-Syria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel's housing minister called for building 2,000 new apartments in the occupied West Bank this year to house Jewish immigrants, Israel radio reported Thursday. The issue of settling immigrants on the disputed land has drawn strong criticism from the United States, which argues that Israel's settlement policy is an obstacle to peace. Earlier Thursday, a Jerusalem planning official disclosed the city government has plans to build a new Jewish neighborhood in Arab east Jerusalem despite American opposition to such a move. The request by Housing Minister David Levy on the West Bank settlements, if approved by the government, could jeopardize $400 million in U.S. loan guarantees Israel requested to build housing for an influx of Soviet Jewish immigrants. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told a congressional subcommittee last week the administration was willing to support such guarantees but only if it received ``assurances these funds will not be used to create new settlements or expand old settlements in the occupied territories.'' Almost 500 Soviet immigrants have been arriving daily in Israel. The radio said Levy, long a proponent of the settlement movement, wants 2,000 of the 30,000 new housing units planned this year for immigrants to be built in the West Bank. A Finance Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Levy's proposal ``is not the policy of the government.'' Levy could not be reached immediately for comment. About 70,000 Jewish settlers live in enclaves in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The government says that about 200 Soviet immigrants moved to the territories last year. Ruth Kaminker, a member of Jerusalem's nine-member City Planning Board, told The Associated Press that the new 225-acre neighborhood was in its ``final stages'' of planning after a three-month study of the site. The development, expected to include up to 3,000 homes or apartments, is planned for a steep slope of a strategic hill known as Mount Homa, said Mrs. Kaminker, a member of the left-wing Citizens' Rights Movement. She said the government requested development of the new neighborhood, apparently in an attempt to strengthen Jewish hold in the Arab sector of the city, which was annexed by Israel after its capture from Jordan in 1967. City spokeswoman Bonnie Boxer denied any new neighborhood in east Jerusalem was in the planning stages. But she acknowledged the site was one of several under consideration in east Jerusalem for constructing new Jewish housing. About 140,000 Palestinians live in Arab east Jerusalem. In the past 23 years, 120,000 Jews have moved into seven new communities around the Arab area. Most countries, including the United States, have not recognized Israeli sovereignty over the Arab sector. On March 3, President Bush leveled unusual criticism at Israeli building in disputed areas of Jerusalem. ``We do not believe there should be new settlements in the West Bank or east Jerusalem,'' Bush said in California. Two previously announced Jewish neighborhoods are also going up in east Jerusalem to house Soviet immigrants and a rapidly expanding population of ultra-Orthodox Jews. But a city building plan for Arab neighborhoods has been stalled for years by the Israeli government, and the initial plan for 17,000 units has been ordered cut to about 7,500. Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt in the 1967 Middle East War. The territories' 1.7 million Palestinian residents have waged a 27-month uprising against Israeli occupation.

DOC.HEAD: Targeted Thrift Challenges Government's Authority in Court
DOC.TEXT: A court challenge mounted by a suburban Chicago savings institution could derail President Bush's savings and loan bailout. Olympic Federal Savings and Loan Association, Berwyn, Ill., contends in U.S. District Court that the director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision is holding his position unconstitutionally. S&L legislation adopted last August allowed M. Danny Wall, chairman of the now-defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board, to serve as thrift office director without being appointed by the president or confirmed by the Senate. Wall resigned in December and was replaced temporarily this week by Assistant Treasury Secretary Salvatore R. Martoche, who has been confirmed for his assistant secretary post but not as thrift office director. Olympic, which is trying to deflect potential seizure by the government, contends in court papers that both Wall and Martoche lack the legal authority to turn a thrift over to the Resolution Trust Corp., a new agency created to sell or close failed institutions. U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth late Wednesday blocked the thrift office from seizing Olympic for 10 days unless the agency provides the court and the S&L with six hours notice. He scheduled a hearing for Tuesday. The case has wide ramifications. Over the past year, the government has seized more than 380 S&Ls in nearly 40 states and has closed or sold 50 of those. More than 120 of the takeovers have occurred since the conversion of the bank board into the thrift office. The government is expected to seize as many as 200 additional institutions. Olympic, with $1.1 billion, had exhausted its tangible capital and was deep in the hole at the end of September, according to Sheshunoff Information Services, an Austin, Texas, consulting firm. An official of the biggest trade group representing S&Ls urged the Bush administration to swiftly render Olympic's legal challenge pointless by nominating a new thrift office director. ``This underscores the fact that the president and the administration have to move with great haste here to appoint a permanent director and get the OTS moving again,'' said James H. Grohl, senior vice president of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions. An administration source said the White House has received a recommendation from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady for a permanent successor to Wall. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, would not reveal the individual's name.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Will Participate in Soviet Space Project
DOC.TEXT: The United States, acting at the request of the late Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov, will participate in a Soviet project using a large orbiting radio telescope to peer into the core of quasars and other active galaxies, it was announced Thursday. ``This is a small but significant step in the evolving cooperation in space activities between our two nations,'' said Vice President Dan Quayle, announcing the U.S. role at a ceremony with Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin. Shortly before his death last year, Sakharov had written to NASA's administrator, Richard Truly, asking the United States to take part in the program, known as RADIOASTRON. The project calls for the Soviets to launch a 10-meter radio telescope into Earth orbit in 1993. It will work synchronously with U.S. ground-based telescopes to produce unprecedented resolution for peering deep into space, the vice president's office said. The United States will provide precision tracking facilities for very high accuracy measurements of the Soviet satellite orbit. In addition, the United States will lend the Soviets data recorders now being developed by the National Radio Astronomy Observatory. ``Space is an area where, in the past, we have had competition with the Soviet Union,'' Quayle said. ``And with the reduction of tensions, perhaps this will be a place where we can have not competition but cooperation.'' Dubinin called the U.S. participation ``a good start'' toward an era of cooperation.

DOC.HEAD: Low Birth Weight on Rise Again, CDC Says
DOC.NOTE: For release 6 p.m. EST _ time set by source
DOC.TEXT: The dangerous trend of low birth-weight babies is on the rise, especially among black infants, after a 10-year decline, federal health officials reported Thursday. The national Centers for Disease Control said the rate of babies born at less than 5{ pounds rose 2 percent from 1985 to 1987 _ the latest year for which statistics are available. During 1975 to 1985, the rate declined by 9 percent. Sixty-nine of 1,000 babies born in 1987 were under 5{ pounds, compared with 67.5 of 1,000 in 1985. The 1987 figures still represent an improvement over the 73.9 per 1,000 reported in 1975. And the rate of babies at ``very low'' birth weight is rising even faster, up 6.8 percent from 1975-87, the report said. In 1987, 12.4 per 1,000 was below 3 pounds, 4 ounces, compared with 11.6 in 1975. ``This rate is a small proportion of births, but it's increasing, which makes it more difficult in the future to improve our infant mortality rate,'' said Dr. Carol Hogue, director of the CDC's Division of Reproductive Health. ``Very low birth weight'' babies, below 3 pounds, 4 ounces, are 90 to 100 times more likely to die in their first year than other babies, she said. Infants under 5{ pounds _ ``low birth weight'' babies _ face at least a five times greater risk of death than babies of normal weight, about 6{ to 9{ pounds. The problem is worse for black infants. ``Black babies, who already have been at greatly increased risk of low birth weight and infant mortality, are experiencing a greater increase in this risk than white babies,'' Hogue said. The rate of low birth weight among black infants is more than twice the rate for white infants: 127.1 per 1,000 blacks in 1987, versus 56.8 for whites. And the disparity has widened since 15 years ago, when the rates were 130.9 for blacks to 62.6 for whites. Low birth weight rose less than 1 percent for whites between 1985 and 1987, but 2 percent for blacks. ``The data,'' the CDC said, ``underscore the substantial and persistent difference between black and white infants in the risk for low birth weight.'' The reasons for the black-white gap are complex, the Atlanta-based agency said in its weekly report. Chief among them: more black women are in high-risk groups for underweight babies _ poor, unmarried, under age 20, undereducated, or lacking proper prenatal care. Other factors include poorer nutritional status, close-together pregnancies and higher rates of unwanted births, the CDC said, adding that infants born less than two years after a sibling run a higher risk of low birth weight. More than 16 percent of underweight black babies were unwanted or mistimed pregnancies, the CDC said. ``The prevention of unintended pregnancies could substantially reduce the difference in rates of low birth weight between blacks and whites,'' the agency said. Hogue said improvements in the nation's infant mortality rate during the past two decades are largely because of improved means of keeping premature babies alive _ not because of improved infant health. ``We're not sure we can continue to improve infant mortality by improving this very expensive technology,'' she said. ``We really need to focus on reducing the incidence of low birth weight.'' About 3.5 million babies are born in the United States each year. Most low birth-weight babies are premature babies; nearly six in 10 are born earlier than 37 weeks of pregnancy, compared with the standard 40 weeks. As such, low birth-weight babies run a much greater risk of serious illness, including respiratory problems, or death.

DOC.HEAD: Advocacy Group Asks $4.6 Billion Increase in Federal Spending
DOC.TEXT: A private advocacy group called Thursday for $4.6 billion in new federal spending on child health and education programs to back up the ``mostly empty rhetoric'' of President Bush and the nation's governors. Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, applauded recent actions by the National Governors' Association and Bush to endorse national education goals. But she said her group's proposal would be ``a significant step toward translating the mostly empty rhetoric about preparing children for school into real dollars and placing children at the top, rather than in the margins, of the nation's agenda.'' She commented at a news conference as her group released its annual report on the status of children in America. The group proposed increases for fiscal 1991 in federal spending on child care, the Head Start program, health and nutrition services and child protection programs. Meeting the governors' goals for national education achievement ``will require far more than lofty rhetoric and token investments,'' she said. Among the recommendations of the group: _Enactment of a comprehensive national child-care bill, costing at least $1.75 billion, plus additional state appropriations. _Expanding the Head Start program, which provides educational, nutritional and health services to needy pre-school children. It called for $1.4 billion in additional spending on the program, plus state supplements. _A $1 billion expansion in programs to protect vulnerable children and families against abuse and neglect. _Additional spending in health, nutrition, immunization and related programs, including expansion of Medicaid health care to cover all pregnant women and children with incomes below 185 percent of the poverty level. She said Bush's campaign pledge to become the ``education president'' was at odds with his proposal for a modest $500 million increase in federal education spending. She said the increase would not allow federal education spending to keep pace with inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Vow to Die for Kashmir's Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 14th graf ``He said ...'' to UPDATE with Gandhi meeting delegation.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Moslems confined to mosques and homes by a curfew vowed Thursday to die for Kashmir's independence, shouting their slogans at top Indian politicians who arrived to assess the situation. Before the curfew was imposed at 10 a.m. Moslem militants and security forces fought prolonged gunbattles, and at least two people were killed and 10 injured, witnesses said. Islamic and pro-independence slogans, broadcast continuously by mosque loudspeakers, reverberated through this city of 1 million people as the politicians drove from the airport to their hotel. The 14 leaders, belonging to major political parties, traveled the 9-mile route in a convoy of 40 cars escorted by paramilitary troops in trucks mounted with machine guns. ``The slogan of the faith, Allah is great!'' thousands shouted from within the mosques as the convoy drove past at noon. ``We want independence!'' they also chanted. The politicians, including former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, were refused permission to leave their heavily guarded hotel. Security forces strictly enforced the curfew, but the broadcasts continued. Many speeches urged Moslems to sacrifice their lives for Kashmir's independence. At least 173 people have been killed since Jan. 20 when the government launched a crackdown on Moslem militants who demand secession of the predominantly Moslem Jammu-Kashmir state from mostly Hindu India. ``I am shocked. If there is no political solution I see some very hard options ahead,'' Gandhi said at the luxury Centaur Hotel on the edge of Dal Lake. ``I do not want to define them.'' Disenchantment with the government was ``incredible,'' he said, while at least 1,000 commandos and paramilitary police patrolled the lake and gardens surrounding the hotel. Gandhi said state Gov. Jagmohan refused to permit the delegation to visit residents of Srinagar, Jammu-Kashmir's largest city and the center of the secessionist campaign. Jagmohan took charge as the state's governor Jan. 18 and ordered the crackdown. He said allowing Gandhi and the other leaders to go out would have created a ``tremendous security risk.'' Jagmohan later allowed a delegation of about 40 residents to meet Gandhi at his hotel, a police official said. The meeting became unruly, however, and Gandhi was forced to leave as the group shouted slogans blaming his 1984-89 government for the strife in Kashmir. Jagmohan said the curfew will be relaxed Friday after the politicians leave Srinagar. When the curfew was lifted from 5 a.m. to 10 a.m., exchanges of gunfire began, witnesses said. Jagmohan, a Hindu, said Moslem snipers fired at paramilitary police at four places during the curfew relaxation, but said he had no details of casualties. Witnesses said they heard firing from at least a half-dozen areas in downtown Srinagar. Militants were firing from rooftops and pinning down paramilitary troops in roadside bunkers, and the soldiers returned fire sporadically, according to the witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It was like a battlefield,'' one said by telephone. ``I have never heard firing like this before.'' At least two people were killed and 10 injured, according to information gathered from witnesses in several parts of the city. Federal Law Minister Dinesh Goswami, a member of the political delegation, said the ``Kashmir situation today is very serious. This problem must be dealt with at a national level.'' Asked if the government was planning talks with the militants, he said: ``You can have talks in an atmosphere of peace.'' The militants have in the past rejected negotiations with the government, saying they won't compromise. The campaign for an independent Kashmir, simmering since 1948, has flared up in recent months with the consolidation of militant groups. India has accused Pakistan of fomenting the trouble, a charge that Pakistan repeatedly denies. The two countries have gone to war three times since their independence from Britain in 1947 _ twice over Kashmir. A U.N.-sponsored cease-fire line separates Kashmir into Indian and Pakistani areas. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of the 880 million population and Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Charged With Staging Shooting of His Police Cruiser
DOC.TEXT: Authorities say a police officer lied about a shooting incident last year and they are investigating another case in which the officer said a woman fired at him. Officer Vincent Aiello reported that suspects fired at him during a chase of a car that ran a red light last March. But authorities say Aiello fired into his police cruiser, using a gun he found in the car after the occupants fled. Aiello, 30, was charged with offical misconduct, obstruction of justice and false incrimination, acting Bergen County Prosecutor John G. Holl said Wednesday. Aiello resigned from the police force Tuesday night and admitted himself into a hospital for psychiatric evaluation, authorities said. Holl said Aiello will be arraigned after his release. ``He was also suspended,'' said Police Chief Lars Oyen. ``I didn't know if I could accept a resignation from someone in his state of mind.''
