Aiello last year said he chased two men in a car from this Bergen County community south to Jersey City, where the suspects' car crashed and the men fled. Aiello said the men fired at him. Mark Lovette, who was arrested Feb. 7 and charged with attempted murder and other charges in connection with the shooting, was released Tuesday after police determined Aiello used Lovette's gun to shoot at the police car. Holl said police are investigating a Jan. 11 incident in which Aiello said he was shot by a woman whose car was stopped on the highway. One shot grazed him and another hit him in the chest, but he was wearing a bulletproof vest and was only bruised. The official misconduct charge carries a maximum 10-year prison sentence upon conviction and the obstruction and false incrimination carry 18-month terms.

DOC.HEAD: Rates at Highest Level Since June
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on 52-week Treasury bills rose in Thursday's action to the highest level since June. The Treasury Department sold $9.75 billion of the bills at an average discount rate of 7.76 percent, up from 7.42 percent at the last auction on Feb. 13. The rates were the highest since June 1, 1989, when the one-year bills sold for 8.18 percent. The new discount rate understates the actual return to investors _ 8.36 percent with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,215.40.

DOC.HEAD: Writers Nominated for PEN-Faulkner Awards
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Five American writers have been nominated for the PEN-Faulkner Award for the best works of fiction published in 1989, the Folger Shakespeare Library announced Thursday. The nominees are Russell Banks for his novel, ``Affliction;'' E.L. Doctorow for his novel, ``Billy Bathgate;'' Molly Gloss for her novel, ``The Jump-Off Creek;'' Josephine Jacobsen for her collection of stories titled ``On the Island,'' and Lynne Sharon Schwartz for her novel, ``Leaving Brooklyn.'' The winner of the 1990 award will be announced in April. The five nominees, whose works were chosen from among 250 novels and short story collections by a jury of three writers, will be honored at a ceremony at the Folger on May 12. The PEN@Faulkner Award, which is administered by the Folger, was founded in 1980 to pay tribute to the late William Faulkner, who used funds from his Nobel Prize for literature to support other writers.

DOC.HEAD: North Sea Clean-up Conference Ends with Britain Isolated on Key Points
DOC.TEXT: A nine-nation conference on North Sea pollution ended Thursday with agreement on lowering dangerous emissions, but left some countries angry with Britain's stand on sewage dumping and under-sea nuclear waste storage. The coastal states pledged to reduce emissions of mercury, lead, cadmium and dioxins by 70 percent in 1995 and to phase out by decade's end PCBs, or polychlorinated biphenyls, believed to be among the most hazardous materials made by man. In a grudging concession to Britain, the dumping of sewage sludge will be allowed until 1998, while British industry will be allowed to dump until 1993 an annual 205,000 to 270,000 tons of industrial waste into the North Sea, one of the world's most contaminated saltwater bodies. ``We were very disappointed that the United Kingdom could not follow us on this point,'' said Hanja Maij-Weggen, the Dutch transport minister and conference chairman. ``We hope the British will be more flexible the next time.'' British Environment Secretary Chris Patten also refused to rule out Britain's storing nuclear waste under the seabed. Danish Environment Minister Lone Dybkjaer said the conference ended in a ``furious row'' on this issue, and he accused Britain of ``betraying the lives of future generations.'' The two-day conference was the third in a series that began in 1984 in the West German port of Bremen. A follow-up meeting was held in London in 1987. Participants were the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Britain, West Germany, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, as well as the European Commission, the EEC's executive body. Ten other nations, among them East Germany and Czechoslovakia, had observer status. ``It was a very, very tough conference and the results don't go far enough for us,'' particularly in the field of sewage treatment, said West German Environment Minister Klaus Toepfer. ``But we signed the final document because it will bring us a step further in the international field,'' Toepfer told reporters here. On Wednesday, Britain underwent a barrage of criticism because of its failure to meet the 1990 deadline for halting sea dumpings of industrial waste, as had been agreed on in London in 1987. The British contend they need time to convert their industrial plant to land-based waste treatment. They also claim that most of the waste is not hazardous to the marine environment anyway. During extremely tough negotiations Thursday, Patten refused to budge on the issue, conference sources said. On the question of nitrates and phosphates, the cause of massive blooms of algae along the North Sea's coast, the conference decided to stick to its 1987 pledge to cut in half emissions of those substances by 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Major Industrial Nations to Discuss Currency Swings
DOC.TEXT: Top finance officials from the world's seven largest industrial countries will meet in Paris early next month to discuss turbulence in global currency markets and dramatic developments in Eastern Europe, officials confirmed Thursday. The special talks involving the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada were seen as an effort to strengthen economic coordination between the major industrial countries at a time of dramatic change in world affairs. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, who was instrumental in scheduling the meeting, insisted that there was no ``special urgency'' for the gathering of finance ministers and central bank presidents of the seven countries. The talks are scheduled for April 7. However, the discussions will occur just one month before these same officials were scheduled to meet for a regular economic review session in conjunction with the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Washington. Currency markets have been especially volatile in recent weeks with the West German mark and the Japanese yen falling in price while the U.S. dollar has strengthened in value. Private economists predicted that the dollar's strength and the corresponding weakness of the yen and the mark would be a key topic of discussion at the meeting. Analysts said that the rising dollar threatened to worsen an already huge American trade deficit by making foreign products less expensive for U.S. consumers while making American goods more expensive on overseas markets. ``The dollar's strength is of great concern to the administration,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``It constitutes a recession threat because it is a further risk to an already beleaguered industrial side of the U.S. economy.'' The dollar's advance has occurred despite coordinated intervention by the United States and other governments to sell dollars on foreign exchange markets and buy other currencies. Some analysts suggested that since government intervention has proved largely unsuccessful, the G-7 officials might discuss coordinated changes in interest rates. Higher interest rates in Japan and West Germany would tend to bolster their currencies while lower interest rates in the United States would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive.

DOC.HEAD: Blue Mooners Crying in Beer After Losing Landmark Status
DOC.TEXT: The Blue Moon tavern doesn't qualify as a cultural landmark, and hundreds of long-time patrons are left crying in their beer. The 56-year-old tavern's lease runs out in four years and, after that, landowner Westlake Capital Corp. plans to tear it down and build a six-story housing and shopping development, spokesman Robert Hannah told the Seattle Landmarks Preservation Board on Wednesday night. When the eight members of the 11-person board present were evenly divided on whether to grant landmark status, dozens of tavern supporters sporting Blue Moon stickers let out a collective groan. The proposal needed six votes to pass. The Forever Blue Moon Committee pushed for landmark status as the only way to save the establishment from the wrecking ball. ``What the landmarks board has effectively done is say it will not designate any cultural landmarks in Seattle,'' said Walt Crowley, a television commentator and former mayoral aide who helped organize the 1,500-member committee. ``If the Blue Moon does not qualify I cannot imagine what could,'' Crowley said. One patron, John Foss, said the Blue Moon ``is the one spot in town where all these groups of people can come in and speak together.'' ``I went in and sat down at a table last Sunday night,'' he said. ``There were five of us, and none of us knew each other. We ended up speaking on everything from rap music to skiing and urban aesthetics.'' Board member Don Brubeck argued that Seattle has many historic taverns, and though the Blue Moon reportedly has quenched the thirst of such luminaries as Jack Kerouac, Dylan Thomas and Pulitzer-Prize winner Theodore Roethke, it doesn't qualify as a landmark. ``There are some really nice taverns in this city,'' Brubeck said. ``They've been there a long time, and they have a lot of physical integrity. ... If we designate this one, why not all the others?'' The tavern was among the first in Seattle to open after prohibition, just outside the one-mile limit around the University of Washington where sales of alcoholic beverages were banned. Its worn wooden booths bear years of carvings and graffiti. Its walls are plastered with postcards, handbills, road maps and business cards. One wall features the original tavern sign, with its 1930's vintage bathing beauty perched atop a blue crescent moon. A replica of the sign hangs outside today, and supporters say that alone makes it recognizable as the bar where David Wagoner wrote poetry in a back booth, and Jack Leahy wrote outlines for his short stories. Board member Horace Foxall likened the Blue Moon to a sort of university with taps, a place where for decades Seattle residents have met and exchanged ideas. Seattle, he said, is running out of the old taverns that marked it as a port town. ``This is about Seattle history,'' he told other board members. ``This is it, this is what we're preserving.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Says Guatemala's Opium Production Merits Drug Watch List
DOC.TEXT: A congressman criticized the State Department Thursday for not counting Guatemala, an opium producer, among the countries that must be investigated before receiving American aid. ``Why wasn't it on the list?'' Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., chairman of a House Foreign Affairs task force on narcotics asked Melvyn Levitsky, the assistant secretary of State for international narcotics. ``Your figures indicate they produced 14 tons of opium,'' Smith said. Guatemala was not on the certification list in its International Narcotics Control Strategy Report presented to Congress last week. The law requires that the president certify that major drug producing and drug transit countries have ``cooperated fully'' with the United States in anti-drug efforts before they can receive U.S. aid. Nations that produce more than 5 metric tons of opium must be included on the list as major producers. But Levitsky said information about Guatemala's opium production was received after the report was prepared in late 1989. ``There is always an excuse,'' Smith retorted. U.S. officials say Guatemala is taking steps to fight its drug production problem. ``The government of Guatemala recognizes the country's potential as a significant source of opium and took steps in 1989 to reduce opium production through an aerial eradication program supported by the U.S.,'' the strategy report said. Guatemala is also a leading transit country in Central America for cocaine sent from Colombia to the United States, according to David L. Westrate, assistant administrator for operations at the Drug Enforcement Administration. The United States withdrew its ambassador from Guatemala this week because officials said President Vinicio Cerezo had failed to contain an upsurge of assassinations believed to be the work of right-wing extremists. In another development, Smith joined administration officials in criticizing Cuba for refusing to cooperate with the United States on drug interdiction efforts. Recounting the story of a plane suspected of carrying drugs that was lost by U.S. radar over Cuba, Smith said: ``So much for (Cuban President Fidel) Castro's representations about wanting to help.'' The department's report said, ``Cuba ... has failed to respond to several U.S. requests about the seriousness of Cuba's commitment to fighting drug trafficking.''

DOC.HEAD: Emergency U.S. Food Aid Continued to Sudan
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is continuing emergency food shipments to Sudan even while phasing out some other programs in the military-run African country. It was not clear if military aid would be suspended. A congressional provision forced the phasing out of economic assistance. Sudan had eight months under the law to reverse a military takeover but the deadline passed Feb. 28. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Thursday that military sales also were prohibited but that food aid and voluntary programs were continued. Congressional sources said, meanwhile, that the administration has provided Sudan with $25 million a year in military help through other programs. Military officers overthrew Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi's civilian regime June 30, saying multiparty democracy had failed to end a long civil war or save the country's shattered economy. Over the last two years, the United States was to provide Sudan with $23.6 million in food and transportation costs to get the food to the hungry. But much of it has not reached its destination because of sabotage and diversion. Thousands of Sudanese have starved as food is caught up in the war between the Khartoum government and leftist rebels in the south. In the meantime, Sudan has not repaid low-interest loans from the United States. This led to suspension under another congressional provision of $21.4 million in economic assistance this year. Apart from emergency food shipments, a few projects will be continued, including one to assist in building roads. A congressional source, demanding anonymity, said the Bush administration was determined to keep military help going to Sudan. ``They've been doing an end run around Congress,'' he said. In power eight months, Sudan's National Salvation Revolution has done little to revive a collapsing economy or end a debilitating civil war that has killed hundreds of thousands and threatens more with starvation. The war pits the military government against The Sudan People's Liberation Army, which launched a rebellion in 1983. The largest country in Africa, Sudan once was considered a potential bread basket for the region.

DOC.HEAD: Ice Makes Midwest a Skating Rink, Snow Still Immobilizes Part of Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: A storm that staggered the Rockies with snow sealed parts of the Midwest inside a thick layer of ice Thursday, pulling down power lines that served more than 90,000 customers in Des Moines, Iowa, and turning roads into skating rinks. Some major Wyoming highways remained closed a third day by deep snow, idling travelers in motels, restaurants, truck stops and shelters, although temperatures rose above freezing. Hundreds of schools were closed because ice or snow made travel hazardous, or because of lack of electricity. South of the snow and ice belt, up to 7 inches of rain fell overnight and flooded parts of Arkansas, forcing evacuation of some homes in Little Rock. A school bus was swept off a flooded road and into a ditch; its young passengers were evacuated without injury by boat. But the rain also soaked into drought-parched fields in southern Nebraska. Freezing rain during the night brought down tree branches and power lines across wide sections of Nebraska, South Dakota, Minnesota, Iowa and Wisconsin. Des Moines was hardest hit, with nearly 60 percent of customers in the metropolitan area blacked out. Police said nearly every street in the city was closed or partially closed at some point by downed lines or fallen limbs. Des Moines received more than 2 inches of precipitation in the 24 hours before 6 a.m., and state Climatologist Harry Hillaker estimated that about half of it was frozen rain. ``I stepped outside last night in a safe place, no power lines or trees nearby, just to hear all the trees snapping off,'' Hillaker said. ``I thought, `I've got to experience this. It may not be like this ever again.''' He said he took his 7-year-old daughter along but she became frightened within a minute. A utility company spokesman said people without service should expect another night in the dark and that some areas might not have service until Sunday. Des Moines schools closed for the first time this winter, as did schools and day cares in most suburbs. Drake University called off classes when the campus lost all power Wednesday night. ``We've got 1,700 kids living on campus with no electricity or phones,'' said university spokesman Gary Bonnett. ``Imagine the food problems. This morning they fed 'em cereal and bananas.'' Iowa Power spokesman John McCarroll said at least 90,000 customers did not have service by Thursday morning, but president Lynn Vorbrich said that number was trimmed to 75,000 by mid-day. Other utilities across the state reported scattered outages, as did utilities in South Dakota and Nebraska. Gov. Terry Branstad declared 11 central Iowa counties disaster areas, making them eligible for National Guard and Transportation Department assistance. Minnesota hospitals reported treating several people who had fallen on slippery sidewalks. In northeastern Minnesota, a pileup involving 20 to 30 vehicles forced the temporary closing of U.S. 169 near Calumet. WCCO-AM in Minneapolis, whose signal covers much of the upper Midwest and on many winter mornings broadcasts lists of school closings, said it received reports of nearly 160 closings Thursday in Minnesota, and more in western Wisconsin. Temperatures leaped above freezing Thursday across the southeastern quarter of Wyoming, largely shut down since the storm dumped heavy snow Tuesday, with 19 inches at the capital, Cheyenne. But about 220 miles of interstate highways remained closed for the third straight day. The Wyoming highway patrol opened one westbound lane of Interstate 80 from Cheyenne to Laramie at mid-morning. But dispatcher Gary Gonzalez couldn't offer a guess on when the rest of I-80 might be reopened between Cheyenne and Laramie or I-25 from Cheyenne north to Wheatland. At Denver, officials of the Regional Transportation District said the public transit system was back on a full schedule. Many schools in northern Colorado remained closed. U.S. 287 north of Fort Collins, Colo., to the Wyoming line reopened Thursday, the last major northern Colorado highway to remain closed after the blizzard dumped more than 4 feet of snow on some parts of the Front Range.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Lawmakers Attend Seminar With President Emeritus
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon, whose political career began in Congress, came back to Capitol Hill on Thursday to dispense geopolitical wisdom to a large audience of Republican legislators who wanted his views. To a rapt audience, some of whom had not been born when Nixon began his first term as a representative from California in 1947, the former president roamed the political globe for more than an hour. Republican Whip Newt Gingrich called the feat ``an extraordinary tour de force.'' Nixon was clearly elated by the response. ``It's good to be back here where my political career started 43 years ago,'' he said. ``Why are you here?'' asked a reporter. ``Because they invited me.'' That, in itself, is something that might not have happened only a few years ago. For a decade after his 1974 resignation _ prompted by an imminent impeachment vote in the House _ Nixon was anathema to Republicans. His name was not mentioned at GOP political gatherings or at national conventions. But he worked his way back, through analytical books about world affairs, magazine articles, a few speeches to influential audiences, off-the-record dinners with reporters, trips to China and meeting with successor presidents who sought his views. He was pale and a bit more jowly than in the past and his walk was that of a 77-year-old man, which he is. But he was in good humor as he talked with reporters _ never his favorite audience _ saying ``as I look at this crowd, I know I'm getting older but the press seems to be getting younger.'' In the closed session with the lawmakers and invited guests, Nixon referred to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev as a ``troika _ a communist, a Russian nationalist and a brilliant practical politician.'' According to a House staff member who was there, Nixon said Gorbachev decided he would risk his power to save his reforms, rather than the other way around. And that, according to Nixon, meant that Gorbachev ``would take credit for something he really didn't want or set out to do.'' Nixon called the developments in Eastern Europe ``a change of the head and not of the heart.'' Reporters asked what he thought of this week's proposal by Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., the House majority leader, that direct U.S. aid be sent to help the Soviet Union succeed in its reform effort. Gephardt specifically called for food aid and freer investment in the Soviet Union. ``My reaction to is that it is a bad idea: first, because Gorbachev has not indicated his wants it,'' Nixon said. ``No aid, directly or indirectly should be provided for Gorbachev unless his reforms have a chance to work.'' Further, Nixon said, Gorbachev must first adopt a less aggressive foreign policy, particularly in the Third World. ``What has happened here is the Cold War is probably over in Eastern Europe but is still being waged in the Third World,'' he said. Gorbachev, he said, should also stop sending aid to Cuba. ``If Gorbachev continues to provide $6 billion a year to prop up Castro, Castro is going to stay. If Gorbachev cuts off his water, so to speak, Castro has to make his deal with the West.'' ``The key is Gorbachev,'' said Nixon. At that point, Nixon was addressed as ``Mr. Gorbachev'' by a tangle-tongued reporter. ``I've been called worse,'' said Nixon.

DOC.HEAD: Government Supporters Stage Demonstration in Cuba
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of government supporters staged a demonstration Thursday in front of a house where witnesses said a meeting of dissidents was taking place. The demonstration featured the chanting of anti-American slogans and noisy expressions of support for hard-line President Fidel Castro. It took place outside the home of Gustavo Arcos, a well-known human rights activist who was said to be meeting with three allies. A similar demonstraton occurred Monday in front of the home of Arcos' brother, Sebastian Arcos, who also was said to have convened a meeting of dissidents. Witnesses said that after neighbors learned of the Thursday meeting the pro-government activists arrived and staged their demonstration ``spontaneously.'' It was a peaceful protest, but several participants reacted angrily when an unidentified woman appeared on the balcony of the home and stuck her tongue out at them. ``They are meeting at this house to make plans for the counterrevolution,'' said one demonstrator. Castro has repeatedly said his country will never embrace the reforms orchestrated by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and increasingly accepted throughout Eastern Europe. An article in a Soviet newspaper Tuesday reflects the growing divergence between the Kremlin and Cuba as Gorbachev moves to reduce the power of the Communist Party in the Soviet Union. In the article, the weekly Moscow News said Castro has used intransigence and relied on outdated ideas to keep his country in check. It noted that state-run Cuban radio carried editorial attacks on the collapse of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe and blamed the changes on ``weak governments unable to tackle economic turmoil.'' ``Such categorical judgments are pronounced in an island with total rationing, which insures people against poverty, but does not give them the impetus to work,'' Moscow News said. It mocked the Cuban leader for his Dec. 7 statement saying, ``if history will attach to us the role of the last defenders of socialism in the world _ we will defend this stronghold to the last drop of blood.'' The Cuban model that Castro wants to defend is based on a complete rejection of a market economy, moral principles over material ones, a militarized state and an untouchable party-state elite, the newspaper said. ``Cuba copied none other but Soviet administrative and economic structures at the time when European socialism was sinking into the swamp of stagnation'' based on the ideological dogma of the late leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, it said. Cuba gets about $5 billion in annual aid from the Soviet Union. Despite Castro's pledge to defend the party at all costs and ignore change in the socialist community, Moscow News said about 15 dissident groups have emerged in Cuba. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Thursday it is not surprising that a Soviet newspaper should be critical of Cuba. ``Cuba remains a rigid police state,'' she said. ``At a time where the Soviet government is changing its domestic and foreign policies, Cuba is becoming ever more isolated and rigid.'' ``Obviously, Cuba is out of step and resisting the rising tide of change,'' she said. ``Castro is isolated even among socialist countries.''

DOC.HEAD: Castro Offers to Leave 1,000 Cuban Workers in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Cuban President Fidel Castro has offered to leave 1,000 Cuban workers in Nicaragua if the new U.S.-supported administration agrees, the Sandinista party newspaper said Thursday. In a front page story from Havana, the newspaper Barricada said Castro offered to keep the volunteers on the Atlantic Coast, where they are rebuilding homes damaged by a 1988 hurricane and helping with health care and other community services. Most of them are in the port of Bluefields, where Castro said they ``can remain if that is the wish of the new government and if it guarantees the security of Cuban personnel.'' Officials of Yatama, the dominant Atlantic Coast political organization which supported President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, said the Cubans were welcome to stay. The newspaper said Cuba had been giving Nicaragua 90,000 tons of crude oil and 50,000 rations of food a year. It said the food was mostly for Miskito, Sumo and Rama Indian communities on the Atlantic Coast. On Wednesday, Castro announced he will stop sending military aid, petroleum or food after Mrs. Chamorro takes office. ``Our military cooperation ... will be withdrawn when the new government takes office. It would not be possible to maintain our presence with a government which has shown its dislike for the Cuban revolution,'' Castro said in a speech to a women's organization in Havana. Excerpts of the speech were quoted in a dispatch by the Cuban government news agency Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico City. Exact figures on Cuban military aid have never been released by Havana or Managua. However, the U.S. State Department said last year that Moscow provided about $500 million in military aid to Nicaragua in 1988. Since Mrs. Chamorro's election, Cuban Ambassador Fernando Ravelo has returned to Havana ``for consultations'' and a secretary at the embassy, who answered the telephone, said she had no information on his return. Last fall, the Soviet Union said it had suspended further weapons shipments to Nicaragua under President Mikhail Gorbachev's liberalization policies. Also Thursday, representatives of the Sandinistas and Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition met privately to make Nicaragua's first transition to an elected opposition government a peaceful one. Details of the talks were not made public immediately. But officials on both sides said they centered on demands for the immediate demobilization of the U.S.-supported Contra rebels and Mrs. Chamorro's plan to sharply cut the armed forces, which are controlled by the Sandinista party. Both Mrs. Chamorro and outgoing President Daniel Ortega have called on the Contras, based in neighboring Honduras, to demobilize immediately. But rebel leaders say they will only do so after Mrs. Chamorro is sworn into office April 25 for a six-year term and after their safety is guaranteed when they return. Another issue reportedly being discussed is UNO's plan to return private property, expropriated by the Sandinistas during their decade in office, as part of a policy of lifting state controls over the economy and encouraging private enterprise. The Sandinistas are balking at returning banks to private ownership. UNO leaders, meanwhile, are complaining the Sandinistas are trying to ram through the National Assembly, which they will still control for more than a month, bills legalizing titles to properties the government confiscated and distributed among Sandinista supporters. In Washington, the State Department condemned what it said were recent actions taken by the Sandinista government, including distributing weapons to their followers, as ``disturbing signs that the Sandinistas are not keeping faith with their promises to honor a peaceful transfer of power.'' Margaret Tutwiler, the department's spokeswoman, also cited the emptying of government offices and threats to enact economic measures. Such measures ``would make it exceedingly difficult to bring about the economic recovery of that country,'' she said. Meanwhile, Mrs. Chamorro left Thursday for Caracas to visit Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez before going to Houston for additional treatment for a knee that she fractured on Dec. 31. It was her second trip abroad as president-elect. Wednesday, she visited briefly with another old friend, President Oscar Arias of Costa Rica.

DOC.HEAD: Top Republicans Predict Party Change on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Two leading Republicans in Congress predicted on Thursday that their party will change the strict anti-abortion stance that has been part of its platform since 1980. Sen. Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the second-ranking Republican in the Senate, predicted the 1992 GOP platform committee will ``come up with something'' in an effort to soften the plank. ``It will speak to the sanctity of life and it will do things and it will be probably altered. I'm sure of that,'' said Simpson, who has long held the position that a woman should have the right to have an abortion. ``I don't know whether it will be an exact excising or changing of it or what,'' he said. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House minority whip, and Simpson disputed the widespread perception that Republican candidates opposed to abortion have been hurt since a Supreme Court ruling last summer. The court gave states more authority to restrict abortions _ and thus intensified political debate on the emotion-filled issue. But Gingrich, who opposes abortion rights, said the new GOP platform will cater to voters' conflicting feeling about abortion by supporting restrictions if not a total ban. ``The Republican Party, I will venture to predict ... will draw the line in such a way that we are clearly the party which will have fewer abortions in America than the Democrats,'' he said. ``We will be for restrictions that NOW and NARAL will not favor such as making sure that 12-year-olds have their parent's consent before they go to an abortion clinic.'' he said. The National Organization for Women and the National Abortion Rights Action League oppose government blocking a woman's right to choose abortion. They also oppose efforts in some states to require one or both parents' consent or notification before a minor woman can receive an abortion. ``We will in fact be responsive to changing circumstances,'' Gingrich said, citing polls that gauge which abortion restrictions are favored by the public. President Bush has stuck by the anti-abortion position that he embraced as a vice presidential candidate in 1980. But Republican Party officials, including national chairman Lee Atwater, have sought to defuse the divisive issue by saying the party has no litmus test and remains open to candidates and voters on both sides of the abortion debate.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf of 1st item to CORRECT spelling of practice
DOC.TEXT: Marcia Hoebreckx can practice piano in her condominium, but only if she keeps her foot firmly on the soft pedal, a judge ruled. A neighbor complained that Hoebreckx's rendition of Chopin violated a 1981 city ordinance that prohibits Boulder residents from ``disrupting the quiet enjoyment of a home.'' Municipal Judge Richard Hansen reluctantly upheld the complaint Wednesday, and fined the pianist $30. If she wants to continue her hobby, she must perform pianissimo, he said. The judge acknowledged the ordinance was a ``poor'' law, and encouraged Hoebreckx to either appeal or orchestrate a campaign to repeal the ordinance. ``I really feel being allowed to play the piano in the privacy of my home is an inalienable right,'' Hoebreckx said. ``My peace of mind, my whole living standard has been violated.'' Hoebreckx, coordinator of a writing program at the University of Colorado, said she never plays before 10 a.m. or after 10 p.m. Her next-door neighbors, Chris Whelan and Julia Ermes, complained to the Environmental Protection Office. When mediation failed, a trial was arranged. Other neighbors testified they weren't bothered by the music, and decibel tests found the noise to be within acceptable limits. But the judge said he had no choice in accepting the ordinance. The City Council, he said, wanted ``a silent town, and they passed an ordinance designed to get that with little or no consideration given to the active people or things that might make noise.'' Hoebreckx says she's considering her options, but they don't include quitting the piano. ``It's what I do and what I enjoy,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Suggests Spy Agencies Differ on Soviet Threat
DOC.TEXT: The nation's main intelligence agencies disagree on whether the waning Soviet military threat could be revived, a Pentagon official suggested Thursday. Pete Williams, a spokesman for Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, ackowledged that Cheney differs on the issue with CIA Director William Webster, who told Congress last week it is unlikely the Soviets would pose a major military threat in the future, even if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev were replaced by hardliners. Cheney contends that Moscow's move toward a less aggressive military stance could be reversed if Gorbachev lost power. Cheney argues that this possibility alone is reason not to rapidly reduce U.S. troop levels and military spending. At a Pentagon briefing, Williams denied a published report that Cheney's view also is at odds with the Defense Intelligence Agency, the Pentagon's intelligence arm. ``There is no evidence that the secretary and the DIA are out of step'' on the question of whether the Soviet reforms are reversible, Williams said, adding later that it would be ``a fair characterization'' to say Cheney and the DIA agree on the issue. Williams' remarks suggested that the DIA and the CIA don't agree on the issue, although the spokesman declined to comment directly on the agencies' exact views. ``We don't discuss intelligence, so I'm somewhat limited in the answer that I can give,'' he said. The disagreement has important political implications because Bush administration estimates of Soviet military capabilities play an important role in the congressional debate under way on next year's defense budget. Williams said the split between Webster and Cheney was not personal and the two planned to hold a breakfast meeting at CIA headquarters Thursday to discuss world events. Williams also sought to play down Cheney's remark in a weekend television interview that Webster's testimony _ delivered on the same day Cheney was giving another congressional committee a different view of the Soviet threat _ was ``not helpful'' to the administration's efforts to win approval of the defense budget. ``Secretary Cheney does not view anyone's job as defending the defense budget in their testimony in Congress,'' Williams said. He added later that Cheney ``has no intention to ... stifle different views within the intelligence community.''

DOC.HEAD: Dying Doctor Settles AIDS Lawsuit; Amount Not Disclosed
LaserPhoto NY27, NY31
DOC.TEXT: A doctor who was suing the city claiming she had contracted AIDS though the carelessness of another physician accepted a settlement Thursday as attorneys were preparing to present their trial summations. The judge would say only that the amount was ``between zero and $100 million.'' Jurors interviewed after the settlement indicated they had been leaning in favor of the plaintiff, Dr. Veronica Prego. Prego, pale and looking tired as she sat between her two attorneys, sighed in relief as the judge dismissed the jurors. She said a short time later she was happy the trial had finally ended. ``It's been extremely difficult for me,'' she said, complaining that her health had worsened because of the strain of the more than 2-month-long trial. ``Now it's time to take care of myself.'' The trial judge, Justice Aaron D. Bernstein of Brooklyn's state Supreme Court, ordered the lawyers on both sides not to disclose the amount of the settlement. ``It's no one's business, except the people who are paying it and the person who's receiving it,'' Bernstein said. ``It has nothing to do with the relative merits of this case.'' Under the agreement, sealed by Bernstein, none of the parties named in Prego's lawsuit acknowledged any guilt. Prego maintained in her lawsuit, which named the city Health and Hospitals Corp. and two physicians, that she contracted the deadly disease when a doctor who drew blood from an AIDS patient in 1983 left the contaminated needle and other debris on the patient's bedding. Prego said she accidentally pricked her finger while cleaning up the waste. Diane Wilner, a lawyer for Prego, said the settlement was reluctantly accepted because defense lawyers said they would appeal any jury victory by Prego. ``Dr. Prego must live the rest of her life with some peace and must be able to put this behind her,'' Wilner said. ``In essence, I believe they put a gun to our head with the appeal.'' An appeal would tie the matter up in the courts for two to three years. Prego's doctor had testified the 32-year-old woman might have less than a year to live. Health and Hospitals Corp. lawyer Stanley D. Friedman said of the settlement, ``We're most pleased, I can't tell you the numbers, but we're most pleased.'' Most of the six jurors said they were glad they were spared deciding the outcome, but indicated they were leaning toward Prego. ``I was on Miss Prego's side because it's a human life. You can't replace that,'' said Jill Goldberg, a 22-year-old cashier. ``I felt bad for her. ... I think the hospital was negligent.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Wants Anti-Smoking Spots to Balance Sports Sponsors
DOC.TEXT: A children's advocacy group asked on Thursday that regulators require broadcasters and cable TV operators show anti-smoking messages on youth-oriented programs if they televise sports events sponsored by cigarette companies. Action for Children's Television, which was instrumental in reviving advertising limits for Saturday morning children's TV shows, asked the Federal Communications Commission to close a ``loophole'' in a 1969 law that banned cigarette advertising from television. The group said cigarette companies got around the ban after it went into effect in 1971 ban by sponsoring televised sports events such as tennis tournaments and car races, making their brands part of the names of the events. ACT said TV cameras also routinely show billboards advertising cigarettes behind the sports action being shown. ACT called them ``hidden commercials'' that subverts the purpose of the 1969 law. Congress passed the law ``because it had concluded that it is not in the public interest to have cigarettes advertised over such unique media that reach into every household and are particularly viewed by the young,'' ACT told the FCC. ``The young are being bombarded over television by hidden messages associated with sports ... that are meant to show that smoking is attractive,'' ACT President Peggy Charren said in an interview. ACT said it was no accident that cigarette companies created the Virginia Slims tour in 1971, Winston Cup racing in 1971 and Marlboro Cup racing in 1973. The sponsors often place billboards in positions where cameras are sure to pick them up, the group said. The filing quoted from an opinion piece by syndicated columnist George Will in the Feb. 25 Washington Post that said NBC-TV's 93-minute telecast of the 1989 Marlboro Grand Prix contained 4,997 images of Marlboro billboards and 249 of the Marlboro-sponsored car. ``The brand name was visible 46 of the 93 minutes _ 49 percent of the telecast,'' ACT told the FCC. ACT called on the FCC to require broadcast and cable networks that show such events ``carry offsetting anti-smoking messages'' during the advertising breaks in ``programs that have large youth audiences.'' Officials at the New York-based Philip Morris Co., which makes Virginia Slims and Marlboro cigarettes, and at Winston-Salem, N.C.-based R.J. Reynolds, which makes Winston, had no immediate comment on the filing. Nor did Washington representatives of the broadcasting and cable TV industries. Charren said she believes the time is ripe to petition the government on this issue in the wake of recent attacks on cigarette advertising by Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan and reports that tobacco companies were aiming new brands at blue collar, white females and urban blacks. Congress also recently imposed a virtual ban on smoking on U.S. airliners, and Rep. Thomas A. Luken, D-Ohio, has introduced legislation to outlaw tobacco advertising and promotion that could reach anyone under age 18. It would also bar sponsorship of events that use a cigarette brand name. Luken's bill would permit text-only ads in newspapers, magazines and other publications, plus signs and billboards outside, but not in, sports facilities. When the 1969 law went into effect the FCC dropped provisions of its so-called fairness doctrine that required anti-smoking messages on television.

DOC.HEAD: Youngsters' Watch More PBS When Left Alone Than Supervised, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: Young children left to themselves watch more educational television than when their parents watch with them, says a new study that looked at scores of working-class households in California. ``These findings suggest that children prefer PBS (Public Broadcasting Service) over commercial networks, but when children and parents view TV together, they watch the commercial channels that the parents prefer,'' the study said. It supported previous findings that preschool children watch about 25 hours of television a week, watch fewer hours after they start school and are usually unsupervised by parents in their programming choices, authors said. ``The important thing to me is that the attitude that parents set up in relation to television in the home seems to have an impact on what children will watch and how much they watch,'' said Dr. Howard L. Taras, lead author and assistant pediatrics professor at the University of California at San Diego. ``Children of parents who regard television more as a babysitter or distraction will watch more TV,'' he said in a telephone interview Wednesday. Also, children of parents who regard television more as an educational tool will watch more PBS, he said. The study found children viewed more PBS programming in households where television was not routinely being used as entertainment, parents were not viewing TV with the youngsters more than 50 percent of the time, and children had a strong influence on program selection. The study was based on interviews with working-class English-and Spanish-speaking parents from households that totaled 66 children ages 3 to 8 in a suburban San Diego community. Findings were published in the March issue of the American Medical Association's American Journal of Diseases of Children. ``I hope beyond hope that they're right, but I can't quite believe it,'' said Peggy Charron, president of Action for Children's Television, a child advocacy group based in Cambridge, Mass. And yet, she said, the findings make sense because preschoolers ``like public broadcasting. ... They relate to Mr. Rogers because he's talking to them, and they really get to know him and _ as much as possible through the medium of television _ get to love him,'' she said in a telephone interview Wednesday. ``He's like a substitute parent. And they love Sesame Street. ... I can't imagine what they get out of commercial broadcasting. It's so noisy and fast, and peculiar and violent.'' Gary Selnow, a visiting professor of communications studies at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, Va., agreed with the speculation of the study's authors: ``If the parents are watching with the kids, there may be sort of subtle pressure for parents to encourage the kids to watch something that would also be of interest to the parents.'' But he refused to ``jump'' on network television. Commercial programs promote many of society's most laudable values _ ``people who help each other are the ones who succeed. Problems are resolved by hard work,'' he said in a telephone interview. The study did not single out particular programs from commercial or public television. Taras said the group plans to follow up on its findings with more detailed research.

DOC.HEAD: New York Lawmaker Urges Recall of Infant Pillows
DOC.TEXT: A New York legislator and a Florida couple whose six-week-old son was found dead on an infant pillow urged the Consumer Product Safety Commission on Thursday to immediately recall the cushions. Republican Sen. Alfonse D'Amato criticized the commission for ``an entirely too casual attitude'' about taking legal action against the pillow manufacturers. The commission on Tuesday warned consumers not to allow infants to sleep on the small pillows or cushions, which are filled with plastic foam beads, because of the potential danger of suffocation. Ten infants have died while sleeping on the pillows since 1987, the agency said. It has not taken action against the manufacturers or distributors because an investigation is ongoing, officials said. Gigi Lindstrom, whose son died on one of the pillows last year, urged parents not to use the pillows, retailers to take them off store shelves, manufacturers to recall them and lawmakers to take action to remove the ``killer pillows'' from the marketplace. D'Amato, who earlier this week praised the agency's warning to consumers, on Thursday complained it had tried to dissuade increased publicity which might ``disrupt delicate industry negotiations'' the agency is conducting. An agency spokesman said officials had not tried to prevent the publicity but said ``there was concern about releasing names of companies ... which could jeopardize our activities down the road.''

DOC.HEAD: IRS, Owed a Dime, Bills for $54.94 in Penalties and Interest
DOC.TEXT: For want of a dime, the Internal Revenue Service hit Mary Frances Stinson with a bill for $54.94. The Dorchester, Mass., woman underpaid by 10 cents when she filed her federal tax return in 1987. The IRS computers eventually caught the mistake and last October sent a form letter telling her she had been hit with a $24 late-payment penalty and interest of $30.84. ``It was almost like a joke,'' Ms. Stinson said Thursday. ``If I have to, I'll pay them, which really stinks.'' She acknowledged, however, that she has yet to write the IRS to clear up the mistake. As spelled out on the form Ms. Stinson received, the penalty is limited by law to 25 percent of the late tax _ in this case that would be 2 cents. The interest on the late payment averages about 10 percent, which would be about a penny a year for Ms. Stinson. ``I wouldn't think we would even send a notice on 10 cents due,'' said IRS spokesman Wilson Fadely, noting that a stamp costs 25 cents. Any time an erroneous bill is send, he said, ``you should just write and tell us.'' Ms. Stinson said she had telephoned her local IRS office and was told to write the IRS regional service center in Andover, Mass., which sent the form letter. ``So it's just a matter of writing up the actual letter and informing them of this,'' she told a reporter. ``But it was a little unreal to me that I'd even get that type of thing in the first place.'' Instead of writing the IRS, Ms. Stinson handed her bill to the National Coalition of IRS Whistleblowers, which was established by the Church of Scientology. The coalition called the form letter an outrage and turned it over to a reporter.

DOC.HEAD: Slumping ``Today'' Show Second in Sweeps Ratings
DOC.TEXT: NBC's slumping ``Today'' show lost to ABC's ``Good Morning America'' in ratings ``sweeps'' for the first time since November 1985, according to audience estimates made public Thursday. In the Feb. 1-28 sweeps, ABC's show, which has won the ratings race for the last nine weeks, averaged a 4.5 rating. ``Today'' had a 3.65 average and third-place ``CBS This Morning'' a 2.7. Each rating point represents 921,000 homes. NBC executives have said they expected ``Today'' ratings to dip after co-host Jane Paley was succeeded by Deborah Norville in January. They say that also happened when Bryant Gumbel succeeded Tom Brokaw on the show in 1982. However, February's figures show a considerable drop for ``Today,'' whose troubles include the leak last year of Gumbel's caustic memo about some staff members, and controversy over Pauley's replacement by Norville. Last year, when a ratings point represented 904,000 homes, ``Today'' won the February sweeps with a 4.6 average, followed closely by ``Good Morning America'' with a 4.2. ``CBS This Morning'' averaged a 2.6 then. The sweeps occur four times a year and are periods of intense audience measurements in the nations's 211 TV markets, according to the A.C. Nielsen Co. They are important to local stations, which use the results to set their advertising rates.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Democrats' Campaign Finance Bill
DOC.TEXT: Democrats pushed their version of a campaign finance bill with fixed limits on how much candidates can spend through a Senate committee Thursday as prospects for a compromise brightened The Rules Committee approved the Democrat's ideas for reform on a 7-3 party-line vote, but lawmakers acknowledged the action was intended only to get serious negotiations started between the two parties. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he intends to bring the issue before the full Senate as soon as it completes action on a clean air bill and crime legislation _ possibly late this month or early April. ``The Senate now knows that the issue is not going away,'' said Okalahoma Sen. David Boren, the primary author of the Democratic bill. ``There has to be a time deadline out there for the negotiations to begin.'' Boren and his key ideological opponent on the issue, Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., both said their hopes for a compromise were buoyed by an outside panel's endorsement Wednesday of limits on how much candidates can raise from political action committees and out-of-state donors. The six-member task force appointed by Mitchell and Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas called for ``flexible'' spending ceilings with a provivion that would exclude small contributions _ possibly $250 or less _ from in-state donors from the total. Boren hailed it as the first bipartisan recognition of the need for some form of spending ceiling while McConnell praised the distinction between ``good money from those who can vote for you and bad money from special interests and other outsiders who can't.'' Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, called the recommendation a ``genius solution'' to the GOP's abhorrence of any spending limits and Democrats' fears of superior Republican Party fund raising. However, there is still widespread disagreement between the parties and within each on how much political action committees, or PACs, should be reigned in and the role of now-unreported, so-called ``soft money'' in politics. The task force avoided the ``soft money'' issue but proposed cutting allowable individual PAC contributions to a candidate in half once the aggregate of them reach's one-third of the candidate's spending ceiling. PAC contributions in recent elections have overwhelmingly gone to Democratic incumbents, and Republicans would like to cut the allowable gift by a PAC to an individual candidate from $10,000 to $2,000 per election cycle. Boren and Mitchel have proposed putting a $100,000 ceiling on PAC gifts a House candidate can receive and an $825,000 lid on Senate candidates. In addition they would tell the parties' Senate and House campaign committees that no more than 30 percent of their total contributions could come from PACs.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel Ends Politically-Charged Case Against Republican Whip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 11-13 pvs to CORRECT royalty figure and clarify book promotion arrangement; picks up 14th graf pvs, ``The partners''
DOC.TEXT: The House ethics committee said Thursday it found ``no adequate basis'' to investigate Republican Whip Newt Gingrich, but criticized his failure to disclose a home purchase and his loose control over his staff. The report concluded that even if most allegations made against the Georgia Republican were true, they would not violate House rules. The No. 2-ranking House Republican, who was the chief accuser in the ethics case that triggered Democratic Speaker Jim Wright's resignation last year, has called the case filed against him a political retaliation. Gingrich said Thursday the report demonstrated the charges filed by Rep. Bill Alexander, D-Ark., were ``politically inspired nonsense.'' He contended the ``political smear'' cost taxpayers at least $300,000 and himself more than $100,000 in legal fees. Jan Keyes, spokeswoman for the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct _ the ethics panel's formal name _ said she could not verify the $300,000 cost. Gingrich was criticized by the committee for failing to report on his annual disclosure forms his joint purchase, with his daughter, of her home in Fulton County, Ga. in 1986. He also was criticized for his staff's use of his official letterhead in December 1986 and January 1987 to promote a for-profit cruise. Gingrich was ordered to ``promptly amend'' his disclosure statments to reflect purchase of the house and was warned of ``more severe committee action'' if he fails to prevent future misdeeds by his staff. But Alexander's complaint was also criticized. ``Some of the assertions are pure speculation,'' the committee concluded. ``Others advance unusual legal arguments not supported by prior committee interpretations.'' The most publicized issue in the case was whether Gingrich violated outside income limits and rules against receiving gifts from those with a direct interest in legislation. The allegations focused on the ``COS Limited Partnership'' Gingrich formed to promote a book, ``Window of Opportunity,'' he wrote with his wife and a third author. Alexander also questioned Gingrich's royalty arrangement. The committee found Gingrich properly listed as royalties the $24,036 he and his wife received from book sales and advances. Alexander questioned whether Gingrich exceeded outside income limits with the payments, but the committee concluded the royalties were exempted from the ceiling. The committee also rejected Alexander's allegation that the $105,000 raised from the 21 ``COS'' investors to promote the book could be considered ``gifts'' from people seeking legislative favors from Gingrich. ``The partners may simply have been seeking, in addition to making investments, advancing the political or philosophical policies which Rep. Gingrich advocated in the book,'' the committee said. Gingrich is the leader of conservative Republicans in the House. ``In sum, the committee is of the firm view that no adequate basis exists for initiating a preliminary inquiry'' in the case, the panel said, referring to the first phase of its investigative process. The committee set up what amounted to an initial investigation when it hired a Chicago law firm last July for advice on whether to pursue the case. The firm recommended last October the case should be dismissed due to lack of evidence that rules were broken. The panel wrote Gingrich a letter on the home purchase and the travel promotion, which paralleled its findings in the report. ``You were remiss in your oversight and administration of your congressional office,'' the committee wrote in criticizing the letters promoting the cruise for senior citizens. Gingrich on Thursday blamed the travel-promotion letters on a staffer _ ``a young man who made a mistake in judgment.'' The panel also wrote Gingrich that the joint purchase of his daughter's home ``as well as the underlying liability you incurred, should have been reported on your financial disclosure statements.'' The panel said it considered _ and rejected _ Gingrich's contention that he was only a guarantor of the loan and signed documents only as an accommodation for his daughter. Gingrich said Thursday he failed to report that he co-signed the mortgage stemmed because he misread of House rules.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Director Denies Suspension Triggered by Agent's Bias Probe
DOC.TEXT: FBI Director William B. Sessions strongly denied on Thursday an allegation that a highly decorated counterespionage agent was suspended because of his efforts to uncover anti-Hispanic bias at the bureau. The charge was leveled earlier this week by attorneys for Fernando Mata, a Miami-based agent who was suspended, with pay, about two months ago. Administration sources, who declined identification, said he was suspected of unauthorized contacts with Cuban intelligence agents. Mata, 48, a Cuban-American, was a key witness in a successful 1988 suit by 311 Hispanic agents who accused the bureau of bias in hirings, promotions and discipline. His attorneys, Hugo Rodriguez and Antonio Silva, have charged that Mata and other Hispanics involved in the suit have been targeted for harassment at a time when a court-appointed panel is about to begin a follow-up review of the case. ``The FBI categorically denies retaliation against Agent Mata,'' Sessions said Thursday in a written statement. ``There is no connection between Agent Mata's being placed on administrative leave with pay and the lawsuit in which he participated. The FBI further denies that it leaked any information relating to the inquiry.'' ``The FBI is acutely aware of its obligations to protect the rights of employees who use legal procedures available to them to express their grievances,'' the director's statement continued. ``Allegations of retaliation against any employee for having taken advantage of these procedures are taken very seriously by the FBI, and, if confirmed, will be met with stern disciplinary action. Allegations that information of an official nature may have been leaked by any FBI employee for any reason will likewise be met with stern disciplinary action if confirmed.'' Mata, who in 1983 received the Justice Department's top award for counterespionage, has said that in 1988, shortly before his testimony in the discrimination case, he was confronted with allegations that he compromised national security while working undercover. No charges have ever been filed against him. ``The case against Mr. Mata is a house of cards,'' said Silva, an El Paso, Texas, attorney who represented Mata in the bias case, heard by U.S. District Judge Lucius D. Bunton in El Paso. ``There is no substance whatsoever to the allegations,'' Silva said. ``It is nothing more than reprisals and retaliation against him.'' Bunton ruled that the FBI had demonstrated a pattern of discrimination against Hispanics, called its affirmative action program ``bankrupt,'' and ordered sweeping changes in its promotion policies. A special panel headed by former Rep. Barbara Jordan, D-Texas, is about to begin its evaluation of the FBI's compliance, and Mata and others are expected to testify once more. In Miami, Rodriguez, Mata's other attorney, said ``It is very ironic that those hearings are going to go forth next month, and that allegations against Mr. Mata and other agents ... are all of a sudden surfacing.'' He said minor administrative actions had been taken against about 10 others involved in the lawsuit, including agents in El Paso and San Antonio, Texas; Los Angeles; San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Atlanta. Overall, there are 425 Hispanic agents among the FBI's 10,000 employees, according to Rodriguez, himself a former agent. Rodriguez confirmed that his client had again been questioned about the possibility of contacts with Cuban intelligence agents several years ago. He said Mata had taken several lie detector tests, and passed them all. ``Fernando Mata is not a spy. They know that, everyone knows that,'' Rodriguez said. Only one FBI agent has ever been charged with espionage. Richard Miller, an FBI counterspy based in Los Angeles, was convicted of delivering defense secrets to Soviet agents, but the conviction was overturned by a federal appeals court last year. A new trial is scheduled to begin later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Bounces Basketball In Anti-Drug Commercial
DOC.TEXT: President Bush took to the basketball court at Georgetown University on Thursday to tape a pair of anti-drug ads that will be aired during the NCAA basketball tournament. He appeared alone in the two 30-second public service announcements. He did not shoot any baskets but dribbled a basketball between takes. The Georgetown Hoyas use the field house as their practice facility but play their home games at a larger arena in Maryland. The ads will air during the NCAA tournament and the Final Four, which will be played in Denver March 31 and April 2.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Who Seized One Armory Gets Another Instead
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff who relieved his overcrowded jail by commandeering a National Guard armory and refusing to budge won a victory Thursday when the state promised him another refurbished armory. Under the agreement, approved by Hampden County Superior Court Judge George Keady, county Sheriff Michael Ashe would move from the Springfield armory to a vacant armory in Holyoke about 10 miles to the north once the state has made about $77,500 worth of repairs to the building. ``Obviously, we're tremendously pleased,'' Ashe said. ``Everyone has won,'' said Lawrence Fletcher-Hill, the state assistant attorney general handling the case. Holyoke officials, however, were outraged by the decision, saying their armory lacks parking, is surrounded by homes and sits across the street from a preschool and kindergarten. ``Our primary concern is that 500 young schoolchildren should not be exposed to a jail 40 yards from their facility. It's highly inappropriate,'' said Mayor Martin Dunn, who ordered city lawyers to try to get a court order blocking the move. Holyoke had officials tried to have the court hearing delayed until Monday, but Keady said the issue couldn't wait. ``I think this matter is such it deserves immediate attention,'' the judge said in approving the order, entered jointly by the state and county. Ashe said he understood Dunn's concerns. He said only minimum-security prisoners close to the end of their terms would be sent to the armory and that other Springfield lockups close to community agencies have operated peacefully. ``I know this is a difficult thing but we had an emergency. Something had to be done and we just had to stand up for this,'' said Ashe, noting that 25 percent of Hampden County prisoners come from Holyoke. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis praised the agreement. ``We all want to keep violent criminals in jail,'' he said. Thursday's amicable settlement contrasted with the days immediately following Ashe's Feb. 16 seizure of the Springfield armory under a 17th-century law. The statute orders citizens to give ``suitable aid'' to law enforcement efforts. The state tried to evict the sheriff, but was blocked by a temporary restraining order he won from a judge. State officials never conceded Ashe's argument that his mission to keep the peace justified his action. It was not clear where funds would come for Ashe to run the armory as a jail. The agreement calls for the sheriff and the state to make their best efforts to obtain the approximately $470,000 Ashe estimates it will cost him to run the Holyoke armory until June. The pact notes that Massachusetts is in a fiscal crisis, and says that if new revenues aren't available, the state may have to dip into funds other sheriffs are trying to obtain for their crowded jails. The ``best-efforts'' clause isn't a guarantee the money will be there, said Dukakis spokeswoman Mindy Lubber. ``It means just that, our best, good-faith efforts. It does not mean this is an insurance policy,'' she said. Repairs to the Holyoke armory, which was closed March 1, should be completed within weeks, and inmates may be moved there next month, Ashe said. The temporary prison will be used only until a new jail is built in Ludlow, which is expected to take at least two years. No limit was set on the number of inmates, but only as many will be moved as needed to keep the old jail at its federal limit of no more than 500 inmates. So far, up to 26 inmates have been kept at the Springfield armory. Under the agreement, Ashe will establish a jail population committee to discuss the best way of dealing with cramped prison space.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Names Panel to Study Coal Health Care Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole appointed a committee Thursday to recommend solutions to the financial problems of health care and pensions in the coal industry. Mrs. Dole named W.J. Usery, the ``supermediator'' in the Pittston Co. coal strike settled last month, to chair the 11-member panel. Pension and health benefits were the key issues in the 10-month dispute between Pittston and Appalachia coal miners. Usery noted that health care concerns have been at the heart of 87 percent of the nation's labor-management disputes in the past two years. ``The knowledge we gain through this commission may shed some light on the means of solving the broader problems of health plans and health care coverage'' in all of American industry, Mrs. Dole said at a news conference. Usery, secretary of labor for President Ford, said he thought the panel might be able to come up with suggestions for the coming decade. Its recommendations are due in six months. ``The issue is health care ... how does this vital industry keep it in the private sector and deliver,'' Usery said. The committee will review a 40-year-old agreement under which coal companies contribute to the United Mine Workers' national retirement and health trust funds. The Pittston dispute stemmed from the company's decision to stop paying into the funds, which cover about 130,000 working and retired miners. Pittston said it could not keep up the payments and remain competitive. The other commission members are UMW President Richard Trumka; Henry Perritt, a law professor at Villanova University and deputy secretary of labor under Usery; Robert Quenon, chairman of the Bituminous Coal Operators Association; Curtis Barnette of the Bethlehem Steel Corp.; Richard Holsten of the Pittsburgh-Midway Coal Mining Co.; Carl Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Industry of America; Dr. Max Pepper of the St. Louis University School of Medicine; Arlene Holen, formerly of the Office of Management and Budget; Walter McNerney of Northwestern University and formerly of Blue Cross-Blue Shield; and Michael Mahoney of the New York actuarial consulting firm of Milliman and Robertson.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Approves Dunne for Civil Rights Post
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted Thursday to approve the nomination of former New York state Sen. John R. Dunne to be assistant attorney general for civil rights. The voice vote came one day after the committee grilled Dunne on his lack of civil rights experience, membership in clubs that excluded women and stock holdings in a company that does business in South Africa. Only one committee member, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, voted against Dunne's confirmation. A committe aide, speaking on condition of anonoymity, said the nomination could reach the Senate floor as early as Friday. Dunne could not be reached for comment Thursday. His secretary said she would have him call back, but when a reporter asked whether Dunne was speaking to the press Thursday, she said, ``No.'' Dunne, 60, of Garden City, N.Y., was tapped in January to be assistant attorney general for civil rights. The post has been vacant since December 1988, when William Bradford Reynolds resigned. President Bush's first nominee for the job, William C. Lucas, then a Michigan county executive, was rejected by the committee by a 7-7 vote last August. Lucas had spent most of his career in law enforcement and had little litigation experience. He was also opposed by many civil rights organization. Dunne, who was a state senator for 24 years, had been criticized by civil rights groups for having very little civil rights experience, but none opposed his nomination.

DOC.HEAD: UNESCO Chief Defends Controversial Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: UNESCO'S director Thursday defended his controversial restructuring plan for the agency after drawing criticism from U.S. and other Western diplomats. Director General Federico Mayor on Feb. 28 established 24 new management posts and promoted 18 top officials, including many who came from the senior staff of his predecessor, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal. Mayor appointed the former deputy director of the Soviet State Commission for Radio and Television, Henrikh Yushiavitshus, to the sensitive post of deputy director general for communications. It had been expected that Mayor would give the communications post to a Westerner as part of his campaign to induce the United States and Britain to rejoin the organization, which they left in the mid-1980s. Another Soviet, Boris Kluchnikov, was proposed as director for Europe, a post that normally goes to a Western or a neutral European. The United States and Britain, which had provided about 30 percent of the budget of the U.N. Education Scientific and Cultural Organization, left the agency because they claimed it was anti-Western, poorly managed and spending too much. Western and Japanese diplomats and the head of the U.S. observer mission to Paris-based UNESCO, Richard T. Miller, called Mayor's plan a mistake. A Japanese delegate said it showed UNESCO ``was going backwards at great speed.'' British news reports have criticized the cost of the plan. Mayor confirmed that the appointments would cost $5 million but said the measures he had introduced the past two years ago had saved three times that amount. In an interview at the Thai beach resort of Jomtien, where he is attending an international conference on education, Mayor called British media criticism of his moves ``misleading and ill-informed.'' Mayor said the choice of officials from the Soviet Union reflected the changing political climate it had inspired through recent reforms. Asked whether the appointments were insensitive to British and American interests, Mayor said: ``I cannot follow the sensibilities of any countries. I have 161 countries.'' ``I have chosen all my staff according to their personal qualifications and professional achievments. I don't take into account their belonging to official systems that were in the past imposed in some countries,'' he said. Diplomats and British news reports said Mayor made his decision without consulting UNESCO's executive board. Mayor said this was true but was his right as the director general of the organization. Mayor succeeded M'Bow in 1987 and promised major reforms, including a new communications strategy aimed at toning down a UNESCO program critics saw as a threat to press freedom. Mayor said he received no political pressure from Britain, the United States or the Soviet Union when making appointments. Japan is now the largest contributor to UNESCO, providing 16 percent of its $370 million two-year budget. Mayor said the Soviet Union was the second largest donor.

DOC.HEAD: Central U.S. Hit by Snow, Freezing Rain, Rain, Floods
DOC.TEXT: A widespread storm sprayed precipitation over much of the central part of the nation Thursday, ranging from snow and freezing rain in the North to flood-causing rain in the South. Freezing rain was a problem over much of the upper Mississippi Valley, icing roads and breaking tree limbs and power lines in parts of Nebraska, South Dakota, Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin. At midday, freezing rain, occasionally mixed with snow, continued to fall from northeastern Minnesota across central Minnesota and central Wisconsin. The freezing rain across Minnesota was expected to change to snow during the night, accumulating to 1 to 3 inches by Friday morning. Snow was scattered over the Nebraska Panhandle. Rain fell across western and southern Wisconsin and the remainder of the southern two-thirds of Minnesota. Rain and occasional thunderstorms also reached across northern Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, western South Carolina, western North Carolina, northern Georgia, northern Alabama, southern Tennessee, northern Mississippi, southern Arkansas and northern Louisiana. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to noon included 1.33 inches at Huntsville, Ala. Many rural roads in southwestern and central Arkansas were flooded by locally heavy rain in overnight thunderstorms, and some residents of low-lying areas of Little Rock had to evacuate. As much as 5 inches of rain fell in parts of central Arkansas and nearly 7 inches fell in southwestern counties, the National Weather Service said. Little Rock got 3.48 inches, a record there for any 24-hour period in March. High wind caused scattered damage in western Tennessee, the weather service said. In the Northwest, snow also fell on the Idaho Panhandle, and rain was scattered along the coast of Washington. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 21 at Grangeville, Idaho, to 88 at Harlingen, Texas. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 12 below zero at Houlton, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: No Birthday Celebration for Torched Youth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with messgaes from White House, Reagan, Dinkins, doctor's description of condition, cousin repeating that he was burned because he refused to smoke crack. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `David, a clean-cut..; Odrige cq, 11th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY23
DOC.TEXT: David Aupont spent his 12th birthday Thursday fighting for his life after a bully allegedly beat him with a bat, tied him up and set him afire in a garage because he refused to smoke crack. While David couldn't celebrate, former President Reagan, the White House and Mayor David Dinkins were among more than 100 well-wishers who showered him with cards, gifts, balloons, flowers and messages, said hospital spokeswoman Diana Goldin. A suspect just a year older than David was arrested Wednesday and charged in the attack, which left the victim in critical condition. David, who was walking to school with three friends when the Wednesday morning assault began, suffered second- and third-degree burns over 55 percent of his body. Police said his attacker soaked him with gasoline and set him aflame. ``This is going to be a long road for this young man,'' Dr. Cleon Goodwin, head of the burn unit at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, told reporters. Goodwin said that even if everything went perfectly in David's recovery, he still would have to be hospitalized for up to four months. He will have to undergo a series of skin-graft operations, which could begin as soon as Friday. David suffered burns on his chest, stomach, arms, legs, chin and mouth. The boy was in critical but stable condition, Goodwin said, adding that the next few days were a critical time in his survival. ``He's a fighter,'' Goodwin said. ``If you ask him if it hurts, he says, `No,' even when we know it does. He's tough.'' Police remained unsure what prompted the attack, although the boy told witnesses in his Brooklyn neighborhood that he was set afire after refusing to smoke crack. An older cousin of David's, Odrige Aupont, said the attacker approached his cousin and asked if he used crack, then ordered him to come smoke crack. After David refused, the youth lit him on fire. Goodwin said David's parents, Luther and Premese Aumont, have been with him as much as they can. ``He does know it's his birthday. He's pretty overwhelmed by what's been going on,'' the doctor said. The boy's father was sitting in the lobby of the hospital after the news conference, holding a floral arrangement sent to his son. He told reporters he had spoken with the boy but started crying and could not continue. David, a clean-cut boy who attended the sixth grade at Walt Whitman Intermediate school, is ``a normal kid. He got along with (other) kids,'' said his step-brother, 22-year-old Rudy LeBrun. David's family moved to Brooklyn from Port-au-Prince, Haiti, about 18 months ago. In addition to his step-brother, the boy has a 15-year-old sister, Naomi. The suspect, who was not identified because of his age, was charged with attempted murder second degree, assault first degree, kidnapping second degree, robbery and attempted robbery, said police spokesman Officer Hugh Barry. He said the suspect looked as if he were 17 or 18 years old. The suspect was taken to the Spofford Youth House pending his arraignment. According to Barry, the 13-year-old had robbed two youngsters on their way to school Tuesday. Those two were walking with David and a fourth youth on Wednesday morning when the 13-year-old came after them again, he said. The first two youths recognized the boy and took off, but the 13-year-old was able to corner David and the fourth youth. After robbing David's friend, the 13-year-old then grabbed David and dragged him into a garage, police said. David, his hands tied behind his back, was beaten with a baseball bat and set on fire inside the garage, authorities said. David managed to escape and ran to an auto body shop where he received help. ``Right now, we don't have a motive,'' said police Lt. Charles Monahan. ``We may be dealing with just a psycho.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Will Push for Aid to UN Family Planning Agency
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, Supporters of, to CLARIFY supporters not talking specifically about override; picks up 4th graf, Adding to
DOC.TEXT: Four senators told President Bush Thursday that Congress will press again this year for a U.S. contribution to the United Nations population control agency, a fight that led to a veto of last year's foreign aid bill.
