The lawmakers said Third World population growth poses ``a grave threat to our own future security'' because of the increasing pressures it places on the environment and on the political stability of poor countries. Supporters of aid to the U.N. Population Fund dropped a $15 million appropriation for the agency as part of a compromise after Bush vetoed the foreign aid bill last year. But they believe they have a better chance of getting the aid approved because of growing GOP restiveness on the abortion issue. Adding to their optimism is an agreement by the U.N. agency to allow the United States to earmark its population aid for specific countries whose family planning practices do not run counter to the president's abortion stand. The House and Senate voted to send money to the agency last year, which would have reversed a 5-year-old Reagan administration policy. Anti-abortion forces objected because the agency sends money to China, which uses coercion and abortion to enforce a one-child-per-family policy. But Sens. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., and Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., told Bush in the letter Thursday that the U.N. agency does not support abortion and has guaranteed it will not use American money in China. ``With the population of the developing countries projected to grow by over 900 million during the 1990s ... we cannot afford to remain outside the UNFPA,'' the senators wrote. A group of moderate House and Senate Republicans sent a similar letter last month to Secretary of State James A. Baker III calling for renewal of U.S. funding for the UNFPA. Last year's veto ``sent the wrong signal to the American public and the international community regarding the Republican Party's support for international family planning services,'' they wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Small Plane Lands on Highway After Running Out of Fuel
DOC.TEXT: A plane ran out of fuel and landed on a four-lane highway Thursday, police said. No injuries or traffic problems were reported. Peter Jacobs, 49, of Lone Pine, Calif., landed the single-engine Cherokee at about 2 p.m. on the southbound lanes of state Route 28 about 35 miles north of Pittsburgh, police said. Jacobs' 16-year-old son, Jeramiah Jacobs, also was aboard the plane. After landing, the plane was pushed to the side of the road and the pilot sat beside his disabled craft waiting for fuel in hopes he could take off from the highway, the officer said. Federal Aviation Administration officials were to decide whether he could do that or whether the plane should be towed to a small airport about five miles away.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Parliament Affirms Polish Border; Kohl Fends Off Accusations
LaserPhoto BON3
DOC.TEXT: Parliament agreed Thursday that a united Germany should honor Poland's western border, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl tried to fend off charges that he heightened international fears about unification. A lawmaker from the opposition Social Democrats, Juergen Schmude, said during a raucous debate that Kohl's handling of the border issue amounted to ``political arson in the European house.'' Parliament passed a resolution that said the two Germanys should adopt twin declarations that ``the Polish people are assured their right to live in secure borders will not be questioned by us Germans through territorial claims either now or in the future.'' It says the future government of a united Germany should sign a border treaty on the basis of those declarations. Poland's deputy prime minister, Leszek Balerowicz, told a news conference in Gdansk, Poland, that Bonn's declaration was progress, but that Poland still should attend talks on German unification. ``The government of the Republic of Poland treats it as a step in the right direction, but it is not complete convergence,'' he said. The invasion of Poland by Nazi Germany in 1939 was the start of World War II. Unease between Poles and Germans is long-standing. Kohl came under fire abroad and at home for his previous reluctance to promise that a united Germany would never lay claim to land ceded to Poland after the Third Reich's 1945 defeat. The chancellor, apparently trying to avoid offending conservative voters with federal elections slated in December, had insisted only the government of a united Germany could address the matter. His demands that a border treaty be linked to Polish concessions caused an uproar, and he withdrew them this week while proposing the resolution that passed Thursday. Germany was split into Communist East and capitalist West after the war. The rush toward unification followed the ouster of East Germany's hard-line Communist leader, Erich Honecker, last October. The Social Democrats charged in Parliament that Kohl's pronouncements had jeopardized the unification process. Social Democratic chief Hans-Jochen Vogel said Kohl ``squandered (world) trust'' of Germans and ``endangered the process of German unification in its most sensitive phase. ``And if people now start talking about the nasty Germans again, if delays (in unification) occur, then you are to blame,'' he told Kohl. Kohl insisted, ``Since I took over the government in 1982, I have never given any reason to doubt that we hold to the spirit and letter'' of standing West German-Polish agreements on border guarantees. ``It is my aim to place reconciliation between the Polish and German peoples on a lasting and firm basis.'' He said the contribution of Vogel and his Social Democrats to unification matters over the past years ``can be characterized as simply pathetic.'' The chancellor also seemed to address concern by Moscow that he is trying to make unification occur too quickly. ``We are producing no artificial time pressures in order to speed up unification,'' he said. But Kohl also said he would like any international concerns about German unification settled soon, noting that a preliminary round of the ``two-plus-four'' talks involving the Allies is set for next week in Bonn. Officials from the World War II allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ are to meet next Wednesday with the two Germanys. Among unification hurdles is the Soviet demand that a united Germany not be a NATO member. Kohl repeated that a united Germany must belong to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He said anew that what is now East Germany could have a special military status, with NATO troops barred from being stationed there. Kohl sought to allay concerns that a united Germany could become an overmighty presence in Europe. ``No one needs to be worried about a German dominance in the European Community. A united Germany would also be a reliable and solid partner,'' Kohl said. Thursday's resolution touches on the two concessions Kohl sought from the Poles _ a demand that Warsaw reaffirm its 1953 decision not to seek war reparations, and to confirm its pledge last year to protect the ethnic rights of Poland's German minority. The resolution says those decisions ``remain valid for a united Germany.'' The Social Democrats offered a resolution omitting mention of the two issues, but the majority lawmakers from Kohl's coalition government rejected it.

DOC.HEAD: Group That Tested AIDS Drug Secretly Gets Government OK for Tests
DOC.TEXT: A San Francisco group that organized underground tests of an AIDS drug derived from Chinese cucumber roots won government approval to resume testing with a purified form of the drug, an official of the group said Thursday. Project Inform, an AIDS treatment and education group, planned to announce Friday that the Food and Drug Administration has approved its application to conduct tests of the drug known as Compound Q on about 100 patients, said Terry Beswick, research director of the group. An FDA official who spoke on the condition of anonymity confirmed the approval and said it brings Project Inform under the agency's sanctioned clinical trials system, assuring that the group's plan conforms to government standards for testing. ``It gives the agency more control over the situation than it had before,'' the FDA official said. ``We had problems with the (secret) trials _ whether the compound was pure, what problems might be with the dose, who was taking it, that sort of thing. This gives us a handle on that.'' Working with Project Inform to come up with a study design that meets FDA requirements was a better alternative than trying to put the group out of business, the official said. ``How would you stop people from taking this drug if they really wanted it? You're talking about quite an effort that might not be successful,'' the official said. ``This way we're assured a good hard look at dose and safety.'' Last May, Project Inform secretly organized a Compound Q study without FDA authorization. The group's leaders said they couldn't wait for the government because desperate AIDS patients were already experimenting with the drug. Doctors in the study infused their patients with Compound Q, the name given to trichosanthin, a protein from the root of a cucumberlike plant that Chinese doctors have used for centuries to induce abortions and treat cancer. The group used couriers to import the drug from China. By the time the FDA told Project Inform to discontinue the unapproved experiments last August, the group had finished treating patients with the drug and had begun to evaluate their data. In September, Martin Delaney, co-director of Project Inform, said early results showed the drug holds promise but also has serious risks associated with it. In earlier test-tube studies, the drug appeared to selectively kill cells infected with the AIDS virus. In the secret tests, about 60 patients were given infusions of Compound Q by doctors in San Francisco, New York, Miami and Los Angeles, according to Project Inform officials. Two patients died during the trial and three others suffered severe dementia or seizures, but recovered. Delaney said doctors did not believe the drug caused the deaths. Under the new study approved by the FDA, the group's research arm, Project Inform-Community Research Alliance, will test a highly purified form of Compound Q on up to 100 patients who previously were treated with the Chinese import, Beswick said. The FDA source said the patients in the new study will be limited to those who were connected to Project Inform's earlier underground study. But Beswick said others besides those who participated in the earlier study could participate. He said ``hundreds of other people'' have been treated with the Chinese version in underground experiments. The purified form of the drug, called GLQ223, was developed at the University of California at San Francisco and Genelabs of Redwood City, Calif. This version of the drug is being studied on patients in FDA-approved tests that were started at San Francisco General Hospital last May.

DOC.HEAD: Bush-Skinner Transportation Plan Would Cost Travelers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 7 grafs to include Skinner congressional testimony and more reaction.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced a national transportation policy Thursday that would cost travelers more and increase local governments' share in meeting air, land and sea travel needs into the next century. Just as the Model T and the Wright brothers' plane ``prepared the way for today's millions of cars and thousands of passenger jets, so it is now our turn to invest in America's future,'' Bush said in unveiling the policy with Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner. Bush said it would help keep America ``the world leader in transportation.'' The 129-page plan, ``Moving America Into The 21st Century,'' calls for more toll roads, local gas taxes, user fees, private investments, competition, deregulaton, research into futuristic systems and openness to foreign air carriers as well as increased attention to safety and protection of the environment. The policy was hailed as an important step by some industry groups, but most expressed some disappointment, and Democratic members of Congress were critical. Aviation and ground transportation groups opposed ``user fees'' and other taxes that Skinner acknowledged would require travelers to pay more. The American Public Transit Association said the policy was ``long on advice and short on help'' from the federal government. Rep. Norman Mineta, D-Calif., chairman of the House surface transportation subcommittee, called it ``a good start'' but said shifting programs to the state and local level without financial resources ``would be the shift and the shaft.'' Bush did not immediately field questions on the proposal, leaving Skinner to face news media. The secretary, who had the policy drawn up after holding 117 hearings across the country, justified proposals for increases in local gasoline taxes and fees by saying polls show that people are willing to pay if they get improvements. Skinner denied the policy represents a shift of responsiblity for transportation away from the federal government, saying it was an attempt to ``strike a balance'' after years in which the federal government has assumed ``almost all of the responsibility'' for funding some transportation systems. ``The federal commitment to infrastructure and to transportation will continue to be at a very high level,'' he said, adding that federal transportation budgets are expected to increase each year. ``It is not the panacea or the answer to all of the problems in transportation,'' said Skinner. ``It was never designed to be that. It was designed to be a strategic plan, or a framework under which we could make the many decisions that we are required to make.'' The plan outlines no major federal programs not already called for in the president's budget request. Its overall goal is to maintain the U.S. transportation system as ``the finest in the world.'' However, the report said ``there are increasing signs ... that the system is beginning to break down.'' Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., chairman of the Senate surface transportation subcommittee, said, ``I'm going to be looking through this to see whether or not this simply doesn't transfer the problems we have ... off the backs of the federal government and onto the backs of state and local governments.'' Rep. John Paul Hammerschmidt of Arkansas, top Republican on a House transportation subcommittee, said, ``I think the money has to come from users, one way or another, and because it is a national plan, the logical way for it to come from users is through a national tax system.'' A coalition of 16 aviation industry groups said it opposes Bush's proposed increases in aviation taxes, which the president's fiscal 1991 budget calls ``user fees.'' Air Transport Association president Robert Aaronson, who represents major airlines, praised Skinner for ``real vision'' in developing the plan. But he said increasing the share shippers and air travelers pay to run the Federal Aviation Administration could adversely affect the economy. ``Before being asked to pay more, funds already collected should be spent,'' Aaronson said, referring to a $7 billion surplus in the aviation trust fund, which is collected from airline ticket taxes. Later, Skinner defended his proposals before the House Public Works and Transportation subcommittee on surface transportation. He said Congress would have to decide the balance of urban and rural priorities when new highway legislation is considered next year. Skinner was criticized by Rep. Robert A. Borski, D-Pa., for a budget proposal that removes $20 million for the Philadelphia area transit system. Skinner said the state government would have to shoulder more of the burden, just as has happened with the Chicago and New York mass transit systems. He said the system could no longer rely on ``the old philosophy'' of ``free dollars in Washington.'' Reaction among top state transportation officials varied. Thomas Harrelson, North Carolina transportation secretary, an appointive post in a Republican administration, said problems are ``fast approaching the critical stage'' and Skinner's policy helps move transportation ``higher on the national agenda.'' Democratic appointee James Pitz, Michigan transportation director, said Bush missed a chance to ``hit a home run'' by not agreeing to spend more of the aviation and highway trust fund revenue. He said the chance for private investment in transportation is ``not overly significant.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Urges Gorbachev to Oust Conservatives
DOC.TEXT: Soviet populist Boris Yeltsin appealed to Mikhail Gorbachev on Thursday to expel conservatives from the ruling bodies and speed up reforms. Yeltsin said the Soviet president's popularity ``is fading rapidly because the people are getting harder times rather than better times after five years of perestroika, as a result of Gorbachev's delays and half-measures.'' Perestroika is Gorbachev's plan to restructure the economy. Yeltsin, saying again that he considers himself a Communist with a soul of a social democrat, suggested the Soviet leader should ``get rid'' of leading conservatives such as Yegor Ligachev, a member of the Soviet Politburo. Yeltsin, a member of the Soviet congress, was speaking at a news conference in Milan during a European trip to promote his autobiography. Leonardo Mondadori, Italian publisher of Yeltsin's autobiography, said royalties from the book will be used to finance a research center on AIDS in the Soviet Union. The Soviet congressman said conservative forces had united in the Soviet Union to form ``an efficient group in the party's central committee.'' ``We must not understimate this danger; we must remove Ligachev. I can't understand why Gorbachev is delaying on the decision to get rid of him. .... Ligachev is stuck to his chair, thus we must get rid of him and of his chair. But it's up to Gorbachev to push the button. He does not allow me to do it.'' Yeltsin said the sweeping political changes in Eastern Europe ``could not have been possible without the beginning of perestroika in the Soviet Union in 1985.'' ``However, the Eastern countries have by now left us behind because the people there showed they can change their nations ... while we stuck to the apparatus. ... ``I am not saying that Gorbachev is the only one responsible for a slowdown in reforms. But he must be more determined and efficient; he must make choices.'' Yeltsin said if the Soviet Communist Party is not radically reorganized at the next party congress this summer, he will support the foundation of a new party and a pluralistic political system. Yeltsin dodged a question on whether he may try for the Soviet presidency. But, he said, ``a change of guard at the top is not easy but would be necessary if things continue this way. ``Certainly nobody quits voluntarily in the Soviet Union.'' Yeltsin also said he did not agree with the decision of some Eastern European countries to remove their statues of Vladimir I. Lenin, the Soviet Communist founder. He also criticized calls by some Soviets to take Lenin's body from the mausoleum in Moscow. ``Lenin is not my idol. He too made mistakes ... but we must preserve his memory. ... Certainly, I prefer to have Lenin's portrait in my office, rather than Gorbachev's,'' he concluded with a broad smile.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Says Strike Illegal, Teachers Can Be Fired
DOC.TEXT: The state attorney general declared West Virginia's first teacher strike illegal Thursday as the walkout spread to more than half the schools in the state. Attorney General Roger Tompkins warned teachers they could be suspended for a year, fired or charged with a misdemeanor for walking off the job. Despite that warning and the governor's refusal to hold talks until they go back to class, the 16,000-member teachers' union voted to walk out in 20 more counties Thursday and in six more by Monday if the Legislature fails to vote them a pay raise. The union initially went on strike Wednesday in 10 counties. Teachers joined picket lines, blocked bus garages and rallied at the state Capitol. Authorities arrested seven teachers on charges of blocking school buses in Kanawha County, and one picket suffered torn ligaments when she was hit by a parent's car. Gov. Gaston Caperton told the Legislature on Wednesday he won't hold discussions with the teachers until ``calm and reason are restored and the teaching force returns to the classrooms.'' ``This state government will not conduct its affairs under intimidation,'' he said to a standing ovation. West Virginia Education Association President Kayetta Meadows said her group is willing to meet with the governor but is not ready to call off the strike. The association, which represents 73 percent of the state's 22,000 public school teachers, says average teacher pay in the state was $21,904, 49th in the nation, before a 5 percent pay raise last month. Mississippi is 50th. The West Virginia Federation of Teachers, which represents 3,000 teachers, said 90 percent of its members also were on strike. State law does not permit teachers to engage in collective bargaining, andthe attorney general said ``a strike or work stoppage by teachers constitutes an attack upon the most important duty and function of this state.'' ``There is no right to strike against the state,'' his opinion said. ``Thus, any strike or concerted work stoppage by the public teachers of this state is illegal.'' Tompkins said it is a misdemeanor for any state officials to neglect or refuse to perform their duties, or to interrupt a school or loiter on school grounds. Teachers can be barred for one year for neglecting their duty by striking, he said. By early Thursday evening, no teachers had been arrested or suspended for staying off the job, authorities said. An agreement with legislators on a 5 percent raise for teachers collapsed Tuesday when the union refused to rule out a strike. House Speaker Chuck Chambers and Senate President Keith Burdette said the strike threat made it impossible for them to win passage of the raise, which would have been financed by a new $1 per ton minimum tax on coal production. More than 1,000 sign-toting teachers rallied at the Statehouse urging lawmakers and the governor to provide teachers with a pay raise. ``We think we can do more here, if we talk to our legislators and get the governor to talk to us,'' said Jane McNeill Laraba, a teacher at Raleigh County's Liberty High School. ``The people in Raleigh County can't help us. The people who can do anything for us are here.'' ``I came to school today with tears in my eyes,'' said Becky Wallace, a physical education teacher at Anne Bailey Elementary School in St. Albans. ``I've been here 12 years. My kids are special. When I think of the kids crossing the road here with us picketing, it's distressing.'' She said teachers are fed up with the governor and the Legislature. ``This is a message to the Legislature and governor,'' Wallace said. ``I think the governor's misguided.''

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Assures Vietnam of Continued Backing at Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Vice Premier Vladimir Gusev met this week with Premier Do Muoi of Vietnam and assured him of Moscow's continued strong backing for Vietnam, an official report seen on Thursday said. In their meeting in Ho Chi Minh City on Tuesday, Gusev and Do discussed reforms in their countries and ways to make Soviet-Vietnamese cooperation more efficient, the Vietnam News Agency said. The report, dated Wednesday, said Gusev left for home that day. Gusev led the Soviet side at the 15th session of the Soviet-Vietnamese Intergovernmental Commission for Economic, Scientific and Technological Cooperation, held Monday and Tuesday. The Soviet Union is Vietnam's main ally, but has decreased its aid in recent years as part of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of retrenchment in costly overseas involvement.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Lied, Prosecutor Declares as Trial Opens
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES with throughout with defense opening statement
DOC.TEXT: John M. Poindexter lied to Congress and ripped up a key presidential document to ``rewrite the history of the Iran-Contra affair,'' a prosecutor argued Thursday at the start of the former national security adviser's trial. Poindexter's lawyer said he was only following Ronald Reagan's orders. Prosecutor Dan Webb also told jurors former White House aide Oliver North, expected on the witness stand Friday, will testify that on Poindexter's instructions ``he lied and he lied and he lied'' to Congress by denying the Reagan administration was secretly helping the Nicaraguan rebels. Webb said Poindexter later congratulated North on lies that the prosecutor said ``worked like a charm.'' But defense attorney Richard Beckler denied that Poindexter ever lied to Congress, and he told jurors: ``Admiral Poindexter always followed the orders of President Reagan.'' Poindexter tore up a ``presidential finding'' that authorized a 1985 arms shipment to Iran only ``because he felt he was protecting the president,'' Beckler said, echoing testimony Poindexter gave Congress about the Iran-Contra affair. ``What was driving this man was not a conspiracy, but what was driving this man was the orders of the president of the United States,'' Beckler said. Poindexter ``met with him sometimes seven days a week, sometimes four, five and six times a day. And he was carrying out the policies of the United States and that is what this case is about. It is not about criminality.'' Poindexter worked to help arm the Contras when Congress shut off military assistance because ``through hell or high water, Reagan wanted support to continue,'' the defense lawyer said. Reagan ``wanted it done within the law and it was done within the law,'' Beckler said, telling jurors he will play videotapes of the former president's testimony taken last month in Los Angeles. As the proceedings got under way, U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene dealt the defense a setback, ruling that when North is called to testify, prosecutors may ask him about seeing Poindexter rip up the Reagan finding. The judge also suggested that North had changed his story on that subject. North testified at his trial last year that he saw Poindexter destroy the politically embarrassing document, but at a Dec. 13 pre-trial hearing in the Poindexter case he testified he realized it was the finding that Poindexter had ripped up only after watching Poindexter's congressional testimony on national television in 1987. ``North appears to have embarked at that time upon the calculated course of attempting to assist his former colleague and co-defendant ... by prevaricating on various issues,'' Greene said. The document stated that the arms sale was part of a plan to gain release of the hostages. The case is about ``coverup, deception and concealment,'' Webb told the jurors who will decide on the five felony charges facing Poindexter, who served as Reagan's top adviser on national security matters from late 1985 to late 1986. Poindexter and North tried to cover up a 1985 shipment of U.S. arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels to ``avoid tarnishment of the Reagan administration,'' Webb said. ``John Poindexter and Oliver North decided to rewrite the history of the Iran-Contra affair,'' he said, after it was exposed in the fall of 1986. ``Oliver North and John Poindexter did not like what the true historical facts were'' because they showed that Reagan broke his pledge not to sell arms to Iran for the release of U.S. hostages, Webb said. ``They did not want the Iran-Contra events as they occurred to be revealed,'' Webb said. ``But they got caught.'' Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, obstruction, and making false statements to Congress about the U.S.-Iran arms sales and the Reagan administration's covert support of the Contras at a time direct military aid was banned by Congress. Webb told jurors North will testify that at Poindexter's direction he lied to the House Intelligence Committee on Aug. 6, 1986, when questioned about whether the White House was secretly helping arm the Contras. The lies ``worked like a charm'' to falsely reassure congressmen that the White House was not circumventing the ban on U.S. military aid to the rebels, Webb said. ``Once Admiral Poindexter found out how successful North was in lying, what did he do? He congratulates North,'' Webb said. ``He sends him a note that says `Well Done.''' Beckler argued that Poindexter was merely ``telling Oliver North he did a good job.'' None of the evidence ``will show it was done as an act to perpetuate a conspiracy to keep information from Congress.'' North, at his own trial last year, admitted that he lied during the Aug. 6 meeting, but said he did not know he was breaking the law when he did so. He was acquitted of a charge pertaining to the meeting, but was convicted of three others including aiding and abetting obstruction of Congress and altering and destroying government documents. Poindexter destroyed it on Nov. 21, 1986 _ eight days after ``Ronald Reagan was on television addressing the nation, telling the country what we were doing in Iran had nothing to do with selling arms and swapping them for hostages,'' Webb said. Also, Poindexter ripped it up just hours after telling lawmakers that he knew nothing of the November 1985 missile shipment until five weeks after it occurred. Beckler argued that when Poindexter testified in Congress about the shipment, he had forgotten when he had learned about it. ``After 30 years in the U.S. Navy and the White House they want to nail him on a five-week mistake,'' Beckler said, his voice rising.

DOC.HEAD: Timber Harvested from National Forests Falls 5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: More than half of national forests lost money on timber sales last year, the government said Thursday in a report that environmentalists say support their call to roll back subsidized timber sales. The U.S. Forest Service, in its annual report on timber sales from the nation's wilderness, said profits on all the national forests rose 4 percent last year even though the total harvest declined about 5 percent. There were 11.9 billion board feet of timber harvested from national forests last year, after 12.6 billion board feet were harvested in 1988 and a record 12.7 billion board feet the year before. Overall, the Forest Service said the government took in $1.5 billion through timber sales in 1989. Operating expenses for the timber sales program were $776.7 million last year and the government paid states $339.1 million for a net sales gain of $402.7 million _ up from $388.6 million the previous year. The timber sale program, in which private companies pay the federal government for the right to harvest trees and a portion goes to states to build roads and schools, generated about 132,371 jobs and $4.4 billion in personal income in fiscal 1989, the Forest Service said. Of the nation's 122 national forests, 66 of them lost money by selling timber at below cost, the report said. But George Leonard, associate chief of the service, said those 66 forests account for only 18 percent of the total volume of timber cut, or about 2 billion board feet. ``The forests where we lost the money are the small forests,'' he said. ``Oregon and Washington are responsible for about half the revenue and they produce about half the timber.'' Timber industry leaders said the net gain in sales shows the program is in good shape, but environmentalists said the losses on the majority of the forests show the government is subsidizing private logging activities. ``The hundreds of millions of dollars the Forest Service loses on subsidized timber sales are nothing more than public welfare for the logging industry,'' said Tom Kuhnle, an economist for the Natural Resources Defense Council. He said the report should aid the Bush administration's proposal to slowly eliminate subsidized sales at 12 national forests. But David Ford, vice president of the Public Timber Council of the National Forest Products Association, said the report proves the program's ``financial soundness. ``The timber program is rare among federal programs in that it consistently earns money for the government,'' he said. The Pacific Northwest harvested by far the largest volume of timber last year with 5.2 billion board feet. Only the Pacific Northwest and Southwest among the service's eight regions posted actual profits last year based on timber sales after payments were made to states for such things as schools and roads.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Judge Accuses North of `Prevaricating'
With AM-Poindexter Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 7-8: ``The Court,'' with Greene's conclusion that North's testimony is ``incredible''
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North has changed his story in the Iran-Contra affair, ``prevaricating'' in an attempt to help his former boss, the judge in John Poindexter's trial contended Thursday. The accusation that North had lied under oath _ a contention that could suggest further legal problems for him _ preceded his expected leadoff appearance as a government witness against Poindexter, his former superior at the Reagan administration's National Security Council. Poindexter's lawyers tried to bar North's testimony. However, U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene ruled that prosecutors could ask North to testify _ as he did at his own trial _ that on Nov. 21, 1986, he witnessed Poindexter tear up a document signed by President Reagan. The December 1985 ``finding'' depicted U.S. involvement in arms sales to Iran as a straight arms-for-hostages deal. North testified at his trial that he saw Poindexter destroy the politically embarrassing document, but the judge said North gave different testimony at a Dec. 13 pre-trial hearing in the Poindexter case. At the hearing, North said he only realized it was the finding that Poindexter had ripped up after watching Poindexter's congressional testimony on national television in 1987. No portion of the prosecution's case may be derived from that Poindexter testimony, which was given under a grant of immunity. ``The Court rejects as totally incredible the suggestion that an eyewitness to the almost ceremonial destruction of a state paper such as a signed Presidential Finding would not know that he had been such an eyewitness,'' said the judge. In a footnote, the judge said that ``since North has changed his testimony several times, a further recantation can obviously not be excluded.'' The judge said the former White House aide was trying to avoid having to testify against his former boss when he made the statements at the hearing. North said at the time that Poindexter was the only one in the Iran-Contra affair who ``didn't hang Ollie North out to dry.'' ``North appears to have embarked at that time upon the calculated course of attempting to assist his former colleague and co-defendant ... by prevaricating on various issues,'' Greene said. ``North told the truth at his trial rather than at the December 13, 1989 hearing,'' the judge concluded. Poindexter's lawyers asserted that North testified reluctantly about how his memory was affected by Poindexter's immunized testimony, but Greene disagreed. North's ``insistence on having been heavily influenced by that testimony was enthusiastic rather than reluctant,'' said the judge. At the December hearing, North ``repeatedly claimed that he could not distinguish between his own observations and the version of events described in another's testimony; yet ... it is unlikely that a witness who was a participant in the events as they occurred, could not make such a distinction.'' At his trial, North testified that ``I saw the finding torn up ... I saw him tear it in two.'' In December, the former White House aide said: ``I don't know for a fact'' that the document was the finding, ``except what Admiral Poindexter testified to, that the document that was destroyed that morning, or afternoon, or whenever it was, was indeed the finding.'' North was convicted of three felonies, including aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress in connection with the November 1985 shipment of Hawks which now figures so prominently in the Poindexter case. Poindexter destroyed the finding hours after he is alleged to have told members of the House and Senate intelligence committees that he hadn't known about the missile shipment until January 1986. His alleged statements to the committees form the basis for four of the five criminal charges against him. The government says it will contend at Poindexter's trial that his knowledge of the signed presidential finding was his motive for concealing U.S. involvement in the Hawk missile shipment.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Says Helmsman Didn't Turn Far Enough To Miss Reef
DOC.TEXT: The Exxon Valdez ran aground on a jagged reef and spilled its cargo of oil because the helmsman failed to turn the ship as far as he was ordered, an expert testified Thursday on behalf of the tanker's skipper. Peter Shizume, who devised a complex computer program used to simulate ship accidents, said the tanker would have gone past Bligh Reef in Prince William with room to spare if the rudder had been turned only half as far as called for by the third mate. ``I think the problem was the rudder was initiated late and not enough rudder was used,'' Shizume testified at the criminal trial of fired Exxon skipper Joseph Hazelwood in the nation's worst oil spill. Shizume, who said he used various formulas to track the course of the tanker, said it would have missed Bligh Reef by about two miles if the helmsman had turned 10 degrees right about 10 minutes before the ship ran aground and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil. Shizume, from Hicksville, N.Y., said as little as 5 degrees less than five minutes before the accident also would have saved the ship. The third mate, who was in control of the Exxon Valdez while Hazelwood went to his cabin, testified earlier in the trial that 10 minutes before the accident he called for the helmsman to execute 10 degrees right rudder. The mate suggested that the helmsman, Robert Kagan, failed to follow the order because he had problems with steering and had once been reprimanded for steering too hard. Shizume said his study of the ship's course recorder showed that Kagan's average turn during the critical period was 4 degrees. ``What is your opinion as to what he was doing,'' asked attorney Michael Chalos. ``He looks like he was swinging the rudder back and forth,'' apparently without any commands to do so, Shizume said. Shizume, a physicist and engineer retired from Sperry Gyroscope Co., said he was hired to create the mock-up system used at the National Maritime Research Center at Kings Point, N.Y. The system is used for training captains and studying shipping accidents. Hazelwood, 43, is on trial on four criminal counts stemming from the March 24 grounding of the Exxon Valdez in Prince William Sound. He faces up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted on all four counts. In other testimony, a naval architect challenged the testimony of a prosecution expert, saying the Exxon Valdez wouldn't have sunk if Hazelwood had been able to work it off the reef immediately after the spill. The prosecution contends that by engaging the engines and turning the rudder from side to side, Hazelwood put the ship in danger of capsizing and further damaged the part of the tanker that was resting on rock. Edward Hoffman, the naval architect, said Hazelwood's crew would have been able to keep the ship from capsizing by transferring sea water into oil tanks to balance the ship's load. Hoffman also testified that he examined the wrecked Exxon Valdez at its dry dock in San Diego and concluded that Hazelwood's actions after it went aground didn't further damage to the tanker. ``My opinion is that the explosive impact with the ship and the reef caused the majority of damage,'' Hoffman said. ``Subsequent to that, the rise and fall of the tide caused further damage.'' Hoffman led off the second day of defense testimony after Hazelwood's lawyers moved to center stage in the criminal trial.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Blast Near Burmese Customs Office Kills 7
DOC.TEXT: A bomb placed in a box in front of a Burmese customs office exploded Thursday, killing seven people and wounding five, a Thai border policeman said. Burmese authorities blamed the attack on unspecified dissidents, the officer said. The bomb in Burma's eastern Myawadi town went off after authorities opened the box, the officer said on condition of anonymity. The injured were sent to a hospital in Mae Sot, a Thai town just across the border, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Argentinians Sentenced in Du Pont Extortion Scheme
DOC.TEXT: The mastermind of a plot to extort $10 million from the Du Pont Co. in exchange for documents stolen from its Lycra plant in Argentina was sentenced Wednesday to 6{ years in federal prison. U.S. District Court Judge Joseph Longobardi sentenced two of 52-year-old Bruno Skerianz's accomplices, Raul Armando Giordano, 37, and Antonio Ruben Inigo, 40, to 3{ years. Longobardi also ordered the three to serve three years probation and pay $100 to a Du Pont compensation fund. Prosecutors said Du Pont, a Wilmington-based chemicals manufacturer, was given the choice of paying $10 million for the documents or having them sold to a competitor. The documents were stolen from Du Pont's Lycra plant in Mercedes, Argentina. Lycra is Du Pont's trade name for spandex, an elastic fiber used in such clothing as swimsuits and leotards. A jury convicted the three Argentines in December on one count each of conspiracy to extort and attempted extortion. Each count carries a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison, a $250,000 fine and five year's probation. A fourth defendant, Jose Petrosino, is fighting extradition from Italy. Charges against Maria I. Lorenzo de Bianchini, who testified for the prosecution, were dropped. Before passing sentence, the judge rejected a defense motion to dismiss the case. ``We're asking for as much leniency as possible, based on their level of participation'' in the scheme, said Giordano's lawyer, John S. Malik. Prosecutors said Du Pont also reached an agreement in which Skerianz and his co-defendants pledged not to work in spandex production for five years and Du Pont would sell spandex yarn for five years to a company chosen by Skerianz. The defense claimed Skerianz had not attempted extortion because he and his cohorts had planned to manufacture spandex for Radicci, an Italian textile manufacturer. Skerianz had worked for Du Pont more than 20 years ago, and the others resigned in the fall of 1988 from the Mercedes plant. All except Petrosini were arrested in February 1989 in Geneva after an aborted attempt to return the documents for $10 million. Petrosino was arrested several months later. Du Pont controls more than half the spandex market worldwide, and sold more than $600 million of the product in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Ryan Recommended to Direct Savings And Loan Regulation
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, bgng: ``After a...'' with 1 graf to add job title; picks up 4th graf pvs, bgng: ``The department...''
DOC.TEXT: T. Timothy Ryan Jr., former chief attorney in the Labor Department, is the Treasury Department's choice to replace M. Danny Wall as the nation's top savings and loan regulator, an administration source said Thursday. Ryan, 44, is an attorney with the Washington firm of Reed, Smith, Shaw and McClay. He served as solicitor of the Labor Department from 1981 to 1983, directing a staff of about 600 lawyers. After a three-month search, the Treasury Department has recommended that President Bush appoint Ryan to head the department's Office of Thrift Supervision, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The department, which assumed responsibility for the thrift office as part of the S&L bailout enacted in August, had at first sought an experienced regulator for the post but could not find an acceptable candidate willing to take the job. William Taylor, chief of banking supervision for the Federal Reserve System, opted to stay with his higher-paying current job. Frederick Wolf, former No. 2 official at Congress' General Accounting Office, withdrew after the Treasury Department failed to forward his name to the White House. In private practice, Ryan has specialized in pension and employee benefit law rather than in financial institution regulation. However, the administration source said Ryan would bring a fresh approach and strong leadership and management skills to the thrift director's job at a critical time in the industry. ``He's someone who has a high degree of professionalism as well as a real sense of what's practical,'' said Martin McGuinn, vice chairman and general counsel of the Pittsburgh-based Mellon Bank. ``I've seen his organizational skills at work.'' Ryan has performed legal work for Mellon and went to college with McGuinn. Ryan is an active Republican. He served as an attorney in both the 1976 campaign of Gerald Ford and Bush's 1988 campaign. He was the legal counsel for the 1980 Reagan-Bush transistion team. It was unclear how soon the White House could complete routine background checks on Ryan. For other appointments, the process has taken several months. Barring an unforseen development, President Bush was expected to accept the Treasury's recommendation. Congressional Democrats, who were backing Wolf, have repeatedly criticized the administration for not naming a thrift director sooner. Wall announced his resignation Dec. 4. He stayed on until Tuesday, when President Bush named Assistant Treasury Secretary Salvatore Martoche as acting director. The administration has been anxious to find a permanent successor to Wall, hoping to stifle legal challenges from weak thrifts facing government seizure. Olympic Federal Savings and Loan Association, Berwyn, Ill., is contending in U.S. District Court that both Wall and Martoche lacked the legal authority to close insolvent thrifts because they were not confirmed for the position by the Senate. Wall inherited the post after Congress dismantled the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, where he was chairman. He resigned after a series of grueling House Banking Committee hearings where he was criticized for his handling of the failure of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif. Martoche was confirmed for his Treasury job, but not as thrift director.

DOC.HEAD: Slovenia Proclaims Economic Independence
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's liberal northern republic of Slovenia on Thursday declared economic independence from the federation, the state news agency Tanjug reported. Tanjug said the Slovene Parliament also decided it would not fulfill the portion of its financial obligations toward the federation that are earmarked for the less prosperous republic of Serbia and the least developed region of Kosovo, which is an administrative part of Serbia. ``The Republic of Slovenia will independently adopt measures of economic self-protection, regardless of the obligations of the federal legislation,'' read a declaration adopted by the parliament. ``(It) will independently take decisions on fulfilment of its obligations toward the Socialist Republic of Serbia and the Federation.'' Serbia, the largest republic, cut all official and trade ties with Slovenia in December after authorities there banned a rally by Serbs seeking to oust the Slovene leadership. The Communist leadership and partisan press in Serbia have lashed out against Slovenia, accusing it of ``treason'' for criticizing Serbia's policies in ethnically troubled Kosovo province. Serbian authorities accuse Slovenia of harboring separatist tendencies and protecting its own interests at the expense of federal ones. Slovenian authorities deny it and say Serbia is trying to politically and economically dominate the Yugoslav federation by introducing greater federal control and by limiting the autonomy of the republics. The Slovene Parliament decided on Wednesday to drop the word ``Socialist'' from Slovenia's official name as part of its drive to distance itself from old Communist symbols and dogmas that still prevail elsewhere in the country. Yugoslavia consists of six republics and two autonomous provinces. It has a population of about 23{ million.

DOC.HEAD: Two Yemen Leaders Meet on Border, Hints They Might Speed Unity
DOC.TEXT: SAN`A, North Yemen (AP) _ The leaders of North and South Yemen met Thursday in a border city to discuss plans for merging their two countries, and reports indicated they may speed the unification process ahead of the November deadline. The Saudi Arabian newspaper Asharq Al-Awsat reported this week that the two leaders would concentrate their new talks on joining military and security forces. The meeting, held in this country's southern city of Taiz, was the fourth between the two leaders since they announced the intended merger last November. The two countries abut one another on the southern tip of the Arabian Peninsula. Thursday's session again brought together President Ali Abdullah Saleh of North Yemen and the secretary-general of the ruling Yemeni Socialist Party in South Yemen, Ali Salem al-Beidh. They earlier agreed to put a unified constitution to their legislative bodies within six months and to a national referendum in both countries before Nov. 30. But Saleh was quoted recently as saying the full merger could be declared much earlier than Nov. 30. Diplomatic sources said the two leaders may be interested in a quicker union because of economic problems in their countries, particularly South Yemen. South Yemen, which pursued a Marxist policy since independence in 1967, has been wracked for months by labor strikes over the country's economic woes.

DOC.HEAD: Najib Says Mutineers Purged; Rebel Vows to Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs on Soviet TV report
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PES3
DOC.TEXT: President Najib of Afghanistan said Thursday that the military has been purged of mutinous soldiers, but the renegade general who led a bloody coup attempt said from hiding he would keep fighting. Radio Kabul put the death toll at 56 and said 200 people were injured in fighting since Tuesday's air raid over Kabul. Some travelers who witnessed the attacks said civilian casualties appeared low considering the ferocity of the battles. The normally bustling markets of the capital opened again Thursday, and the war-weary city was reported calm. Questions surfaced about the strength and loyalty of the Afghan air force, the key factor in Najib's survival since the Soviet Union pulled its troops out of Afghanistan last year. Shah Nawaz Tanai, who as defense minister launched the coup try, said in a taped message to his supporters Thursday: ``We have risen and our struggle will continue.'' Tanai defected Wednesday to the Moslem guerrillas battling Najib's government, but guerrilla leaders made clear Thursday they have no desire to join forces with the hard-line Marxist. ``He's no different than Najib. How can we extend our support to a Communist?'' said Abdul Rasul Sayyaf, leader of the radical Islamic Ittehad faction and prime minister of the guerrillas' government in exile. Radio Kabul said Najib replaced Tenai as defense minister Tuesday and dismissed him Thursday from the Supreme Defense Council. Four other council members also were replaced because of ``national dishonesty,'' said the radio, monitored in Islamabad. They were identified as Niaz Mohammad Momand and Mir Sahib Karwal, both Politburo members; Gen. Nazar Mohammad, an alternate member of the Politburo and a former defense minister; and Gen. Sayed Aqa Aka, a brigadier general who fled to Pakistan on Wednesday. According to the radio, Najib declared that mutinous troops had been purged from the armed forces. And a diplomat based in Kabul quoted the president as telling a news conference: ``The microbes, the radicals among us, have been cleansed. We don't have any more factions. We are more united than ever.'' According to the diplomat, who refused to be identified further, Najib said pro-Tanai soldiers had been killed, arrested or had surrendered. He again declared his government was strong and urged Western nations to revise their pro-resistance policies. In his message, Tanai said he was inside Afghanistan but he did not say where. ``I am sending this cassette with my friend outside to be broadcast to you,'' he said in comments translated by the guerrillas' news agency from Dari into English. ``This is a call for Afghanistan's Moslem people and the army and the real party members. Najib and his dictatorship will fall. For this and for national unity, we have risen up.'' The tape was played to reporters, who recognized Tanai's voice from military briefings, news conferences, and television appearances. Tanai was in at least temporary alliance with one of the most radical guerrilla leaders, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. Sibghatullah Mojaddidi, the moderate president of the guerrillas' exile government, rejected the Tanai-Hekmatyar alliance. ``We do not have any understanding or solidarity with either,'' he said. Tanai and Hekmatyar were bitter rivals during the 12 years of war after the 1978 coup that installed a Communist government in Afghanistan. Tanai had opposed Najib's propsals to talk peace with the guerrillas, and Hekmatyar said he would only support an Islamic government in Afghanistan. They appeared united in their desire to see Najib ousted. When the last Soviet soldiers left Afghanistan in February 1989 after nine years of military intervention, many governments, including the United States and Soviet Union, predicted Najib's government would collapse within weeks or months. But the Afghan armed forces held their ground, largely because of the Afghan air force. This week's fighting resulted in heavy losses to air force aircraft, said one Western diplomat. ``The air force was Najib's only card. It's unlikely it will get back the strength it had anytime soon,'' said the diplomat in Islamabad, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Tanai, a battle-hardened soldier popular among rank-and-file Afghan soldiers, launched the coup attempt from Bagram, the country's largest air base about 30 miles north of Kabul. About a half-dozen warplanes swooped down on the capital, dropping bombs around the presidential palace and near crowded markets and residential areas in the old section, according to diplomatic sources in Kabul and Islamabad. ``I was very scared,'' said Harinder Singh, an Afghan who was among 150 passengers aboard a Kabul-New Delhi flight on Thursday, the first flight since the attempted coup. ``All of us thought we were going to die. A bomb exploded in a taxi near me and I saw the driver being blown apart.'' According to sources in Kabul, the last bombs were dropped on the city Wednesday morning as pro-Tanai soldiers battled troops loyal to Najib at Bagram. In Moscow, Soviet television said late Thursday that five artillery shells landed on Soviet Embassy grounds during the Kabul fighting, but no one was hurt. It said nothing about damage. The Soviet TV reporter said a majority of the military backs Najib and reported most of Afghanistan was quiet, but he said the situation in the near future is ``not simple.'' He said Tanai is from the Khost region and is likely to use his connections there.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Changes Plans and Flies to African Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Black leader Nelson Mandela switched plans Thursday and flew to this capital to thank ambassadors to the Organization of African Unity for their years of support. Interrupting a scheduled six-day visit to Tanzania, the new vice president of the African National Congress hastily changed his itinerary to address the envoys from across the continent. Mandela has received invitations to visit dozens of countries since his release four weeks ago from a South African prison where he was serving a life sentence for sabotage and treason. Mandela had been in prison since 1962, when he was sentenced to five years for leaving the country illegally and organizing an illegal strike by blacks. While serving that sentence he was convicted in 1964 of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white government. By changing his schedule to address ambassadors to the Organization of African Unity at its headquarters in Ethiopia's capital, Mandela found a way to thank many countries at once for supporting him and his group. For years, the Organization of African Unity has been calling for Mandela's release and condemning the white minority government of South Africa for its policies of racial separation known as apartheid. Mandela's speech to the ambassadors was scheduled Friday morning after a meeting with officials of the group. Then he was to fly back to Tanzania to visit African National Congress training camps for guerrillas before leaving for Sweden on Sunday. Mandela flew to Addis Ababa from Zanzibar, the semi-autonomous island off Tanzania's east coast. He spoke at a public rally there, met island officials and laid a wreath on the tomb of Abeid Amani Karume, Zanzibar's first president who was assassinated in 1972.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 15 grafs new with Fitzwater comments; information that Bush placed return call; picks up 9th graf: ``CBS said,'' DELETES 12th graf, ``Eight Americans,'' incorporated higher; adds byline
DOC.TEXT: President Bush last month returned a call to talk about U.S. hostages to a man he was told was Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, but the call turned out to be a hoax, the White House said Thursday. ``This was the first time this has happened,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. He said the government has no idea who was behind the hoax. Fitzwater and other White House officials said that Bush placed the call after a man identifying himself as an Iranian government official called the White House to say that Rafsanjani wanted to talk to Bush about U.S. hostages held in Lebanon. ``The call came in, a number was given for us to call. We were suspicious and began checking,'' Fitzwater said. ``But, ultimately, the president needed to make the call as part of the check. He did make the call.'' The call, first reported by CBS News, came to a staff member of the White House National Security Council, aides said. ``The president has made it known he's willing to talk to Iran at any time,'' Fitzwater said. ``And the ball is in their court.'' The Bush administration has contended that Rafsanjani's government has influence with the captors of eight Americans and citizens of 10 European countries being held in Lebanon. Fitzwater said that the administration has let Rafsanjani know ``through diplomatic channels as well as publicly, that we're willing to talk whenever they're ready. And they have come back and said, `We're not ready.''' The caller said the Iranian president wanted to speak to Bush, and ``various methods were used to check'' the legitimacy of the call, said another White House aide, Stephen Hart. Since the president ``has stated he would talk to anybody if it would help free the hostages,'' Bush agreed to talk to Rafsanjani, Hart said. Fitzwater and Hart declined to answer further questions about the affair, such as how the hoax was discovered or what Bush said to the caller. Asked if Bush immediately realized that the voice on the other end of the line was not Rafsanjani, Fitzwater said: ``I can't tell you how we determined it was a hoax.'' He said he didn't want to get into anything ``that goes to the point of how we check out phone calls.'' However, he indicated that the person on the other end of the line did not identify himself as a hoaxer. CBS said the call came first to Brent Scowcroft, national security adviser to the president, and was checked out by ``various intelligence methods.'' In his conversation with the unknown caller, the president ``repeated U.S. policy that goodwill will beget goodwill but there could be no quid pro quo for U.S. hostages,'' the network said. Bush first used the phrase ``goodwill will beget goodwill'' in his inaugural address 14 months ago. Recent days have seen a flurry of speculative stories about whether the hostages might be freed, and the White House has said it was encouraged by recent comments of Rafsanjani to the effect that a solution might be achieved soon. The Tehran Times, a newspaper close to Iran's president, said in an editorial that 1990 would be the last year of captivity for the hostages. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said on Tuesday ``we are encouraged by the fact that there is speculation'' about a release of the hostages. ``Let's see if that speculation proves out.'' The White House has said it was not negotiating directly with Iran, and it has said it would make no deals for the freedom of the hostages. But ``a great deal is being done that is not publicized,'' said Mike Kraft, an official in the State Department's counter-terrorism office, on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Lieutenant Acquitted in Sex Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Mrs. Haye ...,' to CORRECT that her husband is a sergeant, sted an officer.
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force lieutenant accused of having sex with a sergeant at a Titan 2 missile silo was acquitted Wednesday by an eight-man military jury. ``Thank God!'' 2nd Lt. Naomi Haye's attorney, Morgan ``Chip'' Welch, yelled when the verdict was read after two hours of deliberations. Mrs. Haye dropped into her chair and sobbed quietly as supporters applauded. ``I'm speechless,'' Mrs. Haye, 33, told reporters Wednesday. ``I always planned on the worst and hoped for the best. It's easier to expect the worst. It's too defeating to get the other way around.'' Air Force officials said Mrs. Haye may be entitled to about $75,000 in back pay withheld since she was first charged in 1986 with fraternizaion and adultery. She was convicted that year of adultery and fraternization, but the verdict was overturned by military appeals courts. Prosecutors retried her on charges of fraternization, claiming she had sex four times with Sgt. Thomas Bush, at their homes, at a hotel and at a missile silo while he was on duty. Mrs. Haye now lives in Guam with her husband, Patrick, an Air Force sergeant. The president of the jury, Col. Liegel John, said he found Bush unreliable. ``There was a lot of inconsistencies and not enough there to prove her guilty,'' John said. ``There was no smoking gun.'' Prosecutor Capt. Derek Hill had argued that Mrs. Haye and her husband tried to cover up the alleged affair, and said she declined to deny the charge until several weeks after she talked to her attorneys. The defense said Bush, who has married four times, used his marital problems to get close to female acquaintances. Welch said Bush was ``hustling women through an approach that's as old as the hills _ `My wife doesn't understand me.' He wants counseling. He wants them to mother him. ``He's the only witness to allege sexual misconduct,'' Welch said. ``I'll be the first to tell you I believe Mr. Bush is guilty of sexual misconduct. I just don't know with whom.'' In his closing argument, Hill said there was no reason for an enlisted man to lie about having an affair with an officer. Welch also took aim at prosecution witnesses who supported Bush's testimony. A prosecution witnesss, Staff Sgt. Kim Wilkinson, testified earlier in the week that she caught Bush and Mrs. Haye in an embrace. But two defense witnesses testified Monday that Ms. Wilkinson joked and talked often about sex. ``She saw sex behind every door and every glance and every nuance,'' Welch said. Six of the eight jurors were needed to cast guilty votes to convict Mrs. Haye under military law, but the actual vote was not released Wednesday. Mrs. Haye would have faced dismissal from the Air Force if found guilty.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Pollutes Ocean Reserve for Rare Fish
DOC.TEXT: A tanker smashed into a tug boat and dumped thousands of gallons of fuel oil into an ocean reserve for rare fish along Brazil's southeastern Atlantic coast, officials said Wednesday. The spill occurred Monday night in the marine reserve of Angra dos Reis, 94 miles southwest of Rio, said Elcio Pires, a spokesman for the Rio state environmental agency. The Jacui tanker, owned by the government-run oil monopoly Petrobras, rammed the docked tug boat at an oil unloading terminal, Pires said in a telephone interview. He said 10,400 gallons of oil spilled from a 10-inch gash in the tanker's hull, coating the pristine waters with a thick film. ``The oil blackened at least 13 kilometers (8 miles) of beaches in four islands. Some beach areas on the mainland were also hit,'' Pires said. He said cleanup crews with skimmers were working around the clock to contain the slick but that rough tides were carrying the oil out to sea. Only 60 percent of the oil would be recovered, Pires said. The ecological damage to the reserve, home to thousands of species of rare fish and marine fauna, would not be known for several weeks, he said. Rio state Gov. Wellington Moreira Franco told a news conference that the oil terminal would be shut down for ``an indefinite time until security measures against future spills are taken.'' ``It would be impossible not to punish such continued acts of irresponsibility,'' he said. Petrobras was fined $1,000 for the spill and the terminal will be monitored when it reopens, Franco said. He said 30 ecological accidents have occurred at the terminal since 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect In Random Shootings Arrested; Apparent Bomb Found In Vehicle
DOC.TEXT: A man fired shots at random as he drove around the city Thursday morning, hitting a newspaper delivery man in the head and wounding at least seven other men before police arrested him, authorities said. ``Each and every one of these shootings had no apparent motive,'' said police Lt. Mike McKenna. Police recovered a revolver, the fresh carcass of a goose and a package the suspect said was a bomb from his red station wagon, McKenna said. Police confirmed the bundle was an incendiary device, he said. A major street was closed for more than three hours and businesses were evacuated while a police bomb squad removed the package and took it to a rural area for detonation. There were at least 10 shooting incidents in east Wichita in a little more than an hour starting around 4:30 a.m., McKenna said. Some of the shootings were nearly 10 miles apart. Two of the injured were hit by bullets and the rest by flying glass, police said. The toll could have been much higher had the rampage occurred 90 minutes later as morning rush hour traffic built, police said. The suspect was arrested after he stopped at a fast-food restaurant that hadn't opened yet, and police seeking his station wagon surrounded him. The 50-year-old suspect, who has a history of violence, was taken to a hospital for a mental evaluation, McKenna said. The man was being held without bond, and hadn't been charged. William F. Brown, a 41-year-old employee of The Wichita Eagle, was shot once in the back of the head as he was stocking a coin-operated newspaper box outside a restaurant. Brown was listed in extremely critical condition Thursday night at HCA Wesley Medical Center. Allen T. Cox, 54, of Kechi was hospitalized in good condition with a bullet wound to the jaw that cost him several teeth. The other victims were cut by flying glass and didn't suffer gunshot wounds, McKenna said. Four men were treated at hospitals and released, another was treated by ambulance attendants and a sixth refused treatment.

DOC.HEAD: German Leader Reassures NATO Allies on Unification
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought to calm fears among the NATO allies on Thursday by promising to keep them fully informed on plans to forge a new German state. In what was seen as a dramatic gesture to the alliance, Kohl traveled to the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to meet for nearly three hours with ambassadors and other officials of the 16 nations. Afterward, he told reporters, ``Nobody has to be concerned that the Germans would one way or the other want to go it alone.'' ``This was a very important event for me. We've had a very frank, a very open conversation.'' NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner, a former defense minister in Bonn, called the closed-door talks ``very intensive, constructive, fruitful and lively _ also very friendly.'' He said the discussions marked the start of a ``formal sequence of consultations inside this alliance'' on the issue of German unification and the security questions this posed. He said the allies unanimously supported efforts to join the two Germanys and agreed the unified state should remain in NATO. He said they welcomed the resolution adopted Thursday by the Bonn Parliament calling for a united Germany to honor Poland's Western border. Kohl came here to try to stop complaints from NATO nations about being left out of talks on security aspects of a united Germany. Several NATO diplomats, demanding anonymity, praised his performance here. ``It was a tour de force,'' said one. Another said, ``Kohl came clearly wanting to get things back on track with the European allies.'' In an interview later with The Associated Press, Woerner described Kohl as being ``very frank, not the usual diplomatic attitude.'' Other officials said detailed questions were asked about whether Germany wanted to consult the allies, what its goals were and how it intended to deal with the current territory of East Germany after unification. More than 380,000 Soviet troops now are stationed there. The officials said the questions might have been sharper had not the German legislature dealt with the issue of Poland's borders. Kohl had drawn fire for his earlier reluctance to unequivocally state that a united Germany would never lay claim to land ceded to Poland after the Third Reich's 1945 defeat. Kohl told reporters as he left the building: ``What is happening in Germany at present must be embedded in the ... ongoing developments in Europe. ``German interests must be taken into account, but also the interests of all our friends and partners and neighbors in East and West must be taken into account. ``This means we need to have talks constantly, that we need to consult very closely and that we need to cooperate very closely. That was the idea behind my visit.'' He said the 40-year-old West German state deserved ``confidence and trust.'' Woerner said the allies would be consulted before and after key meetings of the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II allies _ Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union. He said Soviet troops would likely remain on East German territory for years after unification. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Tuesday it was ``absolutely out of the question'' that a united Germany would belong to NATO. East Germany is now part of the Warsaw Pact military alliance. Moscow would like to see a neutral nation formed by the two Germanys. Kohl said events were shaping the drive toward unification. He said 115,000 to 116,000 East Germans moved to West Germany in January and February. ``We want this process to be stopped,'' he said. ``We want these people to stay home. We want them to see their future over there.''

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Warns of Civil War If Contras Fail to Dismantle
With AM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega on Thursday warned of civil war if the U.S-supported Contra rebels fail to dismantle before April 25, when the administration of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is to take over the government. In a speech before thousands of people celebrating International Woman's Day, Ortega repeatedly spoke both of leading the Sandinistas as an opposition force and about the Sandinistas' demand that the Contras demobilize in the transition period. ``There is a calm like those before the storm,'' Ortega said. ``And we have the obligation of avoiding being swept away by the tempest of civil war ... popular insurrection ... violence.'' Ortega said ``thousands of weapons are in the hands of the people,'' who he said would be willing to defend themselves against the Contras. Since the Feb. 25 elections, there have been reports of weapons being distributed to civilians nationwide and of people being trained and organized as Sandinista paramilitary groups called ``sovereignty battalions.'' ``The situation in the country is very tense, very complicated,'' Ortega said. He said Contras continue to attack in Nicaraguan territory ``with the complicity of the Honduran government and the United States government.'' About 10,000 Contras _ most of their force _ are based in Honduran jungle camps near the Nicaragua border. Contra leaders have said they will not lay down their arms and return to Nicaragua before President-elect Chamorro is inaugurated and the Sandinista People's Army and the Interior Ministry give over control of those two institutions to the new government. That's something Ortega repeatedly has said the Sandinistas will not do. ``I am convinced that in the same way that the Contras say they will not disarm ... that the people are willing to grab the arms to finish the Contras once and for all,'' Ortega said. He also said he was not in a position to turn over to Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition alliance the weapons now in the possession of the army and Interior Ministry. ``I don't have any weapons to give up because the weapons belong to the people,'' Ortega said in his speech. He also said the army and Interior Ministry troops, considered a parallel army, ``are what will give all Nicaraguans security.'' UNO leaders have accused the Sandinistas of funneling money into foreign bank accounts. Ortega, however, said in his speech that citizens have been cleaning out their accounts because of the increase in tension and uncertainty. ``There were millionaire sums deposited in accounts, but as the situation has become tense, people have been withdrawing their accounts,'' Ortega said.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Truck Driver, IRA Claims Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs, UPDATING with new killing, Protestant claim. Picks up 4th graf, Tony McCaughey ... editing to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: At least three men killed a truck driver on Thursday in a machine-gun attack claimed by the Irish Republican Army, and a Protestant paramilitary group said it killed an IRA backer the day before. Two witnesses to Wednesday's attack leveled charges of collusion between security forces and Protestant paramilitary groups in this British province. The IRA unit in East Tyrone said its members shot the unidentified driver, who delivered construction materials to police stations and military bases. It said his employer ignored warnings to stop working for security forces. The IRA has targeted construction firms in an effort to prevent repairs on bomb damage it inflicts on security bases. The victim's employer, Henry's of Magherafelt, earlier lost a director in a shooting and a manager in a bombing. Police said the man was driving a concrete mixer when he was attacked outside Donaghmore village near Dungannon, 40 miles west of Belfast. The machine-gunners fired at least 30 shots before fleeing in a car, police said. The outlawed Protestant Ulster Volunteer Force on Thursday night claimed responsibilty for killing Sam Marshall, 31, on Wednesday shortly after he left the Royal Ulster Constabulary base in Lurgan, 20 miles southwest of Belfast. Supporters of the mainly Roman Catholic IRA identified Marshall as a member of its legal political wing, Sinn Fein. He was imprisoned from 1976 to 1982 for terrorist offenses, police said. Two survivors of the Wednesday night shooting accused police of cooperating with the gunmen. Tony McCaughey, 31, and Colm Duffy, 22, said they were under police surveillance when the gunmen attacked. The Royal Ulster Constabulary denied the allegations of collusion with the killers. The three men were out on bail after being charged with illegal possession of ammunition. One of the bail conditions was that the three had to report to the Lurgan police station twice a week on Saturdays and Wednesdays. McCaughey and Duffy said the bail conditions were known only by the police and their lawyers. ``Neither of us will be reporting back to the station,'' McCaughey said. ``We would prefer to go back to prison than go back to the RUC station.'' Duffy said a car followed them to the police station Wednesday night and was seen again just after the attack. He said it was an unmarked police car. ``We want Stevens to carry out the investigation, and to come up with some answers to who owned it,'' Duffy said. ``We have absolutely no qualms about talking to Stevens.'' John Stevens, deputy chief constable of Cambridgeshire, was sent to Northern Ireland in September to investigate a series of leaks from the Northern Ireland police force of lists of IRA suspects. The leaks stirred a furor in the province, the implication being that secret intelligence is falling into the hands of Protestant gangs and helping them choose assassination targets. Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins on Thursday called for an investigation into the new charges of collusion. Duffy said soon after leaving the police station Wednesday night, two masked men armed with rifles pulled up in a red Rover car and fired 40 shots. Police said Marshall was killed instantly. McCaughey and Duffy were unhurt. The British domestic press agency, Press Association, quoted unidentified sources as saying Marshall had been warned by police recently that he was on a Protestant paramilitary hit list. The IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It seeks to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Women Who Made a Difference Lauded Worldwide
LaserPhoto DEL1
DOC.TEXT: Women formed a human chain around India's Parliament to demand equality, and Margaret Thatcher of Britain welcomed Nicaragua's new president to the select club of female leaders during ceremonies Thursday for International Women's Day. The French saluted women who helped bring change to Eastern Europe. A visiting U.S. women's leader railed against the social status of American women. Leaders and women's groups around the world joined in the observances. March 8 was declared Women's Day in 1910 during an International Socialist Women's Conference in Copenhagen, Denmark. The celebration was adopted by the United Nations in 1975. In New Delhi on Thursday, about 2,000 women surrounded the Parliament building in a human chain. The protesters, many with clenched fists, called for more opportunities for women and equality of the sexes. One sign carried by a protester said, ``It is not women chain; it is a human chain.'' In her comments to the male-dominated British House of Commons, Prime Minister Thatcher praised the Feb. 25 election in Nicaragua of newspaper publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. ``How very grateful we are that our small number of heads of government have been added to by another head of government, a woman head of government in Nicaragua,'' she said. She spoke after rejecting an opposition Labor Party demand to mark women's day by increasing state payments to mothers of dependent children. In Managua, Nicaragua, outgoing President Daniel Ortega used his speech marking the day to warn of civil war if the U.S-supported Contra rebels fail to dismantle before April 25, when Mrs. Chamorro takes over. In Paris, ceremonies honored women who have played major roles in the fight for democracy in Romania, the Soviet Union and elsewhere. Among those singled out were human rights activists Yelena Bonner of the Soviet Union and Doina Cornea of Romania, both targets of government repression for many years.
