A symposium on ``Women and Creation'' sponsored by a year-old French feminist group, the Women's Alliance For Democratization, featured a host of international feminist leaders. They included Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women in the United States. ``International Women's Day demonstrates that everywhere women are pretty much treated as less than first-class citizens,'' Ms. Yard said to The Associated Press. Asked about the status of women in the United States, Ms. Yard said ``the picture isn't pretty.'' ``They lose their jobs, they don't get promoted and they get harassed on the job. They're denied tenure as professors, they get beaten up and they get terrible divorce settlements,'' she said. Michele Andre, France's deputy minister of women's rights, saluted the achievements of President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan. She said France will try to provide Romanian hospitals with materials for contraception and abortion. Romanian women were forbidden to use contraceptive devices and denied abortions under the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu, who was executed during the December revolution. In another address in New York, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar lauded the work of women in special U.N. missions in Namibia and Nicaragua. He also said more must be done to promote women in the world body. In Beijing, Chen Muhua, head of the All-China Women's Federation, stressed party allegiance in a reception at the Great Hall of the People for more than 1,000 prominent women. ``Chinese women are convinced that without national liberation, there would be no women's liberation, and without the Communist Party and socialism, they would not have won the status they enjoy today,'' she said. Premier Li Peng, who attended the reception, said women ``under the leadership of the Communist Party will forge ahead to maintain and further enhance the country's economic and political stability.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed as Thousands Demonstrate Against Haitian Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 2 grafs SUB for 11th graf, `A spokeswoman` to UPDATE with details of girl's killing, no investigation. Picks up 12th graf, `President Bush...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Thousands of demonstrators across Haiti set up flaming tire barricades and burned cars to protest the army's killing of a schoolgirl. Three people were killed, including a soldier beaten to death by a mob. Two people were hospitalized with bullet wounds and at least 10 others were injured in clashes with soldiers. About 3,000 people, shouting ``Liberty!'' and slogans against Haiti's leader, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, converged in downtown Port-au-Prince near the National Palace after attending a memorial service on the outskirts of the capital for 11-year-old Roseline Vaval, shot to death by the army Monday. About 10,000 people turned up for her burial Thursday in the small town of Petit Goave. Along the road leading to Petit Goave, outside the town of Carrefour, about 3,000 protesters burned automobiles, including a police car, and erected barricades of flaming tires. The independent Radio Metropole said a soldier and a civilian was killed in the Carrefour clashes. It said a mob carrying sticks and stones dragged a passing soldier from his motorcycle and beat him to death. The radio said the killing was in reprisal for the earlier killing of a civilian by a presidential guardsman. Avril, who came to power in September 1988 in a coup led by rank-and-file soldiers, has been under increasing pressure from opposition groups to resign. ``The will of the people is for Avril to step down,'' said a communique released Thursday night by a coalition of 11 opposition parties which had called on Haitians to rise against Avril. Businesses closed and people poured into the streets pounding pots and pans, garbage cans and metal poles after students called a day of mourning for the girl, shot by a soldier breaking up an anti-government demonstration. Maj. Gen. Serge Saint-Eloi, the inspector general of the army, said Thursday night that a soldier from a passing vehicle shot the girl but there would be no investigation because her parents buried her before an autopsy could be conducted. A spokeswoman for the Haitian Christian Democratic Party, speaking on condition of anonymity, said three soldiers barged into the party headquarters near the National Palace on Thursday and beat three party members with their rifle butts. President Bush remarked on the Haitian situation on Thursday while attending a ceremony in Fort Myer, Va., marking the U.S. invasion of Panama. Bush said, ``The revolution continues. The people have spoken in Nicaragua. When they speak in Cuba and Haiti, our Western Hemisphere will be entirely within the compass of freedom.'' The opposition in Nicaragua, backed by the United States, defeated President Daniel Ortega and his ruling Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections. In Haiti's capital, protesters leaving the memorial in the slum neighborhood of Bel Air left flaming tires at nearly every crossroad along the 1{-mile route into the city. A crowd then made its way to a cemetery for her burial, and soldiers used truncheons and fired into the air to disperse about 1,000 protesters. One unidentified man was killed a few feet from the army headquarters. A doctor at the state hospital said 12 people were injured, including two who suffered gunshot wounds. Reports surfaced of student-led demonstrations in several provincial cities in the fourth day of protest against the government. Schools were closed throughout the country. Radio Haiti-Inter reported the Army High Command had ordered soldiers to use restraint in quelling unrest. In an interview Wednesday, Avril indicated he would consider resigning, saying, ``I will never resist the will of the people.'' But, he said, ``If I step down hurriedly, it will create a lot of turmoil.'' General elections are scheduled this year but virtually all opposition parties have promised to boycott them unless Avril first steps down. They say he is not to be trusted with holding free elections or handing over power to civilians. The parties also want Avril to be replaced by a Supreme Court justice until a new leader is elected. Avril has said he is not interested in running for office and urged his opponents to put aside differences and get on with elections. In protests reminiscent of the demonstrations in November 1985 to protest the army's killing of three high school students, thousands of students have been marching since Monday in the provincial towns of Jacmel, Jeremie, Leogane, Petit Goave and Mirebalais. The 1985 student protests led to downfall of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, who fled to exile in France in February 1986. Avril later ousted Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, who succeeded Duvalier. In November 1987, during the first free elections since Haiti became independent from France in 1804, attackers protected by soldiers killed at least 34 voters at the polls and the elections were called off.

DOC.HEAD: Three Northwest Pilots Suspected of Flying Under Influence
DOC.TEXT: Three Northwest Airlines pilots were arrested on suspicion of being under the influence of alcohol after they landed a commercial flight from Fargo, N.D., here Thursday, airport police said. The three arrested were the captain, first officer and second officer in charge of Flight 650, which left Fargo at 6 a.m. and arrived in the Twin Cities about 7 a.m., said police Lt. Dale Gormanson at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. Douglas Solseth, a safety inspector for the Federal Aviation Administration, reported to police about 6:45 a.m. that he suspected the flight crew piloting the flight from Fargo to Minneapolis was under the influence of alcohol, Gormanson said. Airport police met Solseth at the gate where the plane arrived. Solseth made citizens' arrests of the three pilots, Gormanson said. Solseth did not return phone calls for further comment. Airport police officers took custody of the three, who all consented to provide blood samples, Gormanson said. The pilots were released about 10:40 a.m. pending test results, he said. Alan Muncaster, vice president in charge of corporate communications for the Minnesota-based Northwest, said the results of the blood-alcohol tests won't be known for several days. ``Until we have those results, the pilots have been removed from service,'' Muncaster said. Northwest officials did not know what caused authorities to suspect the pilots may have been drinking, he said. ``We're trying to find out why they were arrested,'' Muncaster said. He said he knew of nothing that occurred during the flight that would have made authorities suspect the pilots were under the influence of alcohol. ``Northwest is working with the FAA and the Metropolitan Airports Commission to investigate this,'' Muncaster added.

DOC.HEAD: Local Educator Named New Chief of Dade Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The Dade ...,' to ADD that system fourth largest in the nation. Minor editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The Dade County School Board late Wednesday selected Paul W. Bell, a 30-year veteran of the school system, as the new superintendent of the district containing Miami. Bell, deputy superintendent for education for Dade County schools since 1987, succeeds Joseph A. Fernandez, who left his $155,000-a-year post to become chancellor of New York City public schools. The Dade County system is the largest school district in Florida with 282,000 students and 264 schools, and the fourth largest in the nation after New York, Los Angeles and Chicago. The board voted 4-3 to approve Bell for the job on the 17th ballot, then chose to make the decision unanimous, said Dade County schools spokesman Andy Gollan. The board, unable to reach a majority decision on a new superintendent after 16 ballots, deferred the issue and took care of other business until several hours later in the meeting, Gollan said. A contract for Bell, 56, whose salary is subject to negotiation, is expected to be submitted at the board's next meeting on March 21, Gollan said. Other contenders for the post included Dade County associate superintendents James Fleming and Solomon Stinson; San Diego superintendent Thomas Payzant and Indianapolis superintendent James Adams. The board initially waffled on whether to conduct a nationwide search or choose someone locally after Fernandez was picked for his new job in September. But the panel spent the last four months conducting a national search at a cost of $60,000. Tee S. Greer Jr., who did not actively pursue the superintendency, served as acting superintendent after Fernandez assumed his new position on Jan. 1, Gollan said. Bell joined the Dade County system in 1960 as a teacher. He has a master's degree in education from the University of Louisville in Kentucky, where he also received his bachelor's degree.

DOC.HEAD: Reporters Withhold Bylines in Contract Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Reporters and columnists withheld their bylines from the pages of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch on Wednesday, one day before contract negotiations were to resume between the newspaper and its unions. About 600 members of Local 47 of the St. Louis Newspaper Guild have been working without a contract since their old pact expired at midnight Feb. 28. The guild is the largest of 11 unions at the newspaper and is one of six unions that have not reached agreement on a new contract. Herb Goodrick, executive director of the local, said he was pleased with the number of writers who had withheld their bylines in the first ``byline strike'' in the paper's history. ``It's been very effective,'' said Goodrick. ``It's to show that they're embarrassed to put their name on a paper that takes the bargaining position that the Post has taken. They're ashamed of it and don't want their name tied to it.'' Post-Dispatch Publisher Nicholas Penniman said only that the writers were within their rights to withhold their bylines under their current contract. The labor dispute comes at a particularly sticky time for the Post-Dispatch, which is no longer the only daily newspaper in town thanks to last fall's startup of the non-union St. Louis Sun by Ingersoll Publications Co. of Princeton, N.J. Post-Dispatch unions have urged a boycott of the Sun, which on Tuesday denied admittance to Goodrick, an attorney and a reporter from the St. Louis Labor Tribune. The Post-Dispatch is owned by Pulitzer Publishing Co. Management and the union are at odds over a number of issues, including the deletion of a 4 percent cost-of-living increase that was offered in a company proposal the union rejected last September. The latest company offer would also deny sick leave to employees who contract illnesses through ``immorality.'' Other unresolved issues include a lengthy managment rights clause, maternity leave, union rights, employee drug testing and a two-tier wage system which would pay new hires lower wages. Goodrick said the union has not threatened a strike against the newspaper. ``At this point we've tried to be very restrained and responsible,'' he said. ``Our objective is to get an agreement. A strike is one of the tools for that, but we think there are other steps we can take before that. ``I'd like to reach an agreement in the next couple of days,'' Goodrick said. ``But if we don't we can't just sit around twiddling our thumbs. We have to do something to motivate people.''

President Bush announced a national transportation policy Thursday that would cost travelers more and increase local governments' share in meeting air, land and sea travel needs into the next century. Just as the Model T and the Wright brothers' plane ``prepared the way for today's millions of cars and thousands of passenger jets, so it is now our turn to invest in America's future,'' Bush said in unveiling the policy with Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner. Bush said it would help keep America ``the world leader in transportation.'' The 129-page plan, ``Moving America Into The 21st Century,'' calls for more toll roads, local gas taxes, user fees, private investments, competition, deregulaton, research into futuristic systems and openness to foreign air carriers as well as increased attention to safety and protection of the environment.

Researchers working with live human cells in test tubes have developed a genetic ambush of the AIDS virus and say the experimental technique could combat other types of viruses. Dr. John J. Rossi, a researcher at the Bechman Research Institute of the City of Hope in Duarte, Calif., said Thursday that his laboratory has made a synthetic ribozyme that is able to genetically cripple the AIDS virus and prevent it from reproducing in test tube experiments. The ribozyme, said Rossie, ``is inside the cell and its waiting there like a soldier waiting for the enemy to come.'' Although the technique is promising, he said it is still far from being available for treating patients.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Moyers and Combat Veterans Return To Old Battlefields
DOC.TEXT: Regardless of which war it was or how many years have passed, the grunts _ the infantrymen who've fought in a war _ don't readily talk about it with those who've never been in one. A common reason: only other grunts can possibly understand what combat is like. It takes an uncommon interviewer to draw these men out, yet avoid a succession of war stories that become routine through repetition. But Bill Moyers somewhow accomplishes the former while largely avoiding the latter in his ``From D-Day to the Rhine,'' an old-soldier special, which the Public Broadcast Service is showing Sunday. In it, Moyers, just a boy when World War II ended, takes a memory-lane visit to the battlefields of France, Belgium and Germany with a group of U.S. Army veterans who fought there in the last two years of the war. Now gray-haired and in their 60s and 70s, most move slowly and talk quietly, occasionally chuckling or grinning about the odd, sometimes funny, little memories that any war produces. They recall the guy who spent a half-hour each day trimming his mustache, the sound of gears cranking as a German tank's turret turned to fire, and the Army pilot who showed up at the Normandy beachhead not long after D-Day in June 1944. He stood out. He was all dressed up, in his class-A uniform. It's a thoughtful, impressionistic show in which recollections of war are illustrated with old newsreels of combat, or contrasted with scenes of today, like French kids clambering over a Sherman tank, now a museum piece. A rolling tour of the bloody past, the program always is headed toward the Rhine, with occasional pauses for interviews in little towns or gently rolling fields where men once killed each other and where cows now peacefully graze. The veterans include a Medal of Honor winner from San Antonio, Texas, Jose Lopez. Now 79, he won the nation's highest military award when he was over 30, which is ancient for a combat infantryman. But he'd lied back then and said he was two years younger. Why? He wanted to be a paratrooper. Why? He shrugs. ``So we could meet the enemy as soon as possible and get the thing over.'' The vets inspect a museum and a graphic tapestry of a much earlier war, the bloody battle of 1066 in which William the Conquerer's troops went to war in Normandy. Moyers later asks one of the soldiers of World War II, a battalion surgeon then, how the tapestry strikes him. The doctor gently smiles. It makes him think, he says, about how endless war is, ``how it's a part of everbody's life, war and death and men fighting men.'' There are the expected visits to U.S. military cemetaries _ but also a stop at a neatly trimmed German military cemetery in France, where the grave of one soldier who fought for Hitler is simply marked ``Ein Deutscher Soldat.'' At times, this 90-minute documentary, filmed and produced by David Grubin, drags a bit. Several stories go on too long; they could have been edited more tightly. It might have made a better show had Moyers brought in a few German ex-grunts, heard their stories, gotten their perspective. They visit the old battlefields, too. But ``From D-Day to the Rhine'' is a good effort, flaws and all. And what strikes you most about it is how quietly humble and plain-spoken most of its old soldiers are. Their manner, their lack of I-was-there bombast, may make a few old-timers think of Ernie Pyle's musings on life after the war, thoughts that the famed war correspondent wrote in France in August 1944. ``Submersion in war does not necessarily qualify a man to be the master of the peace,'' he wrote. ``All we can do is fumble and try once more _ try out of the memory of our anguish _ and be as tolerant with each other as we can.'' __ Elsewhere in television ... ``TODAY'' STILL IS TRYING HARDER: NBC's once-dominant ``Today'' show last week was in second place again. For the ninth straight week, it trailed ABC's ``Good Morning America'' in the ratings. GMA averaged a 4.5 rating. ``Today,'' which had NBC sportcaster Dick Enberg subbing for the genial Bryant Gumbel from Tuesday through Friday, got a 3.8, while ``CBS This Morning'' had a 2.8. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Self Storage Industry Comes Of Age
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 21-22 to clarify that a space of 10 feet by 10 feet can go for about $80 a month
Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation.
DOC.TEXT: For years people have squirreled away personal possessions in those impersonal rows of attached garage-like structures thrown up alongside the nation's roads and highways. ``We don't like to throw anything away,'' said Charles Floss, a representative of the West Virginia-based Parkline Industries which manufactures buildings used by self-storage facilities. ``We're all pack rats,'' Floss said. These days, self-storage operators are benefiting from a new breed of pack rats _ businessmen. They're doing it by offering computerized surveillance systems, climate-controlled units, facsimile machines and even landscaping around what one industry expert calls ``a bunch of garage doors.'' ``In the past, security and lighting were not big issues and the quality of management was not good,'' said Jim Chiswell, vice president of the Sovran Group in Williamsville, N.Y., which manages 33 self-storage facilities nationwide. ``Now the focus is shifting to professional,'' Chiswell said. ``We're not just self-storage operators. We're storage consultants.'' Old-timers in the industry say self storage started about 40 years ago, but they don't agree on the exact location. ``It's believed the industry started in Texas. But there's evidence of it in Florida and Utah in the 1950s,'' said Hardy Good, publisher of Mini Storage Messenger, a trade magazine based in Phoenix, Ariz. Self storage now is a $4 billion-a-year industry, with an estimated 20,000 of the structures spread across the country, vs. 3,500 a decade ago. Some have even sprung up in Canada, Europe and Australia. Some claim they've become such an integral part of American life that you can watch the change in seasons by the comings and goings at self-storage facilities. ``In the spring you see trailers pull up with snow blowers and skis and out comes the back yard furniture,'' Chiswell said. ``In New York City you can judge the change in seasons by women taking out huge garment bags of clothes that they can't store in their small apartments.'' Self-storage operators say in the early years, most business came from people storing household goods _ kitchen appliances, sports equipment and assorted gadgets they never used, but couldn't bear to throw away. As people moved into apartments, town houses and scaled-down houses that lacked basements, garages and even attics, the self-storage industry boomed. ``There's a primary need people have to store things,'' Floss said. ``We don't like to throw anything away.'' That's no longer the case, says John Logan, a sociology professor at the State University of New York at Albany. ``People hanging on to things is what shows up more in people's garages and attics. Keeping things for a long time for nothing more than personal attachment is a luxury,'' Logan said. ``What you find in self-storage facilities is more basic things people need to keep,'' he said. ``When people are actually paying for space, they're more likely to keep only stuff they need.'' This has resulted in an evolution of sorts for self-storage operators, who say they're gradually making the transition toward commercial storage. Self-storage facilities are more sophisticated than their earlier counterparts, offering climate-controlled and built-to-suit units, lighted units, pickup and delivery, and copying machines. Climate control is necessary for people wanting to store computer equipment and business records and larger units can serve as mini-warehouses, Floss said. Cheap space is another selling point. For example a 10 feet by 10 feet space goes for an average of about $80 a month, about a third the price of comparable commercial space in many areas. Self-storage companies rent units ranging from the size of closets to spaces large enough for a car, boat or a miniwarehouse. The 10-by-10 space, the most popular size, is big enough to hold a few rooms of efficiently stacked household furniture. Or 30,000 firecrackers. That's what federal agents seized recently at a self-storage facility in Kent, Wash. Included in the haul were 10,000 M-1000 firecrackers _ each nearly equal to a half stick of dynamite.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Talent Scout Faces Criticism with Affability
LaserPhoto WX14 of March 6
DOC.TEXT: Chase Untermeyer says that being George Bush's chief talent scout is ``rather like painting the Golden Gate Bridge.'' ``Once you finish the job, you have to start in at the other end and start painting it again,'' says the 44-year-old White House personnel director and Bush protege. From a crowded office in the West Wing of the White House, Untermeyer and his staff assemble resumes and sort out the winners from the also-rans in the quest for presidential appointments. With White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, the affable Houston-raised and Harvard-trained Untermeyer makes the final recommendations to Bush on 3,500 jobs. Untermayer and his staff also ride herd on Cabinet and agency heads in filling more than 2,000 other political posts. Untermeyer, once a political reporter, said in a recent interview that ``it's sort of a rule of thumb in this business (that) every time you make an appointment you earn nine enemies and one ingrate.'' There also has been some criticism of the speed with which the White House has filled appointments. Last September, Democrats on Capitol Hill accused Bush of operating ``a Swiss-cheese govermnent'' riddled with high-level vacancies. Untermeyer defends the administration's performance, saying that background checks are time-consuming and that the criticism would have been far worse ``if we had slam-dunked people into jobs.'' ``I personally don't mind being the target of a bad news story or two in 1989 if we are spared in 1990 and thereafter a series of news stories about some cretin or boob or otherwise incompetent individual who was named to office by George Bush,'' he told the Heritage Foundation last year. ``You can bet that the folks writing those stories would not say, `On the other hand, the White House in 1989 acted with admirable speed in putting this fine citizen into office,''' said Untermeyer. In the interview, Untermeyer said the opposition turned up the heat on the pace of appointments ``essentially because we had denied the Democrats ... the so-called sleaze issue.'' ``Practically none of our nominees has come under any controversy, whereas that happened all the time under President Reagan.'' However, several Bush nominees to major posts were defeated or forced to withdraw, including John Tower as defense secretary and William Lucas as the Justice Department's civil rights chief. In addition, Fred Bush, the chief fund-raiser for the 1988 Bush campaign but no relation to the president, was rejected as ambassador to Luxembourg after coming under scrutiny for contracts he had received from Reagan's Department of Housing and Urban Development. Untermeyer was executive assistant to then-Vice President Bush during the first two years of the Reagan administration. He then spent five years in the Pentagon as a deputy and then assistant secretary of the Navy for manpower and reserves, responsible for recruiting, training, health and other matters for the Navy's 600,000 sailors and 200,000 Marines. Untermeyer, who said he longs to leave personnel work and ``return to a policy rule,'' has stayed off the social circuit, partly to avoid being button-holed by job seekers. He routinely logs 12- to 14-hour days, customarily getting by on four or five hours of sleep a night. At his desk on a recent Sunday afternoon, Untermeyer acknowledged that 1989 had ``its grim points, but it had its upside, too. I also met the woman that I'm now engaged to marry.'' He and Diana C. Kendrick, 27, executive assistant to C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, plan an October wedding. ``It was a White House romance. You might say that we met on a Sunday working on paperwork _ which is exactly what's happening now.''

DOC.TEXT: A painting portraying Jesus Christ as a dope addict that was funded by tax dollars through the National Endowment for the Arts will be among anti-Christian items discussed at a conference next week, says the American Family Association. The Conference on Anti-Christian Bias in America March 15-16 at the Airport Park Hotel at Memphis, Tenn., will feature Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif., Los Angeles syndicated columnist Cal Thomas and Rabbi Yahuda Levin of Brooklyn, N.Y. ``The bias against Christians in our society has become socially acceptable in many circles of contemporary America,'' said the Rev. Donald Wildmon, a Methodist and executive director of the Tupelo-based association. ``Just as America must not tolerate anti-Semitism or racism, America cannot tolerate bigotry against Christians.''

Trustees of the Southern Baptist Foreign Missions Board, which has about 3,800 missionaries on the field overseas, have unanimously agreed to continue their policy of not appointing divorced people as missionaries.

Many ministers and members of United Methodist churches in South Carolina support cross-racial appointments of ministers, but others have indicated uncertainties about how smoothly the transitions will be. Up to five United Methodist Churches will get ministers this year who are of a different race than their congregation, Bishop Joseph Bethea said. ``From a practical standpoint, we will have to start small,'' he said. The Rev. Ed McDowell Jr., pastor of a black congregation, said, ``There are some fears and misgivings on both sides. The winds of change are blowing. They are refreshing, but they are also fearful.''

Reforms in the Soviet Union have made it ``a freer place, but the process of opening a closed society has had some unfortunate side effects,'' say two leaders of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B`rith after an ll-day visit there. ``A rise in popular anti-Semitism ... has left Jews in many parts of the Soviet Union feeling isolated and vulnerable,'' said a report by Kenneth Jacobson and Stephen M. Freeman.

Negotiations toward a peaceful settlement in South Africa should be based on the ``principle of equality of human persons,'' says the chairman of the U.S. Catholic Conference committee on international policy. Archbishop Roger M. Mahoney of Los Angeles, hailing the release from prison of black leader Nelson Mandela, said a future South Africa should be based on ``genuine respect for the life and dignity of every human person.''

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has won official recognition of Czechoslovakia's new democratic government, allowing the church full religious rights. The recognition comes in the wake of a meeting in Prague between three Mormon leaders and Czech Deputy Prime Minister Josef Hromadka last month. ``It means we're able to function fully as a church in that nation,'' said church spokesman Jerry Cahill. He said the recognition actually is a ``restoration,'' since the church had functioned in Czechoslovakia from 1929 to 1950. There currently are about 200 Mormons in the nation of 15.6 million. The church announced eight new missions, including three in Eastern European countries, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Graham Holding East-West Berlin Rally To Boost Spiritual Morale
DOC.TEXT: Evangelist Billy Graham is holding a big, evangelistic rally in Berlin this Saturday, intended as the first ecumenical gathering of East and West Germans in more than 30 years. He says churches played a key role in overturning the autocratic East German government last fall. ``This has given new hope to people,'' he said in an interview before flying to Berlin this week. But the aftermath, he said, seems to have left a ``spiritual vacuum.'' ``There's a spiritual vacuum and spiritual hunger both in East and West Germany,'' he said. ``People want something to believe in.'' Graham said that like many others, he had been astounded by the rapid swing away from monolithic communism last year by East European countries. ``I didn't think it would happen in my lifetime,'' he said. ``It could bring about a long period of peace in the world,'' Graham said, ending the U.S. Soviet Soviet conflict and nuclear ``balance of terror'' that has endangered humanity for 45 years. ``We ought to go to SALT 10 and eliminate all these terrible weapons of mass destruction, the chemical weapons and other weapons now on the drawing board,'' he said. ``They're frightening.'' Church leaders both in West Germany and long-communist met with Graham in Berlin last month, urging the joint rally at a time when ``German Christians live between fear and hope.'' Peaceful demonstrations by the East Germans last fall toppled the prolonged rule of Communist boss Erick Honecker and installed a mixed, interim government, pending March 18 elections. Prospects also are being dicussed for reunifying the nation, divided between East and West since World War II. Church leaders on both sides said in a statement issued by Graham's office that ``in the last decades Billy Graham has built bridges of understanding between East and West by encouraging many people to come to a living faith.'' The rally, which many thousands from both sides of the border are expected to attend, is to be Saturday afternoon at the plaza in front of the Reichstag building next to the Brandenburg Gate. ``I'm a little bit afraid _ I don't want to be political and must not say one word with the slightest hint of politics,'' Graham said. ``I'll just preach the gospel and tell of Christian values and morals.'' Graham, 72, has previously preached both in East and West German cities, as well as in all the other Eastern bloc countries except Bulgaria and Albania. He met with German pastors in Berlin last December, on his way back from a visit with Pope John Paul II, and said the Germans felt people there needed an interpretation of recent events ``from a Christian point of view.'' ``They said they wanted a religious figure, someone well-known and accepted on both sides, to provide some Christain word on what has happened,'' Graham said. ``I told them I just didn't have the strength to to do all that. I was determined to say no, but after listening to the East Berliners tell me why I had to come, I had to give in, after all they've been through.'' Graham said the East German churches played a major part in the governmental turn-about there. ``People didn't feel free to meet, except in the churches,'' he said. ``That's where they met and began their marches.'' However, he said, after the Berlin Wall came down last Nov. 9, a sort of lethargy has come over the churches. ``They tell me people now are deserting the churches,'' he said. ``This is particularly a spiritual problem.'' In the political transition going on in Eastern Europe, he said, ``Religion is basic to freedom. Man is first of all a worshipping creature. He has to have something to believe in, a basis for life.'' Graham said that in his numerous meetings with Soviet leaders in the past, he had insisted that ``propagandizing atheism wouldn't work. It goes against human nature. People want the freedom to believe in God, to worship God.''

DOC.HEAD: Covenant House Struggles with a Troubled Life _ Its Own
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-two years after Covenant House started sheltering children from the streets, the nation's largest program for young runaways is struggling with another troubled life: its own. Torn by allegations of sexual impropriety that forced the resignation of its charismatic founder, the $87 million-a-year operation has postponed some expansion plans and steeled itself for a drop in donations. The scrutiny also has revealed criticism from a new source: social welfare professionals who question its style of service. Critics agree Covenant House helps fill the urgent need of sheltering homeless youths; each night, about 2,000 runaways sleep in its centers in six U.S. cities, Latin America and Canada. But some say Covenant House's main thrust _ short-term stays in institutional settings _ represents triage rather than treatment. Others complain that its Roman Catholic philosophy precludes sex education that could help stem the spread of AIDS. Some critics accuse its counselors of harassing homosexual youths, and others charge the organization with institutional arrogance, saying it virtually ignores other privately operated programs. ``They fill the hallways and then call the press in and say, `There's kids on the floor, we need more money,''' said Marion Reidel, clinical director at the Emergency Shelter, a much smaller program for runaways in New York. ``They're notorious for not networking with the other programs in town.'' Since December, a series of former clients has stepped forward to accuse Covenant House's 62-year-old founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, of sexual misconduct. One youth claimed to have received money and gifts from Ritter, and Covenant House has conceded trying to start him off in a new life by giving him the identity of a dead 10-year-old boy, without asking the dead boy's parents. Ritter has denied wrongdoing, but Franciscan officials ordered him to take a leave of absence while they investigated. On Feb. 27, he resigned. The next day, prosecutors said they had found ``questionable financial transactions'' at Covenant House, but none meriting prosecution. Covenant House gets 95 percent of its funds from private donations, relying on appeals written by Ritter and mailed monthly to 800,000 past or potential supporters. Donations fell, recovered and fell again as the allegations surfaced and subsided. Now Covenant House officials are uncertain _ and deeply worried _ about the effect of Ritter's departure. ``There's a real question as to whether Covenant House will be able to grow and expand as it has, or whether Covenant House will be put into a period of retrenchment for some time,'' said Frank Macchiarola, who served briefly as acting president before resigning, also on Feb. 27, because of friction with the organization's board. Covenant House operates large shelters in New York; New Orleans; Houston; Los Angeles; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Anchorage, Alaska; and Toronto, and orphanage-style shelters in Mexico, Honduras, Guatemala and Panama. Plans to establish a shelter in Washington are on hold, but expansions in Los Angeles and New Orleans are proceeding and a counseling center in Dallas just opened. Despite the organization's longstanding practice of spending almost all of each year's income, Covenant House officials said its finances are basically sound and no cutbacks are envisioned. But the criticism of its programs appears likely to continue. ``We have this kind of mixed feeling toward the Covenant House,'' said Fred Griesbach, head of the Coalition for the Homeless. While the rate of AIDS is ``astronomical'' among runaways, Greisbach said, Covenant House does not encourage using condoms to stem the disease's spread but instead counsels abstinence. ``They're not going to deal with it in what I think is a rational way,'' he said. ``We think it's counterproductive. You need to talk about condoms, about abortion, about birth control that goes beyond abstinence.'' Macchiarola said Covenant House's handling of birth control and sex education is guided by principle. ``The policy we follow is church policy,'' he said. ``We have to proceed off what we think is right.'' Covenant House's main purpose is to provide emergency shelter for a few days or weeks to runaways who often return to the street. But critics say smaller, more intensive programs have more success helping youngsters find a new life. ``Young people are supposed to be in a family-type environment,'' Reidel said. ``They're not supposed to be institutionalized. They don't belong in large buildings.'' Covenant House's Manhattan shelter, in tawdry Times Square, fails to remove youngsters from the dangers and temptations of street life and is too big for effective individual counseling, she said. The Manhattan shelter was designed for 250 youths but often sleeps more than 300, some on roll-out pads in lounges. Macchiarola said Covenant House's reluctance to refer youths elsewhere reflects its open-door policy. ``The moment our people think they should refer kids elsewhere is the moment we've taken a different attitude,'' he said. After a brief stay, two-thirds of the shelter's visitors return to the street, where some meet an early death from drugs, disease or violence. The others return to families, find their own place to live or enter long-term residential programs. Covenant House also operates a 150-bed long-term residence in New York, and other organizations run similar, smaller programs. ``And there are advantages to that smallness,'' said Susan Mullgrav, special projects director at the city Department of Youth Services. ``It's more personalized. It's more individualized.'' Yet given the scope of the problem _ with an estimated 100,000 to 300,000 homeless runaway youths nationwide _ Mullgrav and thers concede large shelters do fill the most urgent needs: A bed, a meal and someone to talk to. ``Covenant House has been necessary, in spite of their programmatic problems, because they're one of the few agencies that has that number of beds,'' said Reidel. ``It is better than sleeping on the streets.''

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Just First of Problems for Brazil's New President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Thursday in lead is March 15
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Brazil is mired in its worst economic crisis as it takes the final step to full civilian democracy with the inauguration Thursday of its first popularly elected president in 30 years. He is the conservative Fernando Collor de Mello, who likens himself to a hunter with a single bullet left and a hungry tiger coming at him. The tiger is inflation and Collar says he has to kill it with one quick shot or be devoured. ``But don't worry,'' he adds confidently. ``I'm an excellent shot, and I won't miss.'' Inflation rose 56 percent in January and a record 73 percent in February, with the projection of an annual rate of 71,000 percent. March is expected to be worse. Collor will replace President Jose Sarney, who took over from a military government in 1985 but failed in a number of attempts to halt the nation's economic and financial slide. Brazilians have lived for decades with inflation but have been protected by cost-of-living indexing of wages and bank accounts. Experts now say, however, such government protection may be at an end. ``Hyperinflation marks the demise of this socially exclusive, elitist economic model. It is the state of bankruptcy of the government,'' Edmar Bacha, an economist and former head of the government's census bureau, said in an interview. Today, Bacha added, this country of 150 million is what he calls a ``Belindia'' _ a Belgium and an India side by side. The Belgium half resembles a developed country, with the Western world's eighth-largest economy and third-biggest trade surplus, a world leader in the production of coffee, sugar, orange juice, soybeans, cotton, and iron ore; a producer and exporter of sophisticated goods such as computers, cars, aircraft and rockets. The India part is marked by the Third World's largest foreign debt, put at $114 billion, 7 million street children, 20 percent adult illiteracy, sprawling shantytowns and epidemics of dengue, malaria and yellow fever. However, the consensus is that inflation is the country's most serious problem. ``Collor's credibility and the viability of his government depend on how he deals with inflation,'' said Luiz Antonio de Medeiros, president of the powerful metalworkers union. ``All the other problems he will face _ income distribution, the foreign debt, poverty, etcetera _ are secondary.'' The economy has gone haywire at the hands of inflation. In a Rio department store, a Barbie doll costs more than February's monthly minimum wage of 2,004 cruzados ($70). A linen shirt costs as much as six 3-speed blenders. Identical knapsacks cost 600 cruzados ($21.50) at one store and 2,400 cruzados ($86) at another in the same shopping mall. Investors seek shelter in gold and illegal black-market dollars or in an extremely short-term financial market known as the ``overnight,'' which today pays 105 percent a month. Consumers rush to stock up on food, clothes and electrical appliances before prices go up again. Violent crime is increasing, and Brazilians look anxiously to neighboring Argentina, where runaway inflation has led to the looting of supermarkets and military unrest, as a example of what might be in store for them. ``People are frightened,'' said Graciela Treiyer, the manager of an upscale leather goods boutique in Rio de Janeiro. ``The government says inflation is 70 percent, but we know it's more. Things are just out of control.'' An estimated $1 billion a month is leaving the country, and much-needed foreign investment has dried up. ``One can't plan, one can't contract, one doesn't know how much supplies are going to cost or anything else with inflation so ridiculously high,'' said William Meissner, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Rio de Janeiro. A growing number of Brazilians are seeking financial safety in the United States, Western Europe or Japan. ``We are not an island of prosperity. With hyperinflation, we are more like a continent of despair,'' said Sen. Roberto Campos, a former planning minister and ex-ambassador to the United States and England. Some even are asking whether Brazil was better off under the repressive military regime that ruled from 1964 to 1985. ``Sure we've got democracy now, but what good is it when beans are 38 cruzados ($1.37) a kilo?'' said Jose de Oliveira, a tax office worker who moonlights as a chauffeur at a car rental agency. Collor's remedy is to drastically cut government spending. He has promised to lay off workers, close government ministries, drop subsidies and sell off state-owned companies. Trade barriers will be lowered and protection for domestic industry eliminated. However, economists say Brazil also will have to sharply reduce interest payments on its billion-dollar foreign debt, which amount to $12 billion a year. Collor says he will order the federal police to arrest the ``tax evaders, middlemen, and speculators'' he holds responsible for inflation. ``The blame falls on the elite ... who take advantage of the economic and financial disorder to make more and more money, in detriment of the vast majority of the population,'' he told a recent news conference. Collor is banking on his popularity among the poor masses and his credibility as a popularly elected president. (Sarney was chosen by an electoral college.) In December, Collor defeated socialist Luis Inacio Lula da Silva by 4 million votes in Brazil's first free presidential election since 1960. However, analysts say Collor will meet stiff opposition from Congress, labor unions and the rich who risk losing long-held privileges. ``The elite will use the unions,'' economist Bacha predicts. ``Inefficient and protected industries will claim they'll be forced to fire employees if the government allows imports. It's the same argument Americans are used to hearing in relation to Japanese competition.'' Congress is another stumbling block. Collor's National Reconstruction Party, founded just last year, has only 26 seats in the 570-seat legislature. Da Silva, his adversary in the election, has pledged to form a ``parallel government'' with other leftists to oppose the new administration. Militant labor unions, which backed da Silva, have threatened to strike if the government holds down wages or lays off workers. ``Collor doesn't have support in the organized sectors of society,'' said Eli Diniz, a political scientist at the University Research Institute of Rio de Janeiro. ``He will have to negotiate a social pact to give his measures legitimacy or try a populist mobilization.'' Brazilians, who have seen four anti-inflation plans collapse in as many years under Sarney, are torn between hope and skepticism. ``The people are rooting for Collor and want to help, but they will demand results,'' said psychologist Sigrid Marques da Silva Castro. In a February survey by the respected IBOPE polling institute, 68 percent of those questioned said they had faith in Collor. ``I hate to say it, but I'm optimistic like a Brazilian is optimistic,'' said Meissner of the American Chamber of Commerce. ``Brazil's like a baby with a fever. You're convinced the baby is going to die, and two hours later it's playing outside.''

DOC.HEAD: An AP Photo Package
Wallenda Family Bids Farewell to the Wire
LaserPhotos NY321-326 of March 8
DOC.TEXT: Sitting cross-legged on the gymnasium floor in a rare moment of quiet, 3-year-old Steven Wallenda II scribbles on a pad of paper. He scrawls two overlapping circles and a long tail, like a drumstick. ``This is my mommy's lung transfer,'' he says matter-of-factly, tapping the the circles. ``And this is her fake leg,'' he adds, outlining the tail. Running the pen from the circles to the tail's end, he says, ``When you have cancer, it goes real deep. All the way down to your foot.'' Sixteen feet above, deftly maneuvering a half-inch steel cable, his mother, 21-year-old aerialist Angel Wallenda, is oblivious to the worldly explanation of her illness. She and her husband, Steven, 34, gently traverse the wire, testing its spring and memorizing the tricky parts in anticipation of the evening's event: the final performance of the Wallendas as a family, and Angel's last chance to work on a high wire. Her husband, the last of the clan still performing the feats that made the Wallenda family famous, set up the recent benefit at Mansfield University to help defray the costs of his wife's ongoing battle with cancer. The cancer, a particularly belligerent breed, forced the removal of her right leg below the knee in 1987, then parts of both lungs in 1988. But it wasn't long before Angel was back on the wire, miraculously inching her way along on one good leg and a lifelike prosthesis. ``It's sort of scary,'' she explained with complete calm. ``You can't feel the wire, so you have to just guess, really. But it's an educated guess.'' Doctors at City of Hope Medical Center in Duarte, Calif., plan to operate Thursday to remove the cancer that has reappeared on Angel's lungs. Putting on a good show for the crowd of 2,000 packing the Mansfield gym gave Angel as much a psychological boost as a financial one _ perhaps more. Her grin was constant as she greeted friends, handed out autographs to a seemingly endless line of fans or hoisted her rambunctious son for a moment of parental discipline. ``You can't look too far ahead or you'll get all out of yourself,'' her husband explained after the show. ``I'm just enjoying life today _ that's life, you know? ``That's life,'' he said, glancing at his wife.
Donations can be addressed to the C.C.S.I. Angel Fund, Mansfield University, Mansfield, PA 16933.

DOC.HEAD: THE OSCARS 1990: And the Winner Is ...
Cost of Pictures Means Little to Academy Voters
DOC.TEXT: Here's proof that Academy voters pay little heed to what a movie costs: One of the contenders for best picture was produced for $3 million, another for $8 million. Contrast those figures with the $50 million spent on ``Batman,'' which earned one Academy Award nomination _ for art direction. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has a history of ignoring the cost factor in rewarding the best achievements of the film world. ``Marty,'' with a budget of $343,000, won as best picture of 1955, beating such big-budget films as ``Picnic,'' ``Mister Roberts'' and ``Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing.'' The $1-million ``Rocky'' knocked out its rivals in 1976. Other low-budget winners: ``Chariots of Fire,'' 1981, and ``Platoon,'' 1986. Oscar loves the Cinderella story, and this year it stars the Irish-made drama ``My Left Foot.'' ``We managed to get the picture made out of blind ignorance,'' admits producer Noel Pearson. ``We were two weeks into filming when we lined up the financing.'' He had been a close friend of the film's subject, hard-drinking Christy Brown, who became an acclaimed artist and writer in spite of the cerebral palsy that virtually immobilized him. Pearson started the film with his own money, plus 100,000 pounds sterling apiece from a friend and from Irish television. Everyone concerned with the film, including star Daniel Day-Lewis, worked for bare minimum. An art gallery scene was filmed in Pearson's own house. He borrowed costumes from his theatrical company. ``The film was made for just under $3 million, depending on the rate of exchange,'' said the producer. ``We managed to do that because everybody was committed. It was triumph of spirit over financing.'' The latest estimate for the worldwide gross of ``My Left Foot'' _ $50 million. ``Driving Miss Daisy'' also demonstrates that a film's budget is immaterial at awards time. It was budgeted at $8 million, amazing in view of the $20 million average for mainstream Hollywood films. How could Richard and Lili Zanuck produce such an inexpensive film? It is basically a two-character story and the two stars, Jessica Tandy and Morgan Freeman, are not high-priced. Dan Aykroyd is, but he took a lesser salary to play the straight role of the old woman's son. His change of character paid off with a nomination for supporting actor. Australian Bruce Beresford directed ``Driving Miss Daisy'' on locations in and around Atlanta and the Zanucks tightly budgeted the locations. The film, about the long relationship between a cranky widow and her patient chauffeur, has proved a huge hit, both in awards (nine Oscar nominations, the most this year), and at the box office ($60.3 million after 12 weeks in release). Two other nominees for best picture had average budgets and drew mixed reviews, but their off-beat subjects somehow connected with the moviegoing public. ``Field of Dreams'' invited audiences to swallow a whopper: that an Iowa farmer would build a baseball diamond in his cornfield where long-dead major leaguers would play. Many critics spurned the fantasy, but ticket buyers were attracted by its message of hope and the star power of Kevin Costner. Filmed for a reported $16 million, ``Field of Dreams'' amassed a gross of $63 million. ``Dead Poets Society'' looked like an impossible sell. The title seemed a turnoff. Although Robin Williams was a hot draw in the wake of ``Good Morning, Vietnam,'' he played a relatively brief role as the English teacher who inspires students at a 1960s boys school to think creatively. Most of the screen time in the $20 million film was devoted to the cast of unknown teen-agers. Reviewers objected to Williams as a latter-day Mr. Chips and found the tragic ending out of keeping with the rest of the film. But ``Dead Poets Society,'' directed by another Australian, Peter Weir, sold $94 million in theater tickets. ``Born on the Fourth of July'' proved that film audiences are still concerned with the consequences of the Vietnam war. The film was the result of a long collaboration between Oliver Stone, whose ``Platoon'' was drawn from his own experiences in the war, and Ron Kovic, wounded veteran and anti-war activist. Tom Cruise, one of today's biggest draws in films, and strong reviews helped contribute to the success of ``Born on the Fourth of July'' _ $59.7 million in 10 weeks. Stone directed the film in the Philippines, which doubled for both Vietnam and Mexico, and Dallas, which represented Kovic's home town of Massapequa, N.Y. Despite the complex production, which ranged from battlefields to national political conventions with 12,000 extras, the cost was reportedly $18 million.

DOC.HEAD: THE OSCARS 1990: And the Winner Is ...
Actress Competition: From Cantankerous Dowager to Smoldering Chanteuse
DOC.TEXT: There's a half-century gap in age between Jessica Tandy and Michelle Pfeiffer, who find themselves in reluctant competition for Hollywood's highest prize, the Academy Award. Their roles could scarcely be more different: Tandy as the cantankerous Southern dowager in ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Pfeiffer as the smoldering chanteuse in ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' They are generally considered the front-runners in the race for best actress. ``But I wish (the Academy Awards) ended with the nominations instead of making us adversaries,'' observes Tandy. ``When they pick the nominations, they pick the best of the crop. It's a pity they have to single them out as one winner and four losers.'' Also considered ``the best of the crop'' are Pauline Collins, the wry, rebellious housewife of ``Shirley Valentine''; Jessica Lange, the lawyer defending her father in ``Music Box,'' and Isabelle Adjani, Rodin's tragic model in ``Camille Claudel.'' Only Lange is a previous Oscar winner. She was chosen best supporting actress of 1982 for ``Tootsie.'' For Tandy, 80, an Academy Award would add to the many honors she has achieved since her Broadway debut in 1930. She has won three Tonys _ for ``A Streetcar Named Desire'' (as the original Blanche DuBois), ``The Gin Game'' and ``Foxfire,'' the latter two with husband Hume Cronyn. The TV version of ``Foxfire'' brought her an Emmy. The London-born actress had no qualms about undertaking the part of Miss Daisy: ``I like big roles. I like to be there all the time.'' At 31, Michelle Pfeiffer is cresting a career that might have been relegated to sexpot parts, such as her early carhop in ``Hollywood Knights.'' She proved herself as an actress in ``Scarface,'' ``The Witches of Eastwick,'' ``Married to the Mob'' and ``Dangerous Liaisons,'' for which she won a supporting actress nomination last year. ``The Fabulous Baker Boys'' was only a middling success, but Pfeiffer proved a striking presence from the moment she auditioned for lounge pianists Beau and Jeff Bridges with ``More Than You Know.'' Concerning her newfound success, the actress told an interviewer she knew it wouldn't last and she would again be offered boring parts. ``I've had enough of those to know that I never want to do it again. I mean, I'd rather go back to checking groceries.'' Collins had the advantage of playing her nominated role scores of time in the London and New York theater, though in a different form. ``Shirley Valentine'' as a play was a one-woman show. She won the Tony for her bravura performance. Born near Liverpool, Collins spent most of her career in the English theater and television. Americans know her as the downstairs maid in ``Upstairs, Downstairs.'' The film ``Shirley Valentine'' required her to swim nude in the Aegean with Tom Conti. No problem. ``It's not a big deal in Europe, nudity,'' said the actress, 49. ``My only qualms were that I wished I was younger and thinner. But I ain't.'' Lange applied her usual thoroughness as the Chicago lawyer in ``Music Box,'' studying court cases and reading briefs. ``Ultimately you can observe behavior, but when you get down to playing the role, it all has to come from the character,'' she observed. The actress has a reputation for willfulness on movie sets, but for ``Music Box'' she relied entirely on the director, Costa-Gavras. ``I had such respect and confidence in Costa that I didn't feel the need to get in there and make my opinions known,'' she said. Except for ``Driver,'' ``Quartet'' and the infamous ``Ishtar,'' Adjani has appeared exclusively in European films, and with great distinction. Her performance in Francois Truffaut's ``The Story of Adele H.'' brought her first Academy nomination for best actress in 1975. She has appeared in classics in the French theater as well as such films as ``Nosferatu: Le Vampire,'' ``Possession'' and ``Antoinetta.'' Though most filmgoers consider her French, Adjani was born in Bavaria in 1955, the daughter of a Turkish-Algerian father and a German mother. She spoke German until moving to Paris for her school years.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv

DOC.HEAD: Chevy Blazer: Add Two Doors and Join a Fast-Growing Market
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: It's not often that someone tampers with a winner, especially a winner backed by numbers. But the folks at Chevrolet, while seeing their 2-door S-10 Blazer chalk up record sales years in 1988 and 1989, had their eyes on other numbers, too: numbers that showed baby boomers reaching their 40s and 50s this decade, becoming the country's most affluent chunk of people and, most importantly, buying 4-door sport utility vehicles. Thus was born the 1991 Chevrolet S-10 4-Door Blazer, joining Chrysler's Jeep Cherokee, the Mitsubishi Montero, Toyota 4Runner, Nissan Pathfinder and Isuzu Trooper in the fast-growing 4-door sport utility field. Another sport utility, the Ford Explorer, is due out this year. The test S-10 4-Door Blazer readily showed why it's a worthy competitor. The Blazer was spunky, with its 4.3-liter, fuel-injected V-6 mated to a 4-speed automatic transmission. Even in tough, off-road conditions in 4-wheel-drive, the Blazer was powerful, developing up to 160 horsepower. I was impressed by its good traction _ mud, gravel and water flew as the big Uniroyal steel-belted radials bit into the earth, yet I felt perfectly at home, with no worries. Anti-lock brakes at all four wheels, a standard feature, made for solid stops, and visibility was tops, thanks to the vehicle's tall profile. The dashboard was especially high-tech for a truck. It was digital, with sloping bits of bright blue indicating the oil pressure and remaining fuel. Another nice feature was the styling of the rear seat-belt connectors. They were located in recessed, cut-out areas in the bench seat, which means a person can slide across easily _ no ouch from hitting stiff, protruding seat belt holders. The armrest between the front bucket seats was deep, offering substantial storage room. Up further, nearly under the dash, was the gearbox for switching from 2-wheel-drive to 4-wheel-drive. This shift-on-the-fly feature was easy, and an adjacent diagram of the Blazer's innards confirmed you had moved into 4-wheel-drive when the diagram's front two wheels lit up in bright orange. The gear shifter for the automatic transmission is located on the steering column. As in most sport utilities, there was considerable road noise, and there was a low rumble when the vehicle was in 4-wheel-drive. I also felt some jiggles while riding, and because the vehicle had a higher center of gravity than a car, it had some body roll and sway. The 4-Door Blazer is 6{ inches longer than its 2-door sibling and offers 25 percent more cargo space. A longer wheelbase adds 15 more inches of rear seat hip room, too, making the rear seat quite comfortable for even three adults. Chevrolet looks to produce up to 108,000 of the 4-Door Blazers in 1990; total Blazer production is 180,000, spokeswoman Mary McElyea said. Sales of the vehicles began in mid-January. Recent buyers of 2-door Blazers have had a median age of 38 and annual household income of $50,000, she said. Most had white-collar jobs, with 39 percent being college graduates. Seventy-three percent were men, and most were married. For one-third of the buyers, the Blazer was their first purchase of a new vehicle, she said. The 1991 S-10 4-Door Blazer is base priced at $16,905. That compares with the Jeep Cherokee 4-Door with six-cylinder engine and automatic transmission at $16,405, the Isuzu Trooper with V-6 engine and automatic transmission at $14,849, the 4-door Mitsubishi Montero with V-6 and automatic transmission at about $16,400, and $15,500 for a Toyota 4Runner with V-6 and automatic transmission. Consumer Reports magazine said 1983-88 model S-10 Blazers with two doors and V-6 engines ranged between average and much worse than average in reports of owner trouble. A Chevrolet spokesman responded that the plants producing Blazers are among the highest quality plants in the company.

DOC.HEAD: Shoshone Woman Had Life-Long Mission to Expose Indian Massacre
With BC-Bear River Massacre
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mae Timbimboo Parry will never forget nights as a child at her grandfather's feet. While winter winds moaned outside, she listened in horrified fascination as he spoke of the Bear River Massacre. Six decades later, Parry, the 70-year-old tribal secretary to the Northwestern Shoshone, traces her life-long mission to reveal the truth about the Army's slaughter of as many as 400 Indians in 1863 to the hours spent listening to Yeager Timbimboo, one of the few survivors. ``He was the best story teller. He believed in passing his stories on to his grandchildren, and he expected them to memorize all of them. He'd tell them over and over and over again,'' Parry said. ``We sat on the floor and grandpa sat on the chair. Every few minutes he would ask, `Are you awake? Are you awake?''' she recalled. ``And we would say yes. If one of us fell asleep, grandpa would just get up and leave. So we stayed awake. He wanted us to know who we were and where we came from.'' Yeager, 12 when the soldiers attacked, survived and lay still in the blood-spattered snow until a soldier realized he was alive. The soldier let him live. ``He must have been spared for this purpose. If my grandfather had died, it (the truth) may have been lost,'' said Parry, who has passed Yeager's stories on to her five children and more than a dozen grandchildren. The account of the attack by the man who launched it, Col. Patrick Connor, was one of pitched battle and classic military envelopment against well-armed and entrenched warriors, a view reflected _ to the abiding anger of the Northwestern Shoshone _ on a historical marker commemorating the ``Battle of Bear River.'' In the years after she first heard the Bear River stories, Parry became a repository for the tribe's oral history on the massacre. Eventually, she blended her grandfather's stories with others in what is considered by historians to be an authoritative 1976 monograph on file at the Utah State Historial Society in Salt Lake City. Parry acknowledges that her life's quest stems not only from the impact of her grandfather's stories, but also from the debt she feels to the hundreds of kinfolk in unmarked graves. On countless trips to the massacre site as a child and later an adult, she said, she felt an unseen presence. ``There have been many times as a family we have gone up there and walked,'' Parry said. ``We would talk about what happened. `This was where the soldiers came from; this is where somebody swam the river; this is where the lady dropped into the water and her baby drowned.' ``You really get a feeling that you're among them, and they are with you,'' she said. ``You just feel you are not alone.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Years of Gorbachev Lead to Freedoms But Food Shortages
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised the people a better deal and has brought them far greater freedom during five years in power, but the shortages and discomforts that make daily life a struggle have grown worse. ``The main thing is to make life better for people,'' he told a Western interviewer a few months after becoming Communist Party chief in March 1985. ``There is no goal more important to us.'' Five years later, the Soviet Union and its former Eastern European satellites enjoy a stunning degree of democracy. President Gorbachev has eased the fear of war. He has freed political prisoners from jails and psychiatric hospitals. Little remains of communism in the Communist Party's new program except the spirit and methodology. The party no longer enjoys unquestioned authority, but Gorbachev, a master of the apparatus through which he rose, is on the verge of gaining broad new powers in a strengthened presidency. In the matters of personal comfort most important to the average citizen, however, Gorbachev has not delivered. Food, housing and consumer goods are in even shorter supply than when he took command of the Kremlin. Nearly half the people questioned in a poll published this month said daily existence was harder than in 1985. ``Five years later, the drudgery of renewal continues and isn't yet close to its objectives,'' the pro-reform Moscow News commented. Gorbachev's economic program has been a series of mistakes and half-measures. He has delayed painful but critically needed steps like reform of a price structure that has no relation to costs and wastes resources. Only in recent weeks have legislators approved laws allowing farmers to lease land and individuals to own factories and other means of production. Even ardent supporters of those laws say they do not go far enough. Meat, butter and other foods are rationed in many places. In Moscow, a city of 9 million people, 1.25 million are on waiting lists for better apartments. Jewels of imperial architecture are crumbling. Repairmen and snowplows seem to have vanished. The leader knows it. In a speech to the Communist Party Central Committee last month, Gorbachev acknowledged ``further disruptions of the consumer market, a growth in shortages and lines, and a fall in the purchasing power of the ruble.'' ``We hoped to mount the peak of the crisis in 1989, but recent events have shown ... no change for the better,'' he said. On March 11, 1985, when Gorbachev followed the old, ailing leadership that had presided for two decades, there was much that needed fixing. His predecessors left a nation near bankruptcy, its infrastructure worn out and people dispirited. It had plenty of missiles, but no hot water in two-thirds of the rural hospitals. In the repressive Soviet Union of 1985, however, few dared openly say anything was wrong. Gorbachev changed that. Under the banner of glasnost, or openness, he has introduced greater official honesty and an improved intellectual life. Last year, he installed the beginnings of democracy with the first competitive elections and first working parliament in 70 years. In February, he won agreement from the Communist Party leadership for a multiparty system. Newspapers and television, which once provided endless paeans to the sacrifices of World War II soldiers and hero laborers, have been transformed. The Iron Curtain has disintegrated. Once forbidden books have been published, including Alexander Solzhenitsyn's ``The Gulag Archipelago.'' In 1990, it is expected that 8 million Soviet citizens will visit the outside world, where Gorbachev has had his greatest success and may be more popular than at home. Reformers across Eastern Europe attributed their courage to act, and their success, to the Soviet leader's promise of non-interference and his indications that the time for change had arrived. By setting the satellites free and agreeing with the United States to eliminate medium-range missiles, he helped lessen the danger of war. NATO has reduced border patrols, recognizing the diminishing risk of an attack by the Warsaw Pact. On the horizon are treaties on reducing long-range nuclear weapons by 50 percent and withdrawing hundreds of thousands of U.S. and Soviet soldiers from Central Europe. Even Soviet leaders more conservative than Gorbachev regard such achievements with pride. ``We have lifted the real threat of nuclear war,'' said Yegor K. Ligachev, the leading conservative in the Politburo, when asked by reporters March 4 to name the successes of Gorbachev's five years. ``We were on the brink,'' he said. ``One step more and we could have found ourselves in a nuclear catastrophe.'' Regional and ethnic tensions are another matter. Ethnic conflicts have taken 500 lives in two years and nationalism arising from the new political freedom threatens to dismember the Soviet Union. Lithuanians talk of declaring independence this year, perhaps as early as this month. Activist Kazimieras Uoka told the Lithuanian Review the Soviet Union was so sick that, ``by summer, the situation in Russia will be such that our secession will be hardly noticeable.'' Gorbachev responded to the threat of anarchy by seeking strong new presidential powers, including the right to declare war and suspend legislatures in the 15 republics. After local and regional elections March 4, he told reporters the new powers were necessary because ``stability and order'' were breaking down. He said disintegration of the Soviet Union would be a greater upheaval than China's Cultural Revolution of a generation ago. Parliament member Yuri Afanasiev, who is forming a more radical reformist opposition to Gorbachev, said the Soviet leader's problem is a shortage of public trust, not of power. ``Nobody listens,'' Afanasiev said in a television interview. He said Gorbachev talks about the need to transform a centralized empire into a voluntary union of independent nations, but has not acted on it. Misgivings are increased by the fact that Gorbachev has promised legal guarantees of human rights, limits on Communist Party power and fully competitive democracy for nearly two years, but has not translated the pledges into law. Many citizens were shocked by his televised, finger-wagging tirade against radical reformers who denounced his proposed stronger presidency as dangerously close to dictatorship. Whatever his powers, the hardest part of Gorbachev's job lies ahead. Coal miners frustrated by miserable living conditions are talking of renewing their strike when the weather warms. Hoarding increases. Citizens fear civil violence and ethnic attack. ``People are tired,'' Gorbachev told reporters on election day. ``People can see how difficult it is to get the good things of life, and how much more difficult it is under confrontation and the arms race. Problems of housing, health care and the environment need to be solved.''

DOC.HEAD: Major Events in Gorbachev's Life
With Gorbachev-Five Years
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of major events in the life of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev: March 2, 1931 _ Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev is born in Privolnoye, a town in the Stavropol region of southern Russia. 1950 _ Enters Moscow State University to study law. 1952 _ Becomes a full member of the Communist Party and active its youth organization, Komsomol. 1954 _ Marries fellow student Raisa Maximovna Titorenko. 1955 _ Returns to Stavropol and begins full-time work for Komsomol. 1960 _ Becomes first secretary of Stavropol regional Komsomol. 1966 _ Named to lead the party organization in Stavropol. 1969 _ Elevated to full membership in national Communist Party Central Committee. 1971 _ Chosen as deputy of the Supreme Soviet. 1978 _ Becomes the Central Committee secretary in charge of agriculture and moves to Moscow. 1979 _ Made a candidate, or non-voting, member of the ruling Politburo, led by President Leonid I. Brezhnev. 1980 _ Elevated to full membership in Politburo. March 11, 1985 _ Becomes general secretary of the Communist Party after death of Konstantin U. Chernenko. November 1985 _ Holds first summit, in Geneva, with President Ronald Reagan. Four full summits follow over the next five years. 1986 _ Begins his reform program in earnest with the catchwords ``glasnost,'' meaning openness and self-criticism, and ``perestroika,'' the Russian word for restructuring. Releases Andrei D. Sakharov from internal exile. 1987 _ He and Reagan sign a treaty to eliminate both sides' medium-range nuclear weapons. 1988 _ Calls the first Communist Party conference since the days of Josef Stalin to press for greater reform. Dissolves the Supreme Soviet, to be replaced by the Congress of People's Deputies and a smaller full-time legislature, the new Supreme Soviet. 1989 _ Withdraws Soviet troops from Afghanistan and presides over Congress of People's Deputies that elects him president. 1990 _ Ends Communist Party monopoly on political power and moves to create a stronger presidency.

For Release Sunday March 11, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Accomplishments and Failures in Five Years
With BC-Gorbachev-Five Years
DOC.TEXT: Here is a review of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's record since becoming Soviet leader on March 11, 1985: FOREIGN POLICY _ Declared policy of non-intervention in Eastern Europe, permitting a wave of revolutions that deposed old-style Communist regimes, broke down the Berlin Wall and set the stage for German reunification. _ Dramatically reduced fears of a nuclear war or Soviet attacks on Western Europe or China. _ Cut the defense budget and declared a unilateral reduction in forces of 500,000 soldiers and 10,000 tanks. _ Informally agreed with United States on troop reductions in Central Europe. _ Agreed with the United States to destroy medium-range missiles and try for a second treaty in 1990 reducing long-range nuclear weapons by 50 percent. _ Brought home the 115,000 Soviet soldiers in Afghanistan. _ Changed foreign policy from a struggle with capitalist countries to cooperation with them in fulfilling such ``universal human values'' as the desire for peace and a better life. DEMOCRATIZATION _ Introduced competitive elections in 1989, won agreement from the Communist Party leadership to end its constitutional monopoly on power and vested legislative authority in a new parliament. _ Proposed broad new presidential powers, including the right to suspend the legislatures of republics. _ Promised legal guarantees of a freer press, freedom of assembly, freedom of religion and the right to a fair trial. _ Released hundreds of political prisoners and ended persecution for political views. _ Virtually opened the borders, but has not produced a promised law on free exit and entry. ECONOMIC POLICY _ Failed to improve the daily life of ordinary Soviets, who face inflation, rationing and worse shortages than before. Delayed needed reform of prices that have have no relation to costs and waste scarce resources. _ Won Communist Party leadership's acceptance of private ownership of factories. _ Obtained parliamentary approval of leasing land to individuals, with the right of inheritance, but refused to legalize private ownership of land. _ Made foreign investment easier through joint ventures. _ Legalized small private business cooperatives, but did not guarantee them adequate legal sources of supplies. _ Revealed the long-secret Soviet budget deficit, which this year reached 90 billion rubles, $150 billion at the official rate of exchange. DOMESTIC POLICY _ Permitted independence movements to develop in the Baltics and the Caucasus. _ Sent tens of thousands of Soviet soldiers on peacekeeping duties in restive republics, but could not halt ethnic and nationalist conflicts in which 500 people died in the past two years. _ Adopted the cause of environmentalists, but succeeded in doing little to improve polluted air, water and land. _ Promised a dramatic increase in housing, but has achieved no visible results. _ Restricted production of alcoholic beverages to reduce alcoholism, at a cost to the treasury of billions of rubles. Campaign succeeded in toughening public attitude toward drunkenness.
