DOC.HEAD: Study Says Red Tape Hinders Medicaid Payments to AIDS Patients
DOC.TEXT: Federal law lets Medicaid pay for many out-of-hospital services for AIDS patients, but only six state Medicaid agencies are doing so, and red tape is to blame, the Rand Corp. says. Medicaid programs in California, Hawaii, New Mexico, New Jersey, Ohio and South Carolina help pay for AIDS patients to obtain transportation as well as services from homemakers, home health assistants and adult day care centers. Such services generally are less expensive and more convenient than hospitalization. But for a state Medicaid agency to pay for these services, it must obtain a waiver under a 1985 federal law. Such waivers exempt the agencies from the federal requirement that Medicaid offer the same services to all patients. A study by the Rand Corp., a private non-profit think tank, concluded that most state Medicaid agencies fail to take advantage of the federal law because of complicated application and administrative requirements for getting waivers from the Health Care Financing Administration. HCFA, which sponsored the Rand study, should relax federal controls to help make the program more attractive to state Medicaid agencies, the study said.
DOC.HEAD: Researcher: Chili Just Might Be Addictive
DOC.TEXT: A university scientist said he may have discovered proof of what New Mexicans have joked about for years _ that chili is addictive. ``It's not like a heroin addiction,'' said Frank Etscorn, an experimental psychologist at New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology in Socorro. The key to his theory is capsaicin, the substance that fuels chili's eye-watering pungency, Etscorn said recently. The capsaicin causes the body to release endorphins, natural painkillers that race for receptors in the brain, he said. ``We need a fix of red or green with a side order of endorphins,'' said Etscorn. ``We get slightly strung out on endorphins, but it's no big deal.'' As a natural substance, endorphins are not truly addictive despite being more potent than morphine, Etscorn told participants at the annual New Mexico Chile Conference. Many stimuli ranging from acupuncture to smashing a thumb with a hammer trigger endorphins, he said. Etscorn, a specialist in addiction, said he cooks spicy dishes and often wondered why people craved painful foods. About two years ago he began a research project with his students. Etscorn used a drug called naloxone, used to counteract heroin overdoses. The drug blocks receptors that respond to heroin. Those are the same receptors stimulated by endorphins, Etscorn said. For one experiment, Etscorn gave a research subject five jalapenos. ``It worked. Sweat was pouring off his nose, off his chin. His eyes were runny. His nose was runny. And I think there was smoke coming out of his ears,'' he said. ``We asked him, `Tell us when the pain is starting to subside.''' When the pain began to fade, the subject was given a naloxone injection. The pain increased as the endorphins were shut out, Etscorn said. Etscorn said he plans further research, although detailed studies probably would use the active ingredient capsaicin rather than the whole chili.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used f0125, PM-SASA-First Gibraltar, transmitted March 7 under a San Antonio dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press, in a story March 7 about First Gibraltar Bank's bid to acquire San Antonio Savings Association, erroneously reported the bank's assets and net income for the first nine months of 1989. First Gibraltar had $9.7 billion in assets and reported $112 million in net income for the period ending Sept. 30, 1989, the company said.

After two years on the auction block, MGM-UA Communications said it had accepted a $1.2 billion buyout offer by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications Corp. Parretti also will take over $400 million in junk bond debt as part of the deal disclosed Wednesday, which may be the final scene of a long-running drama in which a virtual cast of thousands considered buying all or part of MGM-UA. A $1.5 billion buyout of MGM was aborted last year when the suitor, Australia's Qintex Group, missed a $50 million down payment.

American workers' productivity in the non-farm portion of the nation's economy last year posted its worst performance since 1982, improving only 0.9 percent, the government said. Meanwhile, hourly labor costs _ a major inflation measure for businesses _ escalated significantly, jumping by 5.4 percent, the Labor Department said Wednesday. That increase, up from 4.7 percent in 1988, was the biggest rise in hourly labor costs since the 1981-82 recession.

Bank profits tumbled 34 percent in 1989, as second-half earnings were depressed by mounting real estate woes in the Northeast and problem loans to Third World countries, the government reported. The nation's commercial banks earned $16.3 billion, down from a record $24.8 billion in 1988, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Wednesday. Earnings fell dramatically to a weak $2 billion in the final six months of 1989 after totaling $14.3 billion in the January-June period, the best ever for six months.

The nation's Big Three automakers are reviewing their estimates for 1990 sales amid signs that sales early this year have been stronger than they had expected. ``I think that as the year begins to unfold, that the more optimistic forecast of more like 14.5 million cars and trucks is more likely,'' Chrysler Corp. Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald said in an interview Tuesday. Late last year, Chrysler was the most pessimistic of the Big Three companies, forecasting car and truck sales industrywide of 14.2 million for 1990, down from 14.85 million in 1989.

AT&T is negotiating to issue credit cards that would combine its current telephone charge cards with MasterCard and Visa bank cards, said industry sources and a company involved in the negotiations. Under the plan, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. would issue so-called affinity credit cards through a Georgia bank to a group of its existing phone card holders. The cards could be used to charge AT&T long-distance calls as well as the goods and services traditionally purchased with bank cards. US Sprint,in December began issuing a Sprint Visa Card that combines the features of its phone charge card with those of the bank card.

One of the nation's most successful computer software designers cautioned Congress against passing laws that would overprotect ``intellectual property'' by extending copyright protection to ideas. ``It's the nature of software for ideas to slosh and flow back and forth between competitors, companies and industries,'' Mitchell D. Kapor told a House subcommittee Wednesday. Kapor founded Lotus Development Corp., maker of the 1-2-3 spreadsheet software. The subcomittee is considering a revision of laws governing intellectual property _ a phrase covering copyrights, patents and trade secrets.

Health Secretary Louis Sullivan said the government will propose a more informative food-labeling system to replace the ``Tower of Babel'' that shoppers now encounter. The proposed changes would require disclosure of the fat, fiber and cholesterol content of nearly all packaged foods and require that they meet standardized definitions to be labelled ``low fat'' or ``high fiber.'' Sullivan said Wednesday the Food and Drug Administration will propose a three-phase change in food-labeling regulations. Final regulations would be in place sometime in 1991, he said.

The House sustained President Bush's veto of a bill to have the government intervene in the year-old Eastern Airlines dispute, dealing a blow to organized labor and Democratic leaders. The vote of 261-160 to override the president's veto was short of the two-thirds majority needed. Also Wednesday, the Justice Department said it has no objections to Eastern's proposed sale of its prized Latin American routes to rival American Airlines.

A federal jury decided that American Tobacco Co. should not be held liable for the death of a lung cancer patient, rejecting claims that the company failed to warn the public about the dangers of cigarette smoking. The six-member jury deliberated about two hours before returning its verdict Wednesday, culminating a three week trial. Lawyers representing the plaintiff, the cancer victim's widow, said they would consider an appeal.

Stock prices posted spotty losses Wednesday after the market ran into afternoon selling. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up more than 8 points at midmorning, closed with a 7.21 loss at 2,669.59. Bond prices declined as the rally in the dollar stalled and the currency ended mixed in foreign exchange. Gold prices fell. Frozen orange juice futures climbed, pork bellies rose the daily limit, energy and gold prices tumbled and grains were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Plans To Issue Credit Cards Combined With Phone-Charge Cards
DOC.TEXT: AT&T plans to issue credit cards that would allow users to charge phone calls as well as the traditional items paid for with Visa and MasterCard, industry sources and a company involved in the negotiations say. Under the plan, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. would issue so-called ``affinity'' Visa and MasterCards through a Georgia bank to a group of its existing phone card holders. With 40 million in circulation, the AT&T phone cards are the most widely held charge cards in the nation and give the company a huge roster of potential customers for the new cards. US Sprint, the nation's third-largest long-distance phone company, in December began issuing a Sprint Visa Card that combines the features of its phone charge card with those of the bank card. AT&T has been in negotiations with Synovus Financial Corp., a bank holding company based in Columbus, Ga., to issue the credit cards, Synovus said. Total System Services Inc., a Columbus-based credit card service company controlled by Synovus, would process the transactions from the AT&T cards under the plan, TSS said. TSS is the nation's second-largest credit card transaction processing company. AT&T spokesman Bruce Reid on Wednesday confirmed the negotiations. ``We're in a highly competitive marketplace and looking at a number of ways of enhancing the AT&T credit card,'' he said. The card competes with similar cards issued by Sprint and MCI Communications Corp., the second-largest long-distance phone company. Reid also confirmed reports that AT&T hired several credit card experts in recent months. He declined to comment further on AT&T's plans. Neither MasterCard nor Visa U.S.A. Inc. would discuss the AT&T proposal. According to The Wall Street Journal, AT&T will announce its credit card plans in an advertising campaign starting March 26. The Journal said AT&T would waive the card's annual fee for at least the first year and offer a lower annual interest rate than most other bank cards, around 14 percent or 15 percent. The current long-distance phone cards are not revolving credit accounts like MasterCard or Visa, meaning balances must be paid in full each month. Several industry analysts said they believed AT&T at one time considered issuing its own credit card to compete with MasterCard and Visa. AT&T would not comment on the speculation. Fierce competition in the credit-card industry may have dissuaded AT&T from such a plan, said Robert Morris III of Goldman, Sachs & Co. Sears, Roebuck and Co.'s Discover Card was the last separate national card to break into the industry and the retailer endured several years of steep losses before turning the operation around. American Express began offering its Optima revolving charge card to holders of its regular credit cards several years ago. Morris said AT&T evidently believes it can increase the use of its phone network through the new credit cards. In addition, the company would get a share of the interest and fees charged to cardholders. Sprint said it launched its Visa card, in conjunction with State Street Bank and Trust Co. in Boston, to help promote use of its phone network. ``It was a way of targeting high-travel users who spend a lot on telecommunications,'' said Hal Poel, Sprint's director of card marketing. With the Sprint Visa, phone calls charged on the card appear on a customer's monthly Visa bill and can be charged to the Visa account. MCI has no plans to issue affinity credit cards, said spokesman John Houser. ``There seems to be enough players in there right now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: More Golden Arches for Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Glasnost and perestroika translate into burgers and fries for the McDonald's Corp., which plans to further expand its fast-food empire in Eastern Europe. ``We've been in Eastern Europe, so we're not reacting to recent political developments there,'' McDonald's spokesman Chuck Ebeling said Wednesday. ``We've been planning for this area for years.'' But he added: ``Political developments there open up promising aspects for us.'' The suburban Oak Brook-based company opened restaurants in Hungary and Yugoslavia in 1988, and is expanding its presence in both countries, Ebeling said. McDonald's also is eyeing East Germany and Czechoslovakia, while Poland is in its ``long-term plans,'' he said. ``East Germany and Czechoslovakia are likely for the next step in development, but not necessarily this year,'' he said. Michael Kennedy, an IDS Financial Services analyst specializing in the restaurant business, believes if anybody can succeed in Eastern Europe, McDonald's can. ``I'm always in awe of McDonald's management. They are able to do things other people say you can't do,'' Kennedy said. ``They are awfully bright and they see opportunities others don't.'' Innovation also has played a role. For example, to ensure french-fry supplies for their new Moscow restaurant, McDonald's took seedlings for a new strain of potatoes from Holland years ago and planted them in Russia. The restaurants in Hungary and Yugoslavia, as well as the first Soviet McDonald's, which opened Jan. 31 in Moscow, have been doing well. ``There's lots of pent-up demand for consumer goods,'' Ebeling said. ``McDonald's is a welcomed addition, something not otherwise available.'' In Eastern Europe, Ebeling said, ``It's pretty much the same menu _ hamburgers, french fries, Coke and milkshakes. It's simpler than the U.S. menu. Breakfast is not served in Eastern Europe, and there's not the same range of products.'' Still, some U.S. investors have been leery of the risk in doing business in Eastern Europe. ``Wall Street wants overnight success,'' Kennedy said. ``They want to know, `Why does it take three or four years for a profit?' ``McDonald's invested $50 million in Russia and only has one store, but five years from now, they will have a major position, and others will be left out in the cold,'' Kennedy said. ``There are 350 million people in Eastern Europe, and your eyes get big when you look at the consumer market over there,'' he said. ``But these people don't have any middle-class spending power and it will be a long, long time until anything of significance comes out of it.''

DOC.HEAD: News and Sing-Alongs: Investors Plan Radio Network for Children
DOC.TEXT: Investors have announced plans for a radio network of satellite-delivered programs appealing to children under 12 with music, jokes, stories, sing-alongs and the news. Orlando station WPRD-AM, which now airs big-band music, will switch to a round-the-clock format for children at the end of this month, becoming the flagship station for the Kids' Choice Broadcasting Network. ``This is more than a commercial endeavor,'' the network's president, Norman Wain, said. ``We're doing this because we really think we can make a contribution to stimulating children's imaginations, and imagination is the first step to literacy.'' Investors are seeking to raise $3 million to $4 million to launch the 24-hour network and hope to have 100 subscriber stations in the nation's top 20 markets by next year. They have an impressive list of personalities on an advisory board, including singers Judy Collins, Harry Belafonte and Pete Seeger; children's television host Fred Rogers; and actors Marlo Thomas and Mike Farrell. The format is based on children's programming at KPAL in Little Rock, Ark., which was on the air from 1985 to 1988 and won a number of national awards. A staff of 10 will play music, tell jokes and stories, preside over sing-alongs and present the news. It will feature original music by Peter Yarrow of the folk trio Peter, Paul and Mary, and children's music by national and international artists familiar to children but largely unknown to most adults _ including Raffi, Rosenschontz, Jonathan Sprout, Peter Alsop and Bill Harley. Each part of the day will be geared toward a different age group. The approach is healthy, wholesome and educational, said Katherine Henslee, vice president of programming. ``If you want them to listen, it has to be entertaining,'' she said. ``Children also want to learn. They want information, so it's very informative through the various elements of each show.'' Ms. Henslee, a former educator, and other officials of the proposed network were behind the KPAL programming. On WPRD, ``Satellite Sam'' Cooper, 23, will be the host between the hours of 6 a.m. and 10 a.m., with music, humor and news from the Weekly Reader, a children's publication. A show designed for kids 5 and younger from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. will feature educational music about colors, shapes and numbers. The host will be Susan Pines, 22. From 2 p.m. to 6 p.m., ``Curbside Carnival'' will have travel, stories and songs about other states, lands and languages by children's musicians. Later programs will have current music for older children, jokes, nighttime stories and variety shows. The radio personalities ``are open and like children,'' Ms. Henslee said. ``Their voices are warm. It's real upbeat.'' The station will offer a toll-free telephone number so children can call during the daily talk programs and ask questions. ``I think it's going to be an absolute sensation because it's filling a need,'' said Wain, a partner in Metroplex Communications, which owns WPRD in Orlando. ``Kids under 12 are an unserved audience.''

DOC.HEAD: Pathe's Purchase of MGM-UA Marks Step in Hollywood Globalization
DOC.TEXT: The proposed $1.2 billion buyout of MGM-UA Communications Co. by European film conglomerate Pathe Communications Corp. represents a bold step in the increasing globalization of Hollywood. With overseas markets growing at an explosive pace, the merger, if completed, will yield a balanced enterprise combining MGM-UA's local film and television production with Pathe's worldwide distribution, executives say. MGM-UA said Wednesday it had accepted the buyout offer by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe, which controls more than 1,000 theaters in five countries. The deal concludes a drama in which an array of individuals and companies _ from Ted Turner to the Walt Disney Co. _ considered buying all or part of the legendary studio. ``The thing that we're just excited about is the total company,'' MGM-UA Chairman Jeffrey C. Barbakow said in an interview. ``We believe that we're now ready to become real players in Hollywood. ``With this, we've increased our library, we have what I believe is the biggest number of screens in Europe, a studio facility in Rome, a laboratory in Paris, a couple of thousand hours of newsreels, new distribution channels, (Pathe's) Cannon films,'' he said. Barbakow's assessment was shared by Parretti, Pathe's president and chief executive. ``MGM-UA's unique library and strong distribution capabilities complement Pathe's existing business worldwide,'' Parretti said in a statement. ``We are confident the transaction will result in a strong, dual company structure which will be strongly competitive.'' Last year, foreign revenue constituted about 38 percent of Hollywood revenue, up from 30 percent in 1980, according to the Motion Picture Association of America. ``Fatal Attraction'' grossed $189 million overseas, more than the $157 million it collected domestically. Likewise, ``Rain Man'' netted $233 million outside North America, compared to $170 million inside. The MGM-UA-Pathe deal is the latest prompted by an insatiable worldwide demand for American entertainment. Japan's Sony Corp. acquired Columbia Pictures last year, Australia's News Corp. owns Fox, and the CBS, RCA and A&M record labels are owned by Japanese, West German and Dutch companies, respectively. England's Television South PLC owns television's MTM Productions. MGM-UA has profitable TV and home video divisions and a film distribution system in place. It has been trying to start producing films again recently after a two-year fallow period while its controlling shareholder, Beverly Hills billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, sought a buyer. The marriage with Pathe, though, may be one of the most unusual in Hollywood history. The Cannon Releasing Group, which Pathe owns, is a leading purveyor of exploitation films, with upcoming releases including ``American Ninja 4,'' ``Lambada: The Movie,'' ``Keaton's Cop'' with Lee Majors and Don Rickles, ``Death Warrant'' and ``Stranglehold: Delta Force II.'' MGM-UA, on the other hand, is one of Hollywood's jewels, with its MGM and United Artists banners responsible for everything from the 1939 Judy Garland classic ``The Wizard of Oz'' to the 1988 Academy Award-winning ``Rain Man.'' Mindful of how a $1.5 billion buyout of MGM was aborted last year when Australia's Qintex Group missed a $50 million down payment, Barbakow said MGM already had commitments from Pathe worth $100 million to distribute Pathe movies. The deal also requires Parretti to come up with $200 million in four monthly deposits of $50 million each, with the first one due Friday, to be placed in an escrow account. ``If for whatever reason this doesn't close, then we have the money for damages,'' Barbakow said. He said he was confident Parretti could line up financing for the deal, but declined to say where. Parretti was traveling Wednesday and could not be reached for comment. In the past, he has financed deals with help from Credit Lyonnais Group, the international financial giant. Kerkorian was expected to retain the right to use MGM-UA's familiar lion logo for his airline and theme park ventures under the separate MGM Grand company, but his spokeswoman Mary Hardy could not immediately confirm that. There were reports, too, that the studio would change its name, but there was no announcement of what the new name might be. MGM-UA Communications has lost money in four of the last five years. The studio's only major release of 1990, ``Stanley & Iris,'' with Jane Fonda and Robert De Niro, was a commercial failure. Pathe, which became a strong U.S. presence following Parretti's purchase of Cannon Group in 1987, produces and distributes movies worldwide. It has film production facilities in Italy, a processing lab in France, and the rights to 500 movies and 2,000 newsreels.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound, Dollar Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The main index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dropped sharply and then recovered dramatically today for its first gain this week, while the dollar rose marginally against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 328.55 points, or 0.98 percent, closing at 33,690.89. The index, which shed 428.74 points Wednesday, briefly fell below the 33,000-point mark because of arbitrage trading, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. However, the index soon reversed its downward direction and recouped more than 860 points by the end of morning trading. The index stayed higher as market players expected little arbitrage selling in the afternoon, although some nervousness remained in the market, dealers said. Institutional investors' buying in the afternoon session also helped the Nikkei maintain its gains, they said. Today's trading was moderate, with an estimated 600 million shares traded on the market's first section. ``We had expected massive arbitrage selling, because today is the last day for trading future issues that are due in March,'' Nomura said. Arbitrage trading is a technique for making profits from price differences between the spot and the futures markets. ``But the index kept coming back even with frequent arbitrage selling,'' he said. ``The market seems to have hit its bottom.'' Analysts have blamed computer-aided large-scale arbitrage trading in part for recent market losses in Tokyo. So far this year, the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index has lost 5,224.89 points, or 13.4 percent. Yasuda Trust and Banking Co. and the department store Mitsukoshi joined other major companies that have canceled or postponed new equity issues because of the market's weakness, Japanese news reports said Thursday. On the foreign currency market, the dollar closed at 150.83 yen, up 0.08 yen from Wednesday's close of 150.75 yen. It opened lower at 150.25 yen and gradually rose back while ranging between 149.85 and 150.85 yen. The U.S. currency fell against the yen in the morning session after active intervention by the Bank of Japan, but rose back in the afternoon as participants began selling the yen to make up their short, or oversold, dollar positions, traders said. ``I assume quite a few market players attempted to buy the dollar because of their short dollar positions in the last couple of days,'' said Yoshitsugu Hanada, a trader with Mitsui Bank. The dollar briefly reached 151 yen Monday, but fell bellow 150 yen the following day after coordinated intervention by members of the Group of Seven nations, including the United States, Japan and West Germany. In early trading today, many market players avoided dollar-buying because of continuing dollar-selling by the Bank of Japan, Hanada said. The central bank, which does not comment officially on its market interventions, was believed to have sold about $800 million today in an effort to support the yen, traders said. The price of benchmark 10-year No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.66 points, marginally lower than the previous day's close of 86.67. The bond's yield was 7.205 percent, up from Wednesday's close of 7.20 percent. Although the bond price was higher earlier in the day, it gradually fell as the yen began to weaken against the dollar, dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most other major foreign currencies in light, nervous European trading today. Gold prices were higher. Dealers said trading was light because market makers were wary of more central bank interventions. Several central banks intervened earlier in the week to stem the currency's strong rise. ``The market is quiet. We're unsure whether or not the Deutsche Bundesbank will step in again,'' said a trader at a large European bank in Frankfurt. Traders said the fundamental reasons behind the dollar's strength have not changed, with continued weakness in the Japanese yen and the West German mark. ``The trend is bullish, but the banks are keeping it in check,'' said a Milan trader. Dealers said they expected subdued trading until Friday when the U.S. unemployment figures are due. Traders said the data could show a slowdown in the U.S. economy. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.08 yen to a closing 150.83 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 150.95 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.7006 West German marks, down from 1.7075; 1.5027 Swiss francs, down from 1.5075; 5.7485 French francs, down from 5.7665; 1.9130 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9155; 1,254.37 Italian lire, down from 1,259.00; and 1.1818 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1853. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6490, compared with $1.6388 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $401.50 a troy ounce, up from $399.25 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $401.40. In Zurich, the bid price was $401.30, up from $400.75 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 86 cents to close at a bid $402.04. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.14 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $5.13.

DOC.HEAD: London Share Prices Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were higher at midday Thursday, helped by scattered buying by institutions and a shortage of stock. Another round of good earnings reports helped and Tokyo's rise earlier in the day also helped boost the market, dealers said. But because volume remained thin, traders said London would remain vulnerable to the slightest bad news and to profit-taking. ``I think it's going to top out,'' said a trader at a major British brokerage firm. ``A lot of what we've seen is technical.'' At about noon London time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was 18.7 points, or 0.8 percent, higher at 2,249.2. Volume came to 247.9 million shares at midday, compared with 193.6 million shares at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Hilton Takes Self Off The Market
DOC.TEXT: Disappointingly low bids caused Hilton Hotels Corp. to take down its ``For Sale'' sign. The hotel-casino concern's board of directors agreed to pull the company off the auction block after rejecting two bids, company chairman Barron Hilton said Wednesday. The company went up for sale last year after a dispute over founder Conrad Hilton's estate was settled, the chairman said. ``We have been considering a sale of the company, among other alternatives, since last summer,'' Hilton said in a statement issued late Wednesday after a New York board meeting. ``At the time we began the exploration process, the world economy, the market for acquisition financing and the investment climate for real estate and hotels were each far stronger than they are today,'' Hilton said. ``The significant adverse developments in each of these areas were reflected in the acquisition proposals we received.'' JMB Realty, a privately held Chicago group, and billionaire Los Angeles investor Marvin Davis were among those interested in the hotel-casino company. Davis and various Asian bidders were believed to have dropped out, but JMB was reported in the bidding as late as Wednesday. Hilton said it will concentrate on new projects: a hotel-casino in Laughlin, Nev., several new Hilton Suites hotels, and new properties in London, Hong Kong, Monte Carlo, Dublin and Cancun, Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Cutting About 20 Percent of Investment Bankers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.'s plan for 2,000 layoffs this month, including about 20 percent of its investment banking corps, is a speeded-up version of the painful retraction taking place on Wall Street, analysts say. Shearson said Wednesday that the firings will include about 200 employees in its prominent investment banking division who will be gone from the firm by the end of next week. Analysts predict that Shearson, engulfed in turmoil recently as American Express Co. seized full control of its struggling securities unit, could lay off another 3,000 people in the coming months. Because American Express wants to turn Shearson around fast, analysts said they expect cuts to occur quickly and in bulk. ``The last thing you want is uncertainty out there,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an industry analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``As soon as they identify a division or business they don't want to be in I don't see why they wouldn't move quickly to get out.'' Eckenfelder and other analysts estimate that Shearson will take a one-time charge of $450 million to $500 million against quarterly earnings to cover the cuts and reserves against bad loans. The investment banking layoffs are deeper than had been expected. Shearson officials said 120 professionals _ 80 in corporate finance and 40 in public finance _ as well as 70 support staff would be laid off. The division employs about 750 professionals out of 1,100 workers overall. Michael Madden, Shearson's co-director of investment banking, said the cuts are taking place in all areas of the department, which handles a variety of corporate financing and advising activities, but that Shearson did not plan to quit any particular field. ``In this climate with business in many specific areas and across the board down it's appropriate to downsize and let your best people remain,'' he said. ``We're trying to get as lean as we can so that in the new environment we can get as profitable as we can.'' Although Shearson had planned to cut investment banking jobs, the number grew after American Express took greater control over the firm, Madden said. Wall Street is contractacting in part because of a slowdown since the 1987 stock market crash and a decline in mergers and acquisitions because of a sharp decline in the junk bond market. The industry has shrunk by more than 40,000 jobs overall since the crash, including more than 5,000 in the collapse of onetime powerhouse Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. last month. According to Securities Data Co., Shearson announced just five acquisition deals worth $5.6 billion from Jan. 1 through Tuesday, compared to 19 deals worth $20.2 billion for the same 1989 period and 33 deals worth $38.2 billion in 1988. Industrywide, the total value of deals announced was down 51 percent from last year, Newark, N.J.-based Securities Data said. In a reflection of the slow times, Shearson is number one in the market so far this year. Investment banking layoffs had been planned and some had occurred at Shearson before late January, when American Express ousted chairman Peter A. Cohen and began taking a larger role in the firm's affairs. Shearson's new chairman, Howard L. Clark Jr., is a former American Express executive. He and top executives are deciding what areas to cut. American Express this week said it was buying back all remaining shares of Shearson that it does not own, boosting its stake from 61 percent. The company also is injecting $1 billion in new capital to shore up Shearson's finances. Shearson reportedly had planned gradual cuts in investment banking of 10 percent to 20 percent by May, allowing laid-off workers time to search for new jobs. But the new layoffs were expected to take effect immediately. Some employees in other departments who were told Wednesday they were losing their jobs were given until Friday to pack their belongings, and personnel department staff placed boxes outside of offices to help them. Shearson is hampered by overcapacity from its 1988 acquisition of E.F. Hutton & Co., outstanding temporary loans that are in peril because of the junk bond market's collapse and a $1.1 billion real estate loans portfolio in a shaky market.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Watches Dollar Plunge Against Mark in Oct.-Jan. Period
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The government allowed the dollar to plunge against the West German mark from October through January and stepped in only modestly to stem its rise against the Japanese yen, the Federal Reserve reported. The quarterly foreign-exchange report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed the Fed and the Treasury spent just $750 million in the three months ended Jan. 31, all of it to buy Japanese yen. The relatively small purchases compared with record interventions during the previous two reporting periods. The government sold a record $11.92 billion in dollars during the three months ended July 31 and $5.871 billion in the following three-month period. The government purchased both yen and West German marks during the periods. What highlighted the most recent period was ``a divergence of the dollar against the various currencies,'' said Sam Y. Cross, a New York Fed executive vice president who presented the report at a news conference Wednesday. The dollar gained 1 percent against the yen but plunged 8.5 percent against the mark. The dollar also lost more than 5 percent against the British pound and the Swiss franc during the three-month period. But rather than characterize the dollar as weak against the mark, Cross noted the mark ``rose against all currencies in part for reasons affecting that currency alone, so we didn't see a need to intervene to resist that rise.'' The opening of the border between East and West Germany in early November unleashed a swell of positive sentiment toward the mark, on speculation that new immigrants would stimulate domestic demand and that liberalization presented greatly expanded business opportunities, the Fed said. ``We were hearing in the market that there was an attraction to investments in Germany and (capital) movements into the mark,'' Cross said. But enthusiasm surrounding the West German currency battered the dollar, which fell from 1.8415 marks at the beginning of November to roughly 1.6630 marks in early January, its low for the period. It has since recovered to the 1.7000-mark level. The Japanese yen, however, was buffeted by uncertainty surrounding parliamentary elections and rumors of scandals involving members of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. The dollar reached its low against the Japanese currency just after Christmas at 141.70 yen but closed the period higher at 144.45 yen. Since then the dollar has continued to climb and is currently trading at about 150 yen. The Fed intervened on only five occasions in coordination with the Bank of Japan. The bulk of the intervention, $600 million, occurred during three days in early January. Cross said the dollar's downward trend against most key currencies was consistent with recent policy of the Group of Seven industrial nations. At their September meeting in Washington, representatives from the United States, Britain, West Germany, Japan, Canada, Italy and France, said they favor a relatively weaker dollar, which is seen as helping reduce the huge U.S. trade deficit. The dollar received some support late in the Fed's reporting period, when a sharp runup in oil prices due to severe cold weather and an unexpectedly large jump in January wholesale prices raised speculation that interest rates were not headed lower. Higher interest rates increase returns on dollar-denominated securities, increasing demand for the currency. Currency traders often are keenly aware of the activities of central banks in the open markets, but the Fed's policy is to comment only well after the fact. The Fed does not provide any data on intervention by foreign central banks.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Firm Rejects U.S. Investor's Demand to Review Accounts
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese auto parts maker today rejected American investor T. Boone Pickens' demand to review the company's financial records. In a hearing in Tokyo District Court, lawyers for Koito Manufacturing Co. argued that Pickens' demand was part of a ``greenmailing scheme,'' rather than the exercise of a justifiable shareholder's right. Pickens is Koito's largest single shareholder, owning 26 percent of the Tokyo-based firm's shares. It was the first hearing in a lawsuit the Texas oilman filed on Jan. 13 following a long stalemate in his landmark battle for increased participation in the management of Koito. Toyota Motor Corp., Koito's largest customer, is the second-largest shareholder with 19 percent. Pickens' purchase of the shares has stirred speculation that he is trying to force Koito to buy him back at a profit, a practice known as greenmail. Pickens has denied the greenmail accusations. Lawyers for Pickens maintained that his suit was based on a section of the Japanese commercial code that permits holders of more than 10 percent of a company's stock to review its books. The court set the next hearing for May 10. Pickens filed the suit after he was denied a seat on Koito's board of directors at the company's annual shareholders' meeting last July. Toyota and other friendly companies together hold nearly 60 percent of Koito's 160.4 million shares, each valued at 3,100 yen, or $20.60 at current exchange rates, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today. In the United States, Pickens' fight is considered by some people to be a test of the freedom of Americans to invest in Japan at a time when many Japanese companies are buying up U.S. companies and property.

DOC.HEAD: USX Stockholders To Consider Icahn's Resolution
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. said today it has agreed to let shareholders vote on a resolution by takeover strategist Carl Icahn proposing the company sell 80 percent of its steel division. The company said in a statement it opposes the resolution as not in the best interests of stockholders. The resolution is non-binding and does not say how shares in the division would be sold, said USX spokesman William Keslar. ``We could sell it either through a public offering or shareholders,'' he said. ``It would be sold somehow.'' Keslar said shareholders could receive the proxy material within the next 10 days. The announcement came as a deadline requiring advance notice of proxy fights against USX approached today. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, did not immediately return calls seeking comment. Under a USX bylaw amendment approved in January, Icahn was required to tell the company by the close of business today whether he would nominate his own slate of directors at USX's annual meeting May 7. Under terms of the agreement, Icahn will not nominate directors or submit other matters for consideration at the meeting, USX said. Chairman Charles A. Corry had said the steel, oil and gas giant's 60-day notice was adopted ``to prevent someone from raising havoc at the last moment.'' USX stock fell $1.37 to $35.62 a share Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange. Icahn, who owns about 34 million, or 13.26 percent, of the company's outstanding common shares, has long been unhappy with USX management and believes the company's stock price is too low. He has argued in favor of the sale of USX's Marathon Oil & Gas subsidiary, which USX management does not want to sell. In 1988, he waged an unsuccessful proxy battle at Texaco Inc., hoping to unseat the oil company's board and force a restructuring to boost Texaco's stock price. A Wall Street source, speaking on condition of anonymity, has said Icahn was considering a similar step at USX. But Greg Drahuschak, vice president of Butcher & Singer in Pittsburgh, said he does not expect Icahn, who also is chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., to attempt a proxy fight. ``A proxy fight is time- and money-consuming,'' he said. ``You can bet your right arm, if not both arms, that USX would fight it vigorously and add to the expense.'' ``I wonder if he can get the money. This is not small potatoes,'' he said. Drahuschak said Icahn's standing with shareholders may be weakened by USX's pledges to bolster the company's stock. ``I think the company is now in a position to control its own fate,'' he said. The recent demise of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which financed takeover bids by selling junk bonds, could also discourage him. John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia, said ``there's more skittishness about doing highly leveraged deals in general.'' ``Icahn is not an Andrew Carnegie who's trying to build a steel trust or an oil monopoly,'' he said. ``He's interested in making sure the investment he has in place pays off.''

The stock market gained ground today, bidding to resume its late-winter rally as Wall Street looked ahead to Friday's monthly report on the employment situation. DOC.HEAD: Japan Strengthens Pre-Eminent Role, Blurs National Origin of Cars
Ed: Recasts grafs 2 and 10 to clarify; CORRECTS Chevrolet Novas to Geo Prizms in graf 17
DOC.TEXT: Robots resembling giraffes and elephant trunks snake around half-assembled Hondas, spewing sparks as they weld steel frames and produce a car in 14 hours. Only in Japan? No, an identical factory is churning out Hondas in Ohio. Thousands of U.S.-built Hondas will be shipped to Japan, and thousands more of the Japan-built Hondas will be sold in the United States. ``Global'' is the theme in Japan's thriving auto industry. Honda, Toyota and Nissan are building more cars abroad and slowly blurring the national origin of automobiles, historically one of the most powerful symbols of a country's manufacturing might. The strategy makes sense to Japanese auto companies because it can deflect or defuse trade tensions from countries growing hostile to Japan's barrage of exports. The strategy also places manufacturing and assembly closer to buyers, which can cut costs. Ultimately, much of the profit still flows back to Japan. ``We do business according to our philosophy of manufacturing products in the market in which they are sold,'' says Honda Senior Managing Director Shoichiro Irimajiri. Localization of research and production facilities ``means they can become new supply bases for Honda's global sales channels.'' Honda says it is ready to export U.S.-made Hondas to Europe for the first time. In labor-short Japan, no one grumbles about exporting jobs. To fill labor needs the auto industry must hire part-timers, who can make more than $2,700 a month, Irimajiri said during a tour of Honda's 9-month-old futuristic factory at Suzuka in central Japan. Conveyers glide silently, raising or lowering cars automatically depending on the work to be done. Workers wear slogans on their white jumpsuits reading _ ``Aim for zero accidents.'' Late last year, a sister factory built from the same blueprints began producing in Ohio _ one of the latest additions to the so-called ``transplant'' shops beginning to dot America's industrial heartland. Honda was the first Japanese automaker to build cars in the United States, a huge success. Last year Americans bought more Honda Accords than any other car, 60 percent of them U.S.-made, and late last year Honda cars were outselling Chrysler in the United States. Overall, Japanese car production capacity is likely to top 1 million in the United States this year, and in Europe by 1998. It's an increasingly stark contrast to the problems besetting American automakers, which have been laying off thousands of employees and closing factories for weeks at a time because they can't sell enough cars. Toyota foresees a 32 percent surge in overseas production this year to 650,000 cars, and Mitsubishi Motors, which operates a joint-venture plant with Chrysler, forecasts overseas production up 33 percent to 410,000. Honda's production abroad will be up 17 percent to 525,000, Nissan's up 7 percent to 683,000 and Mazda's steady at 220,000. Honda and Toyota are following Nissan's lead in building factories in Britain; Mazda is close to announcing a factory built jointly with Ford, probably in West Germany; Chrysler is looking for an overseas partner to build a subcompact, probably with Mitsubishi Motors. Earlier this month, Mitsubishi's parent company announced it was negotiating a cooperation agreement with West Germany's Daimler-Benz Group, in what could provide the Japanese conglomerate with an enormous advantage in setting up shop in Europe. ``None of the Japanese have any kind of sales network in continental Europe, and it's very expensive to set one up from scratch,'' says Rama Krishna, an auto analyst for the investment firm First Boston (Asia). ``You'll see tie-ups between Japanese and local or American manufacturers, a lot more joint production, designing and marketing.'' Many cars already have hybrid nationality. Nissan's new NX-Coupe was designed by Americans at Nissan's design subsidiary in California, and Mazda's new Navajo sport utility vehicle was designed and built by Ford. Mazda builds Ford Lasers, Telstars and Festivas in Japan, and Toyota's joint venture with General Motors in California makes Toyota Corollas and Geo Prizms. A new twist is shipping foreign-made Japanese cars back to Japan. Hnda started importing American-made Accords in 1988, and Toyota plans to start in 1992. Mazda-built Fords have been imported since 1988, and Nissan may do the same from its plant in Britain. Honda plans to import 50,000 U.S.-made Hondas annually by 1991, quintupling this year's imports to Japan. ``It's a totally realistic goal,'' says Honda spokesman Bret Anderson. ``Now we have the capacity to do it. It's also economical for us, and not being done just because of trade frictions.'' Although Japanese car exports to the United States are limited to 2.3 million a year, they were still worth $20.9 billion in 1989 exports, Ministry of International Trade and Industry figures show. That represents about 40 percent of the U.S. trade deficit with Japan, and has arouseed American protectionist passions and warnings. ``We the great believers are having our pants pulled down an inch at a time by a centrally orchestrated, totally committed economic aggressor,'' Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell said in a January speech. ``We had better develop a healthy fear of economic subordination because we are faced with it.'' In Europe, protectionism is rising as well, with carmakers pressing for tighter quotas on Japanese imports. Some Europeans have even proposed that Japanese cars built in Europe should be counted as imports. Europeans spent a record $10 billion on Japanese cars last year, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association says. Japanese moves into North America and Europe have contributed to a decline in car exports for the last four years, but that trend partly disguises the earnings of Japanese automakers from their foreign operations. Moreover, the value of exports are expected to start rising again because of Japan's expensive new luxury models, such as Toyota's Lexus and Nissan's Infiniti. Toyota sold more than 16,000 Lexuses in the United States in the last four months of 1989. Nissan got a slower start with sales of 1,700 Infinitis, but hasn't been selling them as long. The rising value clearly worries some Japanese auto executives because it could incite more trade backlashes. Nissan President Yutaka Kume said his company is attempting to counter the trend by importing more auto parts from abroad in what he called an ``internationalization program.'' Government trade officials, also sensitive to hostile foreign reaction, have asked automakers to keep investment in new plants and equipment from resulting in increased shipments overseas. Heightened exports could especially provoke a hostile response in the United States, where the Big Three _ General Motors Corp. Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. _ all reported severe earnings declines last year. By contrast, Toyota's earnings in the fiscal year ending in July were up 17 percent to $2.1 billion. Nissan reported a 77 percent earnings rise to $868 million in the fiscal year ended last March.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Japan Electronics Groups Propose Plans for Increased U.S. Access
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese electronics industry groups proposed a joint plan Thursday to boost U.S. sales of semiconductors in Japan. A task force created by the U.S. Semiconductor Industry Association and the Electronics Industries Association of Japan recommended a variety of programs for increasing the U.S. share of Japan's semiconductor market. Foreign semiconductor chips accounted for 12.9 percent of the Japanese market in the last three months of 1989, according to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. The task force, composed of five Japanese semiconductor user companies and six U.S. suppliers, called on non-Japanese chip makers to improve their sales and service in Japan and to modify or redesign their semiconductors to meet Japanese needs. Japanese companies have charged that U.S. companies do not supply semiconductors that are suitable for the Japanese consumer market. The task force, in a report, said consumer electronics products account for more than a third of semiconductors used in Japan, but only 7 percent of those consumed in the United States. The report said the five Japanese user firms presented lists of the semiconductors used in some of their major consumer products. U.S. firms currently are able to supply about 6 percent of the semiconductors, and after technical modifications to existing chips, could supply about 12 percent of the Japanese companies' needs, the report said. The task force recommended that foreign suppliers be given a chance to demonstrate their technical and product development capabilities. To achieve this, it called for more exchange of technical information and for increased participation by foreign firms in the design of special semiconductors for products as they are being developed in Japan. Semiconductors have been a focus of trade friction between the United States and Japan since overcapacity in Japan resulted in extensive price-cutting by competing Japanese makers in the United States and elsewhere in the mid-1980s. In a 1986 bilateral semiconductor agreement, Japan pledged to stop selling chips in the United States at unfairly low prices and agreed to a goal of 20 percent of the Japanese market for foreign semiconductors by July 1991, when the agreement expires. Japan has called the figure a target, while U.S. companies say it was a guarantee by Japan. In 1989, Japanese makers held a 24 percent share of the U.S. semiconductor market and 51 percent of the world market, according to Dataquest Inc., a U.S. market research company.

DOC.HEAD: Ridership Continues to Increase on Strike-bound Greyhound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to DELETE erroneous reference to talks held. There were no negotiations Wednesday. UPDATES with ridership figures for Wednesday and report of striker hit by bus. Picks up 11th graf, `In other....'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto RED1
DOC.TEXT: Ridership on Greyhound buses has increased each day since the company's drivers went on strike last week, the company said today. Greyhound Lines Inc. spokesman George Gravely said 40,652 people rode Greyhound buses Wednesday, the largest number since the walkout began last Friday. The number of passengers Wednesday was 38.3 percent of the bus line's ridership on the same day last year. Tuesday's ridership had been 37.6 percent of last year's figure. There have been no negotiations between the company and the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions since talks broke down last week and the company said Wednesday that talks ``would not be fruitful at this time, given the present attitude of the union.'' Earlier today, a striking driver said he was hit by a bus as it left the Mobile, Ala., terminal early today. Police said passengers on the bus reported pickets crowded around the bus as it left but the riders did not think the picket was hit. The striking driver was treated for a bruised knee. Meantime, two Greyhound buses were seized at the U.S.-Canadian border near Plattsburgh, N.Y., after they were found to be illegally transporting Canadian security guards hired by the company, an immigration spokesman said. Greyhound failed to get the special permission needed for Canadian citizens to enter the United States to work as security guards, said Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman Duke Austin. When the first buses arrived at the border, officials discovered two passengers were employed by Greyhound as guards, Austin said. The individuals and the two buses in which they were riding were seized, he said. It was not immediately known whether any charges were filed against the bus line or the Canadians. A Greyhound representative in Dallas said the buses would be held overnight at the border. ``The buses are still there but we're going to get them back,'' said Dana Neal. Some 6,300 bus drivers and 3,000 maintenance and office workers walked off the job Friday after talks broke down over a new three-year contract. The company has been operating at reduced levels, using about 700 replacement drivers plus union members who crossed picket lines. The company says about 350 union drivers are at work; the union says 95 returned. ``The cause of this strike is singular,'' union spokesman Jeffry Nelson said Wednesday. ``The company has refused to negotiate with the union that represents its 9,000 employees in good faith.'' In other developments Wednesday: _ Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, and 10 other senators asked Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole to intervene as she did in last year's Pittston coal strike by appointing a ``supermediator.'' A spokeswoman for Mrs. Dole said she had no such plans because the dispute is still under the normal mediation process. _ In Redding, Calif., about 500 mourners, half of them striking drivers in uniform, marched in memory of a driver killed on a picket line. The mourners were led by the widow of 59-year-old Robert Waterhouse, who was pinned against a building Saturday by a bus operated by a replacement driver. No charges were filed. _ In Richmond, Va., David W. Batchelor, president of Greyhound's Eastern division, reiterated the company's position that the replacement drivers are permanent hires and that strikers who return will get jobs only as slots become available. _ The company obtained its 12th temporary restraining order prohibiting violence, vandalism and interference with operations. Several such incidents have occurred since the strike began, including shots fired at buses in Chicago and windows and mirrors smashed in other cities. Court orders have been granted in Chicago; Cincinnati; Cleveland; Des Moines, Iowa; Jacksonville, Fla.; Los Angeles; Mount Laurel, N.J.; Philadelphia; Pittsburgh; Portland, Ore.; Sacramento, Calif., and San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Stock-Index Futures Battle Issue at Industry Meeting
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 4 grafs to update with Gramm's remarks; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Despite tough ...
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission today urged the futures industry to become more vocal in supporting the agency's fight to retain jurisdiction over stock-index futures. In a speech to the annual meeting of the Futures Industry Association here, Wendy Gramm said futures exchange officials and trading firms must let Congress know they object to the possible transfer of authority over index futures to the Securities and Exchange Commission. ``You must speak out to address these issues, to educate the people who do not understand futures and options markets,'' she said. ``They must be made aware of your commitment to continue to be world leaders in terms of liquidity, innovation and integrity.'' Despite tough talk by both Mrs. Gramm and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the largest market for index futures, the Merc recently has indicated a greater willingness to compromise on the jurisdiction issue, which surfaced in the aftermath of the 1987 stock market crash. The Merc said last month in an outlook for the 1990s that it wanted to resolve regulatory issues surrounding stock-index futures. Merc chief Leo Melamed underscored the point at a news conference Monday to announce his retirement plans. ``We're willing to sit down and get these issues behind us because these issues constantly drag us away from the business of business, and that ought not to be,'' said Melamed, chairman of the Merc's executive committee. But Melamed also said that ``if that compromise means we give and no one else gives, forget it.'' The SEC, which regulates stock trading, appears to be gaining congressional support for shifting regulatory control over index futures to the SEC from the CFTC. The idea also has gained favor on Wall Street. On Tuesday, Robert Downey, a managing partner of Goldman, Sachs & Co. and chairman of the Securities Industry Association, told a Senate subcommittee the SEC should regulate both markets. Index futures allow investors to buy and sell the cash equivalent of baskets of stocks without ever owning the stocks themselves. The Merc trades futures on the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index. The SEC started the regulatory tug-of-war after the October 1987 crash, which some experts believe was worsened by computer-driven program trading techniques involving both the stock and stock-index futures markets. Mrs. Gramm disputed that claim in an unusually pointed speech three weeks ago in which she said individual investors had been leaving the stock market since the late 1960s, so stock-index futures, which arrived in the 1970s, were not to blame for the recession on Wall Street. Critics of stock-index futures also have called for government authority to set the amount of ``margin,'' or downpayment, that investors must put down to buy or sell futures contracts. Mrs. Gramm believes the exchanges should be allowed to continue setting their own margins.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Reportedly Refusing Concessions from Pilots Union
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines has refused an offer of $40 million in concessions from its pilots union in exchange for getting strikers' jobs back, according to a newspaper report. The report in Thursday's editions of the Atlanta Journal-Constitution quoted unidentified sources familiar with contract negotiations under way in Washington. Last March, Eastern's pilots and flight attendants unions struck the airline in sympathy with the striking Machinists union. Although the sympathy strikes ended in November, no former striking pilots and only 215 former striking flight attendants have been called back to work. The Machinists union remains on strike against Miami-based Eastern, which has been operating under the supervision of a federal bankruptcy court since March 9, 1989. In a separate development Wednesday, the House sustained President Bush's veto of a bill to have the government intervene in the Eastern dispute, dealing a blow to organized labor and Democratic leaders. Also, the Justice Department said it has no objections to Eastern's proposed sale of its valuable Latin American routes to rival American Airlines. Eastern says its pilot jobs have been filled by 800 pilots who refused to strike or who crossed picket lines and by 1,000 new replacements. Leaders of the Air Line Pilots Association say about 1,400 former striking pilots want their jobs at Eastern back, while an equal number have retired or found jobs elsewhere. On Monday, a federal mediator called ALPA and Eastern negotiators into a new round of talks, the Atlanta newspaper said. Spokesmen for the union and Eastern said they couldn't discuss details of the talks, but Eastern ALPA Chairman Skip Copeland told the newspaper, ``We're willing to make enormous concessions.'' The concessions totaled more than $40 million, the paper reported. The report said ALPA has insisted that Eastern honor its contract by awarding pilot jobs according to seniority, a request that Eastern has refused. If that were done, most former strikers would displace the replacement pilots. ``It appears to be a philosophical impasse, not an economic impasse,'' Copeland was quoted as saying. ``What they're trying to do is break the union.'' If the National Mediation Board decides further negotiations wouldn't be worthwhile, it can trigger a 30-day period after which Eastern could impose contract terms and the union could strike. If that happened, or if Eastern asked the bankruptcy court to void ALPA's contract, the union probably would ask members to vote on whether to return to the picket lines.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Traders Plead Innocent
DOC.TEXT: A dozen traders from the soybean futures pit at the Chicago Board of Trade pleaded innocent today in a new federal indictment totaling more than 751 charges. U.S. District Judge George Marovich, who also heard the innocent plea of a 13th soybean trader Wednesday, rescheduled the trial for the 13 from June 12 to Sept. 10 to allow lawyers more time to prepare their cases. The defendants had originally been indicted in August on 539 charges involving fraudulent trading practices, but a grand jury last week returned a superseding indictment against the 13. Marovich also agreed Wednesday to a motion by defense attorneys to hold separate hearings for six of the defendants, who contend that incriminating statements made during surprise visits to their homes by FBI agents and prosecutors in January 1989 were involuntary and should be thrown out. A total of 47 traders and a clerk have been charged in an FBI probe of alleged fraudulent activities at the Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The exchanges trade futures contracts that are used as hedges against sharply rising or falling commodity prices . Those who pleaded innocent today were Scott Anixter, Bradley Ashman, Charles Bergstrom, Edward Cox, Martin Dempsey, Joel Fetchenhier, Thomas Kenney, Bruce Mittelstadt, James Nowak, John Ryan, Sheldon Schneider and John Vercillo. William Barcal pleaded innocent Wednesday. The clerk, Michael Weiser, and five soybean traders have pleaded guilty in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Will Go to Paris to Meet With Group of Seven Financial Leaders
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs of further details after 4th graf, Asked further...; picks up 5th graf pvs, The meeting ...
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today he will go to Paris next month to meet with financial leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations to discuss recent economic developments around the world. Before appearing at a House Appropriations subcommittee hearing on the Treasury Department budget, Brady was asked about a report that he and Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan would travel to Paris on April 7. ``Definitely,'' he replied. Asked further if the trip involved meetings with the G-7 leaders, he said, ``Yes.'' Since the regular meeting of the G-7 is scheduled for May 7, Brady was asked as he left the hearing whether there was any urgency for the preliminary meeting. ``There's no special urgency,'' he replied. ``We've always had a meeting previous to the regular meeting and this was just the time that was picked. Last time it was in February and this time it is in April.'' The meeting of finance ministers and central bank presidents from the world's most powerful industrial democracies _ the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy _ would be the first such session since the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe. An official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States had proposed the meeting to discuss how changes in Eastern Europe are affecting currency markets and the economic coordination efforts among the major powers. In recent weeks, the value of the dollar on world markets has climbed sharply while the Japanese yen and West German mark have declined. A stronger dollar threatens to worsen America's already huge trade deficit since it would make imports less expensive for American consumers and U.S. products more expensive on overseas markets. The G-7 countries have been coordinating efforts this week to sell dollars and buy Japanese yen and West German marks in an effort to dampen the dollar's climb but so far the government currency sales have had limited impact. In addition to the recent volatility in exchange markets, the G-7 officials were expected to address the question of the unification of West Germany and East Germany. Some economists fear this development could worsen inflationary problems in West Germany, especially if a proposal to exchange the West German currency for the East Germany currency on a one-to-one basis is carried out. The April 7 meeting of the G-7 countries will be held just one month before a previously scheduled May 7 meeting in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Outboard Marine Idles 3,100
DOC.TEXT: Outboard Marine Corp., manufacturer of Johnson and Evinrude outboard engines, says it will lay off 3,100 workers temporarily because of lagging boat sales. The company made the announcement Wednesday, saying it will stop building boat engines for several weeks. The company said its stern-drive plant in Lexington, Tenn., will be closed for six weeks beginning late this month. Seven outboard engine plants, including a plant in Waukegan, Ill., that employs 580 workers, will close for two to three weeks in April. Slow sales which began last summer have continued into the first quarter, said James Chapman, president and chief executive officer of the company. ``We are reducing our engine production this spring to prevent inventory from building up in our plants and in our dealers' showrooms this summer,'' he said. ``We aim to improve our efficiency and competitiveness by taking this action now to better match our production to the realities of the marketplace.''

DOC.HEAD: Nissan Expands U.S. Exports
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Corp. in U.S.A. on Thursday began exporting U.S.-made cars and pickup trucks to Taiwan, expanding the number of vehicles shipped overseas from the company's assembly plant in Tennessee. The first shipment from the Port of Los Angeles consisted of 330 Sentra XE sedans and four-wheel-drive Hardbody trucks. Nissan has been exporting U.S.-made Hardbody King Cab trucks to Japan. The shipments will enable Nissan Motor Co. Ltd., the Japan-based parent company, to sell vehicles for the first time under the Nissan nameplate in Taiwan, which restricts the import of Japanese-made vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Chief Expects Stable Prices Despite Winter's End
DOC.TEXT: OPEC Secretary-General Subroto said he expects the oil market to remain stable through spring, according to a published report Thursday. ``Demand for oil usually drops in spring. We know the behavior of the market and the changes which accompany it, but we expect there will be no changes,'' said Subroto, in an interview with the state-run newspaper Al-Ittihad. Subroto, who uses only one name, spoke on the eve of the March 16 meeting in Vienna of the market monitoring committee of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The cartel is committed to a production ceiling of 22 million barrels per day for the first six months of 1990, aimed at maintaining a reference price of $18 a barrel. Iraqi oil minister Essam Chalabi, in an interview with the Bahrain-based Gulf News Agency, said he did not expect the meeting to make any substantial changes in the existing OPEC accord. ``It is a meeting merely designed to take stock of the market without taking any decisions in its connection,'' Chalabi was quoted as saying. ``This is a chance for the oil ministers to exchange views on the conditions of the oil market.'' He said the full meeting of all 13 OPEC member will convene May 25, with frequent consultations on stabilizing the market and maintaining the current market. Iraq's earlier call for a gradual increase in oil prices through limiting production contradicted the stand of producers like Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, who have been calling for higher production. Hisham Naser, oil minister of Saudi Arabia, the largest OPEC producer, met with the Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil ministers earlier in the week. They announced an agreement on a common policy to smooth the way for the OPEC meetings. But no details had been disclosed. Oil prices reached well above the $18 mark in recent months due to the high demand for winter fuel. Subroto said the usual drop in demand would be offset by anticipated oil requirements of reforming eastern Europe. ``The Soviet Union was unable to meet the eastern European needs of oil in the last few years, and these states will start looking for alternative sources of oil supplies,'' Subroto said. He referred to deals already concluded between eastern Europe and some OPEC member states, but he did not go into detail. Subroto also said declining production in the United States and the Soviet Union could create a huge boost in demand in the next five years, forcing an ``explosion'' in world prices if production capacity was not increased. Subroto, of Indonesia, urged industrial states to help invest up to $60 billion to develop production capacity to meet demand. Current production capacity is 27 million barrels a day.

DOC.HEAD: Houe Sustains Bush's Veto of Eastern Legislation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf, Why hold ... to CORRECT by inserting dropped word ``false.'' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: House members who helped sustain President Bush's veto of a bill to create a commission on the year-old Eastern Airlines dispute say the measure wouldn't have helped the 8,500 striking workers. ``Why hold out false hope to those who've already been hurt so much?'' Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said Wednesday before a 261-160 vote to override fell about 20 votes short of the two-thirds majority needed. The bill would have created a four-member bipartisan commission to study the strike and recommend ways to resolve it. Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas, challenged colleagues to be truthful about whether a commission would help resolve the complex matter, now before bankruptcy courts. ``Look at our own deficit and answer that question for yourselves,'' DeLay said. White House spokesman Stephen Hart praised the House action. ``We have long felt it was inappropriate for such action to be taken. This lays the issue to rest. We continue to feel the appropriate course of action in addressing the dispute is between labor and management,'' Hart said. Michel and other Republicans said Bush was right to halt government intervention because the strike by members of the Machinists union had not created a transportation emergency in any region of the country. Noting that Bush had vetoed the measure in December, Michel said Democrats would have pressed the override sooner if they had considered the bill an emergency. During the hour-long debate, as about two dozen uniformed Eastern employees watched from the gallery, the legislation's congressional supporters said it was ``the last, best hope'' to save the carrier. ``Our government is turning its back on the working men and women of this country,'' said Rep. James McDermott, D-Wash. ``The president said there is no emergency, but he doesn't have to fly on an airline that's on the verge of collapse.'' Minority Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia, one of 25 Republicans who voted against Bush on the issue, said the matter amounted to ``a question of national policy ... the right of people to expect their government to look into situations like this.'' Gingrich has also said he felt he owed it to Atlanta airport workers, many of whom are his constituents. Rep. Bud Schuster, R-Pa., said Democrats had an ``uncontrollable urge to bash the president'' but were ignoring a warning from bankruptcy examiner David Shapiro that congressional intervention might jeopardize the remaining 17,000 jobs at Eastern. Last week, Shapiro said in a report that there was evidence to suggest that Texas Air Corp., Eastern's parent company, may have treated Eastern unfairly in a dozen financial transactions. The vote marked Congress' second veto confrontation with Bush during this election-year session. The president won the first showdown in January, when the Senate narrowly upheld his veto of a bill protecting Chinese students from deportation.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 41 Percent Profit Rise for 1989
DOC.TEXT: WPP Group PLC, the British advertising group which owns the U.S.-based agencies J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, reported Thursday its profit climbed 41 percent in 1989 even as it continued to expand rapidly. After-tax profit for the 12 months ended Dec. 31 came to 29.7 million pounds, or $49 million, compared with 21.1 million pounds in 1988. Earnings per share came to 73 pence, or $1.20, compared with 54.3 pence. Profit before tax soared 86 percent to 75 million pounds, or $124 million, from 40.3 million pounds a year earlier. Revenue rose 84 percent to 1.005 billion pounds, or $1.66 billion, from 547.1 million pounds a year earlier. The former J. Walter Thompson Group, acquired in June 1987, had margins of 10 percent and its net new business billings rose 18 percent to 449 million pounds, or $741 million, the parent company said. It said Ogilvy Group's margins reached 10 percent for the portion of the year following its mid-year acquisition and its net new business billings grew 44 percent to more than 316 million pounds, or $521 million. ``The board believes that the results for 1990 will reflect continuing progress,'' WPP said.

DOC.HEAD: French Publisher Expands U.S. Distribution Network
DOC.TEXT: The French publishing group Hachette SA announced Thursday that it has expanded its distribution network in the United States by picking up two wholesale press distributors. Hachette said that its U.S. subsidiary, Hachette Distribution Inc., has acquired just over 50 percent of Imperial News Co., a Long Island-based distributor of magazines and paberback books. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but a Hachette SA spokesman said it will include assumption of some debt. Hachette said that immediately following the takeover, Imperial acquired control of another distribution agency, Yankee News Co. Together the two companies distribute publications to 6,500 retail outlets in the greater New York City region including Brooklyn, Queens, Westchester County, Connecticut and Long Island for annual sales of about $100 million. Hachette already has a solid footing in the U.S. magazine distribution sector through its subsidiary Curtis Circulation Co., which controls 25 percent of the U.S. market.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Rose
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing stock prices. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose Thursday on London's Stock Exchange, as several healthy good corporate earnings reports gave the whole market a lift. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 19.7 points, or 0.9 percent, to 2,250.0. The Financial Times 30-share index gained 17.4 points to close at 1,774.4. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 10.38 points to 1,219.18. Volume amounted to 436.7 million shares, compared with the 419.4 million shares Wednesday.

The stock market inched higher today, bidding to resume its late-winter rally as Wall Street looked ahead to Friday's monthly report on the employment situation. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 3.61 to 2,673.20 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 715 up, 621 down and 557 unchanged. The Labor Department's report on employment Friday morning promises to give investors one of the first signposts of the economy's performance in February. Hopes apparently spread today that the figures would reinforce the view that business activity was continuing to expand at a sluggish but presumably sustainable pace. Advance estimates call for the data to show an increase of perhaps 250,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, not far below a 275,000 rise posted for January. If cosensus projections are met, the report will also put the civilian unemployment rate at 5.3 percent, unchanged from the month before. Hilton Hotels led the active list, down 11\ at 49}. Agriculture futures had been depressed by reports of more rain in U.S. growing areas, with additional showers forecast in the next few days, said analyst Susan Leighty of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Wheat staged a late rally along with soybeans. But a lack of new large export business weighed on corn prices, which finished mixed, said Mrs. Leighty.
