DOC.HEAD: Elders Announces Major Restructuring, Deal With Grand Met
DOC.TEXT: Elders IXL Ltd. on Thursday announced a major restructuring under which it will spin off its agribusiness operations into a new public company and sell other assets while retaining its brewing business. Elders also said it would buy Grand Metropolitan PLC's breweries for an undisclosed amount and enter into a joint venture with Grand Met to operate the two companies' 8,500 pubs. Elders had been frustrated in past attempts to expand its extensive brewing interests. The announcement was made in Sydney, Australia, and a copy was made available in London. The restructuring was intended maximize value for all Elders shareholders by creating independent corporate entities focused on single businesses, Elders said. Elders Chairman John D. Elliott said, ``The reconstruction will position these companies to continue their growth strongly into the 1990s.'' Elders IXL will become Fosters Brewing Group Ltd. and focus on its brewing interests, the announcement said. Its best-known brands are Fosters and Courage. Elders said it would spin off its agribusiness operations by creating a new publicly held company called Elders Ltd. and giving Elders' existing shareholders stock in the new company. The spinoff requires shareholder approval, Elders said. Other assets, including Elders IXL's interests in Elders Finance Group and Elders Resources NZFP, will be sold and the surplus cash will be distributed to shareholders over time, it said. Harlin Holdings Pty Ltd., an Australian company that owns 55 percent of Elders' stock and supports the restructuring, said it plans to reduce its interest in Fosters Brewing to below 50 percent and maintain its stake between 40 percent and 50 percent. Harlin will scale down its holding in the agribusiness company as well, Elders said, without providing specifics, and will retain representatives on the two boards of directors. Elders said it has reached ``an understanding'' with Grand Met, the British food, liquor and leisure group that owns Pillsbury Co. of the United States, to acquire Grand Met's four breweries. The 50-50 venture to operate pubs will be called Inntrepreneur Estates Ltd. and will operate Elders' more than 5,000 pubs and Grand Met's more than 2,000 pubs. Elders said it intends to make a definitive announcement on the brewery purchase and pub joint venture shortly. It did not say how much it would pay for Grand Met's brewing interests, but it said the purchase and the combination of the pubs would offset each other. ``The two transactions would be cash neutral,'' it said. The deal with Grand Met requires approval from British regulatory authorities and of Grand Met's shareholders, Elders said. Last year, the government blocked Elders' hostile bid of 1.6 billion pounds, or $2.6 billion, for the British brewer Scottish and Newcastle PLC for competitive reasons. Britain's brewers have been seeking to restructure their operations since the government, in an effort to encourage competition, decided that brewers' could own only 2,000 ``tied'' pubs which sell the owners' beers. Any pubs owned above that number have to be ``free'' houses selling whatever beer they like. Explaining the restructuring, Elders said its board of directors decided that Elders' market value does not reflect the value of its brewing operations and that the way to rectify that was to create a separate brewing company which was likely to be more attractive to shareholders. The restructuring has been ``a longstanding objective,'' it said. Fosters Brewing will have strong competitive positions in Australia, Canada and Britain, and significant potential for future growth, Elders said. Before the Grand Met deal, Fosters Brewing would be the fourth-largest brewing company in the world, the company said. Among other things, the agribusiness company will be a leading provider of farm services in Australaia, the largest wool broker, largest livestock sales and rural merchandise supply organization and a major provider of financial services to the rural industry.

DOC.HEAD: Hove is Leading Candidate for FDIC Post
DOC.TEXT: Andrew C. Hove Jr., a small town Nebraska banker and Republican activist, is the leading candidate to fill a vacancy on the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. He was recommended for the job by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Rep. Virginia Smith, R-Neb., said Thursday. President Bush is expected to make the appointment. The post requires Senate confirmation. The FDIC insures deposits in both banks and savings institutions. Its board supervises the Resolution Trust Corp., a new agency created in August to carry out President Bush's savings and loan bailout. The White House also received Brady's nominee for director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates solvent S&Ls, said an administration source, who spoke on condition of anonymity and would not reveal the name of the person recommended. Assistant Treasury Secretary Salvatore R. Martoche has been serving as acting director since Tuesday, replacing M. Danny Wall, who resigned three months ago under fire from Congress. However, savings institutions in danger of failure have challenged Martoche's legal authority and the administration, which until recently had been unable to find a candidate, wants to move swiftly to appoint a permanent director. Hove, 55, is viewed as a representative of small town and farm banks. He served as mayor of Minden from 1974 to 1982 and is a political supporter of Smith and Gov. Kay Orr of Nebraska. Banking's two principal trade groups, the American Bankers Association and the Independent Bankers Association of America back him. The appointment would be a victory for FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman, who at times has been at odds with the Treasury Department over the conduct of the S&L bailout. ``I think he's a fine appointment. We'll be very pleased to have him on this board if the president appoints him,'' Seidman said. There had been speculation among industry insiders that Treasury would use the appointment to gain control of the FDIC board. Two Treasury officials, the thrift office director and the comptroller of the currency, hold seats on the five-member board. Since October, Seidman publicly campaigned for the appointment of an ``independent banker'' to his board. ``This appointment looks potentially to signal a new era of good feeling and a closer working relationship between the FDIC and Treasury,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the independent bankers. ``I think it underscores a new recognition (by Treasury) ... that you should have people other than Wall Street types in top positions of the government,'' Guenther said. Hove is chairman and chief executive of the Minden Exchange Bank & Trust Co., Minden, Neb. A former aircraft carrier pilot, he steered his bank through the farm depression of the early 1980s and served as president of the Nebraska Bankers Association. His appointment also likely would be viewed as win for small banks, who are fighting suggestions within the administration to scale back federal deposit insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Gradual Switch to Private Banking System to Start April 1
DOC.TEXT: East German and foreign enterprises will be able to take stakes in private commercial banks when the country begins switching to a Western-style banking system April 1, central bank director Horst Kaminsky said Thursday. Kaminsky said the plan to switch to a Western system, approved Thursday by the Cabinet of the Communist-led interim government, was an important move in making East Germany's economy more compatible with West Germany's, with an eye toward eventual currency unification. Kaminsky, who spoke at a news conference following the weekly cabinet meeting, said foreign enterprises would be allowed to participate in the new banks but gave no details other than that the transformation would be gradual. Since the hard-line Communist leadership of Erich Honecker collapsed last fall, the government has moved to make East Germany's centrally-planned economy more compatible with West Germany's capitalist system, as the countries move toward unification. But East Germany's economy has slowed drastically ahead of the country's scheduled March 18 free elections, which will seat a new parliament that could alter any decisions made by the interim government. Kaminsky's proposal includes an autonomous central bank, based on Western models like West Germany's Bundesbank, that will steer cash and credit in a mixed commercial banking sector. Kaminsky said a series of banks would be released from state ownership and an independent banking watchdog commission established. The new banks would perform general commercial functions, similar to West German banks, he said. They would include Deutsche Kreditbank AG, Genossenschaftsbank Berlin AG, Deutsche Aussenhandelsbank AG, the East German foreign trade bank that already operates commercially abroad, and cooperative banks for trades and crafts. Kaminsky said one consequence of the switch would be the emergence of a capital market and a stock exchange. But he declined to say whether a bourse could be set up before the end of this year. Responding to questions about reports that East Germany's foreign exchange reserves had dwindled recently from a total of $1.76 billion to $940 million, Kaminsky said: ``Those rumors about our currency reserves do not represent the reality.'' While admitting the uncertainty surrounding East Germany's future may have unsettled some foreign creditors, he stressed ``there is no cause for panic reports.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials Confirm G-7 To Meet in April
DOC.TEXT: Top finance officials from the world's seven major industrial countries will meet in Paris early next month to discuss turbulence in global currency markets and the dramatic developments in Eastern Europe, officials confirmed Thursday. The talks involving the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada were seen as an effort to strengthen economic coordination at a time of dramatic change in world affairs. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, who was instrumental in scheduling the meeting, insisted that there was no ``special urgency'' for the gathering, scheduled for April 7. However, the discussions will occur just one month before these same officials are scheduled to meet for a regular economic review session in conjunction with the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Washington. Currency markets have been especially volatile in recent weeks, with the West German mark and the Japanese yen falling in value against the U.S. dollar. Analysts said the rising dollar threatened to worsen the huge American trade deficit by making foreign products less expensive for U.S. consumers while making American goods more expensive overseas. ``The dollar's strength is of great concern to the administration,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``It constitutes a recession threat because it is a further risk to an already beleaguered industrial side of the U.S. economy.'' The dollar's advance has occurred despite coordinated intervention by Federal Reserve and other central banks to push the currency lower. Some analysts suggested that since intervention has proved largely unsuccessful, G-7 officials might discuss coordinated changes in interest rates. Higher interest rates in Japan and Germany would tend to bolster those currencies while lower interest rates in the United States would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive. But Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who will attend the Paris meeting, has opposed further cuts in U.S. interest rates because of inflationary pressures at home.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Company in Default on Loans to Two Lenders
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp., the financially distressed owner of U.S. department stores operating under bankruptcy-court supervision, said Thursday it will not pay $5.2 million in interest due on loans from two major lenders. Failure to pay the interest, due Wednesday under special arrangements made last week postponing earlier payment deadlines, meant Campeau went into default on loans from Olympia & York Developments Ltd. and Edward J. DeBartolo Corp. But the lenders have agreed they will not move to collect their collateral without notifying Campeau nine days in advance. The loans total $705 million. Two loans of $75 million and $150 million were made by two subsidiaries of Olympia & York, owned by the Reichmann family of Toronto. The loan from DeBartolo, a big Ohio-based shopping mall developer, amounts to $480 million. Campeau ``expects to continue discussions with Olympia & York and DeBartolo regarding the development of a long-term business plan for the operations of the corporation,'' the company said in a statement released at its Toronto headquarters. Word of the default followed intense discussions with the lenders late into the evening Wednesday. Campeau spokesman Richard W. Wertheim said a deal to defer payments for several weeks had been worked out Wednesday with Olympia & York and was contingent on a parallel deal being reached with DeBartolo. But the DeBartolo talks fell through, he said. DeBartolo has claims on Campeau's California-based Ralphs Grocery Co. chain, but the Ralphs' shares are held by another Campeau company, Federated Stores Inc., which is under bankruptcy-court protection in the United States. That means DeBartolo would have to line up with other creditors to seek the approval of a bankruptcy court judge to seize the Ralphs' assets, Wertheim said. The collateral on the Olympia & York loans includes various properties. Neither DeBartolo nor Olympia & York have yet given notice they intend to seize assets, he added. ``Our focus, and their interest as well, is on the long-term plan for the continued operation of the company,'' Wertheim said, adding that ``our discussions with all lenders are focused on the long term, not satisfying something on a day-to-day basis.'' He said: ``There really is no question that we have the $5.2 million to pay if we wanted to.'' The Olympia & York and DeBartolo loans were used to help finance Campeau's ill-fated acquisitions of the U.S. retailing groups Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. in 1986 and 1988. But unlike most of the financing, these loans were guaranteed by the Toronto-based parent. Allied and Federated are currently operating under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Act, which gives them some time to reorganize under court direction. When they filed for protection from creditors on Jan. 15, they listed $7.7 billion in debts. It appeared unlikely that the outcome of Campeau's discussions with Olympia & York and DeBartolo would have any direct bearing on the Federated and Allied bankruptcy proceedings. Wertheim said given the circumstances Campeau has maintained good relationships with its bank lenders. The inability so far to reach agreements with Olympia & York and DeBartolo on long-term loan payment deferrals doesn't imply Campeau's collapse is imminent. ``Right now there's no plan for us to fold up our tents,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi Says Takeover of Aristech Nearly Complete
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Corp. and managers at Aristech Chemical Corp. now own 98 percent of the chemical company, Mitsubishi said Thursday. ACC Acquisition Corp., a partnership formed by Aristech executives and Mitsubishi, paid $859 million, or $27 a share, for 31.8 million shares of Aristech, officials said. Management at Aristech won't change, Mitsubishi spokesman Peter Rosenthal said. The Japanese company owns 80 percent of ACC Acquisition, he said. Aristech's board rejected a $25 a share offer from Utah industrialist John Huntsman last fall. Aristech posted earnings of $15.1 million, or 43 cents per share, on sales of $222.6 million during the last quarter of 1989. In all of 1989, the company earned $82.1 million, or $2.36 per share, on sales of $996.4 million. Aristech, a maker of thermoplastic resins, employs 1,800 people at 10 plants in eight states. Its management bought the company from steel and energy giant USX Corp. in 1986. Aristech Chairman Thomas Marshall led the management side of the current buyout.

DOC.HEAD: Selling Saps Strength Again From Energy Futures
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices sagged Thursday for a third straight session amid selling associated with bearish supply and demand expectations. Energy market analysts said earlier weakness in Asia and Europe set a negative tone on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract for April delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, shed 15 cents to close at $20.78 per 42-gallon barrel after losing 65 cents on Wednesday and Tuesday. Contracts for delivery during May through July finished lower by 16 cents to 18 cents. The April contract of No. 2 home heating oil dropped 0.85 cent to 55.34 cents a gallon, adding to Wednesday's and Tuesday's losses of 1.03 cents and 0.77 cent, respectively. Contracts for delivery further in the future also declined but more moderately. Among other refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, the April contract of unleaded regular gasoline fell 0.59 cent to 56.14 cents a gallon, bringing its decline over the past three sessions to 3.16 cents. Contracts for delivery during May through July also declined, with the May contract off 0.88 cent. Randall Rothenberg, a broker at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said selling momentum overseas carried over into U.S. trading. Traders sold on the assumption that supplies currently are adequate to meet demand. The reopening of a major New York harbor waterway might have dampened buying enthusiasm to some extent, he said. The waterway was temporarily closed after a barge loaded with heating oil exploded and caught fire earlier in the week, the third oil-related mishap in the area this year.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest to Give Away More Free Flights to Bumped Passengers
DOC.NOTE: EDS: DELETES 3rd graf to remove incorrect reference to DOT figures, EDITS 4th graf to conform; picks up 5th graf pvs bg'ng, Northwest has ...
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines plans to give away more free-flight coupons in hopes of appeasing passengers bumped on oversold flights. In the first three months of this year, the airline will reduce its rate of involuntary-denied boardings by 60 percent compared with a year earlier, Robert Fornaro, Northwest's vice president of marketing planning, said Wednesday. Involuntary-denied boardings are the bumping of passengers who don't want to get off planes. In the fourth quarter of last year, Northwest involuntarily bumped about 2,200 passengers, or 2.53 for every 10,000 passengers boarded. Northwest has been steadily improving by that measure since the problem peaked last summer, the airline says. In the fourth quarter of 1989, it bumped about 2,500 fewer people than in the same quarter a year earlier, and the bumpings were reduced even though total passenger boardings rose 12 percent. Northwest's 1989 rate of involuntary bumpings was 3.83 per 10,000 passengers boarded, down from 4.26 in 1988, said Northwest spokesman Doug Miller. The airline also showed progress in the fourth quarter in the number of people who are bumped ``voluntarily''. That means they take a later flight because the carrier offers them incentives such as cash or coupons for free flights in the future. ``It costs us a few more free tickets, but that's the price you pay,'' Fornaro said. Most major airlines aim to hold overbooking to a minimum, in an effort to reduce both voluntary and involuntary bumping. But when a flight is overbooked, they want to convert as many travelers as possible to the voluntary side by offering them the freebies. Northwest offers freebies to bumped passengers now, but it hasn't offered enough to entice larger numbers of fliers to give up their seats voluntarily. Fornaro said it is especially difficult for Northwest to cut its number of involuntary bumpings because it has large numbers of passengers on long flights over the Pacific. Passengers on longer flights are generally less flexible in their plans than those on shorter hauls. Many travelers, especially business fliers, reserve seats on several flights to ensure they will have their choice of departure times. That forces airlines to book more reservations than they have seats, or risk having lots of empty seats.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Of Two Companies Making AIDS Vaccine Bolstered By Testing
DOC.TEXT: Two small biotechnology companies that have devised an AIDS vaccine have seen their stock shoot higher following an official go-ahead for human testing of the substance. Stock in Alpha 1 Biomedicals Inc. of Washington, D.C., and Cel-Sci Corp. of Alexandria, Va., jumped after California health officials approved the first phase of human testing. The approval, announced Monday, was the first for human trials of the HGP-30 vaccine in the United States, according to the companies. Those involved in the tests cautioned it could take years for the development of a true vaccine. Nevertheless, the price of Cel-Sci nearly doubled Tuesday, to $2.66 from $1.56 Monday, while the price of Alpha 1 shares nearly tripled that day, to $7.69 from $2.88. Both saw unusually heavy trading volume. The prices of both issues, which are traded on the national over-the-counter system, eased somewhat Wednesday. By late afternoon Thursday, Cel-Sci was trading at $2.09 a share and Alpha 1 shares fetched $4.88. Cel-Sci and Alpha 1 are 50-50 partners in a joint venture called Viral Technologies Inc., which devised the vaccine. The vaccine is synthetic; it contains no live or dead AIDS virus components, unlike many other AIDS vaccines under study, meaning there is no chance it could induce infection with the deadly disease. Geert Kersten, vice president and treasurer of Cel-Sci, said the price of his company's stock has been volatile since it went public in 1983. ``It's a very emotional stock,'' he said. Kersten owns about 15 percent of the 32 million outstanding shares, while Cel-Sci's founder, Maximillian de Clara of Switzerland, owns about 9 percent, Kersten said. Much of the remaining stock is believed to be held by individual investors, he said. Managers and directors of Alpha 1, which went public in 1986, own about 15 percent of that company's 4.6 million shares, said Robert J. Lanham, chief operating officer. The rest is believed to be held by small investors, he said. Both companies have lost money since their founding, which is typical for biotechnology start-ups. Kersten said Viral Technologies began testing the vaccine on humans in Great Britain last May. So far, the results have been encouraging, with the immune systems of those in the study producing the expected defensive response to the AIDS virus, he said. The vaccine targets a core protein of the AIDS virus, which is found in all strains of the virus. Most other potential vaccines under study target the outer shell of the virus, which can vary because the virus often is mutated, Kersten said. Several other companies also are testing an AIDS vaccine on humans, including Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., a joint venture of Chiron Corp. and Ciba-Geigy, and a joint venture of Merck & Co. and Repligen Corp., said Stuart Weisbrod, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

DOC.HEAD: K mart Posts $20.5 Million Quarterly Loss
With AM-Retail Sales, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp. on Thursday blamed costs of an accelerated five-year plan to build new stores and renovate older ones for a $20.5 million loss in its fourth quarter. Chairman Joseph E. Antonini said recently that costs of speeding up the $2.3-billion expansion and renovation program, now scheduled for completion in 1994, would cut into profits at the nation's second-largest retailer. He said Thursday that price-cutting and completing the expansion program were essential to keeping competitors at bay. ``We anticipate sales and earnings in future years will benefit significantly from the acceleration of this program,'' Antonini said. But analysts suggested the retailer is feeling pressure. ``I think they feel that we're going to lose confidence quickly if they don't make some kind of dramatic move,'' said analyst Sally Schaadt at New York-based Fourteen Research. K mart said its results translated to a loss of 10 cents a share for quarter ended Jan. 31, compared with a net profit of $393.2 million, or $1.96 a share in the year-ago quarter. Revenue for the period totaled $9.75 billion, up 16 percent from $8.42 billion the year before. The company took an after-tax charge of $416.1 million during the quarter to cover the restructuring program, said spokesman Orren F. Knauer. Without the charge, K mart said fourth-quarter earnings would have been $395.6 million, or $1.97 a share. For the fiscal year, profits fell 60 percent to $322.7 million, or $1.61 a share, from $802.9, or $4 a share. Revenue was up 8 percent at $29.53 billion, compared with year-earlier revenue of $27.3 billion. The figures included a $422.5 million after-tax charge in connection with the construction and renovation program. K mart is the nation's largest retailer after Sears, Roebuck and Co., but No. 3 Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has surpassed K mart in profits, recently reporting $1.1 billion in 1989 earnings on sales of $25.8 billion. ``We have already opened several prototype stores and have enlarged and relocated many of our stores,'' Antonini said. ``Customer acceptance of the layouts, fixturing and new merchandise assortments has been very good and sales results have exceeded expectations.'' K mart also said Thursday its February sales were up 14.7 percent from February 1989, and sales on a comparable store basis _ for stores open at least one year _ were up 4.4 percent. Antonini said the increase included strong gains in clothing lines.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher in Quiet U.S. Trading
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mostly higher Thursday in extremely quiet domestic trading as investors spent the day on the sidelines wary of provoking the central banks to intervene. Gold prices slipped in New York after finishing mixed overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $400 a troy ounce, off 20 cents from Wednesday. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $399.80 a troy ounce, down 80 cents. Currency trading was lackluster worldwide. ``The day never really got started,'' said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader with the Bank of Boston in New York. ``It was almost like a holiday market.'' Traders said only one factor dampened activity _ the threat of central bank intervention. Dealers were surprised on Wednesday when a group of central banks aggressively and repeatedly sold dollars to keep the currency from rising. The Federal Reserve was believed to have entered the market more than once Thursday to sell dollars against the Japanese yen, but the action was modest compared with the previous session, traders said. Still, sentiment toward the U.S. currency remains very bullish. ``More and more people are seeing that the economy is not doing as badly as original expectations, so there should be no real easing of interest rates,'' Morrissey said. Higher interest rates generally support the dollar by enhancing the value of fixed-income securities. Foreign investors, typically major purchasers of instruments like U.S government bonds, need dollars to make their investments. Further evidence of the strength of the U.S. economy will come on Friday, when the Labor Department issues its unemployment report for February. The consensus is for non-farm payrolls to show an increase of about 240,000 jobs. Separately, officials confirmed that finance ministers from the Group of Seven leading industrialized countries will meet in early April in Paris, where they are expected to discuss global currency exchange rates. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 150.83 Japanese yen, up from 150.75. Later in London, the dollar closed at 150.80 yen. But in New York, the dollar finished at 151.09 yen, up from 150.35 yen on Wednesday. In London, one British pound cost $1.6427 late Thursday, more expensive for buyers than Wednesday's late $1.6388. But the dollar gained against the British currency in New York, where one pound cost $1.6385, cheaper than $1.6465 on Wednesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates included: 1.7008 West German marks, up from 1.6982; 1.5080 Swiss francs, up from 1.4995; 5.7495 French francs, up from 5.7400; 1,255.25 Italian lire, up from 1,252.75, and 1.1807 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1831. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Wednesday's late rates included: 1.7015 West German marks, down from 1.7075; 1.5080 Swiss francs, up from 1.5075; 5.7525 French francs, down from 5.7665; 1.9164 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9155; 1,255.75 Italian lire, down from 1,259.00, and 1.1792 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1853. Gold closed in London at $401.95 bid a troy ounce, up from $399.25. The closing Zurich bid price was unchanged at $400.75. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $401.95 bid, down from $402.45. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery finished at $5.112 a troy ounce, down from $5.122 on Wednesday. In London the metal traded at a bid price of $5.15 a troy ounce, up from $5.13.

For release Sunday March 11
DOC.HEAD: Casting Call: Businessmen Played By Hollywood's Howard, Grazer
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Imagine a child TV star turned successful movie director, starting a company with a savvy Hollywood producer who takes credit for helping launch the careers of Michael Keaton, Darryl Hannah and Tom Hanks. Add a splash of comic instinct, a public stock offering that raises $81 million, distribution deals with a major film studio and a cable TV network. The result is Imagine Films Entertainment Inc., an independent production company created and co-chaired by director Ron Howard and producer Brian Grazer. Imagine was launched as a public company in July 1986 and seems to be entering the 1990s on a steady footing _ at a time when some independents in the field are struggling. Imagine's stock, traded in the over-the-counter market, has been fetching $14.50 a share recently, up from around $10.50 a year ago and a low of $2 after the market collapse in October 1987. The company started to turn a profit last September. ``We've been incredibly lucky,'' Grazer said in a recent interview of him and partner Howard, a longtime friend. ``We raised money from the public on no assets.'' Well, not exactly. Howard and Grazer are helping prove that talent can be packaged into a marketable security on Wall Street. ``There's a very real strength,'' said Christopher Dixon, an analyst who follows the entertainment industry for Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``It's a group of hands-on producers and directors who know their industry.'' Howard, 35, has directed hit comedy films including ``Night Shift,'' ``Splash,'' ``Cocoon'' and ``Parenthood''. But he is probably best known to a generation of TV-weaned baby boomers as cute little Opie on ``The Andy Griffith Show'' and later as all-American teenager Richie Cunningham on ``Happy Days.'' ``I tend to be a bit ponderous, a bit deliberate about what I'm trying to do, where I'm going,'' Howard said. ``Sometimes you can stall out from that approach. ... Brian has great instincts. He's a great self-starter.'' Howard, who began his acting career at age 18 months, still projects the same boy-next-door wholesomeness he had on screen, though his ginger hair is thinning and his suit is conservative. Big-time success, and his forays into Wall Street, don't seem to have jaded him. Grazer, 38, has the same ebullience. He started his career developing TV projects, moving into a producing deal with Paramount Pictures in 1980. He admits that in the early days, many doors slammed on him and his zany ideas. Now, the two entrepreneurs make it look easy. ``It's not that tough,'' Grazer replied when asked about the duo's encounters with investment bankers and other financial operatives. ``They're fascinated with the way we work.'' Imagine's business plan, they tell financiers, avoids risk. The Los Angeles-based company aims to produce mainstream commercial films with ``high visibility, high quality and broad appeal.'' Most importantly, Imagine has signed a deal with Universal Pictures for Universal to distribute as many as 20 films produced by Imagine and an agreement with Showtime-The Movie Channel for TV rights for up to 30 movies that would run in theaters first. In addition MCA Inc., Universal's parent, has invested $10 million in Imagine securities, which give MCA the right to convert into a 24.8 percent share of the company. Howard and Grazer each own 17.6 percent of Imagine's shares. The deals with Universal and Showtime, a cable TV network owned by Viacom International Inc., are designed to give Howard and Grazer extensive outlets for marketing their work without impinging on their creative control. Both speak passionately about Imagine, finishing each other's sentences in rapid cadence. Both see Hollywood analogies everywhere, including a recent meeting they had with Wall Street financiers. ``It was just like something out of `Trading Places,' Grazer said, referring to the Eddie Murphy-Dan Aykroyd spoof of commodity futures trading. Don't assume Howard is responsible for the creative side of the company and Grazer only takes care of business. It was Grazer, for example, who came up with the concept for ``Splash'': an innocent mermaid who comes ashore in New York. So far, Imagine has produced ``The Burbs'' starring Tom Hanks, ``The Dream Team'' with Michael Keaton, and ``Parenthood,'' starring Steve Martin and directed by Howard. All three were released last year. ``Parenthood,'' the most popular and profitable of the trio, grossed an estimated $96 million. A newer project is ``Cry Baby,'' described as a 1950s musical, starring Johnny Depp of TV's ``21 Jump Street,'' due to be released in early April. ``Opportunity Knocks'' is scheduled for release at the end of March and ``Problem Child'' is due later this spring. In the fall, NBC plans to launch a weekly TV series based on ``Parenthood,'' produced by Imagine and Universal. In George Lucas's 1973 film ``American Graffiti,'' Howard plays a high school senior in the throes of self-discovery. Hassled by a nitpicking male teacher at a school dance, he snaps, ``Why don't you go kiss a duck or something.'' With Imagine, Howard seems to have told the conventional moviemaking establishment to do the same. But this time he's hedged his recklessness by buttressing the company with solid financial backing.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Transportation Policy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the major elements of the Bush administration's national transportation policy released Thursday:
DOC.HEAD: EXPANSION
DOC.TEXT: The policy would preserve and maintain existing roads, highways, airports, railroad lines, waterways and other transportation facilities and focus on moving people and goods, not simply vehicles, in planning new systems. Expansion would be accomplished in partnership with state and local governments and private investors, with federal programs focusing on projects of ``national significance.''
DOC.HEAD: FINANCING
DOC.TEXT: The federal government would rely more heavily on user fees to finance its share and give state and local governments more authority to raise their own revenue through toll roads, local gas taxes, airport passenger taxes and other fees. User fees are also proposed for Coast Guard services and railroad safety activities of the government.
DOC.HEAD: COMPETITION
DOC.TEXT: The government would encourage competition by continuing to remove regulations, including federal requirements on truck rates and services and on liability procedures affecting the railroad industry. The Transportation Department also would review federal maritime programs and pursue international negotiations to help U.S. shipping lines compete in world markets.
DOC.HEAD: SAFETY
DOC.TEXT: The government will launch a campaign to reduce highway traffic fatalities and will continue to address concerns about hazardous materials shipments, aging airliners, transportation vehicle design and the distribution and use of illegal drugs.
DOC.HEAD: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION
DOC.TEXT: The policy recognizes the need for more fuel-efficient vehicles, the implications of global climate changes and the problems associated with aircraft noise, but it recommends no specific action.
DOC.HEAD: TECHNOLOGY
DOC.TEXT: The federal government would provide some money to encourage research by private companies and educational institutions into magnetically levitated trains, alternative power sources for cars, hypersonic planes, computerized vehicles and roads and other innovations.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market climbed to an eight-week high Thursday, resuming its late-winter rally as Wall Street looked ahead to Friday's monthly report on the employment situation. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 26.58 points to 2,696.17, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11. Over the last 11 sessions the average sports a gain of just under 132 points, or 5.1 percent. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by nearly 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 983 up, 507 down and 476 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 170.90 million shares, up from 163.58 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 204.35 million shares. The Labor Department's report on employment Friday morning promises to give investors one of the first signposts of the economy's performance in February. Hopes apparently spread for fresh evidence from the figures that business activity was continuing to expand at a sluggish but presumably sustainable pace. Advance estimates call for the data to show an increase of perhaps 250,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, not far below a 275,000 rise posted for January. If consensus projections are accurate, the report will also put the civilian unemployment rate at 5.3 percent, unchanged from the month before. Hilton Hotels led the active list, down 10] at 50|. The company ended its quest for an acquirer, saying it hadn't attracted the kind of bids it had hoped for because of adverse financial circumstances. C.R. Bard, which recalled two catheter products, fell 3[ to 13|. Compaq Computer, up 3| at 95~, and Businessland, up \ at 11, were strong for the second straight session following news of an agreement for Businessland to resume carrying Compaq products. USX rose 1 to 36|. Carl Icahn, the financier who owns a big chunk of USX stock, is pressing a plan to spin off at least an 80 percent stake in the company's steel business. Other gainers among the blue chips included American Telephone & Telegraph, up } at 41}; General Electric, up ] at 63; International Business Machines, up 1{ at 107, and Coca-Cola, up 1 at 72]. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $28.01 billion, or 0.86 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.58 to 187.35. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 4.00 to 393.02, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 3.32 at 340.27. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market picked up 4.03 to 436.50. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.51, up 2.48.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Gains
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Feb. 26, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,264.8 billion from a revised $3,256.5 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,072.9 billion from a revised $4,069.1 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $804.9 billion from a revised $800.4 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 5.2 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.2 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,235.0 billion, a 6.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,051.5 billion, up 3.3 percent, while M1 rose 5.0 percent to an average of $796.4 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $115 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $136 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $301.0 billion in the two-week period ended March 7, up from $300.6 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $2 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 499 money market mutual funds rose $2 billion in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise, to $390.79 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed revised drop of $1.9 billion in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The funds' assets surpassed the previous record high of $390.69 billion set in the week ended Feb. 21, 1990. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 245 general purpose funds increased $505.2 million to $132.9 billion, assets of 101 broker-dealer funds rose $1.29 billion to $166.14 billion, and assets of 153 institutional funds rose $212 million to $91.75 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.92 percent from 7.94 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.64 percent from 7.65 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 42 days, down from 43 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.26 percent as of Wednesday from 6.27 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.06 percent from 5.07 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.86 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.87 the previous week. Yields were 7.96 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.94 percent; 7.95 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.96 percent; and 8.01 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.00 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Distributes Profit-Sharing Checks
DOC.TEXT: Profit-sharing checks averaging $1,025 each were distributed Thursday to Ford Motor Co. hourly employees, in the largest such payout this year by the Big Three automakers. Ford's $166 million in profit-sharing payments to hourly and salaried employees tops the $22.2 million, or about $50 to each of 443,000 workers, in profit-sharing that General Motors Corp. will distribute next week. Ford declined to give the amount of the average salaried profit-sharing check or to say precisely how many of the 150,891 eligible employees were hourly or salaried. Chrysler Corp.'s 1989 earnings of $359 million, were not enough to trigger profit-sharing provisions. Payments were about $2,800 last year for Ford employees, $254 for GM workers and averaged about $700 at Chrysler. Profit-sharing payments are based on each company's previous-year earnings from its North American operations. Combined Big Three profit-sharing payments this year amounted to about $188.2 million, or about 69 percent less than the $604.1 million the companies handed out last year. Total Big Three profits in 1989 fell 24.9 percent from the previous year to $8.42 billion, due to increasing competition from Japanese automakers, costs of buyer incentives and slowing sales.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Prices Surge
DOC.TEXT: Livestock and meat prices surged Thursday for the third consecutive session at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid concerns about tight hog supplies. On other futures markets, grains rallied, but gold, energy products and orange juice contracts all declined. At the Chicago Merc, the frozen pork bellies contract for delivery in March rose the daily limit of 2 cents after four contracts posted the maximum increases allowed in the previous session. ``The market is reflecting an insufficent supply of hogs to satisfy packer needs,'' said Chuck Levitt, an analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``Packers simply don't have the hogs they need, and the consumer and investor are paying more.'' The advance in cattle prices ``was mainly a spillover from the strong pork complex,'' he said. Cattle settled .30 cent to .70 cent higher, with the contract for delivery in April at 77.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent to .85 cent higher, with March at 81.87 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .65 cent higher, with April at 52.07 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .37 cent to 2.00 cents higher, with March at 50.95 cents a pound. Frozen orange juice futures fell on the New York Cotton Exchange in one of the few down days since the December freeze in Florida. Shearson's Judy Ganes blamed the drop on profit-taking. She also said that a Florida growers' report, originally thought by traders to be 3 million boxes shy of the U.S. Agriculture Department estimate last month, left some traders Wednesday with the wrong impression. The growers' figure didn't include 3 million navel oranges and gift fruit, but matched the USDA's estimate in other areas, she explained. Frozen concentrate orange juice settled .10 cent to 1.00 cent lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $1.90 a pound. Soybean and grain futures finished higher after opening slightly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. Purchases by Iraqi investors in the soymeal cash market and rumors of Chinese interest in soyoil helped push soybean prices higher, said analyst Mark Weidner of Cargill Investor Services Inc. Wheat staged a late rally on news of China's bid for 400,000 metric tons of U.S. export bonus wheat, and corn followed suit, traders said. Wheat settled 2 cents to 3{ cents higher, with the contract for March at $3.83{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2 cents higher, with March at $2.42} a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher, with March at $1.45} a bushel; and soybeans were 4 cents to 7 cents higher, with March at $5.81{ a bushel. Oil prices sagged for a third straight session on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Randall Rothenberg, an energy market analyst from Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said selling momentum overseas carried over into U.S. trading. Crude oil settled 11 cents to 18 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in April at $20.78 a barrel; heating oil was .01 cent to .85 cent lower, with April at 55.34 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was .25 cent to .88 cent lower, with April at 56.14 cents a gallon. A stronger U.S. dollar sent gold and silver futures lower on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Gold settled 20 cents to 50 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $400 a troy ounce; while silver was 1 cent to 1.2 cents lower, with March at $5.11.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Proposes Looser Rules on AT&T
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf pvs, bgng: The FCC ... to CORRECT to within 30 days sted 30 days' notice. Shorter version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission, taking another big step towards a deregulated interstate long-distance phone business, proposed Thursday to loosen rules on AT&T because the onetime monopoly company now faces ``significant competition.'' The commission, in a 4-0 vote, adopted a staff proposal that, if finally approved, would give the American Telephone & Telegraph Co. the freedom it says it needs to maneuver against some 500 long-distance companies in the $55 billion long-distance marketplace. The commission said it would study competition in the interstate long-distance arena and adopt necessary regulatory reforms. But it tentatively concluded ``interstate services as a whole are now subject to significant competition and that competition in the provision of business services is particularly vigorous'' _ a key finding that must be made to deregulate AT&T. Based on those conclusions, the commission proposed a phased-in package of changes in certain business services, extending later to 800-number services, international calling and operator services. The commission decided not to propose any changes to residential and small business services at this time. The proposals are a victory for AT&T, which the FCC formally declared in 1981 as a ``dominant'' carrier that should be subject to regulation to prevent abuses to competitors or customers. AT&T won another victory last year when the FCC dumped its 20-year-old rate-of-return regulation of AT&T's profits in exchange for a system that controls AT&T's prices within certain limits tied to the rate of inflation. AT&T has argued that it no longer is dominant and that it has lost $10 billion in business to competitors since the 1984 breakup of the old Bell System. Prices have fallen 40 percent and its share of the long-distance market has dropped below 70 percent. MCI now has about 12 percent of the business, US Sprint about 9 percent, and the rest is scattered among hundreds of smaller companies. AT&T's arguments apparently fell on fertile ground at an FCC under new Chairman Alfred Sikes, who believes there is too much government intervention in the phone business. ``The changes in market shares reflect the fact that competition has worked,'' Sikes said Thursday. Sikes also said earlier this year the FCC would drop rate-of-return regulation on the interstate revenues of local telephone companies in 1991, and the commission issued proposed guidelines Thursday for this new price cap regime. Besides capping prices, the plan also would require the local phone companies to share any earnings above a certain level with customers. AT&T applauded the proposals for long-distance carriers, saying the commission ``took a major step toward shaping policies based not on outdated orthodoxy but on future flexibility. ... The FCC's proposal validates AT&T's premise that everyone gains when all competitors are free to anticipate and meet customer needs.'' Competitors were less pleased, with MCI saying that while it too welcomed the FCC inquiry, the FCC ``clearly recognizes'' that ``AT&T can leverage its dominance to abuse'' competitors. Sprint said it was ``generally pleased'' with the FCC's approach and that the FCC was ``appropriately'' moving towards deregulation where rules no longer are needed. Under current regulations, AT&T must make a public filing with the FCC each time it proposes to offer a new service or change the terms and conditions under which it offers any service already sanctioned by the FCC. AT&T says the public disclosure of its offerings and the length of time it takes to get FCC approval puts it at a disadvantage in today's fast-moving telecommunications marketplace. The FCC apparently agreed, proposing a ``streamlined'' filing process that would allow AT&T to give one day's notice for certain business services without submitting the cost data now required. AT&T also would be freed of some provisions of the new ``price cap'' regime the FCC imposed last year. The FCC also proposed that AT&T be permitted to offer certain business services to individual customers, as long as they file contracts and summaries of their provisions within 30 days of the effective date of the contract. The commission also proposed that all long-distance carriers be permitted to withdraw some of their facilities from the public phone network for use by private businesses. The commission will ask public comment on its proposals, and the opposition is expected to be strong from those who say AT&T still has enormous market power _ and is likely to gain even more clout if it is deregulated.

DOC.HEAD: On Capitol Hill: Experts Debate, Debunk Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Witnesses at a congressional hearing on junk bonds warned Thursday that defaults in the high-risk securities were likely to grow, but did not necessarily think Congress should act to restrict them. Representatives from the bond rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corp. were among those testifying about the future and possible dangers of junk bonds before a subcommittee of the House Energy and Committee. ``A junk bond is a shaky debt. It is the promise to pay of a debtor who is just getting by,'' said James Grant, editor of the newsletter Grant's Interest Rate Observer. Bonds are, in effect, corporate promises to pay back borrowed money at a later date while paying a regular, fixed interest. Junk bonds, however, are ``non-investment grade,'' meaning that rating services like S&P or Moody's give them a greater chance of default than more stable investment grade bonds. To compensate, they pay a much higher interest yield. Pioneered by financier Michael Milken at the firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., junk bonds helped a number of small or fledgling companies expand while also assisting corporate raiders in financing huge corporate takeovers with little up-front cash. But the $200 billion junk bond market has been rocked repeatedly in recent months by Milken's indictment on racketeering charges, defaults by corporate junk borrowers, the withdrawal of many savings and loan institutions as buyers of the securities and the bankruptcy filing by Drexel's parent company. The subcommittee's chairman, Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., said there were questions about whether plunging prices in the junk market and the collapse of Drexel had endangered the long-term health of U.S. companies that rely on high-yield financing. ``The risks of the junk bond market have been exaggerated by the press,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist with DRI-McGraw-Hill, adding that Drexel's demise ``is a symptom of the problems in the market more than a cause of new problems.'' Thomas J. McGuire, director of Moody's Corporate Department, said the default rate for speculative-grade bonds, which includes junk bonds, has risen to 5.4 percent, the second-highest rate since 1970. ``And the outlook _ given the increase in lower rated issuers and the potentially unfavorable economic environment _ is for still higher levels of defaults in the early 1990s,'' McGuire said. Mark Bachman, senior vice president of S&P's Corporate Finance Department, said current problems in the junk bond market ``are by no means inherent in the nature of all non-investment grade bonds, but rather stem from the excess of financial leverage that came to characterize'' junk bonds issuers in the late 1980s. Both Grant and Wyss cautioned against trying to correct the junk bond market through legislation. ``I would advise the subcommittee to be wary of pushing the market toward even greater stringency,'' said Grant. ``Legislation is more likely to worsen than help the problem,'' said Wyss. ``Leverage is a response to the incentives in the tax law, and unless those incentives change, attacking the symptoms will just cause problems elsewhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Aquarium Light Cords Recalled Again
DOC.TEXT: A discount and variety retailer said Wednesday that it is recalling 39,000 aquarium light cords for a second time because consumers have not responded to the initial effort. McCrory Corp. said it recalled the electric light cord assembly part of its Aqua Hex Aquariums last summer because ``the wires may short circuit and ignite the cord.'' Spokeswoman Joy Shepp said the company then advertised the recall for seven days in January in USA Today. ``Consumers are paying no attention to this recall,'' Shepp said. ``We're doing our best to warn consumers and comply with Consumer Product Safety Commission concerns, but we're not having a good consumer reply.'' Shepp said the company had sent only 250 replacement cords as a result of the first recall. The cords were sold nationwide between July 1988 and February 1989 by Bargain Time, Britts, Elmore, McCrory, H.L. Green, Kress, McClellan, T.G. & Y, Silver Kittinger and Newberry stores. The fish tank also was sold by some independent variety stores, the company said. The company said in a statement that it was aware of three incidents in which the cord short-circuited or caught fire. No injuries have been reported, it said. Consumers should detach the defective light cord from the aquarium hood and return it, without the bulb, for a replacement from the store where it was purchased or contact McCrory Stores at 1-800-284-3704.
